Roth so loses himself in the role that, even as I viewed this a 2nd and 3rd time, knowing who it was under that ape make-up, I still could find no traces of him. It's a triumph of make-up FX and stellar method acting. All the actors who play apes in this picture, including Bonham Carter and Clarke Duncan, succeed in dazzling the audience to such a degree that, unfortunately, all the ones playing humans, including the main lead, come off as very bland. The climactic battle between the two armies is exciting and we tense up some more as Thade's villainy appears to near an end. Then everything becomes abruptly copacetic on this weird world and the final (secondary) climax back on Earth still doesn't make sense to me, not after the 3rd time, and probably not when I see it a 4th time. I think Burton's just messing with us.

Remakes are a hazardous business. Shown not least by all the completely wasted remakes floating around out there. And it seems remakes are all the rage today, considering how many movies are actually based on previous works. Right now the Asian industry is the one being plagued the worst by this trend.When it comes to unnecessary remakes i would have to rate this 2001 remake of the classic "Planet of the apes" as one of the foremost. This version of the movie is not without it's qualities, but in general it's a step down from the original in many ways. The social pathos is more or less completely removed, replaced instead with a focus on action and comedy. While the original movie commented on segregation in society and the arbitrary treatment of certain groups as lower standing, this movie doesn't deal with the themes at all. Of course there is a general discussion going on through the movie, and a tension between liberal and conservative powers, but it never feels like more than window dressing.The qualities here lie mostly in the sure-handed visual style that is director Tim Burtons hallmark. The effects as well as the set designs are top notch, as is the sound and music. The acting leaves a mixed impression. Tim Roth is quite astounding as the evil ape commander Thade, Mark Wahlberg is his usual pale self as the protagonist. The acting from the rest of the cast is decent enough.The qualities of this remake fall tragically short of making up for it's weaknesses. I feel that a remake should always have something new to offer if there is to be a point in remaking a movie in the first place. Not only does this movie have nothing new to offer, it even deducts many of the points of the original. And that makes this one of the most pointless, and even degrading, remakes ever. I rate it 3/10 for the entertainment it still provides despite it's obvious weaknesses as a remake.

Tim Burton was careful to call his take on "Planet of the Apes" a "re-imagining" rather than a "remake."  And he does quite well here.  This version has a dark look that works to a point.  The ape makeup on the actors does look convincing.  And having them actually move like apes was a nice touch.  But, to tell the truth, the new twist ending didn't really make sense.  And I did miss seeing the Statue of Liberty in this version. Perhaps Tim purposefully left Lady Liberty out because people expected her?

Review title: Jon Monsarrat review: sub-intellectual but not awful
Review_body: I'm not very arty and I don't expect films to contain exceptional choreography or makeup. But I do expect it to make sense, be engaging, and have a moving plot. And I like car chases and when stuff blows up. And I like science fiction.But even with these factors in my favor, I was very disappointed by Planet of the Apes.The film is poorly acted -- especially the natives, and the world does not seem realistic, so instead of being spooky we don't really get drawn in. Most importantly, I don't like a sub-intellectual film that insults my intelligence. Some of the plot twists just didn't make any sense. The original version had something to say; that all gets lost here.What a disappointment, and the ending was brutally concocted and unsatisfying.Who should see this film:-- Sci-fi film buffs who didn't mind the stupidity inthe remake of "Lost in Space", or "Independence Day"(which admittedly is a lot of people)-- I can't think of anyone elseI regret I can only give "Planet of the Apes" an uninspired 5 out of 10.

I'm not sure, but I think it would take a million monkeys on a million typewriters a million years to come up with a dumber movie.   This film was an absolute mess and should never have been made in the first place being a remake of a movie that didn't need one!Mark Wahlberg essentially plays the same character he played in THE BIG HIT (a blandly "nice" guy in some sort of trance), except this time he's landed on an ape planet in a small spacecraft which can miraculously keep track of what year it is when he goes through wormholes.  Of course he stumbles onto an advanced tribe of apes slightly better made-up than in the original, but at a technology level further back (these ones don't even have guns).  It isn't long before he's walking in Charleton Heston's footsteps in befriending an ape woman and, (sort-of) falling in love with a human woman, and leading a small revolt against the although this time around there isn't even a legitimate reason for him to be doing so.  The entire premise is completely ruined by changing it so that all the humans on the planet can talk and think at pretty much a 20th century level. The original PLANET was based around Charleton Heston trying to prove to the apes that humans were just as smart as they are, but politics and religion alike suppressed the historical truth.  This film has none of this. It's just a dumb action sci-fi movie with little action (most of the violence is off-screen, a la BATTLEFIELD EARTH - an eerily similar sci-fi disaster) and no plot! What semblance of a plot there is is completely ruined by the multitudes of red herrings, plot holes, and a general lack of depth in any area.  Never is the ape society really explored or revealed, nor are any of the characters fleshed out.  We never learn who the other servants are or why they bother tagging along with Wahlberg in the first place.  We never learn how many apes there are or why they have superior technology to humans.  For some unknown reason there are several different species of apes (Gorillas, Orangutans, Chimpanzees) on the planet, yet the ship they all originated from carried ONLY CHIMPANZEES!!   More uncalled for changes: They made the monkey women way too "pretty" in this one, not looking any different from normal women except for their hairy hands and big noses (most of them could actually probably pass for humans) and the human women are all in full make-up with manicures and perfect teeth... when the humans are supposedly living in the stone age!  I know it's just a movie, but COME ON!  How dumb do they expect us audience-members to be.This all wouldn't be so bad if the film hadn't resorted to so much useless parody, such as an ape saying "Get your paws off me you damn dirty HUMAN" or later when Charleton Heston's ape character says about humans "Damn them all to hell!"...  my jaw just about literally hit the theater floor for that one.  What were the scriptwriters thinking?  Do they imagine the few of us who remember those lines from the original will be amused at all by this mutilation of the franchise.  I think even BATTLE FOR... was better... at least the ending of that movie made sense!  I'm not going to ruin it for you but the ending really surprised my by how awful it really was... not that I couldn't see it coming miles away but I honestly never imagined the writers would be THAT tacky.I'm usually very forgiving watching bad sci-fi movies, but this one was WAAAY below lowest common denominator...insulting to my intelligence, confusing, AND boring.  It hasn't been since I watched BATTLEFIELD EARTH or STAR WARS EPISODE 1 that I have sat in the theater completely appalled at what I was watching.  Let's pray that this disaster acts as a career killer for director Tim Burton.  He's made a few very good movies but the magic is over.

In another ape universe far far away...sorry, I just hadda do it! Anyway, this reawakening of the ape universe something was left behind...like an amazing, coherent story that grabs every fiber of your being. Sure, it had the obligatory special effects that permeate todays theater world, but it also bears little resemblance to the original for which it was named. Yes, I am essentially a purist so for me if you find an equation that works don't mess with it! At least not much...this version simply did not have any of the magic, the wonder that was in every minute of the 1968 masterpiece. It felt like a pasted together puzzle of several story lines. Chimps are taught to fly souped up space pods for exploration, space storm captures pod with chimp inside, "handler" goes frantic and takes another pod to rescue chimp and gets sucked in to a space warp. OK, that's story one. Story two: chimp handler exits space warp and lands hard on "Earth", only to run into a Super chimp raiding party hunting humans as pets and workers...OK OK, so that is a sorta direct clone of the original. But the remaining 90% of the film is a third story of the handler being befriended by a "cute" female chimp who sympathizes, then she helps him free the oppressed humans. They fight a mini-war with thousands of war apes led by a deranged chimp general, and at the last second we have "missing chimp" arrive in his pod and all the warring apes bow down to "missing chimp" who just happens to resemble their God ape from antiquity...well, that takes you up to the last five minutes of the flick, which turns into a misguided attempt at irony. Not amazing, not incredible, certainly stressful to watch in its entirety.

I hope that those who complained about this movie changed their minds after watching Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011) and all the movies that might follow.The reason i pointed this out is because Tim Burton's effort is the only movie in the franchise that has a decent script, at time almost at Shakespearean heights. In addition to that, the actors played the apes in realistic costumes. Prior to this movie the costumes were funny, to say the least, and the 2011 prequel used CGI.Personally, this movie was a huge improvement, because the only thing worth mentioning in the old movies has been the scene with Charlton Heston confronted with the Statue of Liberty protruding from the sand. The 2011 and 2014 prequels were visually better but scripts were poor.

Review title: This is NOT Burton's best film!
Review_body: Remakes come in all shapes and sizes. What's the reason for making remakes of the classic movies that fitted well? Some remakes get to show a different side of view like Martin Scorsese's Cape Fear in 1991 where rather than showing a happy family in peril (like in the original 1962 classic), Scorsese shows a dysfunctional family filled with anger and a disease where it made audience applaud for De Niro's character.Tim Burton is known for making movies in a goth emblem from Beetlejuice, Batman Returns (the best of his work), Sleepy Hollow, Edward Scissorhands and much more. Now he directs this 1960's classic about how a man from space gets stuck in an island filled with talking and vicious primates. Mark Whalberg is Capt. Leo Davidson who doesn't do much except try to wow women with his boyish good looks where one of his lab chimps goes inside a space rocket and leaves the space station where he goes into another planet. Leo tries to find his pet until he realizes that once he arrives everything is upside down with humans in cages and use for enslavement while primates (Gorillas, monkeys, orangutans, etc.) rule the planet. The leader is General Thade (Tim Roth, who stands out) who wants to abolish all humans from the face of the earth. His henchmen involves the volatile Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan), Limbo (Paul Giamatti) the fool, and sweet Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) who crushes on Captain Leo.If you seen the original movie about how the humans and some of the chimps fight off the bad primates, there's a twist in the ending. There's no enthrallment, no cheers, it felt as if certain scenes from the trailer worked rather than the film itself while breathing in relief after I walked out of the theater.

I am a fan of the original but was looking forward to Burton's take on it. Ive enjoyed many of Burton's other films: Beetlejuice and Edward Scissorhands were imaginative, beautiful and clever. Sleepy Hollow was gorgeous and had wonderfully creepy moments but the wrap-up of the story was clumsy and rushed. But, THIS, THIS thing he has stitched together is so god awful that I was shocked. First off, yes, he has shot it well, he always will, but the script (HA!) just stunk of guys pitching various "let's think out of the box" type ideas that just lay there like some well-intentioned pot-soaked student film. I'm a huge fan of Tim Roth and I felt he was terrible. All he did, over and over and over, was glare up at the camera from under his "brow" snarl and do a villianous voice out of a Scooby Doo cartoon. It was so one-note. Wahlberg just played it monotone and flat. I thought he accepted the idea of being in a cage being pulled by other humans while being beaten by talking apes - pretty well. All in a day's work as a chimp-studying space man. And (SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS***********this so called twist ending was like out of a SCTV sketch. I expected it to read Apraham Lincoln for goddsake!) And I know I'm really in the minority on this one - but I kept thinking the make-up wasn't that great. The gorillas were amazing, probably the best of the bunch, but the way they tried to make the chimps look a tad more human with that strange nostril configuration was just bizarre and hokey. And I congratulate Estella Warren for giving TWO AWFUL DEAD EYED performances in the same year: first the Stallone stinker"Driven" and now "Apes". My god, yes, she's beautiful, the blond hair, the bee-stung lips, the model's body, but talk about the lights are off and no one is home!!!! NOTHING behind her eyes. Ever. At any point in the movie. She walks badly, she rides a horse badly and the way we're supposed to FEEL anything when her and the female chimp are eyeing each other with jealousy over Wahlberg was ridiculous.

....after 16 years Tim Burton finally disappoints me!!!! Whatever happened to the old Burton who read "The Dark Knight Returns" by Frank Miller as research for his preparation to direct Batman back in 1988-89? By the looks of it Burton didn't research the book nor the movie cause he got everything WRONG! This movie sucks! It's not as good as the original and it doesn't deal with the same subject as the original. If you want a good ape movie watch the original.**out of****stars

Planet of the Apes (2001, Dir. Tim Burton) An astronaut trying to retrieve a monkey in space ends up landing on a planet inhabited by talking human-like apes. Leo Davidson (Wahlberg) finds himself captured by the apes and placed in a cage with other humans. All the apes take this same 'human hating' attitude, with the exception of one. A kind, female ape called Ari (Bonham Carter) sees something different in these humans, and plans to help them in whatever they need to do.Even with wonderful performances by the actors, a small amount of action and a poorly crafted ending makes this version of the classic ends up as one of Burton's weaker films.Are you trying to put me out of business? These are the skankiest, scabbiest, scuzziest humans I've ever seen.  Limbo (Paul Giamatti)

Planet of the Apes Tim Burton-style is a disappointment. It's a good film, but I have learned to expect more from Burton than just 'good'. As with all Burton-films though, Planet of the Apes is visually stunning. Costumes, make-up (brilliant!), the production design, the cinematography... Simply amazing. However, the script is seriously lacking pace in the first half hour and the ending is an abomination! One of the worst movie endings in years. Doesn't stand a chance in comparison with the ending in the first Planet of the Apes. After the slow beginning, the movie builds up nicely to a final battle scene, which is great, but that ending... My, my... What a mistake.In a fine cast (though Mark Wahlberg is a bit boring) Tim Roth is certainly the stand-out. He delivers a great performance as Thade.In short, an entertaining sci-fi adventure which is let down by a silly ending and a slow start. Visuals are stunning and well worth the admission price.Could have been such a great film... (6/10)

Review title: With all of the bungling, protracted, witless summer movie sequels invading theatres, you've gotta wonder when Hollywood's going to stop monkeying around.
Review_body:
Ah, Planet of the Apes. Sniff it all you want; it smells enough like a case of the remake to fall in line with this summer's sequel monotony, but upon closer inspection, it's clear that this is a chimp of a decidedly different breed.Director Tim Burton reinvents the aesthetic and tonal gestalt of the 1968 classic without ditching the original's thematic underpinnings, creating a world that is both visually fascinating and painstakingly complete.
When Air Force pilot Leo Davidson, (Mark Walberg), leaves his space station in search of a test chimp deployed to survey a magnetic storm, things go awry, leading to a crash-landing on a planet where humans are enslaved by a breed of apes that are uniquely advanced, cognizant and cultured. But their refinement is little more than a thin veneer hiding their aggressive animal drives, which can lead them to the brutal treatment of their captured humans. Leo, who isn't acclimated to the Apes' tyranny, revolts against them and becomes a heroic figure and leader to the enslaved humans who know little else than the servitude and submission they have faced since birth. Helena Bonham Carter (you know, from Fight Club) plays Ari, an ape with compassion towards humans, while Tim Roth brilliantly portrays Thade, a snarling, aggressive (really pretty damn scary) ape general, who wishes to see his planet cured of humans, and his fellow apes cured of their human-derivative tendencies.Under the façade of a fast-paced sci-fi/action blockbuster lays an entirely different animal. On the most primitive level, Apes is gargantuan, pounding its fists with energy and a capacity to amaze that makes this film monumentally entertaining. But like the skillfully crafted latex ape masks through which the actors' subtle, universal, seasoned human facial expressions are transmitted, Apes breathes life of its own beneath the glaze of action. Burton paints a textured portrayal of man's struggle against subjugation, with settings and characters that are unearthly, yet dually dark, gritty and present. The director ditched the early-proposed ideas of digitally animated apes or live apes with computer-generated mouths, enlisting A-list actors instead to give each ape a uniquely human core.Perhaps the real feat here is that Burton was able to make these apes so utterly creepy and animalistic (much more so than their original counterparts) yet still found a way to maintain their human characteristics. Roth and Bonham Carter learned an entire behavioral language for their roles, complete with loping, off-kilter strides and dexterous, long-armed gesticulations. It takes a while to get a grasp of the full complexity of their movements, but once the language is understood, you quickly see how the ape dispositions intensify the actors' capacity for human emotional expression.Other apes include Limbo, a pandering human-slave dealer played by Paul Giamatti, and Attar, Thade's loyal silverback, played by Michael Clarke Duncan (who incidentally, is perhaps the only Ape actor that sounds as though he's using his normal voice). Charleton Heston makes a cameo, donning full ape regalia to play Thade's dying father, and Lisa Marie Pressley appears briefly as a snooty socialite chimp.On the human side, two words: Estella Warren. She says close to nothing (perhaps a throwback to the mute humans in the original, perhaps not). With a character that grows envious of the affection formed between Walberg and Bonham Carter (yes, a man and a chimp) Warren is left to primarily convey her dissatisfaction through looks and body language. And looks plus body are a definite can-do on Warren's checklist. Things seems a little exploitative at times; her garb is close to non-existent, and the camera, perhaps a bit too kind, but Warren certainly helps heighten the degree to which this film is visually fascinating. Unfortunately, it isn't all bananas and cream pie. The Apes script incorporates a few narrative devices that are just too convenient, such as the illogically timed event that causes the wrap-up to the climatic battle scene. Although the majority of dialogue in the film runs smoothly, certain characters (take for instance, the shifty-eyed comic relief, Limbo) are developed in a stagnant and predictable way. Walberg's pre-battle scene speech, despite its relative brevity, is still a little laughable. The re-vamped surprise ending is creatively done, carrying certain light-heartedness to it, but the film leaves things too easily opened ended. However, with a sequel planned 'open-ended' is something that was planned.
Ultimately, Burton's overall design is so meticulous and aesthetically comprehensive and his ape characters, so believable and culturally complete that you can't help but be lured into his stunning visual world, which seems (if not only momentarily) to take precedence over other concerns. You haven't seen anything quite like this. The film may have aped the original, but it stands on its own two feet.

Review title: Loved the movie Hated the actress
Review_body: Well what can I say, I love planet of the apes, all except one actress who I could not get used to through the entire movie. And that would be Estella Warren, i cannot pinpoint it but I just thought her character really threw off the whole admiration thing to the main character played by Mark Wahlberg. It looked silly as she did the same thing he did, like jumping in the water when the question was asked, How long can a human hold his breath under water? It seemed to hokey to me. And even though her lines were not that long, even when she spoke it gave no passion, no heated conflict to be aware of. Her role just did not fit the story. Everything else was fabulous, Tim Roth as thade, Paul Giamatti that played the slave trader, which to me was a wonderful addition, for the humorous side to a mad world. And yet Micheal Duncan Clark also gave a great role as Thades general and subordinate. But one other that seemed to throw it off another notch was the irritating kid, who thought he could do everything in the face of danger, yet bungles it up just as badly as he rode the horse. This in itself did not make the stories strength, the strength came from the apes, and that to me is the story. Estella to me just wasn't the right one picked for her character, she was too flimsy... and too blank to be believed. And as for the runt, I couldn't see it he just did not look the type to play a would be hero. Yet besides these flaws i still thought the movie was a great adaptation to the novel, especially the features of the apes and mannerisms. Which to me seemed more real than the old seventies version. Fantastic time to watch this again. If only i could stomach the other two.

Review title: Forget the original and watch with fresh eyes, this is more honest to the novel.
Review_body: Not such a bad film as some people have reported, I actually liked it, and I'm also deeply worried about the talk of the many cuts made.Allegedly Tim Burton made it as close to the book as possible, and even included some scenes such as a human-ape love scene. However, this is also one of the main reasons why fans of the original Heston film were upset, `where is the Statue of Liberty scene?' Well, it's not in the book!However, all this aside, and it is a really enjoyable movie. I'm a growing fan of Mark Wahlberg, and he just proves why yet again with his talent shining through. There's a superbly crafted ending here too, and one that I so enjoyed. This was another sticking point for some critics.My advice would be, drop the ideas from the original, and go and see this movie with fresh eyes.

Why does Tim Burton ruin every classic story he decides to remake?And why is he so vacant of true creativity that he can't make an original film? This remake is an obamanation.There's nothing redeeming about this flick.It plainly was made by someone who is collecting a paycheck and doesn't care one bit about the original, near perfect flick.Bad story telling, bad story, bad directing, bad writing.Maybe it made money off the publicity machine but any fan of the original will hate Burton for pretending to be more than a hack director.Please Tim -- retire before you ruin another classic.

Review title: A Different Planet of The Apes
Review_body: Of course you have to compare this with the original Charlton Heston film, and I think it stands up pretty well, the storyline is a bit different, with the Apes occupying a different planet and not a future Earth, the humans can speak and the end is very different, but apart from that, it more or less runs like the original, there are even a couple of famous quotes copied from the original film, but that was a good point. Near the end, the astronaut chimp that Leo Davidson (Wahlberg) lands on the planet, days after Davidson did, but he was behind the chimp in the shuttles when leaving the spacestation, which did not ring true with the story! and the twist ending was a bit odd, but possible, the odd thing about it was the apes as 70's style over-the-top cops, I assume made intentionally like that.Mark Wahlberg plays it Ok, however he did not look too surprised to discover the apes and the fact that humans populated this new planet in a different time, also his dialogue was a bit quick at times. But apart from that it was good, The others did ok, Helena Bonham Carter was quirky, but the best was Tim Roth as General Thade, you can see he put his all into the character. Charlton Heston and Linda Harrison from the original even had cameos in this.It was made well, the Ape costumes were much better than the originals, hardly surprising. the scenes were good, and photography excellent, as were the special effects.It does not have the style of the original, so that is why I only gave it an 8 rather than 10 for that, but apart from that it is very good, apparently Tim Burton wanted longer time and more control over it, but didn't get it, if he had I think it might have been a lot better.

Many remakes suck, and are worse than the original. This is not one of them.Whether it's the music, the effects, the sets, the costumes and makeup, the story, or even the cast, this film is superior to the original in almost every way. Indeed, there are only two problems I have with the film, and they're familiar problems other people have with it. I just don't think they sink the film. (1) Where did the horses come from? The film should have answered that. (2) The ending is both unnecessary and tough to explain. For me, the film ends when the craft launches back into space.Instead of being a laughable moralization about war, dependent on ridiculously fast human-controlled speeds to get there, this is a more stripped down story about what happens when the descendants of your pets evolve capabilities similar to your own, while you're tossed about by an unknown space phenomenon. It's more watchable, and more believable.That said, while I prefer this over the original, I don't prefer it so much as to give it a different rating. Both films deserve 7/10. They are good, but not great.With the original film, it does share the flaw of failing to understand how evolution works. There is not a single "direction" for evolution, and not all species, or offspring within a species, will follow the same path. I do not buy either film's claim that non-human apes all somehow gain the ability to speak English at the same time.

Review title: Underrated doesn't even begin to describe it.
Review_body: I think I might be the only person in the world that loves this movie. I found it to be an immensely entertaining, compelling blockbuster with an interesting story. I love the tale of how the apes came into control and how everything is so shocking at first but then warps around on itself in the end; it all relates. The epic battle at the end was very well-done and just plain badass. The makeup for the apes and the art direction were just sensational (as these two aspects always are in Tim Burton's films). The style is pretty un-Burton (there's no Gothic elements or anything like that) but it still immerses the viewer and Danny Elfman's score does a great job of putting us into the world. In blockbusters you're never really looking for great performances, but Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth were both very good. Burton's decision on the ending creates one of the biggest stunners I've ever seen. It's chaotic, confusing and immensely terrifying. Unlike the rest of the world, I love it.

While this film is visually far superior to the original from 1968, the plot and characters fall far short, due mostly to a poorly written script and some wooden acting. Burton's style is out in full force on this one, and it works very well for the film, but the plot dives into action when it should be focusing on plot & character development. The first third or so of the movie works very well, homaging the original while retaining its own style. Unfortunately, the story falters and the suspense, horror, and sci-fi thrills - which were built up very well - are sacrificed for the sake of big action scenes. The final battle is a complete mass, topped only by the unbelievable, albeit intriguing, ending. The twist defies logic in all its forms, but it's still cool to see. A disappointment, to be sure. Something tells me this would have worked much better as a sci-fi horror/thriller than an action/adventure.There are some intriguing concepts at play within the film, mostly dealing with the evolution of the apes and their culture. The fact that they all evolved from the monkeys that the humans took with them is quite an ingenious idea, made even more so by the fact that the apes all worship these simple monkeys. A nice jab at our own religious beliefs when Ari states that their story of creation is nothing more than a fairy tale. The ape culture is interesting because of its apparent similarity to, yet stark difference from, our own - seems to suggest that evolution turns out the same regardless of species. A thought, though - if the apes evolved from the monkeys who rebelled against the humans, then where did the humans on the planet come from? Definitely a plot hole. Still, the overall concept is quite good, marred unnecessarily by the poor storyline.Technically, the film is superb. The makeup, costumes, production design, music and special effects are all top-notch and very cool. The apes look, act, and move like real animals, not just humans in monkey suits. The score, especially during the opening credits, is excellent and quite appropriate for the film. The ape village is very Burtonesque, which suits it well. Some of the early scenes are startling in their dark beauty. Most of the cool shots in this movie are in the first half, save the final scene. The second half goes awry with silly battle scenes and lame attempts at character development. Once again, the script is to blame. The acting is all over the place, ranging from scenery-chewing (Roth) to mediocre (Wahlberg) to downright bad (the blond chick). In general, the apes seem to do a much better job than the humans - not sure why Burton felt the need to make the humans talk in this one; the muteness of humanity in the original is one of the contributing factors to its greatness. The only human that should matter in this film is the lead character - the rest of the humans are just animals to the apes, and if they can talk, it ruins the idea. Still, the film looks beautiful.All in all, this was a great disappointment. A director as visually skilled as Burton, a classic film just itching to be remade, and loads of money for effects? It's too bad the script fell far short - this would have been a modern classic. Still, the first half or so is great to just look at, if you ignore the inane plot and annoying characters. The twist, however cool, is nothing more than a sorry attempt to top the original's ending - but it's not happening. Burton should have just stuck to homaging the original ending, rather than trying to beat it. Maybe have Wahlberg encounter an ape Statue of Liberty - that would have been cool. Overall, a beautiful film marred by a poor script.

(spoiler warning)No matter what can be said about the remaking of classic films, "Planet of the Apes" makes for the best of them. This can be attributed to not being very much like the original since only some basic premises and plot lines are the same. And being so lush with fantastic scenery, great makeup and effects, the 2001 edition is much more exciting to watch, despite being a little less concerned with afterthought. Tim Burton is a favorite of mine. His dreamscapes are sometimes a tad lacking in the meaning department, but they are always resplendent with true artistic ambitions. "Planet of the Apes" is no exception.One could argue about some of the differences from the first movie of 1968. A major one is making humans able to speak, which can be seen as a weak spot. Though helping Leo Davidson (Wahlberg) considerably, this "new" feature makes some of the philosophizing somewhat dimmer - the apes ask themselves whether humans have souls. But would one actually argue that a being that is able to form its own thougts and speak them would not have one? I wonder. On the other hand, since Davidson is responsible for the entire future scenario on this planet of apes, ancient grudges can make the apes selective in their thinking: humans tortured them for so long. Philosophic arguments might not go a long way with them.Humor is an important ingredient in the new "Planet of the Apes". While the original is sternly sober and not very witty at all (Heston's grim look is heavy to bear), this one flirts quite handsomely with human characteristics transferred to apes. Very funny and Burton-esque. I also appreciate the careful depiction of the apes movements and behavior. While clearly developed beyond their ancestors, the apes still retain a great deal of "monkey" characteristics - growling, aggressiveness and jumping around rather than walking. The original "Planet of the Apes" had the monkeys walking around much like ordinary humans, which flattened some of the impact.Still, it is unnecessary to compare them in other respects, since the new one is not really a remake and not really a sequel either. I for one welcome it. It doesn't contain the same degree of commentary on humanity that the 1968 movie did, but that one is not anywhere near as spectacular. A good job. I bow my head to Tim Burton and his crew.

After all those reviews and comments, I feel that I have to add mine.I'll start with the things I liked:The make-up is fantastic. The always-amazing Rick Baker did an incredible job here and created some truly realistic apes - I'll risk in saying that it's probably the best ape make-up ever made, and - as some people have already mentioned - a lot better than the make-up used in the original series. I especially liked the make-up for Thade (Tim Roth). My least favorite is the make-up for Ari (Helena Bonham Carter), which looks quite different from the rest; I guess Rick wanted her to look "half-human" (a similar approach was used for the wolves animatronics in the 1994 "Wolf"), but for me it was too distracting, as it looked too fake. Actually, she's the ONLY ape who looks fake.In addition to the make-up, costumes (Burton's regular Colleen Atwood) and sets, I realized that what makes the apes especially realistic is their movement and their use of space (jumping all the times, using trees and roots, etc.). This aspect is another credit point for Burton, who always put special attention to the behavior and movement of the characters (Lisa Marie as the Martian Girl in "Mars Attacks!" immediately comes to mind) and made the actors go to "ape school".Danny Elfman's score is always fantastic and this one is no exception. The use of primitive tools and jungle motives in the main titles is great. It starts quietly, as a simplified and primitive tune and builds up (as usual in Danny's themes) to a march piece of heavy metal instruments, "like bars closing in", as one review described it. While the theme reminded me past works such as "Men in Black" and "Dead Presidents", other cues reminded me of Danny's earlier works such as "Mars Attacks!", "Edward Scissorhands", "Batman Returns" and the "March of the Dead" from "Army of Darkness". Now that I listen to the soundtrack, the final part of the track titled "The Return", which ends the movie, seems to be highly influenced by the work of Bernard Herrmann (Danny's mentor).One thing that I liked about the plot *SPOILER ALERT* is the added explanation for the apes being "smart" - the genetic treatment, which is unfortunately ruined totally later on (I think. Depends on how you understand the ending). *END OF SPOILER*Two bits that made the movie entertaining for me were the parts of Limbo, the slave trader (played by the hilarious Paul Giamatti), and the two guest appearances by Glenn Shadix and Lisa Marie (as Senator Nado and Nova) - I wish they had a bigger part in the movie.And now to the things I didn't like:First of all - Estella Warren. From the very first moment she appears on screen, early in the movie, I felt her casting is wrong. Except for putting her as an attraction for the male audience (me amongst them), I saw no reason for using an amazing blonde model, dressed in small rags, for this part. It simply distracts you from the movie and damages its realism. I wanted to see Lisa Marie in this role, just so she could have a bigger part, but this one wouldn't solve the real drawback -Aside for the casting of Estella Warren, the role of Daena (and her entire family, for that matter) seems absolutely redundant - She has almost no interaction with the hero, and seems to exist only to fill the role of the traditional "blonde girl the hero kisses at the end" - not to mention that this kiss seems completely out of place, since they had no interaction before that. The same, though on a smaller scale, goes for the rest of her family, which seems to be "dragging" along with the hero for no apparent reason.I think the biggest drawback of the movie has to be its script. There are lots of things to say about it, and I'm not sure where to start. Here are several points: The script (especially the last quarter) seems like a big mishmash of bits from the movies in the earlier series; The script has no "social meaning" at all - the writers seem to have taken an everyday-life cruel behavior towards animals (and a politically-correct objector) and reverse the roles, without debating any valuable issue; None of the characters seemed to have depth and we get no reason for Ari being so fond of the ugly humans; *MAJOR SPOILERS ALERT* The fact that the apes and humans, who live as primitives without any technology and don't know what a gun is, are not a bit surprised by digital gadgets, spaceships and "a weapon that blow-up everyone", in addition to the fact that is made by primitive humans who can't invent anything; The ending that didn't make much sense to me, other than trying to give a shock and a surprise that would be different from the one in the original movie - one which you simply can not top; This in addition to the disappointment in revealing (a minute earlier) that the "planet of the apes" is indeed a strange planet and not Earth (which, as I mentioned earlier, destroys the rather good logic that was built up to this point). For a moment I thought the writers were trying to play a trick on us: because we were expecting to hear that the humans destroyed Earth, we instead see that apes have overtaken Earth - so perhaps they are the ones to destroy it? But then, the earlier planet is not Earth; There also seem to be some plot-holes concerning the time traveling, both of the money and the spaceship itself; I also found it highly unbelievably, after the money came down from the skies, that all of the apes, who up until then considered humans to be filthy and primitive, decide in an instant that humans and apes are equal - the only reason for that seemed to be that the writers needed to get to the end of the movie. *END OF SPOILERS*

Review title: It's hard not to like a Tim-Burton-film
Review_body: ATTENTION, SPOILER!Many people told me that «Planet of the Apes» was Tim Burton's worst movie and apart from that much weaker than the original film. So I decided not to see it. Another friend of mine who hadn't seen the movie yet, advised me to watch it in spite of this because `a Tim-Burton-movie is still a Tim-Burton-movie'. I decided to do it, and I found that he was right.It's clear that a remake of such a famous film as `Planet of the Apes' is automatically influenced by commercial thinking. Still, Tim Burton managed his film to represent his weird playfulness just as well as `Beetlejuice' or `Batman'. If you are already fond of Burton-movies, it's hard not to like one of his films, even if it has some flaws: nerve-racking monkey squeals, over-dressed apes and a leading actor who could have been, without difficulties, replaced by anbody else.What the film gives us in the first place, is an answer to the question: What's the result when Tim Burton is instructed to create a remake? First of all, Burton wouldn't be Burton, if he wouldn't refuse to call it a remake from the start; it's a `re-imagining'. On the other hand, Burton knows that almost every viewer of his movie has seen the very first film version starring Charlton Heston (as human), and he knows that a remake doesn't exist without its model and that the two films will not stop being compared. So all he does is playing with this comparison at every moment of his film, e. g. by referencing to quotes. Concerning the story-line, Burton does a brilliant job by answering open questions of the original first, and then driving the whole audience to despair by destroying this wonderful clarity and ending the movie with  AND HERE IS THE SPOILER  Leo coming back to earth and finding himself inside a world that seems to have been ruled by apes forever. Now, this is the burtonesque answer to people's expectations they hold because of the astonishing, shocking ending of the first `Planet of the Apes'. An ending, even more unexpected, more astonishing and: completely confusing, because  and here I'm disagreeing with various `Planet of the Apes'-homepages and -platforms  it does not make any sense. There cannot be a meaning to it, or just a so complicated one that it becomes ineffective. Tim Burton is playing his cruel games, he does it with a grin and he does it well. Burton fans will sure like it, others may feel betrayed and complain about some sort of manierism. Well, and I don't think producers will ever ask Burton to direct a remake again

I won't spend much time reviewing this film for in all honesty many critics have done that better than i could ever do it. This only a brief take to a unmitigated disaster.This film was one of the the most hyped of its era and it was thought that it could do it. A great director, a cast full of Oscar winner and nominees and extremely well made visuals and make-up, so what when bananas and made this film so bad?For ones it is almost the same with the original, second dialogue that makes me wish to be deaf, third a stiff acting and finally one of the most idiotic ending in film history. I honestly am unable to say anything more .If something is to be said is that this film destroyed the reputation of Tim Burton as a great director and from this point on he is but a shadow of his former glory, many actors reputation was stained by that film and it took them years to come back in to the spotlight. However in all this disaster there is one good thing that came out: A guide of how not to make a remake ,which future directors and studios can uses in order to make good films and I believe that it has help ,if the new trilogy of the Planet of the Apes films is any indication.

Review title: "You apes sure made a monkey / You fine-lee made a mon-kee out of meeee!!!"
Review_body: Um... okay.Well, this is darn near indistinguishable from the original "Planet" except that it *looks* better.  That's funny, you see, because the original *sounds* better, so to speak.So, what about the Surprise Ending?I won't spoil the THREE (count 'em) surprise endings.  The first two were pretty darn obvious.  The last doesn't leave you much to think about except for the nasty, bile-like taste of subverted racism.

Review title: Unmemorable but honourable attempt to revitalise the Planet series
Review_body: During a failed detour, Air Force astronaut Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) lands on an alien planet where apes rule the world and humans are their slaves. It is pretty much a straight forward remake of the 1968 sci-fi classic as opposed to the recent Andy Serkis fronted reboots which takes the premise in a different way. There are pretty good moments including the opening titles which are delightfully scored by Danny Elfman, making us feel we are certainly in Burton's take of this world. Tim Roth is very good as General Thade; a sadistic warrior ape who is frighteningly murderous and untrustworthy. Roth has a lot of fun with the role and does provide the films standout moment towards the end, delving into the scary energy that chimpanzees can have. The classic twist ending is effectively done and a good homage to the original. Paul Giamatti is also pretty good as the comic relief of the film and it's a helluva role! The production was documented as pretty troubled. As soon as Tim was recruited to direct, there was already a release date a year away as the studio were desperate to start the franchise up again. Script rewrites were being done while sets were being made just weeks before shooting began. Under immense studio pressure, the shoot sounded stressful and tight with editing having to take place in conjunction with the shooting. All the while undergoing personal issues, it's no wonder that the film unfortunately doesn't fully stand up on its own. It's no fault of any crew or cast member who do give it their all; it's just circumstance and bad timing culminating in a rushed and churned out Hollywood flick. There's a certain charm however to seeing Rick Baker's ape make-up work which is a nice homage to the original while also embellishing on their more animalistic mannerisms. It also marks the first collaboration with Helena Bonham Carter who has started a family with Burton since and went on to star in all of his films throughout the '00s
Ok remake of P.o.A's series. Had the Tim Burton feel, nice cameo's by a few old stars, great special affects to boot!

While it's not possible to fully talk about this movie without taking the ending into account-- which I'm not going to do-- I will say that no matter WHAT the ending turned out to be, it was definitely not worth sitting through this dull, boring, illogical mess.The make-up is fantastic.  Let's get that out of the way right now, so that we may focus on how uninteresting any of the story or characters were.  Mark Wahlberg coasts through this one, with no character to play, other than a very animalistic, primal human (ironic, no?) who only wants to get back home.  Helena Bonham-Carter and Tim Roth have some fun (and give fun performances) playing their parts, but any political commentary is lost as each scene is just an excuse to blow something up, smash set pieces, or set something on fire.As an action movie, it's so-so.  As a clever, thinking-person's film (which is what the original movie was and is), it fails completely.  In 5 years, no one will remember this "re-do" ever existed.6/10.  Make-up and special effects are NOT enough to make it a good movie. Will someone take away William Broyles Jr.'s parking pass, please?

Lush settings and advanced makeup artistry are the highlights of Tim Burton's quasi-remake of the 1968 Franklin Shaffner film (itself based on Pierre Boulez' novel) but there isn't as much of interest going on here as there was in the first film. It's an action film, pure and simple. Whatever political comment Shaffner's film had is bleached out of the screenplay (by William Broyles, Jr. who penned `Cast Away', Lawrence Konner and Mark D. Rosenthal); about the only stance the film takes is on the humane treatment of animals and the topic isn't nearly provocative enough in this context. There's a large cast, including Mark Wahlberg (not yet enough of a presence to carry an action lead), Helena Bonham Carter (as stuffy as usual, even in full ape costume), Estella Warren, Paul Giamatti and, as the villain, Tim Roth. Everyone seems to be enjoying themselves but their performances are definitely in a minor key. Burton himself seems to have a curious disinterest in the project and none of the passion that infuses `Sleepy Hollow', `Beetlejuice' and even the misbegotten `Mars Attacks!' is evident here. Still, it's a passable, entertaining diversion with a flair for big screen excitement.

I never saw the original 1968 Planet of the Apes, which was extremely popular but I decided to give the 2001 version a watch. Tim Burton once again proves just how great and Gothic that he can direct a movie, Burton has the darkest touch of anyone in Hollywood. Being a Bigfoot enthusiast a movie like Planet of the Apes is just a must see for me. This movie is more than just about a human who has to battle an ape for the rights to get along on the planet. Apes are shown and portrayed as being very smart and clever Burton must have done his homework as he well showed in this movie for example apes bury their dead and of course they can't swim, and Bigfoots are the same way! I strongly believe that apes and bigfoots are among us all anywhere that is proven with the ending of this film!

This was a disappointment.  The effects were state of the art but the screenplay was riddled with cliches.  I've seen better stories on "Lost in Space".  Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth were good in their roles given the poor script.  I expected a lot more.  Estella Warren was convincing as a wooden extra with cleavage.

Remaking the original Planet of the Apes was always going to be a big challenge for any director. The 1968 classic was a fantastic sci-fi vision with a bubbling undercurrent packed with issues at the forefront of the era like race-relations and the ever-gnawing fear of nuclear devastation. On top of that, it had a gripping and involving storyline and quite rightly ensured its place in cinema history. However, with Tim Burton attached to this new version you could be easily forgiven for imagining it would be a taut, character-driven new film with much to commend it. After all, it's not like Paul W. Anderson was handed the reigns was it? So it comes as a massive disappointment to say that the 2001 Planet of the Apes is a disaster on every level. The normally reliable Mark Wahlberg is terrible but considering what he was given to work with it'd be unfair to place all the blame on his shoulders. As Captain Leo Davidson he takes on the equivalent to Charlton Heston's lead from the 1968 version but has none of the gritty determination that his predecessor had and spends most of the movie looking utterly bemused, possibly because he's found himself running around a world ruled by apes, possibly because he's been given such a terrible script to work with.The rest of the cast are no revelation either. Tim Roth is an unrestrained monster, but rather than being a credible villain is simply yet another cardboard cut-out Hollywood bad guy whose only separation from cinema's other dastardly Brits is the fact he's done up in a chimpanzee outfit. Burton's squeeze Helena Bonham Carter meanwhile turns in an especially cringe-worthy and highly irritating performance as the daughter of a lead ape senator who helps the humans escape. Funny how it's always family members of incredibly extreme politicians who believe in what's right isn't it? And as she spends most of the film running around talking about how unfair her kind treat the humans, fawning over Mark Wahlberg or screeching wildly, it's very hard to give her any kind of sympathy. Looks like the attempt at making an ape sexy back-fired spectacularly there fellas.It also suffers from Hollywood's tendency to move things along as quickly as possible in case the audience gets bored, for no sooner has Marky-Mark set off on his trek to find a human spacecraft than he's arrived at his destination and is ready to lead a resistance movement. The climax is a huge let down as the ruck between the apes and humans is over within minutes and before you know it, Wahlberg's jetting off into space and returning to Earth for the much talked about ending.Elsewhere, the clichés and general sense of corporate film making abound. Ape suppression of humans means they hit them with sticks and talk like the Uruk Hai from out of Lord of the Rings an awful lot and the script is packed with cringe-worthy tributes to the original ("Get your filthy paws off me you dirty stinking human," urrgh). The finished product is nowhere near the film you could imagine Burton making unless you'd seen it and the whole thing feels like an extended episode of a fourth rate science fiction show that takes itself too seriously. Poor, very poor.

Very good indeed, more actions and better theme song. I am about to give a 9 rating for this one but the ending is simply disappointed. Also, that is not a good idea to change America's national heritage to something ridiculous. Although i am not American, i think this is not acceptable.Anyway, about the story, well, at first very impressive opening theme and story. It goes well until almost the end of the movie, the last five minutes of the scene which might some audiences confused. But, a totally enjoyable movie to be seen. Well done.

This is one of the worst wastes of money & resources I've seen. From make-up that was no better...and in some cases worse...than 1968's version to destruction of a creative plot line in the original, to screaming, jumping violence that makes it inappropriate for seeing as a bonding experience with children, to the blatant & sophomoric political commentary against opposing political & religious views (clever & subtle in the '68 original) this thing is a hairy, stinky mess. The only reason I "stuck with it" through to the end was thinking there had to be some redeeming value. Rrmembering the shocking ending of the original I'd hoped something similar would happen here. But they mucked up even that. Why I expected more from people with so little creativity that they got paid for mimicking (like chimps?) the wardrobe design of '68, too, instead of doing something new. If you go to the zoo you may see primates throw their poop at you. This movie is why.

Review title: Tim Burton's Unique Different Kind Different Version Of Planet Of The Apes Which i Thought Was Pretty Okay.
Review_body: Mark Whalberg Plays An Astrosnahnt Who's Space Pod Has Landed On a Deserted Apocalyptic Planet Which it Has Population Happened To Be Taking Over By Apes As He Leads a Group Of Human Fighters To Go Up Against The Apes. The Film Also Stars Michael Clarke Duncan, Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter, Paul Giamatti, Estella Warren, Kris Kristofferson And The Original Planet Of The Apes Star Charlton Heston. i Thought Tim Burton Did a Very interesting Take On a Planet Of The Apes And The Story To it.

Thank you Hollywood. Yet another movie classic utterly ruined by a cheap, shallow, effect-heavy and redundant remake. The original "Planet of the Apes" was an intelligent and thought-provoking movie with a very clear message. It was a movie that focused almost entirely on dialogue, which sounds very dull but was in fact very interesting. This movie, on the other hand, seems to have done away with pretty much ALL the dialogues. Instead of a great movie we get an incredibly stupid two hour chase movie. Dialogue has been reduced to a mere minimum, character interaction and development are non-existent and most of the time it's extremely hard to figure out what's going on. Instead, we get a bunch of pointless action scenes, some marginally funny one-liners and some very hollow quasi-intelligent conversations. The only thing worth mentioning about this movie is that it looks absolutely fantastic. The make-up of the apes is magnificent, and the sets and backgrounds are beautiful too. However, this does not distract from the fact that "Planet of the Apes (2001)" is a very shallow and simplistic movie, filled with paper-thin characters, stupid dialogue and a nearly non-existent plot. Please Hollywood, stop ruining great movies by turning them into senseless blockbusters.Oh yeah, the ending did not make ANY SENSE WHATSOEVER.
* out of **** stars, mainly for the visuals

I won't get into the discussion if an original masterpiece can be improved by a remake. This review is written 20 years after Tim's remake and it still looks up to date. His vision unintendedly reveals where current CGI movies stand shy. Exceptions like f.i. smeagul not included, no computer generated or live action character replaces an actor (yet). Better to invest in descent make up than CGI.

Review title: Avoid the comparisons. Just enjoy it.
Review_body: So many people are angered about this film... it's quite obvious something is going on here.Mainly, the fact that, being a remake, this movie had to stand up to the original one. A huge risk that Tim Burton took, and seemingly, with bad consequences.I was born 6 years after Charlton Heston went bananas on the original. I have *never* seen it. Once it was on TV, and I lost interest after five minutes. Not because it was a bad film, mind you, but because it looked too dated for me to watch, and I was in that terrible phase known as "adolescence". It would have been uncool to watch a '68 movie. I will correct this mistake later, when I buy the original "Apes".Anyway, I came into the movie theater with only one image of the original movie forever burned in my mind: the epic Statue of Liberty climax. I purposely avoided all reviews of this film, so as not to spoil the fun. And I found myself deeply immersed in another Burton fantasy, where reality is as dark and grim as the lush landscapes that are always depicted in his worlds of madness. He is an expert in depicting outcasts (as in Batman, Sleepy Hollow and Edward Scissorhands), and although Mark Wahlberg wasn't as strong as Johnny Depp, Jack Skellington (or even Michael Keaton) as a main character, he was credible enough. Helena Bonham Carter is still incredibly seductive, even under tons of makeup and (gasp!) a beard. The rest of the characters are convincingly depicted, and the makeup excels.Again, not knowing the plot of the original, the only thing I disliked about this movie was that during the first half hour it dragged a bit. I guess that was due to the number of characters that were introduced. Afterwards, the movie turns quite philosophical (at least, IMHO). Was it directed at racism (which, from what I've seen, is still alive in the U.S.)? At animal cruelty? Was it a veiled message that we, as a thinking race, are doomed to remain evil and cruel with each other for all time? Or was Burton only trying to entertain us? (I doubt the last assumption). Whatever it is, this is one of those rare movies that open up a world of possibilities due to the use of metaphors. In a way, very similar to fairy tales, where the main character has to have enough resources to thrive and survive in a hostile environment...*SPOILER AHEAD* *SPOILER AHEAD* *SPOILER AHEAD* ...that is, unless you realize this is a mythic story and not a fairy tale, and that the ending has an amazing twist. One that, if sequels are avoided, could be one of the best endings in *ages*.Mr. Tim Burton, please, DON'T make a sequel, and you will have done a homage to the original series. The ending is just *perfect* as it is.I hope watching the original movie doesn't change my mind about this one.

The latest version of 'Planet of the Apes' is an interesting misfire. It has a lot of ideas, good and bad, and seems unable to distinguish between the two, and ends up emphasizing the bad ones more than the good. In a very broad sense, it follows the general idea of the 1968 film, that of a world where apes rule and mankind is considered inferior, and of a time-travelling astronaut who becomes stranded there. The apes behave quite differently in this film though. They are apparently meant to behave like real apes, aside from the fact that they are more intelligent and can speak. So they growl, screech, roar and leap all over the place when excited. An ape army leader, General Thade (Tim Roth), is particularly savage in his manner; the other ape characters seem generally less so. Mark Wahlberg plays the astronaut, Captain Leo Davidson, who is stranded on the planet. He has one of two reactions to any situation- annoyance or confusion. Or both. His one-note, furrow-browed performance doesn't allow the audience much emotional involvement in his plight. As the female ape who cares, Helena Bonham Carter's character Ari very much recalls Dr. Zira from the earlier movie. Here though her interest in Leo seems much more than a professional or humanitarian one; she obviously has the hots for him but don't worry, nothing along those lines ever happens. Carter gives far and away the most credible and nuanced performance, however her ape make-up is far too 'cute,' and provides a constant distraction. Perhaps the main thing missing from this 'Planet of the Apes' is a hero. Wahlberg is definitely no Charlton Heston and it's apparent the script never intended him to be. In fact, despite a few back-and-forth gags vis-a-vis human/ape behavior and stereotypes, it's hard to know exactly how this film wants us to feel about the planet's society and its treatment of humans. (Probably the funniest line in the movie has to do with getting rid of human 'pets' before they reach puberty- "Believe me, you don't want a human teenager in your house!") The huge battle between apes and humans at the end is pointless and unsatisfying, and the tacked-on epilogue is just downright stupid and reeks of desperation to find some kind of clever ending. Rod Serling would not be pleased.

Unbelievable as it may sound, the actors sound like they're speaking... from behind masks. I mean, some of them were paid millions of dollars to do nothing but talk - you can't recognize them and their faces don't move - yet their voices are muffled and their pronunciation is inhibited. It gets worse - they each move in a different style, as if none of them went to the same monkey school. Thirty years after the first realistic monkeyman prosthetics were developed for A SPACE ODYSSEY comes this incredible failure, featuring makeup as bad as that in the original PLANET and its weak TV-budget sequels, and movement training that so far from helped the actors, they seem neither monkey nor man, but simply fake.And that's just the monkeys. Every set looks like a set. Every costume looks like a costume. Every line of dialog screams, "Written for a summer picture!" The lapses in logic, and the errors of taste and judgment, are among the most egregious in film history. And yet this is about as much money as you can spend on a movie. I mean, they really tried. Tim Burton, a bunch of good actors, top of the line fx, expensive writers... and it is really about as bad as movies get.

Review title: What do you want from a summer movie?
Review_body: Wow!  Lots of comments here, and most of them negative!It wasn't that bad.  Tim Roth was terrific (villain of the year?), great special effects, great action, great humour, even some satire.  What else would you want from a summer movie?  Not the best or most logical script in the world, and not a patch on the original movie, but this is not unknown in a remake.  If you believe what you read Hollywood has been trying to make a new "Planet Of The Apes" movie for years, and Tim Burton was the man who actually managed it.  For that at least he should be applauded.The ending didn't really make any sense.  Many people have already commented on the ending, and I will not add to the comments here.  What I would say is that I wonder if Tim Burton, who has said that he will not be involved in a sequel, chose this ending as a challenge to whoever will be doing the sequel - and surely there will be a sequel.  You know "explain that, if you can?".  Just an idea.

In the context of the present day audience awareness the original Planet of the Apes (1968) has many flaws but the time travel reasoning and the rise of the apes made some sense. One is inclined to be a little more forgiving given that the movie predates the first moon landing of 1969.As for the 2001 effort, it is very poorly constructed. Most will abandon hope after the first 60 seconds - why have a monkey control the space pod at all? Poor logic and sloppy story line permeate the entire movie.Kids and lovers of wired apes might be amused - everyone else should run for the exit.5/10 being generous

What a bad film! I like to think of myself as a Tim Burton fan. However, I feel that when he gets a big budget, his work suffers. Ed Wood was his lowest budgeted film and was by far his greatest work. "Mars Attacks" and this "Ape" movie both had big budgets and were really horrible. Someone needs to tell Hollywood, that when you revisit a classic story, bring something new to the story. Special effects alone is not enough. I believe that Hollywood thought that by just having more elaborate costumes and apes, they would have a better movie, wrong! The story was just paper thin and the script was one of the worst ever. The first hour of this film was just a bunch of campy jokes. I have never seen more uninspired performances. However, to be fair, the actors had nothing to work with. The story is just patched together. Few characters are developed or have any importance. Man, this was a bad film. However, people will consider it a smash hit, because of the box office totals. However, most of the money taken in by this film was in the first week, so the negative word of mouth had not gotten out yet. This film has dropped like a rock since week one. Let's hope that Burton can return to actually telling a story and a weird story at that. That was one thing this film was missing, there was no "Burton Weirdness" anywhere. Bland and boring. * out of *****.

Review title: I've always felt this was a solid film
Review_body: I watched this movie for the first time along time ago and have watched it since. The story is okay it basically follow the same story as the orgnial with a few differences. It always had potential to be better. I always found it werid costumes for the monkeys. Even though it was made in 2001 it feel at times alot more dated. One thing that is really poor is the sound track the orgnial was much better.
First act was slow, gradually got better. Final fight scene was average but the dust made it really difficult to see. The ending was a shock but still confusing.

Review title: A fine technical achievement that falls flat because of its lack of a good story.
Review_body: Tim Burtons interpretation of The Planet Of The Apes isn't the complete disaster it was labelled.It is by no means a great film either.The good things about the film are all in the technical arena.The makeup and costume design are inspired,some of the best i have ever seen.The visual effects are top drawer but the film is let down by a wafer thin plot with a head scratching ending that seems to be more of a homage to the classic original film than a conclusion in itself.Tim Burtons visual talents are on display here but he doesn't seem to have much direction with his film.Its almost as if he decided to make a Planet Of The Apes film before an idea had been decided on.A so so experience.

THIS MOVIE SUCKED!!!Ok, now I got that out of the way. No, I didn't. THIS MOVIE SUCKED!!!! There, I added an extra exclamation mark! When I came out of the theater, I was so embarrassed for having seen it, I was praying that no one I knew would be there to recognize me. The last time I remember having that feeling was when I came out of Caligula back in the early 80's.I really can't hardly figure out where to begin because the number of insanely, ludicrously, mindless flaws in logic (or is it ludicrously, mindlessly, insane) were so overwhelming that I truly thought anyone with an IQ of over 60 would NEVER admit to liking this movie. Incredibly, there are actually humans that know how to type (unless some ape is doing it for them) on this web site who liked this pile of garbage.I'm serious. I don't even want to waste time on the number of impossible coincidences and ridiculous plot holes and staggeringly insipid assumptions that were made. It was cheesy, predictable, boring, stupid, insulting and, did I say MINDLESS?The ape costumes were decent, but decent special effects nowadays are assumed. The rest of it was pure, unadulterated junk. IF you have even half a brain, you will be terribly disappointed. If not, have fun and bring your banana. You'll fit in just fine.

Review title: Good movie but nowhere near original
Review_body: Planet of the Apes is a pretty good film but it had its ups and downs. The movie is about a astronaut named Leo (Mark Whalberg) who gets sucked into a portal and lands on a planet where apes rule. Tim Roth plays Thade, an army general who hates all humans. His right-hand man Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan) follows and executes all of Thades orders. Leo escapes with the help of a compassionate ape named Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) and is now a fugitive on the run from the apes. This movie I liked but I don't think was 100% perfect. I thought the make-up was not as good as the originals. The acting was pretty good by my standards. Like all Apes movies, the endings have to twist which this one did. Overall this movie was good, and recommend to sci-fi fans, but probably not to Apes fans because it really wasn't a remake in my book.8/10

More of a reworking of the idea rather than a remake of the original. I must admit I was pleasantly surprised by this effort. Of course, it was never going to be as good as the original, the ending to the Charlton Heston classic has to be one of the best endings to a film in movie history. I was satisfied that things were well enough explained throughout this film, for example, the talking humans, and how the apes got to inhabit the planet in the first place. What I couldn't work out was the ending, I wont go into details for those who haven't seen it, but I do feel that because the 1968 classic had such a shocking and thought provoking ending, the writers of this version almost `felt obliged' to try and live up to that and as a result it doesn't really make any sense and tie in with the story you have just followed for the past 2 hours  or maybe it does and I just missed the point!, either way  FAR too confusing! (Although it screams "sequel!" - how convenient!!). Wahlberg is okay as astronaut Leo Davidson, while Tim Roth is wickedly good fun as cruel military ape `General Thade'. Charlton Heston appears unbilled as Thade's dying father, who's character name is `Zaius'  is there a doctor in the house?

I think there are more than enough plus points in POTA to make it well worth watching. Firstly I think the make-up of the apes and the way they move is outstanding, the whole look of the film is excellent. The music by Danny Elfman is great. Tim Burton does a great job directing the action. I thought all the actors were great, apart from Wahlberg who I find a little wooden, I thought the same about him in The Italian Job but he's not that bad. Tim Roth is the best and makes a great villain, one of his best performances since Rob Roy I feel. I'm actually surprised how many of the IMDB users seem to hate this film, probably because the ending doesn't seem to make sense. I too found the ending baffling but I enjoyed the ride in getting there. I must say It took me a long time to get round to seeing this movie, I eventually picked it up very cheaply in a supermarket and I'm glad I bought it. Sadly I think the overall reaction to this film has killed any chances there were of there being a Planet of the Apes II. Pity because I would have loved to have to seen how they would have tried to explain the ending. Also I must say I enjoyed this Tim Burton film a lot more than some of his others namely Batman Returns and Mars Attacks, I think he delivered a great movie here. Oh well each to their own ***7/10***

Review title: Worth watching for those who missed out on it
Review_body: Despite some unbelievable pod landings, "Planet of the Apes" a movie that attracted negative reviews at the time was one that is my personal favorites. A decade later I decided to pop the movie in and give it another go. Yep, I still feel the same! Love the movie, love the makeup and costuming, love the themes discussed and by all means, love the cliff hanger Tim Burton uses in the end. I have all kinds of love for this movie. Seems like Tim Burton had a vision of more movies in the Ape regime; sadly for some of us it just did not see its way through due to the entire mixed acceptance back in 2001. Tim Burton as all you readers are aware is quite unorthodox and eccentric in his directorial choices. For those of you who are not as familiar as some of us, he gave us "Alice In Wonderland" , "Sweeney Todd", "Corpse Bride", "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" "Sleepy Hallow" & "Edward Scissor Hands" to name a few. If you are a reader who follows movies not by trailer but by director, 8 out of 10 have watched all of the above. "Planet of the Apes" with comparison to Burton's style is quite different. It's a Sci Fi that discuss themes of Animal Cruelty, Humans vs Nature and also if you want to be scoffer who hates this movie, a remake of classic Sci Fi from 1968. I respect classics, however what if I can watch it done slightly better. The costuming and make up is brilliant in comparison to the classic. However my intention is not to compare this with the reputed classic. 5 Stars and a round of applause for the magnificent work put in by the team with the makeup and costuming. For a movie made a decade ago this is brilliant, I have watched movies done in the past 2 years that can't even hold a candle to this effort. There is a lot of emotion that is required to be conveyed, which was a vital element to carry out the emotional wave. Giving the extra advantage of excellent facial movement makes it so realistic, never would I have for a moment felt, it is false and it is just a movie. I was right there in the middle of it all. Thumbs up yet again! As much as I respect Mark Wahlbergs performance, I have to side with Tim Roth on this one. Bold performance! The ferocity, the valor, the true determination to make every human suffer he nailed it all. Tim Roth although under so much of makeup, has his presence; he is just scared to look at. He is the meanest Ape I have seen so far. Helena Bonham Carter, who later marries director Burton in real life, was convincing and also was the vital link that ties human affection and animal cruelty on a broader perspective. Personally though I felt that Carter has so much more potential is capable of contributing more. (But wait! Am I comparing her to who she has become before she became?)We do not realize what it is like to be caged, or to be treated as pets or even as beasts, but seems like there is much to fathom from this, animals feel as much as we do. These are lessons for some of us who beat our pets up, or for those who don't leave a clean bowl of water for your dog every day. Doesn't look too great when the tables are turned does it? Also we humans don't realize that once done, certain things can never be undone (You have to watch the movie till the end to understand this). Wahlberg clearly states in the movie that we humans hurt each other way more than we hurt animals on his home planet? Have you ever stopped to think how true that it is? With such beautiful themes that are very well deeply hidden it disheartens me that this movie never got the place it rightfully still deserves. A decade is a long time, but the copies are still out there. I am pretty certain that most of the younger generations never have seen this one; just like back in 2001 I had never seen the 1968 classic!

I am a Tim Burton fan. I respect his work because he dares to leave his imagination free, in an arty yet commercial way. I always enjoyed his movies, but after continuously watching them for many years now (especially since they were released on DVD), I can finally spot their weakness.You see, some annoying feelings come to surface when you watch 'Batman' or 'Sleepy Hollow' for a tenth time. They are boring movies! Or to be fair, the are movies with long, boring scenes. Evidently Tim Burton seems to fear and respect every frame he shoots while editing and this behaviour creates very long dialog scenes, that work against the pacing of the movie.Long dialog scenes that don't provide exposition should be cut in a non-drama movie. Let's face it, Tim Burton has never worked with a 'Taxi Driver' script, so most of the long dialog scenes should be divided among action scenes.Also, the suspense doesn't change much in his movies. 'Sleepy Hollow' runs in the same way from start to finish, so does 'Batman'. I must say that his best work, is his comedies and maybe he should try to transfer the mood of those films to his other work too.'Planet of the Apes' is bad and I'm not talking about the ENDING, which is the best part of the movie. Only a moron would try to analyse what really happened there. Have you noticed that stupid people, always need to lower every situation to their own standards, in order to understand it? Of course this creates even more confusion (to them) and they won't get this ending no matter what, so let's proceed. By the way, true cinema is about expressing emotions and not opinions. If you need to state an opinion, the printed word is the perfect medium for it.The biggest mistake of the movie is this Burton element. 'Planet' needed aggressive editing, in order to become fun and not boring, which is what it is now. Specifically the dinner scene and the escape scene in the village. Burton treated this script like it was 'Godfather', so we watch the apes discuss over dinner about every day and social matters for ten minutes, like we care. They're talking apes! On with the story please! Obviously they wanted to balance the action with some drama scenes, but the writing is very bad. A lot of other scenes are boring too and should be deleted, since they destroy everything.
