Burton seems to have lost his humor in this movie too, since these long scenes could work if they were funny, but they are merely irritating.Unfortunately the script is quite weak, so even if that editing took place, it wouldn't make a masterpiece out of the story. Mark Wahlberg looks like a little kid in the whole movie, possibly because of Burton. He wanted him to become this anti Charlot Heston, an action hero who's in the movie only for the fun ride. It just doesn't work.On the positive side, Burton shows off his craftsmanship for one more time, providing us with some fairy tale images and an introduction in a space station, which is the most spectacular cinematic work since 'Superman'.'Planet of the Apes' shouldn't be made at all. How can you recreate perfection? What's next, a remake of 'Lawrence of Arabia'? Anyway, for once more Burton made an action movie that doesn't stand the test of repetitive viewings and this is because of his fear for aggressive editing.4/10

This movie was 100% boring, i swear i almost died from boredom at the theater. It wasnt funny and didnt really hve that much action in it either, it was BORING and i hope whoever out there that liked this movie, god be with you in the future when you find out what this movie was really like and try to jump off a bridge or something like that

An inferior remake of the original, "Planet Of The Apes" (2001) has Mark Wahlberg playing an astronaut who gets sucked into a time warp thingy in space and crash lands on a planet where apes rule and enslave primitive humans. Luckily for Wahlberg, a female ape (played by Helena Bonham Carter) has the hots for him (!) and sets him free. With the help of a couple of apes and a band of humans Wahlberg has set loose, they search for his ship that contains a device that can send an S.O.S. to Wahlberg's mother ship. Closing in behind Wahlberg's group is a large, ape army all stirred up to kill Wahlberg and any human who dares defy the dominance of apes.My most memorable, movie moment of "Planet Of The Apes" is the final scene, which is a surprise, twist ending. Unfortunately, it doesn't make sense. I suspect idiot, studio executives were to blame, probably counting their chickens before they hatched (or should I say counting their monkeys before they were born), looking for a way to introduce a possible sequel and didn't care that it made no sense. Damn you, idiot, studio execs! Damn you all to hell! In a nutshell, this remake of "Planet Of The Apes" is a rock covered in a fancy wrapper. It doesn't matter how pretty the wrapper iswhat you have is still a rock.Mannysmemorablemoviemoments

With some pretty amazing Makeup Effects, Visionary Director Tim Burton, and extremely talented actors like Mark Whalberg, Paul Giamatti, and Helen Bonham Carter. You'd think this would be a pretty great remake. However the story falls extremely flat and some of the acting feels like everyone is trying too hard or too little. The film is a pale comparison to the original (and the remakes that came after it), however the makeup is astonishing.

Review title: Not a bad remake, but it could have done much better
Review_body: The 2001 remake of the original 1968 classic, "PLANET of the APES" is directed by Tim Burton and starring Mark Wahlberg as the lead character and since I'm only doing three of the PLANET of the APES film reviews, I decided to start off with this one.The sixth film produced in the Planet of the Apes franchise, it was loosely adapted from Pierre Boulle's 1963 novel of the same name and the 1968 film version. It tells the story of astronaut Leo Davidson crash-landing on a planet inhabited by intelligent apes. The apes treat humans as slaves, but with the help of an ape named Ari, Leo starts a rebellion.The film also stars Tim Roth, Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan, Paul Giamatti, and Estella Warren Development for a Planet of the Apes remake started as far back as 1988 with Adam Rifkin. His project nearly reached the pre-production stage before being canceled. Terry Hayes's script, titled Return of the Apes, would have starred Arnold Schwarzenegger, under the direction of Phillip Noyce. Oliver Stone, Don Murphy, and Jane Hamsher were set to produce. Creative differences ensued between Hayes and financier/distributor 20th Century Fox. Chris Columbus, Sam Hamm, James Cameron, Peter Jackson, and the Hughes brothers later became involved.With William Broyles, Jr.'s script, Tim Burton was hired as director, and the film was put into active development. Lawrence Konner and Mark Rosenthal rewrote the script, and filming took place from November 2000 to April 2001. Planet of the Apes was released to mixed reviews, but was a financial success. Much criticism focused on the confusing plot and ending, although Rick Baker's prosthetic makeup designs were praised.The story is a little confusing, but it is easy to look at for me, but for everyone else, a lot of people and critics and also fans of the franchise hates this story and the ending. The ending is just confusing also, but it's easy to overlook these two major flaws.The music by Danny Elfman is just awesome and the song that plays during the end credits titled, "Rule the Planet Remix" is awesome, mixed by Paul Oakenfold and composed by Danny Elfman. The rest of the music including the opening theme music is just spectacular and the film does wonders with the music.The visual effects and makeup is just spectacular also, but Rick Baker did the prosthetic make-up effects for the apes and it is a blessing of him. The visuals are a little cheesy, but works for this type of movie.The acting, is just good and bad. The only credit that will be given to is Mark Wahlberg, his performance as the lead was amazing. Helena Bonham Carter, Estella Warren and Michael Clarke Duncan puts on really good performances as well, but they can get way too over-the- top in some of the scenes. Paul Giamatti is hilarious and he does an amazing job. Luke Eberl and Erick Avari is in the film, too, but they're performances were a little confusing. Charlton Heston has a cameo as Thade's dad. Tim Roth plays the villain, Thade and he is okay, but even then, he is over-the-top as well.Overall, with the 2001 remake of Planet of the Apes, it's not a bad re-imagining, but it could have done much better than this. I like and hate this remake of the 1968 original classic.Despite its financial success, 20th Century Fox chose not to produce a sequel, and later rebooted the franchise in 2011 with Rise of the Planet of the Apes.

"Planet of the Apes" reminds me of one of those times when I had no idea what to expect of myself.Was I going to like the movie?Was I going to hate the movie?I waited anxiously for the release of the film,knowing that it was not going to be the best film ever made.Basicly,when I go to see these types of films,I don't worry about the quality of the acting and the directing or it's script.Some people on this website like to watch films with a story and quality performances.That's sensible.I am different.I look at "Planet of the Apes" this way.One,it's a science fiction film.The genre of science fiction takes you anywere your mind takes you.Finally,two.The only purpose these films have is to entertain the audience.I was very much entertained by the way this film turned out."Planet of the Apes" was to me seven dollars that was well spent.Leaving the theatre,even though I knew there were better ones,I appreciated the film for the fact that it led me on a trip through the entertainment world.Mark Wahlberg is pretty good as Leo Davison and so is Tim Roth is General Thade.What else impressed me about this film is Rick Baker's impressive makeup which I believe is a dead lock for an academy award."Planet of the Apes" is a fun filled journey that thought was never a waste of my time.Every minute was worth it.

POSSIBLE SPOILERSAs with many of you reading this, I love both Planet of the Apes (1968) and the films of Tim Burton.However, like oil and water, the two are not a great mix.I like the fact he had a brave stab at one of Hollywood's best sci-fi movies and Rick Baker is bound to get an Oscar for his work on the make-up.However, that script and plot left a lot to be desired.There are little things that bug me, not the huge sweeping visions of apes thundering across the planet in Braveheart mode.When astronaut Mark Wahlberg puts his hand on a thousand year old door lock, it opens with barely a problem. If I leave my car door closed for a month it seizes up.
And when Mark crashes his space pod at the end, he strolls from the wreckage like he's just got up from his chair to make a cup of tea. Where is the logic in simple inertia and seized up mechanics. It doesn't take a genius to apply these little things that make all good sci-fi films work. Okay, it doesn't have to be Nasa approved but it does have to have a modicom of reality we can all relate to.2001 has been one of the bleakest years in living memory for movies and the news. Planet of the Apes will not be remembered for turning things around but merely burying them in a deeper pile of misery.If you only watch one film this year, make it Moulin Rouge and leave Tim Burton's flawed offering well alone.

I loved this movie.  When I first heard that Planet of the Apes was being remade, I was so incredibly disgusted.  I loved the original series of movies, and I felt there was absolutely no way they could even come close to making a decent film.  And I was pleasantly shocked.  Right from the beginning of the film, you could tell it was directed very well.  And the movie kept a very good pace, I was never bored.  I loved the costumes, the music, and the attention to detail.  I also thought the film was very well acted by all.  In a weird sense, I was reminded of Star Wars, maybe it was the scenes of the ape city.  The ending, I'm not sure it sat well with me, but I understood why it was done that way.  I really enjoyed this film, which is a very rare occurrence these days.  I'm a movie snob and tend to only like the older films.  But this new film was very good and I highly recommend it.  The story stands out on it's own and doesn't need the original films at all.  Even Charlton Heston's cameo was great!

I enjoyed" Planet of the Apes" very much but the ending brings the rest of the film down. Tim Burton has a great eye for gothic visuals and he doesn't dissapoint here. Most of the movie is very dark and moody. The performances are good also, Mark Wahlberg does a good job playing an air force Pilot who crash lands on a different planet in time, Michael Clarke Duncan, Helena Bonham Carter, and Tim Roth also are convincing as apes from another world, the majority of this film is good, but like I said the ending brings it down, it's not totally bad but you're left saying, "oh, sure, Whatever". Other than that, I reccommend seeing this film.

You all already know that I love sci-f movies, especially the post-apocalyptic one!Believe it or not but I have not seen any movie from the series of " ... Apes ". With the new release of Dawn of the Planet of the Apes (2014), I feel like I need to watch all previous ones first (modern versions), even though they are not really connected with each others, at least as far as I know!This movie currently has a low rating of 5.7 and normally I would skip it... but it is was made by Tim Burton and I love this guy's work! Let's see if it's really as bad as people rate it!11 minutes - here we go... and I thought it was so nice... I mean it still is but the logic is out of its place... I can handle it, not a big thing.17 minutes - hooray! Kris Kristofferson! so what that I thought this is Jeff Bridges at first lol, it's always a pleasure to see a familiar face, especially on another planet!23 minutes - so far it's really interesting, kind of disappointed though... I thought they are going to be high tech apes, but they are totally opposite... It's still interesting to see an alternative life.27 minutes - the typical Tim Burton's background music starts being annoying... It's too distinctive, loud and it eclipses the movie...40 minutes - I am not racist or anything but... damn those apes looks fugly as hell! + Mark Wahlberg's facial expressions look like he really need to take a massive dump but he holds it instead...52 minutes - the movie is certainly not as bad as people rate it... and I have to honestly admit that the actors playing apes are doing a hell of a good job.1h - so much hard work has been put in all these nice make-ups, environments etc. but still, it doesn't make up for the movie which is a bit dull...1h 37 minutes - the apes can kill every human in half of a second but apparently Mark Wahlberg is special... LAME...God damn! The ending was really unexpected and nice! This movie is certainly not as bad as people rate it on IMDb but I understand that most of them just didn't like the remake... If the apes would have been high tech, I would enjoy it more :) tgchan's rating: 6/10

To start with I'll just say, the original movie is a true classic, a lot better, and I advise you to see it. Also You'll understand this movie a bit better.Visually this movie is wonderful, and the new ape suits are incredible. Unlike the original movie, the apes have a more realistic appearance, they act more, and sounds a bit more like apes. But the apes are still the dominat and intelligent species on the planet. This movie is more based on the original novel by the French author Pierre Boulle. And I'm sure he would be pleased with the story arc in this movie, even though all the french factors have been Americanized.Mark Walberg show us a strong performance, and the movies "villain" general Thade, portrayed by Tim Roth, is just terrifying. To be candid the two adversarial roles really saved this movie.It may not be as mind-boggling as the original movies, but it's still well worth watching. It's great for remake standards and shouldn't be compared to much to the original.

Pros:
Decent sets, costume designs were pretty inspired as well
A lot of the apes move like apes
Can be a bit funny, even some clever writingCons:
Pretty bad acting, even from people who didnt have 3 inches of makeup
Terrible action due to over reliance on wires
Boring plotline, didnt really care about our heroes or what they were doingBest part: ape politics at the dinner table, purest look at an ape civilization and how it works
Worst part: big final battle, wire stunts and bad sound design, a lot of weak looking hits, generally uninteresting and bad

Review title: I thought I was going to see Jurassic Park 3!!!
Review_body: I saw this movie in a single-screen theatre in Minden, a town just south of our cottage. I thought I was going to see Jurassic Park 3, but this was playing instead. Anyways, I'm not sure why I stayed. This is a really bad movie and, even though I can't compare it to the original which i haven't seen, I'm sure the original made a lot more sense at the end. Even though I thought Estella Warren was dead sexy, the movie stunk like crap.I did eventually see JP3, which was better than this movie but still the worst of the JP trilogy. I still say this is the worst thing I have seen in the theatres.

Review title: Not as good as earlier version
Review_body: The casting was poor for the second version and the acting and the plot are awful. The movie makers went to great lengths to get the ape army to walk like apes, but Helen Bonham Carter never learned how. The special effects were of course much better than in the original but they do not make up for its other shortcomings.

Review title: Entertaining, but doesn't live up to its potential
Review_body: Tim Burton's remake of "Planet of the Apes" may well be a disappointment to fans of the original and perhaps even an abomination. However, it is an entertaining film which is not one of Burton's finest, but is decent blockbuster fare.The plot clicks along at a cracking rate, so it is never dull, although a bit more time dwelling on the central character and the world of the film would not have gone amiss and would have injected a bit more interest into the film. Burton cannot make up for this lack of development, but he does provide the film with his excellent breed of design which does make this, at times, an interesting visual spectacle.The characters are also fairly thinly sketched, although there are some good lines in this film, particularly those that reference the original. However, some of the performances, most of which are done through extraordinary make-up, are very good. Tim Roth chews the scenery and most of his prosthetics as he delights in the part of the villain, Thade. Helena Bonham Carter is pretty good, and Mark Wahlberg is fine, although this performance gave no hint of what he would achieve later in his career.However, the wayward climax and somewhat bewildering conclusion let the film's solid base slip and this reviewer was left satisfied, but felt that this could have been so much more. This is a bit of a blip by Burton's standards, but, as blockbusters go, this is pretty good entertainment.3 stars out of 5

Review title: Watch it for the effects, not the story
Review_body: I had mixed feelings about this film.Let me start by saying my enjoyment would have been greatly increased had this been a pseudo-sci-fi, action, ape-based flick that stood on its own merits instead of being associated with "The Planet of the Apes".  There were certainly things in this film which made it worth seeing.Despite what is said, the visuals and effects were interesting.  There was enough story to at least hold the interest of most.Sadly, what it lacked are those elements which made the original PotA good. The original had weak effects to be sure and the plot even had its problems. Nonetheless the depth of the plot, the debate about the content of man, the thoughts and concepts that were classic, are all missing.  I would have hoped that in a "re-imagining" the philosophy and concepts would have CHANGED; but not that they would have been omitted.I still use illustrations from the original to elucidate points.  I didn't walk away with such a feeling from this movie.  The debate between superiority of human vs. ape has been reduced to scant allusion to racial tension.  There is enough illogic to not deserve itemization (the horses have already been discussed quite throughly).  Worst of all was the ending. My friend and I are quite familiar with sci-fi, fantasy, irony and great literature.  We "get" most every reference.  However, BOTH of us looked at each other and said "huh"?  While there may be some explanations for this they didn't even establish enough clues for some healthy hypothesizing.  It seemed just "thrown in" and out of context with the rest of the movie.To close out the critique I will just state that there is a positively tragic movement in Hollywood to "dumb down" every creation.  It's like Hollywood has the touch of mental mediocrity.  You'd think for scores of millions of dollars they could somehow come up with a story and content worth the millions of dollars of effects.  Give us something that can stimulate our minds, not just our senses.  I fear this "re-imagining" fell prey to this phenomenon.That being said, I return full circle to the fact that this movie enough going for it to have been enjoyable were it to stand on its own (and taking into account the current brain-dead state of today's Hollywood scripts). There were a couple homages to the original movie which gave us a laugh or two.  As I said, the effects and even visual composition were worth seeing. If you wish to see a movie to go "ooooh" and "aaahhhh" over the effects as opposed to the "invisible effect" approach (where you are engrossed in the story, not aware of the visuals being "effects"), then you will enjoy this.I would recommend watching this.  Just enjoy it for what it is and don't expect a level of content comparable to the original.  At the very least, this movie is FAR beyond the level of any "Apes" SEQUELS, which had thoroughly useless plots without the concession of good effects.

Review title: Am I the only one who's glad
Review_body: Roddy Mcdowell didn't live to see this movie? Unfortunately Kim Hunter probably heard about it & got sick to her stomach.What in the name of God??????? All the Ape faces brings to mind Halloween masks with the backs out. Shoulda recycle "Nightmare before Christmas" & "Corpse Bride" puppets or told it in CGI/animation. & again the low-lighted sets? Memo 2 all involved in film financing & distribution movie: keep his man away from remakes of any type especially musicals &, except for "Mars Attacks", this genre. & and talk of too many humans. The original two Apes films kept the human numbers to less than 20 to my recollection.I thought I'd never say this--The role of Captain Leo Davidson SHOULD HAVE WENT TO JOHNNY DEPP! He's got more versatility; will at least try to stretch his acting (Although for my taste he's being more and more horribly miscast in Timmy films). He was excellent in "Astronaunt's Wife"--Pretty Boy Wooden on Kazoo Wahlberg? Oh please! Or how about this casting Michael Keaton if not Depp??? Timmy B don't know how to cast a male lead to save his life! In terms of female leads he does better with HB-C but her in this???? IMO she should have been skipped over for casting in this flick at any & all levels. Elegant &/or down the down to every woman, whatever the character type or past & present, is her forte. As much as I hate her squat screen time role in "Charlie & the Chocolate Factory", it wasn't a SCI-FI Film! Get Veronica Cartwright, Robin Curtis, Terry Ferrell any experienced sci-fi actress who could rise above the level of unbelievable.The reasons I believe Timmy B had Chalty Heston doing his little bit here are 2 fold: 1) thought it would wow fans of the 1st movie ergo they'll come in droves trying to find what scene he's in; & 2) promised he'd pad Heston's bankroll. In case of reason #1, next time he wants to draw in fans of a media icon to a cinema adaptions, especially in the area of sci-fi, talk to Michael Bay regarding his casting of a main robot character 2007 movie adaption, for crying out loud!Oh wait a sec, just remembered--"The Astronaunt's Wife" wasn't directed by Timmy.

Just a quick word to say how I enjoyed this movie. No, it is not perfect, neither was the original. This one was very exciting to watch. The film is always visually interesting. The CGI work is top notch. The battle action is suspenseful, and the apes running along side the horses is unworldly.  Most actors did very well, under what must have been very heavy makeup. A successful re imagining of the original. The hero came off a little like "Gladiator" meets the planet of the Apes. No problem here. The twist at the end was a good one. See this picture, don't expect Hamlet, and enjoy. Fine entertainment.

Review title: Not bad, but still a disappointment
Review_body: Pierre Boulle's original novel of apes ruling an earthlike planet is an absorbing and truly terrifying piece of science fiction. Unlike the 1968 film version with Charlton Heston, this film retains (an Americanized version of) the original ending, which actually works pretty well. There are good scenes along the way too, but somehow, the story just doesn't quite make it. Excellent performances by Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth shore it up a bit, as does the superb make-up. In the end, though, poorish special effects, unmemorable music, and a seeming indecision on the part of the filmmakers as to whether to stick with the original story or write one of their own mean this movie just doesn't work as it should. Watch it by all means, but a classic it is not.

Review title: Its a good flick... with a poor ending.
Review_body: Okay by now I'll assume you've heard there is a "surprise" ending for Apes. I mean in the original story it turned out the "planet of the Apes" was Earth all along, so Burton had to avoid that, and he did, nicely, but he then felt obliged to do his own twist ending and that is where the movie falls apart. This movie was an interesting visual journey with a nice background mystery (how did the apes get this way?) although when all is said and done I am left wondering two things: 1- Where did they get all the horses? And 2- Where is Rod Serling in the end shot? I can almost hear him saying "Picture a man far from home..."

Tim Burton's folly... The lamest film of the series that was made with no point or end goal aside from making $$$.Mark Wahlberg is awful. He plays his character like a confused elderly person. In fact all the characters are awful and seem miscast. There's a weird kinda beastiality romance between Mark Wahlberg and Helen Labottum-Carter, the humans seem savage, but they speak and have developed tribal cultures of their own. The Ape society makes no sense, they see humans both as savages and a slaves.... it's a mess.The ending sucks, Tim Roth sucks, Markie Mark sucks, everything sucks.... Except for the makeup and the set design is very nice and good looking. It's a lot of wasted effort for this garbage plot. Ugh, skip this trash.

About 5 minutes in after the opening titles I knew this was going to be a criminal miscarriage of what could have been. Character exposition in the opening sequence was axed in order to bustle the hero (or lack of one) into the so-called action as soon as possible. What results is a woefully underdeveloped series of events thrusting us along on an adventure that is laughable and miserably cheap. Tim Burton's influences lay in many obscure and cheesy drive-in sci/fi movies and TV shows of the past (which he actually tries to pay homage to rather than satirize) and it's not surprising that this film plays like Lost in Space meets One Million Years BC meets Claude Rains' version of The Lost World meets Planet of the Apes. If Burton felt that people would be excited at the prospect of seeing his own self-indulgent vision of the Book and Heston's classic, full of gawdy touches typical of his style, he was badly mistaken. His realization of Batman was far more successful.When I first saw the commercials for this movie I was immediately taken. Images of marching Ape armies and the atmospheric visuals inspired hopes of a science Fiction action epic like no other. Spartacus conquers the Apes as it were. Sadly it was all window dressing and the truly best parts of this movie are ALL in the commercial spots. What we are subjected to is an unspeakably badly written visual feast which belies a very limited budget lurking just below the surface. The only reason to see this abomination is for the costumes and make-up design, as well as the production design (aside from the space station and space suits which look to have been stolen from the 2001 prop vault).The original planet of the apes is not one of my top ten favorite films but it is an honest and intelligent piece of science fiction. Though a bit of a talk fest, it does bring up some very thought provoking issues (thanks to the great Rod Serling) and ends on one of the most powerful and stunning climaxes in movie history. It's a film deserving of its classic status and rated a better remake than what Richard Zanuck and Tim Burton have foisted on us here. In fact, Zanuck should be fined and his producer's license suspended as he was also in involved in making the original.Any and all intellectual content is missing leaving us with good actors buried under mounds of make-up. Except for Wahlberg, who should have just been buried. This guy is the most vacant action hero since Keanu Reeves in Speed. Aside from disobeying commands in order to rescue his chimp, his motivations are unwritten, leaving him to loaf from one scene to the next muttering little more than "hey" or "what" or "whatever", while glancing more than periodically at his Tandy hand-held. The guy has the intelligence and personality of a soapsud. An actor with a grasp of dead-pan humor might have made this character zing. Wahlberg just sits there, looking constipated as another IMDb reviewer mentioned.As far as the other cast members are concerned, what is the deal with Kris Kristoffersen. He has two lines then gets run through with a spear. Estella Warren is atrocious as the obligatory female human. She's no Raquel Welch in the looks department and is an even worse actress. Helena Bonham-Carter is wasted, as is Tim Roth as Thade and Michael Clark Duncan as his Right-Hand Gorilla. One wonders why they hired big-name actors to be unrecognizable under all that latex when they could have hired medium priced actors and saved some money on the budget. Marquee power I guess. As good as he is, Michael Clark Duncan just sounds like the guy who played Worf in Star Trek.As far as Charlton Heston's uncredited cameo as Thade's father, spouting familiar lines he used to condemn the Apes in the original, though here in reversed context: maybe in another script, with a better director for the material, it would have been sly and humorous. Not here. The same goes for other memorable lines quoted from the original.Much has been debated about the ending, which is about the only pure Burtonian stamp on the movie. It has no relevance other than to set-up a sequel (would anyone care to see it?). It pays homage to Serling and is a twist on the original's shattering ending, but really it comes off more of a tribute to Marty's nightmare sequence in Back to the Future Part II than anything else.What we're left with here, in the wake of other deficient hack jobs such as U-571, The Patriot, Pearl Harbor, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas, is a clear message that a great deal of Hollywood no longer cares about providing their audience with a well written and performed production once their marketing machine has lured us into the theatres. If people keep falling for it it's going to end up sealing the end of quality entertainment for good.Here's hoping that The Lord of the Rings doesn't turn out to be a mishandled treatment of Tolkien with GREAT commercials.

I like this movie!  This is a really good movie... yet I don't know what it is about it that makes me like it.  That's the strangest thing.  I actually saw this movie in theaters because a friend asked to see it (I only wanted to see Jurassic Park III).  Turns out it could almost be called one of my favorites!I have never seen the original.  I'm sorry to say this, but I don't know if I ever will since this remake was so good.  I am satisfied with the way this one was done.  I am afraid of disappointment if I watch the original.The plot is excellent, first of all.  There's a nice plot twist at the end involving the origins of all apes that puts everything together and just feels right.  There is plenty of action and, in a way, romance, too.  It's a great sci-fi flick with plenty of action.The storyline isn't too original--escape, then get reinforcements to fight off the antagonists.  But it still does its job.  It keeps you watching.The music is composed by Danny Elfman.  He has a certain militaristic flare in this movie which really sounds good.  The music is excellent, taking on tribal drums at some points and bombastic themes that whirl together perfectly.The costumes are great.  The apes look just like they should.  The graphics are decent, but not overall groundbreaking.I was and am still really impressed with this movie.  It has a lot of things that kept me going and makes me want to watch it again and again.  But I can't compare it to the original.  I wouldn't even if I had seen it.  I can only say that this movie is really great.

This version of Planet of the Apes was obviously not supposed to be like the mature Heston version.  The original version had more dialogue in which acting ability was so important.  But the old version also moved along at a rapid pace.  This version played more like an action version but was also very good.  Tim Burton for the first time seems to draw the audience in to the movie unlike his previous films which seemed more rock video.  Burton is sure to make many more films and has greatly improved from Sleepy Hollow. 
I saw this film twice and with the second viewing certain details become more understandable.  It is interesting to see how the apes seemed to have imitated human culture.  Burton has the apes doing all the things humans do even saying grace.  But the ape's have no deeper understanding of anything. If you see the film you will understand. I believe Burton has the apes more as a creation from humans and not an evolved species.  The first film has the apes emerge out of a human created disaster of nuclear war.  This film treats the creation of apes in a unique way.I have heard more long debates about this film than any other film of the Summer.  As far as all the criticism of the ending, it seemed much more clear the second time.  SPOILER:  I think it was more of a beginning than an ending.  And if you look on the plaque you will see the name Thade.  Perhaps in the next one we will see a battle by humans to retake a new technologically advanced ape world.  SPOILER: Whatever, it may be that the ending may be another example of apes having imitated the human world by finding books.  Bring on Apes 2 especially with pretty pouty Bonham in it. Lets put Angelina Jolie in it too.

This is one of those films that you just watch once and desist to watch it again. I must confess something: I never liked very much Tim Burton's cinema, and this time it wasn't an exception. The worst thing I find in this film is the whole plot. It's so strange that I'm sure that even Tim can't give a proper explanation.From now on: WARNING, SPOILERS AHEAD.I always heard that time travels are mathematically possible if we follow Einstein's theory. I also saw films like Back to the Future where a change in the past affected the future. But I never saw a film where a change in the present could affect the past. What happens in this film is so weird that it needs a powerful explanation to make it acceptable. As powerful as a second movie, and maybe that's just what Tim was thinking.Here: END OF SPOILERS.Behind the makeup, Helena Bonham Carter looks more like Michael Jackson than like an ape girl, Mark Wahlberg's character is plain and insipid, and the film as a whole is quite boring. I have seen much worse films this year, but this one is bad.5 or 6 out of 10.

And with that comment goes the first, last, and only bad primate pun in this review.Leave it to Tim Burton to take a familiar franchise or story, keep enough of the source material to make it familiar, then add his own unique twist. "Planet of the Apes" is much like "Batman" or "Sleepy Hollow" in that respect.  You know what you're getting, but not sure of how it's going to be told, or what surprises lie along the way.This is "B movie" fun at its finest.  Of course, you're dealing with a film about talking monkeys, so if you're going into this film expecting something overtly serious, you're not going to find it.  It's a very surreal film, both in its ideas and in watching the human-like apes, swing, beat their chests, ride horses, and carry on conversations.  It's fascinating and a little scary at the same time.  Burton's quirky sense of humor is definitely apparent in the ape cities.  The make-up in this film is great, especially the gorilla soldiers.  The actor cameos are fun to spot (Watch for Heston - Burton does a good job in paying homage to the original series), and the twist in meaning of the original film's dialogue is definitely worth a laugh or two.The story was an interesting take on the original series.  At times it was silly (and seems aware of this), but not necessarily in an unpleasant way. The biggest problem that I had with the story was in the resolution (I thought a lot of the conflict issues were too neatly and conveniently tied up).    Burton also did a nice job providing a new spin on the classic film's infamous "Statue of Liberty" scene.  There definitely seems to be plans in the works for a sequel by the way it ended.I think this film will get some criticism for what it is, but you know, this isn't the type of film that is going to teach you something about yourself, nor will it provide the solution to all the world's problems by the time the end credits roll.  I had fun with this.  It was wild, it was campy, the acting performances were good for this type of film, and the special effects were entertaining.  I enjoyed this film for what it set out to do, and I'm glad it's not simply a rehash of the original film.Burton has still been unable to let me down, and still remains one of my favorite directors.  I'll definitely add this to my "Burton DVD" collection.

*SPOILERS  *SPOILERS*  *SPOILERS*The original is already a classic and here the makers got the chance to introduce the story to a younger generation taking advantage of the technical advantages of today while using one of the original director of today's Hollywood, Tim Burton, whose unique style is something that can give the edge the film needed. However the result is less than you expected from a technical or story and characters development point of view.As usual there are a list of good and bad things and I'll start with the good ones:Make up - Almost perfect. The actors look like apes and you would not guess that there are real actors under the masks(I won't be surprise if the make-up will win an Oscar). That saying there are some reservation. While the man apes are perfect the female apes are less good. They look like actors and not like real apes. The decision to let the apes walk and jump like apes do is used to a great effect and is the big advantage of the film.The dark tone of the story is been reflected in the dark cinemtography. Even when there is light it is not a strong one but it is moody and dark.Music- As usual the music from Danny Elfman is effective and serve the film.Tim Roth as General Thade is excellent and his performance convey the menace and the hunger for power that exist in his character.That all I can say that was good in the movie. The list of bad things will be longer:Mark Wahlberg as Capt. Leo Davidson is weak. He doesn't carry the film on his shoulders and moreover he is not as strong as Tim Roth's Thade. How can anyone see him as a messiah is beyond my understanding.In the original film the main female character, Dr. Zira(Kim Hunter), was a scientist. She fought for the humans to have equal rights because she think they are intelligent but she could not prove it because all the humans in that film couldn't speak. The arrival of Col. Taylor(Charlton Heston) gave her the tool to prove her theory because he could speak. Beside that she was a strong and believable character. Here the main female character, Ari(Helena Bonham Carter,) is been portrayed as "human lovers". There is no reason why shy thinks like that or what made her change her mind in such an hostile environment towards humans. It doesn't help that her performance is so weak and her contribution to the film is less than zero. In general the female apes are less convinced than the men apes.Towards the end of the film,the chimpanzee that was sent in the beginning of the film and that we thought has already died, re-appear,out of nowhere. This development in the story is very contrive and served only as mean to end the battle between the apes and the human. How the chimpanzee has survive the magnetic storm. Your guess is as good as mine. Another development that strike me as contrive is the decision of General Thade's aide to simply turn to the other side just because he doesn't believe The General anymore. Why has this happened? Through the whole film that aide is a loyal servant. He has no reason to doubt The General so what happened now? Was it enough for him to hear Cat.Davidson's words in order to change his heart? In short no logic in both events.The ending doesn't help making the film coherent. The only explanation i can think of is that the storm was not only a jump through time but also a jump through dimension. Otherwise the whole film stand on very weak basis and the ending make the whole film illogical.I like Tim Burton. I have seen every film his has done(not all perffect) and I would continue to see his films. However something is missing from this film. He is in his best when he direct projects that he initiate or are close to his heart. His best films were the ones that have an outsider as a hero that Burton, as an outsider himself, can identify with. I didn't have the feeling that he was fully committed to this project, probably because he was hired to direct this film and didn't initiated it.At the end I was very disappointed. Something that looked good and promise to taste good turned out to be not as good as it should and could have been. Just like an half baked cake. It looks good from the outside but it taste bad because someone forgot to put some of the ingredients that would have make the best in the world.

Not much I can add that others already haven't.  This is a typical Burton movie where story is sacrificed to visuals.  There is barely enough story to provide an excuse for all the lush visuals to exist.The movie is entertaining enough, but why does nobody give a crap about script anymore? This movie could have been so much more but its only real contribution is to advance ape make-up technology.  It's not a movie I'm anxious to see again; very few films made these days seem to have that quality.All the various flaws in the film have been pointed out already, but there is one thing I'd like to address and that's the question of female chimpanzees being the sexually dominant one.  First off, why introduce this "fact" if it's not going to be explored?  Second, it's not correct.  There is an offshoot of the chimpanzee, the bonobo, (which tends to walk upright as often as not) where the female is more dominant, but in the main species (the one which scoots around on all fours), the male chimp rules the roost and I don't think this film was cognizant of bonobos or much of anything else, for that matter.

This movie was entertaining and very different from either the original movie or the book (actually it was closer to the book).  The special effects were excellent as well as the make-up and the body movements of the actors.Charlton Heston makes as an ape and quotes verbatim one of his most famous lines from the original movie but it seems out of context.Possible Spoiler ahead:
Not to give away the ending, but it seemed the writer tried to have it parallel Pierre Boulle's ending but it causes great confusion.  You are never quite sure whether they are traveling to the future, past or to a parallel world existing in the same time continuum.

Review title: I've seen it 3 times and I still dont know if I like it
Review_body: I've seen this film 3 times and I still dont know if I like it or not. There were some element of this film that were great. the special effects were of masterpiece quality.this movie has lots of action. The story moves at a decent pace. the plot(although predictible)is good. The actors did a good job. The real let down to this movie was the disapointing resolution to the climax, and the bazaar twist on the ending that left me wondering what just happened. this film would've been one of the all time great sci-fi flicks ever had the last 10 minutes of this film hadn't have ruined it. All in all I will have to say that Planet of the Apes 2002 is a good special effects movie with a weird and disapointing/empty ending.

Excellent make-up, some convincing acting, good sets and a few eye-candy scenes don't make up for the dead flat screenplay, the sloppy storyboard and the overall sloppy direction.I found myself yawning, slightly irritated, mildly bemused, waiting for something really interesting to happen... just like with some cheap TV-series, just with more pulley systems, more effects, more musical manipulation, and more money.Did I mention that the make-up was great?Well it's not such a bad movie, rather average than bad. Worth seeing for the make-up (in case you didn't get it..;-)), and Helena Bonham Carter's nice performance as Ari.Just don't expect too much of an involving story, and definitely not a movie to remember.

I just got back from screening Planet of the Apes at the theater I work at. What I was most afraid of was whether or not the movie had SDDS sound.  It does, thank god. I am a fan of Tim Burton's.  He makes great movies.  When I heard about this movie, I thought, although a bad idea, that it might be an interesting movie.  I'm not too familiar with the original "Apes" movies, so I can't compare, but this movie does have a surprise ending similar to the original's, minus the surprise.I noticed the movie was written by William Broyle's Jr., as well a two other guys.  I got worried after that considering he wrote the horrible "Castaway".  I can't really give him credit for making this movie bearable, though.  Burton and his crew pretty much deserves the credit for that. This movie's plot is riddled with cliches from a General who was outcasted getting revenge only to die to an old Ape guy dying RIGHT AFTER telling Thade (Roth) what WE need to know.  It's as if the writers were afraid their slightly unique version was too unique and was becoming unrecognizable.SPOILER WARNING:I thought some of the ideas in the movie were intriguing and scary.  Not so much the idea that apes COULD become the leaders of a planet due to time travel and evolution from experimental monkeys, but that they DID.  I felt the whole play on equality was too preachy and phony, however.  Planet of the Apes is far from being the best movie of the summer - that title still belongs to The Mummy Returns - but it's a decent movie, although it lacked any humor whatsoever.

Review title: Reasonable re-imagining of a classic tale
Review_body: I liked this film... it was not a great film, but it was a good film.  I felt that it entertained me for the 2 hours or so that it was on and I didnot feel screwed out of 6 bucks... however, this film did not MOVEme the way the original film did... it danced with certain issueswithout ever really delving into them... it used the image of slaverwithout addressing the substance (and so had to rely on deus exmachina resolution rather than the more cerebral ending of theoriginal...)Overall, I think that the ending of this film would have been better atthe end of the original movie, reminding us that WE were the apesand bringing home the point of the film a clear way.  However,since this film only used racism a slavery as a plot device theending simply seemed to say 'boo' rather than to make one thinkor reflect.This is not to say that I disliked Tim Burton's version in any way,but simply to point out that it does not have the same resonanceas the original... worth seeing, but make sure you give the 1968one a read as well.

I just watched this on tv.  I agree with the earlier comments rating this as mediocre and illogical at every turn (within the bounds of the fantastic premise of course.)  I haven't read most of the 1238! comments but don't see any bringing up an aspect which jumped out at me.  __  To digress, I was stunned to see that, when the film Ghost Busters was turned into a tv cartoon series, Aykroyd's & Murray's characters were transferred not unlike the originals but Ernie Hudson, the one black ghost buster, was replaced by an ape!  Planet of the Apes strikes me the same way.  __  I'm white and do not presume to speak for blacks but I cannot see how this movie, with only one token black human surrounded by otherwise entirely white humanity, can avoid coming off as comparing blacks to simians.  Yes, I realize that this flick is presenting a lame, elementary-school-level case for liberalism.  I do not however see that as negating the fact that, while the film repeatedly instructs us that slavery is bad and that intolerance is bad, the humans are basically purely white, which means that the other set of characters (the apes) must represent blacks.  __  A weak claim is made that humans enslaved apes and now, after turnabout, apes have enslaved humans.  The problem with that is that humans do not use apes as slaves.  Hmm, who did whites used to enslave if not apes?  Blacks.  So then, if this society represents a reversal of our own, who must the apes represent?  Blacks.  __  Other fantasy films successfully make the desired point by either having characters of different colors or races on both sides, thus pointing out that intolerance is not inherently caused by racial difference, or by having characters with cultural differences which in no way resemble actual ethnic or racial groups.  I am in no way saying that the apes in this film resemble actual blacks but I am saying that some of the characteristics (besides their ability to ignore the laws of physics) they exhibit are exactly how bigots used to make fun of blacks.  __  Am I the only one here who was alive before the civil rights movement and thus what I'm talking about is totally foreign to the rest of your experiences?  Please explain to me how I am reading things wrong, if I am.

Tim Burton is one of Hollywood's darkest, most imaginative filmmakers, so one must wonder what went wrong with his latest venture, a reworking of the 1968 sci-fi classic, Planet of the Apes.  This is Tim Burton-lite, and as easily distinguishable as his prior films are, it's disheartening to see that he clearly gave in to Hollywood blockbuster mentality, as Planet bears no sign of his signature dark style.Planet of  The Apes is loosely based on its predecessor.  Mark Whalberg (here a cardboard cut-out action hero) stars as an astronaut who gets sucked into a time warp (?) and finds himself crash landing on a planet and captured by talking apes who have created a society where humans are their servants.  He finds a friend in female ape Helen Bonham Carter. The rest of the movie follows our hero Whalberg as he attempts to escape from his captors, in particular a nasty General played by an unrecognizable Tim Roth.The story is hardly noteworthy.  It's merely a clothesline on which to hang a few charged action sequences, grandiose sets, and the human actors eluding their captors.  What made the classic so striking was its scenes of the apes treating the humans as livestock.  Here, director Tim Burton has instead chosen to eschew characters and rely on the quality of the first film to garner any sort of sympathy for his characters.  The only likeable characters are, again, Helen Bonham Carter as an ape who sympathizes with and wants to help the humans, and Paul Giamatti, as a wise-cracking ape who by the end becomes very grating with his one-liners.The only true innovation in this updated version is the makeup; it's light years ahead of the 1968 version, and the actors disappear behind it, as well as the militarized costumes.  The apes look more ferocious, but this is a very poor substitute for an actual story.  Even the action sequences are dumbed down, with bullets and spears flying, there is no blood onscreen whatsoever.  Was it the studios who persisted in Burton to not show blood? Sleepy Hollow was a gorefest, but I imagine since this is a huge studio summer blockbuster, all controversial images and language were censored in order to have a more family oriented (money-making) movie.With all its flaws, Planet of the Apes is made watchable thanks to the amazing makeup and the performances from Roth and Bonham-Carter.  Perhaps Tim Burton will push the envelope with his next film, as here his influence seems nonexistent, except for the dark ending bound to leave audiences looking for a total mindless summer film confused.6 out of 10

This movie is definitely Tim Burtons best. This movie also gets criticized by many people which it does not deserve at all. It is entertaining and has terrific make up work. I think it should get nominated for an oscar for its make up. The movie did not make as much money as I expected. It made $178 Million and I expected it to make at least 200 million but there was so much competition that i think it did fine, and will do much better on video and dvd.

I've read somewhere that this is the worst movie Tim Burton has ever made. Well, for that, its pretty cool !On the other hand, there is nothing in it to get in any way excited about it. Just a very average science fiction story. Well the surrounding are made very nice. The apes really look and behave like intelligent apes. But the story itself lacked any noticeable inspiration, except maybe some nice jokes - such as apes fearing water. On the other hand, there where story holes, and unexplained parts. Especially the end was really bad.For men, there is Estella Warren with her supersweet kissme-mouth. But she appeared quite seldom in the scenes, and had not really much more personality and charisma than the boring Marky Mark, the main actor. Helena Bonham Carter was however very good, as was Tim Roth.I can't really recommend this one.

Review title: A movie by monkeys for monkeys (or apes or whatever)
Review_body: Hello, Tim Burton are you out there! No you are not. You were "out there" before and that why I've loved most of your movies, but you've really crash landed with this boring, conventional and leaden remake of "Apes". (I can't believe that I'm using the words, boring, conventional and leaden in association with your name.) In fact this movie was so bad that my friend and I walked out of it BEFORE it ended. This is only the 2nd time I've ever done this in my life. Fortunately for you I'm only 2 years old (if I was living on Pluto that is --I'm actually 43). Hello Mr. Broyles and your co-screenwriter did you ever see "X-Men"? It had similar themes about racism and segregation but it kept it speeches to a minimum preferring to show rather than tell us. I got tired of talking apes early on in this movie (or was it a stillvie because it didn't move much). Barry Sonnefeld once said that when he was done making a movie it was as bad as possibly could be. Well guess what Mr. Burton you proved his point with "Apes". However you are in good company and I'll tell you why. Tim Burton's "Planet Of The Apes" is the biggest disappointment since Stanley Kubrick's "Eyes Wide Shut". Bring back Catwoman.

I saw the clips,I read the bad reviews but I went to see the movie AND BOY DOES IT STINK, The story line is horrible,the acting is hamy,the sets looks like they came from the 68 version,in one scene the set even moves. This is Ed Wood meets the apes.

What has happened to Tim Burton?  Given a big budget he just can't seem to put it to decent use.  And, what is worse, he turns perfectly decent actors into inept mumblers (although talking through several inches of latex can't be easy).  Even the great David Warner seems to be wholly uninvolved with the drab performance he is giving.  This is just a very bad move and that is a shame, considering the technical tricks that were used --- and wasted --- in the enterprise.

I expected so much from this movie.  I was very excited to go see it, and I hoped that this would be the one good movie this year, after a long, long list of absolutely TERRIBLE movies for 2000.  Of course, it did not break the trend. This movie was just as terrible as all the other over-hyped crap that came out this year.  SPOILER ALERTA little warning here:  I am going to reveal the ending.  But it is of no consequence because the movie is total garbage and the ending makes no sense, so when you see the movie for yourself you wont even care how it ends, you will just be hoping that it DOES end!A laundry list of complaints: The script has too many holes in it to be forgiven.  There is WAY too much dialogue.  So much so, this movie cannot be considered an action movie. I almost fell asleep!  The make up for the apes was not as great as everybody makes it out to be, and the actors have a really hard time spitting out their boring lines with those big, prosthetic teeth in their mouths.  Its very distracting.  The acting is poor and the sets are TOTALLY CHEAP!  The Monkey City looks like something out of the Pirate Tour at Disney Land.  I mean REALLY CHEAP!  There is no edge to the movie.  The viewer should keep in mind that this movie was rated PG-13.  There is very little violence, and when a character does die, the camera conveniently cuts away to something less disturbing, giving the movie a very "MADE FOR TV" feel.  I mean it looks like something slopped together by the Sci-Fi Channel.  Humans should have been getting ripped in half like so many phone books at a strong man contest.  But they weren't.  Also, Tim Roth's character of General Thade was acted well, but he had nothing to work with!  He was supposed to be the big, evil protagonist.  But in the movie, we never see him do anything all that evil. Instead, he just grimaces in an evil way and hops around a lot when he gets mad.  By the way, there is a lot of unbelievable jumping in the movie.  It looks terrible, you can almost see the wires and the harnesses on the actors.  It does not look like they are jumping at all, but SWINGING through the air. 
At the end we discover that all these stupid apes evolved from the experiment apes on board the crashed space station.  But there are MANY species of apes inhabiting the world, and there were ONLY chimpanzees on the space station!  This is ONE of many, many plot holes in the movie that are just unforgivable. Then, at the end, the little chimp flies his space pod down to the planet and makes a PERFECT three point landing and then hops out like a little pro. Marky Mark INSTANTLY jumps in to the SAME exact pod and flies off to space and then tries to land it, but totally crashes it for NO explained reason. Is the chimp a better pilot than Marky Mark?  HOW STUPID!After CRASHING his perfectly good space pod, Marky Mark discovers that he is on a planet just like Earth, but again, totally ruled by Apes.  And he sees the "Lincoln" memorial, and there is a statue of General Thade with a STUPID Lincoln like hair do.  The ending makes ABSOLUTELY no sense at all and it was the final down point to an already over-long, boring, and under-achieving film.  These are just a few of the glaring plot holes in the script.  Doesn't anybody proof read scripts in Hollywood anymore?  I hated this movie, I was disappointed by this movie, I was BORED by this movie, and I strongly, STRONGLY recommend that you do not see this poor waste of celluloid.

Review title: Do not expect a social message: this is an action flick
Review_body: In this remake by Tim Burton (who had not the desired creative liberty), the focus is not so much on the story but more on the visuals, what makes this, basically, an action movie.Plot: the beginning resembles the 1968 movie with some added prelude scenes. A test-monkey in a shuttle from a space-lab enters a space- time rift and the scientist in charge follows him, crashing on a planet where the dominant species are intelligent apes that enslave humans; the scientist is captured but manages to free himself and from here on out the movie is escape-pursuit action until the climatic final confrontation, with some stops here and there to add short dialogues that add nothing to the story. The final sequence divides opinions, being ambiguous and leaving questions unanswered, promising a sequel that never happened.As incredible as it may seem, the 'apes' act way better then the humans. If you've already seen the 1968 and 70's installments, don't expect to find some social message in this remake. This is a pure entertaining action flick, and a decent one at that.

This is definitely one of the better films I have seen this year, perhaps even the best.  Tim Burton once again delivers a movie that oozes with style, class and sophistication, with a world so detailed and believable it's almost mind-blowing.  Not being familiar with the original movie/tv series myself, I didn't quite know what to expect.  I knew from the few articles I had read that Mark Wahlberg plays a pilot who crash lands on a planet ruled by apes, and in an interesting twist, finds himself as the "alien".  The story is a great concept and really brings up some interesting issues to think about.  This is one of the things I appreciated about it.  It is one big role-reversal but in two different ways.  Firstly we're no longer the master species in control, we're the animals without the souls to be used and abused. Secondly, instead of being discriminated against because we might be black, white or purple, we're now discriminated against because we're simply human. It says a lot about how we as humans treat others, whether it be animals or people...  I really liked this movie.  The actors were great, especially Tim Roth as Thade.  I've never encountered such a menacing, intimidating character as Roth's Thade on screen before.  Helena Bonham Carter's Ari was curious, naive and likeable and Mark Wahlberg didn't disappoint.  In general, all the ape actors did a fantastic job and combined with the stunningly detailed make-up, pulled it all off in a very convincing fashion.Danny Elfman is the man responsible for the film's score and I remember thinking during the credits, "Hmm, that name is familiar..."  I will definitely remember his name from now on.  The score is excellent, and at times spine-chilling, particularly during the opening credits.I'm an every-movie person and I really couldn't find much to fault Planet of the Apes on.  My only gripe is that like so many movies these days, it leaves you feeling just a little unsatisfied somehow..  Maybe it's how film-making has changed these days, or the new techniques they use, I really can't put my finger on it.  But with this film it's only a minor thing.  See it.  You wont be disappointed.

Review title: Never send a man to do a monkey's job.
Review_body: Do I have the right to comment on this? I mean, I missed the movie I was laughing so hard. This is a movie about a man torn between two females: a blonde and a monkey. You have to see the slutty "Oh!"-look on the face of the blonde when the guy kisses the monkey to know what I mean when I say this movie is hilarious! Anyway, although many efforts went into this--or so the dvd told me, I wondered about the security of a space helmet which was open at the bottom. And why can't the man land a pod right once when the monkey does it so easily! Never send a man to do a monkey's job! The movie's quality allows me to poke fun at its weak spots, the make-up is pretty good, and the ideas not so bad. It's funny that they managed to have the two major gorillas be played by ethnic minorities: The loyal African american colonel Michael Clarke Duncan and the loyal Asian servant Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa.

To be fair I watched this movie before I watched the original story. This movie is convincing mostly because of the story line. It sounds like tall tales. In other words, not convincing as the original Planet of the Apes which do deserve an 8. This one is one of those movie I won't recommend my friends to watch except for the beginning ape chase scenes. The story falls on a couple of things that makes it difficult to accept. Time traveling through the future in an electrical storm in space seems too far fetched compared to the original movie, which traveled near light speed. The fact that the space station had a couple of "space pod" and Standard Operating Procedures, it's unlikely that any space station would be traveling around chasing space pods lost in electrical storms. Space stations' aren't built for chasing or rescue missions. They could have sent a couple of space pods, with a chimp is more plausible. The fact that humans became a slave, and yet they can speak English and talk, makes it unconvincing compared to the original movie which they aren't able to talk as the Apes are convinced that humans are unintelligent. The original movie the Apes assume humans to be stupid since they can't communicate is a more convincing story. The ending of the movie, I believe spoiled the movie completely and this is where the scoring is bad. In any good movie there are three things that's is key to scoring. The plausibility of the story, the beginning movie to pull us into the story, the ending that wraps up the entire move is the most important. The story fails on plausibility as mentioned here. Why are humans too passive is unconvincing. The fact that humans in this movie has no capacity to use weapons and being unorganized is very unconvincing. Humans are well known to be organized in times like these. The ending is really hard to rationalized into the story and no plausibility at all. It creates a Pandora's box. So if I were a movie producer and I was to do something different, time traveling through a wormhole, a black hole is more convincing, if we want to add to the old original story. The fact that a small space pod to travel long distance is unconvincing also even with all the technology in this movie. A human slavery is only possible through greater limitations of freedom as in concentration camps conditions is more convincing I believe, or the fact that the humans brains were "neutered" into stupidity, as in the removal of frontal lobe is another possibility. The fact that human slave they became a butler and a maid is an unintentional comedy and too unbelievable. The fact that they put humans in wood cage and to assume humans are too stupid to find a way to break those bamboo wood sounds unrealistic. Humans intelligence couldn't be that stupid given a slight 2000 years or more of evolution. I can continue to criticized this movie because of it's many mistake. In my opinion the movie compares slightly better than Snakes on the Plane movie. You can make another Planet of the Apes...if the story line is a plausible one, I believe and make some of the fixes mentioned here. As you noticed directors in general ignore good story writing but in animations where changes are very difficult and costly, a good story is much more possible. This is why Pixar Studios and Disney have such an impressive list of classic movies in spite of the fat that its a cartoon. While story writing can be written on the fly, it is this reason why Xanadu flopped, or in more recent one Disaster Movie was a complete flopped. The movie was made before the story and they had no idea as to the title of the movie.

I am very surprised IMDb rated this movie lower than 6. I watched this movie when I was in elementary school, it was a groundbreaking setting to me back in that age. The spaceship, the monkey spaceman, and the time-traveling, and the complete developd apes society, all these settings were awesome packed. I watched it again many years later, and I had some different thoughts about the ape girl.In the movie, human girl and the human guy didn't have a happy ending, and I felt pity to the girl when I was little. However after the second watch, I felt much more touch with the Ape girl. She is a noble birth in apes planet, yet she is smart, curious and full of sympathy to human unlike other ruthless apes, they treat human as pet or slave. When she was attracted to a human, she was so brave to fight the society. I couldn't figure out this conflict when I was little, because kid only knows hero and heroine should be together. Simple left me after I grow up. Last mind of the rewatching, I would want to say, it is OK to be different because your inappropriate might be right in future. Even your love is across species. Lol.

If this had been the FIRST Planet of the Apes, I think reviews would be quite different of this movie.  But, unfortunatly, because of the cult following that the original series has (me included), it is compared with the classic.  I myself can see why it doesn't compare with the original, and I agree, it is NOT as good as the first Planet of the Apes.All that being said, I must say that taken by itself, this version of Planet of the Apes is actually quite good.  The make-up effects were GREAT as were the other special effects.  As for the story, I didn't it was bad.  The dialogue could have been better, but what do you really want from Burton? As for the acting, so Wahlberg needs some acting lessons?  Tim Roth was very good, as was Michael Clarke Duncan.  And even though she had all that make-up on, Helena Bonham Carter was STILL sexy as hell. 
Although not exactly up to the original classic, this version is a fun movie.  I also, hope that there is a second one.  This time maybe get somebody other than Burton to direct it.

Having never seen the 1968 version, I went into this not knowing quite what to expect. It occurs to me that this film wouldn't exist without the Charlton Heston version and its sequels. Imagine if Franklin Schaffner had never adapted Pierre Boule's novel. Do you suppose that now someone would still come along and say, hey, that would make a good movie? Actually let me re-phrase that: would that make a movie ANYONE would be interested in seeing? Not likely. So having seen Tim Burton's newly 're-imagined' "Planet of the Apes," am I glad there was an original whos coat-tails it could ride? Well, it's not terrible. At times it's downright interesting. Ultimately, though, it's just unnecessary. But that doesn't mean you can't enjoy it as long as it's around. Like any Burton film, this one is about escape. It transports you to another place and time. The sets, the makeup, the effects all work hard to create this temporary reality. It's convincing but, visually, I was hoping for something more like "Sleepy Hollow." I was never amazed by anything in "Apes" but was stunned by some of the things Burton and his crew accomplished on such previous films as "Sleepy Hollow" and "Batman." "Apes" seemed like fertile ground for the same visual opportunities, but Burton doesn't make good. At best, he's made the kind of cheesy sci-fi he poked fun at in "Mars Attacks." The irony! This didn't look or feel like a Tim Burton film at all. Where is the weird coolness that creeps into every single shot? Think of "Batman," how it more than overcame that horrid script with Palance and Nicholson, along with Burton's twisted vision of Gotham City. And where did the humor go? Burton picks NOW to get serious? THIS film? I mean, if this was the best he was going to do with "Planet of the Apes," he should have just stuck his name on it as producer and let some up-and-comer direct (actually, that will happen with the inevitable sequel, er, sequels). Not even Tim Burton can save us from Summer 2001, a film lover's nightmare.
Grade: C-

What took so long to re-make this 68 sci-fi classic? I had been expecting it since the early 90's! From reading the reviews, however, I get the feeling that it was probably only me who made that prediction. Why did I predict or even insisted that there would be a re-make of Planet Of The Apes?  Well, for one thing, I believed that the advanced cinema techniques could add so much flavour to the original screenplay, which was superbly revolutionary (please read my review for the original Planet Of The Apes 68' to see why I consider the original screenplay to be "revolutionary"). I have always thought that the original Planet Of The Apes was full of imaginative thoughts but it lacked juicy action scenes that could have made it even more fun to watch (however even this drawback didn't stop it from becoming a classic sci-fi, probably the best of its genre). The other reason why I expected a re-make was because I wanted to see my most favourite sci-fi saga being re-imagined, as director Tim Burton put it. My Vote: 7/10Things I liked about the movie: In contrast to other people, I liked the screenplay. In fact, I thought that it was brilliant. It was probably the best screenplay that could have been written for this movie without the "it-was-earth-all-along" concept that shocks the audience in the 68' version. I was as much amused by the twists in the end, as I was amused when I watched the original 68' version. Even the last 4-5 minutes were such a great enjoyment. I honestly think the screenplay works. But as much as it works, screenplay was not the best thing about the movie. I personally think that there are mainly two things about this movie that left me in complete amazement, 1) Tim Roth's performance and 2) The original score of the movie, both of which well deserve Oscar Nomination. Tim Roth was the only REAL APE in the movie; the rest were just humans under ape costumes. Tim Roth was the only one who really gave his character an identity. He was not just an ape; he was an ape with a personality. The rest of the cast couldn't even manage to act or even look like apes, except for their costumes, of course. The original score was totally mind-blowing. It is a musical expression of what's going on in the movie. Marvellous achievement!Things I didn't like about the movie: In contrast what other people think, I thought that the apes were too human. They were humans under ape costumes. Most of them didn't even try to act or move like an ape (except for Tim Roth). Obviously, they thought that wearing an ape costume was enough. I could puke at the dinner scene when the elderly ape character was speaking: he was just TOO HUMAN. And again, in contrast what other people think, I wasn't satisfied with the make up. Well, for one thing, the cast put too much trust in their make-ups; they didn't make the slightest effort to give themselves an ape-like personality (a couple of scenes showing them hanging upside down from the ceilings or trees don't redeem that - if they are ape enough to do that then how come they are so much human when talking?). Secondly, the make up in the original version was as good as it could get; it was revolutionary in its time. That's why, there was nothing revolutionary about the make ups in this one. Briefly, it was not better than the make ups in the original 68' version. Lastly, I saw a couple of flaws in the make up. For one thing, the one ape character -the one who sells humans as gifts- hadn't had his eyelids painted; every time he closed his eyes, his eyelids would look white (am I the only one who saw that?). Some of the actors' upper teeth had ape-like appearance, whereas their lower level teeth were obviously human-like. What about the hair of Ari (Helena Bonham Carter)? It looked like she had hair done in a beauty salon; it was too human. And her make up was terribly cheap, as if she was a little girl who didn't know how to put a make up. Maybe, Tim Burton wanted to give story a different respective with these ideas on purpose. But honestly, I don't think they work. My last criticism is the inappropriate sense of humour, which has become the disease of Hollywood in recent years. Directors must be very careful about the timing and the nature of the humour otherwise they spoil the whole movie. There are some silly jokes that work perfectly fine in the genre of comedy (Rush Hour, American Pie, Jim Carrey / Eddie Murphy kind of comedies and the like). But when you use jokes out of these movies in a movie that has a totally different personality, it spoils it. Within that respect, I have found the scene where the elderly ape character is taking his fake teeth out and putting into a jar absolutely inappropriate. Other then these flaws, the movie was a perfect re-make of an old sci-fi classic. Possible Academy Awards Nominations: 1) Best Performance By A Leading Actor In A Motion Picture: Tim Roth. 2) The Original Score: Danny Alfman

Review title: One of the more solid movies in this disapointing summer
Review_body: Planet of the Apes is far from perfect and definetly not as good as the original. I still found it to be enough of an entertaining ride to enjoy as a summer popcorn movies. Perhapse I would be more strict on this movie if there was actually better movies out right now. Pearl Harbor, The Mummy Returns, Tomb Raider and The Fast and the Furious were all disapointments for me and I mildly enjoyed Jurassic Park 3. This movie has entertaining battle scenes and has a good look like Burton films generally have. The ending left me somewhat unsatisfied and it didn't seem proper. Still it's better than most big movies out there. I give it a 7 out of 10.

This movie has great looks, the apes (with a few exceptions) really look apelike, you've got lush jungles, deserts, big, action packed fight scenes, and a whole ape city that looks totally realistic. Director Tim Burton wasted no expense or effort to make this a visual feast. Too bad he didn't put the same effort into creating a terrific story, especially since there was so much potential to work with. The 1968 original is considered a Sci-Fi classic, not just because of the story, but also the issues it dealt with. It used a society where apes are the top species to comment on and satirize our own society. There are moments of this in "Apes 2001", but mostly it's another big budget action film, only with actors in monkey costumes. As proof of this, the lead character, played by Mark Wahlberg (aka Marky Mark) is just another hotshot fighter jock, meaning there's no problem he thinks he can't solve by simply blasting the bad guy to bits. Which is a shame, since it would be much more interesting to see him outwit his enemies, thus showing who really was the superior species. Also, it doesn't help that the female lead, played by Helena Bonham Carter, doesn't even remotely look like a real chimp. I guess Burton & Co. couldn't resist making her look sexy, complete with a fashionable hairstyle. So, ultimately what you have is lots of good looks, but not much in the way of brains. I'm looking forward to viewing the 1968 original, just to see how this film falls short by comparison. 5/10

WARNING:  SPOILERS BELOWIf anyone else in the world wasted its resources the way this movie does the global media would howl.Tim Burton has been quoted as saying he never went to film school, or that he never finished it.  Sad to say, his movies show it.  He's consistently come up with interesting outsider characters but at least the story revolved around them.  Here, there are several out-of-place characters around whom no story is told.On top of that, like in Burton's other movies he substitutes here a weak ending for a hard-hitting one that could have paid off all that gone into the movie.  We get a miasma of red herrings and actions that drag on for no reason because neither Burton nor the writers had the neither the maturity nor the nerve to end their movie with any one thing.  Murdered characters whose discovery leads to no further development.  The fight with Thade ends not with a dramatic kill-or-be-killed but with him holing up undercover - but then we never see the consequences of his cowardice.  One gorilla changes his alliegiance after the battle but we're never given a foreshadowing of this.  The apes survive a rocket engine blast but we're never given an earlier clue that they can.  What we're shown as a space station turns out to be a space ship as well but we don't see that until we see the wreckage on the Planet of the Apes, nor are we given a clue as to how it got there - did it come through the same vortex as our hero?Then they had to end their movie with an post-ironic, self-referential, wise-acre college-student twist that said absolutely nothing about all that had gone before.  Rod Serling these guys are not.If this wins any awards it should be the 2001 Golden Rasberry.  It certainly won't wins Oscars for writing or direction.  I can only hope the Sci-Fi Conventions refuse to award it any prizes
