Review title: Slow-moving, dull, and without logical plot
Review_body: I don't think this inept script could have ever been produced withoutthe name of Tim Burton behind it. Science fiction aficionadosshould take note that, unlike the original PLANET OF THE APES,this non-remake makes no effort to lay any kind of logicalconnection between the different time frames alluded to in the plot.If you have ever seen any time travel films before, even mediocreones, you will have come to expect some logical inconsistencies(reflecting that time travel is theoretically impossible in the firstplace), but Burton seems intent on simply giving the finger to anysemblance of logic here. If you haven't seen the film yet, you haveprobably been told to expect a surprise ending; I would tell you toexpect a surprisingly stupid ending that is surprisingly insulting tothe audience's intelligence.Burton's fondness for dark sets is apparent here,  but instead ofthe decadent, wildly overgrown urban landscape of his GothamCity,  all you get here is sensory deprivation and an urge to nod offduring one of the film's frequent and lengthy periods of inactivity.The ape makeup, which was groundbreaking at the time of theoriginal film, has not really improved much. Some of it is quitegood (Tim Roth as Thade), but it is otherwise uneven, as is theacting.Burton makes much of the difference in strength and agilitybetween apes and humans, but the way he shows this is not byendowing the apes with natural animal-like grace, but by loadingthem onto hidden catapults and launching them into the scene. It'slaughable.The DVD has a few extras, including commentary by Tim Burtonand Danny Elfman, but I got the best laugh from the cast biosection, which gives page after page of gushing plaudits forBurton's untalented girlfriend, Lisa Marie, who is alleged to haveappeared in the film. Darned if I could find her though. Jeez, what_won't_ Burton stoop to to keep his bed warm!Rating: 3/10.

Review title: Did not work for me for ONE MAIN REASON
Review_body: Now that I've finally seen the big Planet of the Apes remake, and before I look again at the reviews. I am asking myself why the movie just didn't work.  And I think I know.It wasn't awful, not to me anyway.  I enjoyed the effects, I enjoyed Elfman's score, the makeup was wonderful, the acting of all the ape characters was pretty terrific, the plot was at least interesting.  Those are all good things, and made it an endurable experience, not like, say, Nightfall.So what was wrong?  One factor.  MARK WAHLBERG.He's just *nothing.*  He's this bland, flavorless, rice-cake/styrofoam object filling up air and reflecting light rays.  Not Rufus Sewell obnoxious/bad, not David Birney talentless/bad, just... this-was-supposed-to-be-a-steak-and-it-turns-out-to-be-tofu bad.I will never see Boogie Nights, so I will never have a comment on his "work" in that, I don't remember him from Perfect Storm, so I don't know if Wahlberg is capable of being interesting.  The part wasn't written terribly interesting (but think Sean Connery, John Wayne, Jimmy Stewart - a talented actor can *make* a part interesting).  Doing a lot of standing around and staring, occasionally broken up by some moving around and staring, won't breathe life into a part.And when he did do something or speak, I found his character unsympathetic and centerless.Now, I didn't think much about the original while watching, because I think such comparisons are unfair and usually irrelevant.  But I feel I need to say one more thing: Charlton Heston.  Not one of my favorite actors, but compare the life and scope of that character to this listless... thing.Too bad.  The movie could have been a lot of fun.

Almost everyone involved in the making of this movie is to be lauded for their individual creative efforts; this much is certain... great costumes, props, makeup, etc.My only problem with the end result of POTA is its emphasis on action, and very little attention to the human vs. ape and mankind philosophies so aptly and dramatically demonstrated in the original 1968 film on which the "reimagined" 2001 Tim Burton movie was partly based (The screenwriters who worked on this one also pulled information from Pierre Boulle's short sci-fi novel "Monkey Planet.").True, everything made nowadays must have one sense-throttling, action packed sequence strung almost imperceptibly to the next, never stopping to look at the wondrous 'flower' that made the 1968 film so unique.  The original film was nature vs man, evolution alongside devolution, and an overall downward spiral towards mankind's oblivion (or pretty much the next worst thing, anyway, since people aren't totally extinct by the time the main character crash lands on either eponymous planet).The best things in the 2001 remake are the handful of pop references made first in the original movie, the references to modern (some 21st Century) attitudes ("I'm having a bad hair day," says one female chimp in Burton's version), and the overall upgraded feel and tone of the movie now that more than thirty-three years have elapsed in the world of cinema.Its a given to say that special-effects are a boon to this new, improved version.  Yet, I miss hearing all that (somewhat) great dialog heard in POTA 1968.Everyone I know who's seen the Burton version has mentioned something about its ending, and the questions it poses.  Let us all hope Simos (the name of the simian deity in this film) answers our inquisitive, and slightly confused, prayers in a rational manner... ...and will there be an even more confusing sequel to this reimagination?

Review title: First hour - wow! Second hour - ugh!
Review_body: I loved the first half or so of Tim Burton's Planet of the Apes. Other than a few lame visual gags that were played as an attempt at humor (i.e. apes smoking hash like humans in the Middle east), the set up of POTA was impressive, a little scary and, for a sci-fi fantasy movie, "believeable."But the logic holes kept building and compouding, so that in the second half of the movie, when even bigger holes appear, the thread is lost and the movie practically shouts, "Hey! This is a summer movie! Don't think too hard!"I don't want to give away spoilers, so I'll avoid several thoughts about the ending. I will simply say that for the end to have occurred as it did requires multiple inconsistent assumptions about that kind of travel travel.Anyhow, one of my larger problems with POTA was the fact that the humans speak English, and in fact they speak the same language as the apes. Yet the apes still treat humans as animals. Now, I don't know about you, but if apes (or any other animal) on our earth started speaking English, I think my first reaction would be to INCREASE my respect and treatment of them, not LOWER it. The fact that apes treat humans appallingly, even though they KNOW they are as intelligent, is silly.This negates most of any kind of message about humans today treating other species badly. Hey, if my dog talked, I would feed him better food and give him his own room. I wouldn't do what these apes do.But then, the movie handles this inconsistently. In one scene, Thade seems shocked that one human look at him. Well, why wouldn't he? The humans can talk and walk and obviously are intelligent. Why wouldn't one look at the ape leader? It's not like they are the mute, cowed humans from the original POTA movie.Speaking of, Tim Roth does an OUTSTANDING job bringing Thade to life. He not only walks and moves as an ape, he moves with a sense of menace. Great job.The other apes, well, they are kind of ape-like. But unlike many reviewers, I didn't think they moved all that realistically. They looked like humans trying to move like apes.And there are lots and lots of convenient coicidences, like in one scene a spaceship showing up at just the right time to play a key role in an ongoing struggle. And a ship thousands of years old that has not only a power source (OK, I'll buy that), but devices that still work (like the wires and other more sensitive components would have lasted that long?).Still, I gave POTA a 7 because, huge holes aside, I just enjoyed it. I hope there is a sequel that is written better.

I. What? So. I don't know.You see. Uhm. Wait.
That was one of the many problems with this movie was it supposed to a profound commentary or a campy movie?Some of the dialogue was embarrassing. "Can't we all just get along." Bad acting especially Estelle Warren. Great lips a plus but that's it. As for Marky Mark if it wasn't for this movie we would have 'Entourage' so he gets a pass. Great costumes but movie just didn't work.

Review title: Excellent entertainment, although not Burton's best...
Review_body: Sure, this new adaptation of Pierre Boule's classic novel Planet of The Apes isn't a wonderful exploration of human behavior or something like that, but that is not it's target. Instead it tries to be an incredibly entertaining summer movie, while still being intelligent and retaining Burton's gorgeous visual style. And with that in mind, it fully accomplishes its goals. First of all, the soundtrack, made by long-time Burton collaborator Danny Elfman is up to the composer's high standards. The brutal percussion-based sounds of his score fit the movie perfectly. The story is very satisfying and the ending is excellent. Touches of clever humor add to the script. But, of course, what steals the show is Burton's gift for creating memorable images and his army of apes, led by General Thade, a memorable character played to perfection by Tim Roth. For this movie, Burton often leaves his trademark dark and blue colors, but the movie still has his wonderful touch. As for the apes, they are very impressive. The cast is good, without having very hard jobs to do, but as I said earlier, Roth shines. So, this may not be Tim Burton's best movie, but it is the perfect summer entertainment, offered to you by one of history's greatest directors.85%

When I first read that they were going to do this remake I thought it was a ridiculous idea. The original premise was so silly that I thought if there is one movie that did NOT cry out to be remade it was this one. I was incorrect in assuming this. The prosthetic makeup is so much better than the original(you can see the actor's real faces beneath the ape facade)that the biggest hurdle is immediately overcome. Tim Burton excels in working unusual concepts in his film and this is more of the same. Mark Wahlberg fits as the protagonist and while he is not Laurence Olivier the material isn't Shakespeare either. I went expecting little and was pleasantly surprised. With people staying away from the theatre in droves this summer I don't think the film will do that well in the box office but I will recommend it.

Review title: Tim Burton should be ashamed of himself
Review_body: I LOVE Tim Burton.  He's original, he's smart, and his movies are usually visually inventive.  I guess you can't win 'em all.The story in this waste of time is close to non-existant and doesn't give the talented cast any chance at all of projecting any kind of character. There is one mildly entertaining action sequence, and there is the odd in-joke that works (most notably Charleton Heston's cameo), but that's about it as a MOVIE.As a technical exercise, this film displays little of Burton's usual brilliance, but Rick Baker's makeup definitely deserves special mention. The ape characters are incredible, and show remarkably subtle facial expressions.  Had the characters themselves be better written, there's some chance this wouldn't have been a total waste.3/10 for outstanding makeup and a few cool in-jokes.

Review title: Do not compare to the original
Review_body: This movie stands on it's own merit. The original was a timeless sci-fi classic. A stand alone. I was obsessed with the original, sequels, TV show, merchandise, anything ape! I used to draw ape faces all over my Pee Chee folders! (Kids, ask your parents). So I qualify as a huge fan! This movie does have it's flaws but it's not the abomination some reviews have said. It's good popcorn fun!

PLANET OF THE APES   * *   Unnecessary remake brings nothing new to the table in terms of imagination or inspiration.  Performances by Helena Bonham Carter,  Tim Roth and many of the others playing apes are the only redeeming features.  Everything money can buy, expensive sets, makeup, costumes and actors, can't make up for an incoherent and illogical script.   Finally, if the average movie  goer has to research the internet to try to understand the final scene, then the moviemakers haven't done their job.

One word comes to mind: Stinker! I waited thirty years for this freak show. Numbingly disappointing. A gargantuan gas bag of celluloid claptrap. Tim Burton's dreadful spin on a four-star classic renders off a slickly produced, but lethal aroma of a movie, that, when looked at closely, would have even the gorillas at the Bronx Zoo scratching their heads in disbelief. Burton's big mistake (I think) was creating a different, unfamiliar ape universe from the previous series. Strangely, I believe the film he achieved in remaking here was the Wizard of the Oz. Mark Walberg, the lead, is no Charlton Heston. He's too short and grim. Someone needed to tell him to lighten up. He spends the entire film behaving like "Dorothy." I know. I know. He wishes to go home despite meeting two potential love connections--one human, one ape. AND he starts a global civil war for good measure. Nice fellow. He mopes around the planet like some kind of self-centered jerk. Tim Roth's character is the worst kind of evil: boring. He jumps around the cheap sets as if he was suffering from a terminal case of ants-in-his-pants. I did, however, enjoy Danny Elfman's pulsating score. And Rick Baker's make-up for the apes deserved more recognition and some awards. Also, I felt the Christo-like red tents, that the ape army used on their march across the wasteland, were beautiful and abstract. There are occasional stabs at social commentary--but they fall flat. Rod Serling and Pierre Boulle must be turning over in their graves.

This movie has the same problem as all the other big-budget flicks these days - it was made from a recipe instead of a screenplay. Burton's trademark eye candy is still there, but there is absolutely no soul or authentic emotion anywhere. Marky Mark is clueless, and therefore Ari's crush on him is inexplicable. Tim Roth plays 'psycho' for the whole film. In fact, except for Bonham-Carter and Tagawa (Krull, the disgraced soldier gorilla), the acting is horrendous for a movie this expensive. And did we really need a wise-a** character like Limbo? The original film was great because it was played straight; this one feels like "Scary Movie 3", without the bathroom humor. What a disappointment!

Review title: A remake is a remake is a remake when the original is a standout.
Review_body: This one isn't just a remake, it's a spinoff, a miniature update with a celluloid umbilical chord still attached to the mother film released in 1968.  This Ape movie doesn't stand on its own but lopes along in the shadows of its predecessor.  It beats the original only in the amount of violence portrayed and at the box office (which probably results from curiousity about about how they could redo the thing).Not without some clever touches but, overall, it's a massive huh?

Tim Burton has managed to take a science fiction classic and "reimagine it" in a way that manages to be both faithful to the themes of the original film, while accommodating today's action-demanding audiences.Of course in many ways the film IS superior to the 1968 original. Rick Baker's makeup is a marvel, and more than makes up for his King Kong debacle of 25 years ago -- even though they still can't seem to create an ape mask that doesn't make the actors lisp. The action sequences are fast-paced and brutal, and the actors do such a marvelous job ... er ... apeing the moves of primates you're forgiven if you think Burton tossed a silverback or two into the melee just to liven things up.Mark Wahlberg is a disappointment as Leo, coming off as a one-dimensional jerk. The only times he shows any real humanity is when he interacts with a favorite (real) chimp, though he's certainly capable in the action sequences.Helena Botham Carter as the cute, human-loving Ari is the best thing in the movie, presenting a very well-rounded character when she isn't making lovey dovey eyes at Leo (best not to think about it too much). Estella Warren as a sexy slavegirl gets to show off the best lips in Hollywood, engage in an aborted catfight with Ari, wear very little, and go off in a huff of jealousy when Leo seems to want to spend more time with Ari. I get the strong feeling her best moments were left on the cutting room floor. It's always good to see David Warner and Kris Kristofferson, though their time on screen is brief.Tim Roth is fun and scary to watch as the villain, Gen. Thade, while Michael Clarke Duncan makes a menacing figure as Thade's right hand ape.Look fast for Linda Harrison -- the original slave girl in the original movie. Rick Baker himself also appears as an ape. And Burton's longtime love Lisa Marie makes her obligatory appearance, with a funny bit as a snotty, horny ape.The biggest laugh in the file comes from an otherwise dramatic cameo by original film star Charlton Heston. I won't spoil the reasons why it's funny -- only clue: it's not just in the dialogue.Nor will I spoil the ending. I was confused by it at first until I realized... it was CLASSIC Rod Serling. Once I realized Burton was paying homage to the Twilight Zone -- and let's not forget Serling co-wrote the original film -- everything fell into place.My only advice to Burton is to let sleeping apes lie and not attempt to reimagine the other films in the original Apes series. This is a good one-off, but best to move on to the next idea.

Review title: Definitely Something to Go Ape Over!
Review_body: Sorry, I couldn't resist the bad pun.  Ah... finally, this summer there is a true summer movie, featuring not only the big budget, cool special effects and the action, but also a seasonable plot and acting to rake in tons of teenagers' (as well as their parents') summer-job money.While I don't know/care to discuss the budget, it certainly went to good use.  The make-up effects are amazing (the make-up in the original was just as amazing when it was released, but look how far make-up artistry has come!); the big action scenes near the end featuring flank after flank of the ape army are truly a sight to behold.  Unlike in the original series, there are multiple species of ape on this planet, including chimpanzees, gorillas, and even a few orangutans.  All look amazingly realistic, physically way more intimidating than any "human" character could ever hope to be.  It must have been a nightmare for the actors under the makeup though.Besides, looking fantastic, the apes actually act like apes!  It's just so interesting and exciting to see an ape character such as General Thade yelling at someone in English, then jumping and climbing around, screeching in anger.  Next to that, it's really not possible for the human actors to contend at all... I mean they're not bad, but they are easily overshadowed by the apes, especially the soldiers, who not only look menacing, but through their harsh tones of voice and shrill screeches, are menacing.  It's too easy to forget that there were originally people underneath all those apes. Along with their appearance and manner, the apes' society is also interesting.  There is an ape religion, with the belief in a soul (and subsequent belief that the human "animals" don't have souls).  Other aspects of their society mentioned in the film include inter-special marriage (e.g. a chimp and an orangutan), a senatorial government, and humans, depending on age, sold as pets or slaves; there are even "human rights" activists.  While it may not offer as much social commentary as the original series, it's still enthralling enough, and it's great that the writers decided to offer details on the ape's religion, which is also a vital part of the plot near the end.  The only complaint I could offer about the society portrayed is that, like the original film series and unlike the book, the apes don't use vehicles.The unfortunate thing about summer films is that they usually end up sucking a few years later, as they are based solely on the special effects.  Tim Burton and crew have broken that mold with Planet of the Apes, which holds through all the way to the twist/ending (which is different from the original, and, though definitely an unexpected surprise, just a little bit of a let down).  See it for the special effects, and see it again for the intricacies of the ape society, religion and plot.

Review title: Not As Good As The Original, But Still Reasonably Entertaining
Review_body:
Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes" is not a remake of the original version of the film, but rather a "re-imagining" or different take of that original material.  Wise move.  The original "Apes" is a film that still holds its own as an all-time sci-fi classic; pretty much any attempt to remake it faithfully would wind up like Gus Van Sant's remake of Hitchcock's "Psycho". . . a pale imitation of greatness.  By "reimagining" the original film, Burton gives himself the opportunity to start with the established mythology of the "Apes" series, as well as the ability to travel in a new direction with that mythology.  The end result?  The new "Planet of the Apes" is nothing Earth-shattering (pardon the pun) -- in ten or twenty years, it won't be looked at with the same reverence or respect as the original "Apes" -- but it's still good, and brings enough new ideas to the table to make a reasonably entertaining film.The story, which ranges in spots from good to barely mediocre, possesses some serious gaps of logic and suffers from an awkward opening.  The first fifteen minutes of the film makes little sense, and lurches along aimlessly for awhile until it stumbles into the heart of its story.  (Examples of some nonsense: Couldn't chimp-piloted ships simply be controlled by computers? Would highly experimental exploration pods be able to launch from a space station just by one rogue pilot punching in a two-second launch sequence?) The opening of the film admittedly does make more sense by the end of the film, but it's still not very good.  It appears as though the writers thought of a solid middle and ending for their version of "Planet of the Apes" . . . but had no idea how to get the story past the opening credits to that middle and ending.  The weak beginning seems like their best attempt to get the story moving to those points.  As for the rest of the story, it contains a lot of good, even original elements, but some points are glossed over in a rather hurried fashion -- there's little effort made to explore some plot threads, and some of the explanations as to how and why things happen in the film are either weak or come completely out of left field. The story's excellent  . . . for a second draft.  I've read that Twentieth Century Fox rushed this new version of "Planet of the Apes" into production. Too bad.  The story and script could've been excellent -- and more important, solid throughout  -- with some more work.Despite the uneven story, though, director Tim Burton does a nice job, given the script he has to work with.  If nothing else, Burton has a knack for giving films an eccentric look, and his version of "Planet of the Apes" benefits greatly from his eccentric touch.  He evokes a lot of the weird imagery of the original films (the weird scarecrows, the desolate landscapes) without ever blatantly stealing from them.  He also does a great job when it comes to focusing on the smaller, quieter moments in the movie -- for example, there's a macabre scene where a child ape puts her pet human in its cage for the night that manages to be disturbing and funny at the same time.  Burton, though, doesn't appear to have a clear idea of the overall tone of the movie.  In "Planet of the Apes", he goes for a blend of action, comedy, and seriousness . . . but the blend doesn't always work. Some of the humor seems out of place, and the action often seems stilted, as if Burton didn't know what to do with the apes apart from having them leap around menacingly.  The film is one of Burton's better efforts, but much like the script, the direction contains a few distinct weak spots.
As for the actors . . . again, it's a mixed bag.  The apes comprise the stronger half of the cast, which makes sense, since the apes are the weirder of the two groups - and Tim Burton specializes in weird.  In regards to the human characters, Burton would've been better off making the humans in his version of "Planet of the Apes" more like the humans in the original film - mute.  Apart from the protagonist Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg), none of them add anything of import to the film anyway. The highlights of the individual actors come from mostly from the main characters.  Tim Roth nails the part of villainous General Thade perfectly - he's one of the best sci-fi screen villains to appear on screen in quite awhile. Wahlberg plays Captain Leo Davidson in a manner similar to Heston in the original film; he's a man who's not terribly interested in contemplating how he arrived at a planet ruled by intelligent apes . . . he just knows he wants to leave.  Fast. He's a pragmatic hero, one who reluctantly tries to help others in distress, but doesn't want to die in the process.  Also worth mentioning is Paul Giamatti, who provides some much-needed comic relief as the peculiar orangutan slaver Limbo.  On the other side of the acting coin, the biggest disappointment came from Helena Bonham Carter as Ari.  Given the poor quality of her character in the screenplay, she does what she can for her character, but all she really does for the whole film is to go around being nice to humans.  Period.  Some reasons as to WHY Ari feels so passionately about helping humans would've been nice.Tim Burton's `Planet of the Apes' is an action movie that manages to take some of the influences of the original `Apes' films, and then creates something eccentric and new.  Does it always work?  No, although in general, the good outweighs the bad.  Is it better than the original?  Absolutely not.  In a summer filled with blockbuster duds, though, there's something to be said for a film that provides some thrills and some fun, and the new `Planet of Apes' does exactly that.  Overall, it's an enjoyable film; it's just not a spectacular one.  Grade: B

This was an awesome movie and I don't care what anybody say, it wasn't a perfect movie but it was very entertaining and kept your attention the whole way and this was the movie that showed me how good of an Actor Mark Wahlberg is, he was great in this movie.

Where do I even start with this one? I saw the original Planet of the Apes a long time ago on TV but I do not remember much about it to be honest. I saw this DVD on sale in the local DVD store for 2.50 - so I bought it. First mistake. Let me start with the director / plot. Tim Burton is a hot and cold director for me - I loved Scissorhands but not Batman. He's a gifted individual for sure but not everyone's cup of tea. Certainly not mine. However, he must have been on some sort of sedative when he decided to do this movie. The script was poor to say the least - which could have been written by a team of monkeys - such are the glaring inconsistencies and holes in it. I read somewhere that Wahlberg agreed to do this within 5 minutes of meeting Burton. I'll give him the benefit of the doubt that he never read the script because if he had - then I don't think he'd be so ready to sign on. The sets on this film looked just like they are - i.e. sets. Never was I ever convinced I was on a space station or in a spaceship or in an Ape city. Everything looked like it was made of cardboard and plastic and inside a huge hangar. I was extremely disappointed with Burton here as he has gone out of his way in the past for visually fantastic creations - here it is just lazy. Some of the cuts in the "action" scenes were laughable. Wahlberg supposedly gets thrown a distance of 30 to 40 feet in one scene and lands on the ground with a thud. The cut to him landing looks like he just jumped two feet onto the sand. Poor editing and no excuse for a director this experienced. Now the cast. Wahlberg - I must admit that he is a likable guy in movies normally and gets by. He always seems like a guy out of his depth though and someone punching above his weight. His brother Donnie is the more talented actor of the two - but because of Marky Mark's physique and modelling background, he gets the better gigs. Here though, he carries about as much dramatic weight as a wet rag. He whispers his lines without any tension or pathos - so much so that we as an audience do not care what happens to him. As I was watching, his character made no connection with me at all. He goes out in a pod in space, he crashes, he gets captured - and all the while I don't really care. Some of this is obviously script-related, but Marky has to take some of the blame too. Personally, I don't think he was ready to lead a movie at this stage of his career. He doesn't have an ounce of charisma. Roth - A talented actor normally - reduced to looking like "Teen Wolf" here and snarling in almost every scene to an off-screen object whilst close to the camera. He chews the scenery but underneath all that make-up he must have been so embarrassed. I was embarrassed watching him for God's sake so I cannot imagine how he felt. Bonham-Carter - The best of a bad lot to be fair. But she looked scarily like Michael Jackson that it put me off each time I laid eyes on her. But I thought she did the best she could with what she had. Warren - her part was just pure eye candy. Her character had no relevance to anything. Kristofferson - barely spoke and killed off early. Lucky him. Giamatti - unrecognisable under the make-up. Comic relief part only that wasn't even very funny.What's left to criticise here? It is not the worst film in the world - but it is not far off it. The ending just beggars belief. You will find yourself shouting the word "What???" at the screen on at least 5 occasions in the last 10 minutes - at plot contrivances that are so absurd, you'd wonder did ANYONE read the script before shooting began.A dead-in-the-water movie that in all honesty I would recommend only to my sworn enemy.3/10 - and the 3 is just for Estella Warren's lips alone.

Where should I start? The hype for this movie came out months before its release and generated a lot of interest, including mine. Mind you I've never really seen the original movie, at least not all of it. But from the promos and interviews, this was Tim Burton's version of the movie, which was basically a bit more up-to-date, realistic, and cutting edge. But I couldn't help but wonder what or who would allow the ending they chose to be shown. Let me warn you that there may be spoilers in this review.The basic premise to this movie revolves around a scientist (Mark Wahlberg) getting stranded on a planet years into the future. The situation arises because of a strange anomaly they encounter in space and at the time, humans were using chimps as test pilots to send into unknown or high-risk situations. Their test pilot was sent in to examine the anomaly (which was to do nothing more than to do a fly-by) and suddenly vanished. Wahlberg's character, being the softhearted scientist, against wishes flew in to rescue the test pilot and himself disappears only to reappear hundreds of years into the future to crash land on a strange planet. He discovers very quickly that humans are not the dominant species on this planet but apes are and he is quickly rounded up to be a slave. His only driving goal from that moment on is to escape and somehow get back to his crewmates.
To be honest, the storyline isn't very strong, nor is it overly intelligent. The audience is given a very basic premise and is told to go along with it. However, if it weren't for the ending, I think a lot of people wouldn't have minded. There are little things throughout the movie that make you wonder how it's possible that something could happen. One of the major ones is that in the future on this strange planet, apes have evolved into intelligent speech cable creatures. But they allegedly came from the science station that Wahlberg's character came from as a result of them coming to search for him and crash landing on this planet. However, the science station was using chimps as their test pilots so where did all these apes come from?? As well, there are humans on this planet, which the movie at one point indicates that the entire crew of the science station was killed by the chimps when they turned on them. Where did all these humans come fromand the horses?? Yes there are horses! It seems for the sake of making this movie they made a lot of assumptions and conveniences but the audience is not that dumb. They will pick it out and they will remember when the sequel comes out. There's no doubt about the sequel. The ending was left in such a way that a sequel would be created. Was there anything I liked about this movie? Well they did remain accurate on ape movements and that element created a sense of fear and menace that the apes in the original movie didn't quite have. The make-up and special effects were pretty good but then Tim Burton has always been good at those areas. Overall I wasn't overly impressed. The movie was acceptable up until the ending and after what I saw for an ending, it kind of ruined everything prior to that. It sounds like I'm being harsh but if you don't believe me, go ahead and see this movie. Just don't write back to me complaining about it because I warned you. On a scale of 1  10, I give it a 5. I thought it could have been much better. Not enough time spent on developing a reasonable and logical plot line.

This film was bad because there was nothing interesting about it. It was sort of a remake but then again, not really. I was very disappointed considering the tools that Tim Burton has at his disposal. He had great make up and CGI available and lots of money ($100 million) but can you honestly say that what we got was as good as the original film that was made for less than $6 million? Heck no. So in that regard, the film fails.At least in the original film, the statue of liberty scene was shocking but there was nothing shocking in this film even the end scene because you could kind of see it coming. And, by the way, if you give it some thought, and I did, you can figure out how the ending could come about. I just wish I had back the time that I wasted thinking about it.This film would have been brilliant and fun if it stayed along the lines of the first film and adopted part of "Beneath the Planet of the Apes". Here's how I would have written it:An astronaut (it really should have been more than Marky Mark because he's not good enough to care a film all by himself so I would have put in three guys) that would land on what they would think would be another planet, encounter humans (not mutes), a city ruled by apes, were hunted, made friends with some good apes, discover that they're on earth via finding some destroyed ruins, end up running into crazy mutant humans living beneath the earth, a war breaks out between the mutant humans and the apes, and then....well, let your imagination run wild on how you want to end it.But my point is that there could have been so much more to this film. Sadly, Tim Burton really knows how to wreck a good thing. Consider what he did with the Batman series. He's a rotten director inspite what of people think. He's trendy so he must be good goes the thinking. Sorry, but no. If anyone else had done this film, it would have turned out far better and would have been far more satisfying.

Review title: Burton provides an entertaining yet flawed ape escape
Review_body: Tim Burton has a unique, dark style that sets him far apart from other filmmakers of his generation, and he has a knack for getting the best efforts from his crews and actors.His "reimagining" of "Planet of the Apes" is a rare instance in which those qualities never come to the fore. I won't bother with prattle comparing this to the 1968 original, simply because I haven't seen it and don't plan to anytime soon.He brings back nearly the entire crew he worked with on the superior "Sleepy Hollow"  costume designer Colleen Atwood, production designer Rick Heinrichs, editor Chris Lebenzon, and composer Danny Elfman, but this formidable unit fails to fully click this time around.Makeup guru Rick Baker (the "Nutty Professor" series) is responsible for the impressive simian facades, but most of the time they look instead like very expensive Halloween masks that muddle the actors' voices. The diction left much to be desired; some characters speak too low and fast (I sat in the fourth row and the theater had THX sound), and some baritone-voiced males sound as if they're talking with their mouths full.The acting is adequate but sometimes as stiff as the monkey mugs, starting with a wooden Mark Wahlberg as the centerpiece of the film, Leo Davidson. He is an Air Force captain, yet he works way up in space. The setup for his eventual crash landing onto the Planet of the Apes is flimsy and rushed. When that time comes, he doesn't look too concerned about being alone and stranded, and eventually imprisoned, in a strange new world, and he goes through the film as if this is all small potatoes to him.Thanks to bad dialogue, he inadvertently forges what may turn out to be the new pickup line of the 21st century: "I can show you something that will change your world forever."Needless to say, the simians are the best thespians, and that's not saying much. Tim Roth hams it up to the hilt as the villain Thade, but he can only do so much in a movie of this style. His chief henchman, played by Michael Clarke Duncan, verbally berates and knocks a few humans around here and there, and snarls lines such as, "Get your stinkin' hands off me, you filthy human!" and "Bow your heads!"  And, that's it.Helena Bonham Carter is solid as Brit-accented human sympathizer Ari. Coincidentally, out of all the Apes, she looks the most human as well (and is nearly a dead ringer for Michael Jackson). Paul Giamatti, on the other hand, is annoying as Limbo the orangutan, the film's thin attempt at comic relief.The weakest link, as if it isn't too obvious, is Leo's gang of human fugitives, especially an annoying teenage boy and the token Black man whom we all know will get knocked off at some point in the film. They have no personality and serve no purpose in the plot whatsoever except to chip in with a cheesy line here and there. Supermodel Estella Warren, playing a slave girl whose father (Kris Kristofferson) is killed by the Apes, is as pointless as a broken pencil. Her skimpy outfit contained more depth than her screen presence. Most of her activity consists of staring into space with her mouth agape.By the way, I didn't realize the Planet of the Apes contained any beauty salons, because she manages to look like she just stepped out of one whenever she appears on screen.Oh, and Burton brings aboard his squeeze Lisa Marie once again for no apparent reason. This time around, she's buried under an Ape mask. As usual, she has nothing to do here except display her one-dimensional feminine wiles.The cinematography, courtesy of Phillippe Rousselot, does a nice job of stressing the foreboding, moonlit jungle environment. It's the only saving grace of the lackluster action sequences, especially in the beginning just after Leo crash-lands and finds himself in the middle of a wild huntdown of humans by Ape soldiers. Elfman comes through on the music front; because of his powerful score, I loved the opening credits sequence.Unfortunately, while Heinrichs' sets are always a visual treat, they aren't as gripping as his Oscar-winning work from SH. They are small and constricted due to the fact that there are sometimes too many characters cavorting on the screen. Upon seeing the Apes' village for the first time, I couldn't help but think of the planet Endor from "Return of the Jedi." The wreckage of Leo's USAF space station, however, is fantastic. It's also the location of a surprising twist in the story.Now to the plot. The reason why it falters for the most part is what ultimately crippled "Shrek": it has an unpleasant air of preachiness to it. By itself, the plot is as thin as Wahlberg's music career, but in a twist that seems rather uncharacteristic of Burton, "Apes" plays the race card. This I didn't care for. I'm aware that this angle is in the original, but it's a white elephant in Burton's version.And yes, an Ape actually utters those infamous six words...I'm sure you know what they are.The suspense factor is all but nil, and the plot twists leave behind numerous holes, such as, for example, the controls on the destroyed space station being able to work despite the wreck apparently being thousands of years old. (Plus, where did all those horses, the Apes' sole means of transportation, come from?)Then there is the well-publicized "love triangle" between Wahlberg, Carter and Warren that Burton hinted at in interviews. To make a long story short, if you plan to watch this solely on the basis of seeing this angle, you're in for a disappointment.Sorry, but I won't waste my breath on Charlton Heston's forgettable pot-and-kettle cameo.Save for the aforementioned chase sequence after Leo's crash landing, the action and fight scenes are pathetic. Simple punches send both humans and Apes flying a few dozen feet into the air. And don't ask the Apes to hit targets in the water that are two feet from the shore. The huge Apes-humans showdown near the end is a yawner.The much-ballyhooed ending is both surprising and ambiguous. Though Burton has vehemently denied any rumors of his helming a sequel, the conclusion is like that of a comic book and does leave the door wide open for a second installment.The film's most comical moments occurred offscreen. Before shooting began, the actors had to undergo "ape training" to learn primate mannerisms, and spent hours in makeup before stepping in front of the cameras. On "failing" ape school, Bonham Carter quipped, "I was told I had AADD  Ape Attention Deficit Disorder." On becoming an Ape: "It's flattering to be cast as a chimp, because you know they haven't cast you for what you look like." Duncan hurt his ankle while filming a pivotal scene with Kristofferson, who slipped, fell, crashed into Duncan and wound up having to get stitches. Duncan was rushed to the hospital (yes, rushed for a turned ankle  that's Hollywood for ya), in full makeup, no less. When he announced himself to a room full of patients, they burst into applause.While "Planet of the Apes" has some major flaws, it doesn't mean it's not entertaining, which it indeed is, but it just doesn't have that signature Tim Burton look and feel to it. It's ultimately just another Hollywood action flick.After all is said and done, his best effort to date still remains "Sleepy Hollow."  7.5/10

Review title: Great effects but misses the point of the story
Review_body: This slick version fleshes out the brutal details of the original but lacks its memorable storyline, social commentary, vision and beautiful original soundtrack. The metaphoric value of the book/original film are lost by the fact that humans here can already speak - english as usual -so the only superiority the apes have is physical. In fact, since all the humans were killed on the space station, who were all those long-haired Harley Biker dudes (the "humans") descended from?  Without the constant philosophical criticism of man's evil nature(throw in guilt and original sin too, what the heck), it turns into Humans versus hairy Roman empire-Mafiosa-Nazi-etc.-type aliens (Tim Roth is a composite of many movie evil archetypes). It looks like they borrowed the plot twists and F/X from the new "Lost in Space" movie, but that movie didn't really have to compete with the original series. The ending is reminiscent of the book BUT doesn't make sense in terms of time travel in our universe, so if he went back in time in an alternate universe, all quantum universes being equal, then it's just a coincidence he returns to an ape-ruled earth (rather than an INEVITABILITY which was THE POINT in the book/original film). To put it another way, if Burton's movie came first, noone would be inspired to remake it 30 years. Great effects, costumes and menacing apes but very uninspiring.

This movie was magnificent. The scenery, the script, and of course- the makeup. this movie is one of Tim Burton's best pieces of work. But there has to be a sequel! The ending is so mysterious that you have to know what happens! This was a masterpiece but there just has  to be a sequel!

Review title: Burton slips slightly, but still very entertaining
Review_body: This new version (I can't quite call it a remake) of a sci fi classic doesn't seem determined to light up brain cells, question our place in nature, or examine our society and our attitude toward "lesser beasts". It's just a good, exciting science fiction adventure film, and on that level, it succeeds quite well with only a few small stumbles.Tim Burton remains the only director I can name who has never made a film I don't like.  You might call me biased, but I do go into every new Burton film afraid that this will be the one.  Fortunately, I'm still waiting.So why is this not a remake?  Well, there are no characters from the original story (either the novel OR the film), and the situation is significantly altered.  While still being the story of an astronaut who lands in a strange new ape-dominated world, very little else is the same. Only a few lines of dialogue intended to evoke the 1968 film remind us.What's good?  First, of course, is Rick Baker's absolutely astounding makeup.  The original appliances still stand up quite well, so this was a nightmare assignment for any makeup artist.  Baker is one of the very few who could handle it, and handle it he does.  There has never been such amazingly detailed, expressive work in the history of film; the actors are able to come right through the latex and hair.  Too much praise cannot be heaped upon his work.  Then there's the patented Tim Burton visual approach; this is easily his best-looking film since "Edward Scissorhands", and really helps to lend the proceedings an otherworldly appearance.  The acting from the performers in the roles of apes is uniformly excellent, particularly Tim Roth in one of the most frightening villain roles I've seen in years.  He truly gives the impression of being dangerously unpredictable; a genuinely great movie psycho.  Mention must also be made of Danny Elfman's score, his most dynamic and interesting in years.  It recalls Goldsmith's work just enough to remind us of what we're watching, while also moving into new territory.What doesn't work?  Well, the humans.  They talk, but have nothing of consequence to say.  Why is Estella Warren so much cleaner than everyone else, and where did she get that lipstick?  And if she's intended to be a love interest for Wahlberg, shouldn't they have a conversation or two?  And sadly, we're given only the barest peek at the ape society before our heroes escape and return to the wilderness.  I really would like to have seen more of their culture.Now, the ending has already become much-debated and argued over across the Internet and elsewhere.  First off, I like the ending.  While it may not have quite the punch of the original's, I think it's a good twist for those going in expecting a twist (and weren't we all?).  Without revealing too much, let's just say that the screenwriters have obviously read the novel.In conclusion, this is an entertaining and exciting sci-fi adventure.  It won't open up your mind much, and it may not be among Burton's best works, but it's a lot of fun, and has a great deal to admire.  7 out of 10.

No, I'm not reviewing "Tomb Raider," or even "Hobgoblins," but a film somewhere along that line: The remake of "Planet of the Apes."It might be unfair to judge something without seeing/reading/whatevering the original, and I haven't. But I nearly did once, and after watching a few minutes, I left. I couldn't do that with this one, because I came with my brother, his teacher, the teacher's son, and the son's friend, and couldn't go anywhere else. [sob] Just kidding there.I have got to start coming into movies with NO expectations. When I want an okay film, it sucks; when I think it'll be bad, it is; and whenever I think it'll be good, it's okay, and that isn't good enough. Here, I thought it would be bad. Tim Burton's remake (I'm not calling it a reimagining, it doesn't deserve such a title) was such a bad film, that whereas I thought in the theater, it was closer to the "okay" line, now I think it was closer to the evil of Tomb Raider. (Maybe it exceeded that.) Quite a turnabout!I'm an 11 year old (and am awfully smart for my age), and I had to do homework for a week-and if you knew me, you would know that I wouldn't consider it without a bribe-to see this. I barely got by, and after leaving, I said to myself, "I did a week of homework for THAT?!" It's that bad.The only redeeming part was the ending. And even that sucked. (Spoilers ahead, just as you would expect from me.) I mean, the first part was stupid-the apes caused the humans to mutate like that? (It was subtler, but that's the general point.) The final scenes where he gets back to Earth were cool-replacing the Abraham Lincoln statue with an ape-but it leaves a plot hole bigger than my lust for death after the film. If Earth's humans get turned into apes like that, how the f*** did Leo stay human? (I'll leave out the words next in my mind, because the IMDb would reject this thing.) Plus, how does the theater audience stay human? (Just kidding, but still...)This is the type of film that makes people consider suicide. Name a worse film that I haven't seen, and I'll consider seeing-and destroying-the film. No? FiguresRating: -2537396746584475673/6 (Lately, that thing hasn't been working.)

Review title: A planet that makes no sense
Review_body: (Spoilers)Illogic that people should have noticed:1. It seems like the heroin was wearing lipstick!2. Why didn't the apes die from that explosion?3. If anyone had written this, they might as well have been on the planet... they were the apes playing basketball near the opening. (Those are kids... get it?)4. Speaking of which, how do apes know basketball?5. Since when do all warriors play for the side they seem to be on? That kid should have just killed the apes!!!!6. Since when does a person disobey his boss on a ship? Marky Mark disobeys the person he was told by to NOT go after his monkey... and he does! As pointed out by Blake French: "Is he stupid, suicidal, or both?"All I have to say is:I want my money back

Review title: Planet of Apes + Star Wars + Back to the Future = Silly
Review_body: Very disappointing. Most of the criticisms are correct (no plot, bad acting etc.) but I also thought that the special effects were so-so. *Very* derivative and I can only assume that everyone was in it for the money. So save your own money and avoid. 3/10 (5 for Tim Roth and -2 for the rest).

Review title: Burton is no good as a gun-for-hire director
Review_body: If there's one thing that annoys me most in seeing a bad film, it's seeing it done by experienced film-makers who ought to know better. This "re-imagining" of Planet of the Apes could have used some imagination, to say nothing of essential elements of character development. Nova, the girl in the original Planet of the Apes, was a better developed character than Daena in this version, for all that she does not say a single word. One certainly expected a lot better from Tim Burton, a man who has hitherto combined an incredible visual imagination with intelligence, wit and humour, all of which were notably absent from this production.There were problems in basic plot development. The first big mistake was allowing the humans to talk. This was the fundamental difference between apes and men that made *all* the difference in the original film. Even while he was mute, his ability to communicate was what marked out Heston's Taylor as being different from the other humans. In the current film, Mark Wahlberg encourages the (talking) human slaves to revolt, but there is no overpowering reason for them to have not revolted and reclaimed their emancipation already. They are dexterous tool-users and have the ability to communicate in order to form plans, something mute humans can't do. It needs no man to fall from the stars to save them. Indeed, since he comes from a technological civilisation and finds himself in a pre-technology era without (at first) any gadgets to help him, it is Wahlberg who ought to be at a disadvantage, not the humans who are used to living there.It was sad to see Helena Bonham Carter working so hard to generate some kind of spark between herself and that unresponsive brick wall Mark Wahlberg. Her best scenes were with the villainous Tim Roth.The humans were practically ignored until they were needed in the third act, at which point Daena started showing some actual interest in Davidson (Wahlberg), and a young boy suddenly changed from part of the background to a feisty gung-ho freedom-fighter. This was poor character development. (Estella Warren, in particular, looked as if she would have been capable of a great deal more than she was given in the script). Wahlberg's puzzlement at the end as to what these humans see in him was certainly shared by me, as he has scarcely interacted with the humans throughout.Creating the apes: half a plus point and two minuses: Ape make-up was excellent on the males, particularly Michael Clarke Duncan who has incredibly expressive eyes (which was why he was so good in The Green Mile), and the makeup design allowed him to use them fully. But the ape females looked like nothing on earth, neither ape nor human. The minuses were the ape jumps which looked about as realistic as Flash Gordon's rocket: jumping apes looked as if they'd just been fired from a catapult, they had none of the long-limbed grace of genuine apes. Secondly, the poor sound mixing - when the gorillas roar it is quite clearly dubbed from some animal, probably feline, making them sound ridiculous and unrealistic.In the original film, the various "human" things the apes do and say are handled as light relief ("I never knew an ape I didn't like." "Human see, human do!"). Here, the apes just talk matter-of-factly exactly as 21st Century humans do, and there is no humour in it at all. The only genuinely original idea was Ari writing with her feet.Nothing made me cringe more than the "V-Ger from Star Trek" moment near the end of the film. First of all, the apes had apparently been able to read Roman lettering in the distant past, for them to know the name of the Forbidden Zone in its partly concealed form. Secondly, the mysterious inscription giving the name is merely covered with sand which Wahlberg just brushes away, something any ape could have done centuries ago. This moment was, for me, far worse than the much-maligned ending of the movie.Things of that nature, however, are typical of most science fiction movies of today. Back in the '60s and '70s, they generally didn't have the budget to make convincing futuristic sets, but they dealt with genuinely original themes and ideas which were truly science fictional. I'm thinking of 2001: A Space Odyssey, the 1967 Planet of the Apes, THX1138, Soylent Green, Silent Running and the 1972 Solaris. The first Planet of the Apes even utilised the only scientifically valid and physically possible method of travelling forward in time. However, this film includes just about every bad science fiction cliché going: space storms, anomalies and worm holes straight out of Star Trek; the planets of the solar system and their moons apparently all visible together as large globes (in reality from any one planet, all other bodies, even their own moons, are just points of light); a conventional rocket powered shuttle travelling from Saturn to Earth in a matter of minutes instead of years; two-thousand year old equipment firing up and fully working the minute the hero presses the button. To say nothing of a conveniently bulletproof internal glass door. In a contemporary setting, you'd have to explain *why* it was bullet proof, but because it's "science fiction" you don't have to!Overall, Burton's most disappointing film.

This movie was by far another wonderful movie from one of my favorite directors, Tim Burton.  I loved all his other movies  ("Sleepy Hollow", "Edward Scissorhands," "Beetlejuice," "Batman," etc.)  but it had everything I wanted from a Tim Burton movie- special effects, great cast, wonderful score (composed by the great Danny Elfman),  and a surprise ending.  It's just like the 1968 original "Planet of the Apes," but, the new one's different.  I recommend this movie to anybody who's looking for a good movie this summer or who's a Tim Burton fan.
A+ ****** stars (out of ******) 10/10

The new Planet of the Apes flick is sheer entertainment from the very beginning, right down to the insanely amusing finish. Tim Burton directed it, but it doesn't seem like a Tim Burton film. He seemed to want to pay more of an homage to the original than change it with the distinguished macabre feel of his other films. The story is great. It has been modified a bit, but nothing has really changed. Everyone in the film is superb especially Paul Giamatti as the wise-cracking comic relief. Though some of the plot twists and situations don't really make much practical sense, they are all interesting and brilliant. A+!!
            9/10

Review title: Awful... almost as bad (and the same) as Battlefield Earth
Review_body: What a terrible, terrible movie! I had a high expectation for it too. It's a shame. I'll give the make-up artists (e.g., Rick Baker) credit. Bravo. And Danny Elfman's opening score was interesting. But otherwise, this movie was utter crap. (small spoilers follow) First we get this DS9-like space station shot with the wonderful title card that informs us that it's the year 2029!!! Hello! I knew right then that this was going to suck. Science fiction needs to be smart. Then he finds himself on the Ape Planet and the next 90% of the movie is just simple "escape and chase". Yawn... But to try and make it interesting they throw in some cliché and ever-not-so-subtle comments on racism and religion. The script was lousy, let's face it. Then the end of the movie improves slightly (this doesn't say much) until we get the "surprise" ending. Whatever. Tim Burton has the imagery skills but except from Edward Scissorhands and Pee-Wee's Big Adventure, I'd say he's a failure as far as making good stories. The similarities between Planet of the Apes and Battlefield Earth are remarkable. And considering how lousy that movie was, why would anybody allow this script to pass? Certainly a better movie could have been made from the same idea. Oh well, it already has.

I thought that the film was good.  I did not really have any preconceived notions other than the "Burton" touch.  His films are usually dark but beautiful spectacles in my opinion.Sometimes I wonder why people take movie plots so seriously.In the original, a lot of political statements were made (not unusual for Sci Fi films of that area).  It was safe in that genre to make political statements that would be blasted in other genres.The original Planet of the Apes series adequately addressed the issues of the time.  What would be the purpose of reiterating it in 2001?I actually liked the plot.  It was an interesting take or twist of the original.  There was some tongue and cheek dialogue as well.  The ending was the kind the either you liked or thought was really corny.  I liked the ending though, even if it did catch me off guard.I really liked the movie and would buy the video when it becomes available. I am really happy though, I saw it on the big screen.The choice of actors was excellent, I think Tim Roth stole the show, he was so convincing and seemed to enjoy every minute.  I was impressed with the good job that all the actors did.  It did not look easy.I wonder what Tim Burton will do next.  He is truly an artist.

Review title: DO NOT GIVE AWAY THE ENDING!
Review_body: DO NOT GIVE AWAY THE ENDING! Tim Burton...what can you say about this guy. He just keeps coming up with spectacular, off-kilter films that no-one else could. Batman, Edward Scissorhands, The Nightmare Before Christmas, and now this stunning re-vision of a sci-fi classic. To be honest, today's youngsters aren't likely to watch a film from the 60's anyway, so it was quite acceptable, and logical, to update it. And what an update! This and Jurassic Park III and going a long way to making up for the lame-ness we've had so far this summer. DO NOT GIVE AWAY THE ENDING!

Review title: Not as shabby as I thought it was going to be!
Review_body: I say if you were even thinking of going to a film that just plain visual and somewhat entertaining....see this in the theater!  I won't tell you that parts of it weren't just corny or over-Hollywood-ish, but it is rather fun and if you don't go into it expecting too much, you may leave thinking that it really wasn't too bad!  Like I did....... I thought that the special F/X were great, the costumes were pretty well designed, and the scenery was very enticing to the eye and mind.  Granted, the dialog was mostly silly at best, but again, for an entertaining film with interesting effects and a nice twist on the Ape saga, Go see this movie.  It may be good on DVD with surround sound speakers on a big TV, but if you don't have that, go see this while still at the theaters.  I think that the graphics and visuals will be lost on small screen.  I gave it 7 out of 10 - just for shear entertainment of the flick, not anything more than that.....  Burton's mind is very creative, too and deserves a lot of credit for this film.

Review title: Roth sells out! Puts on Ape Suit!
Review_body: This movie is a muddle, lots of things make no sense, not the least of which is this; why are all the big mean apes afraid of little Tim Roth, jumping about like a gnat? And why is Estelle Warren wearing lipstick? And just how many millions did it take to get good actors to dress up like apes? I won't even address the ludicrous ending, or the waste of Tim Burtons great talent doing drek like this. Please, Mr. Burton, go back to your original films, stop with the Hollywood crap! We your fans miss you!

I count myself very fortunate I did not see this on the big screen. I had watched snippets before and was very unimpressed. I'm one of the many that loved the original. So when Burton attempted yet another remake (and I still can't get into Alice in Wonderland as my family can), I treaded very carefully. This movie came on TV, non letterbox, not that it would matter for the piece of junk it is. Bland story, uninteresting characters....oh what a waste of time. I got about 50% of the way through, then realized I had much better things to do and wasn't going to waste my time. So I did jump to the last 10-15 minutes to catch the infamous ending. The worst Burton film of all time. He doesn't have anything close to the wretchedness of this film. Thank goodness! He's one of my all time favorites. Can't believe the total current rating is 5.5.

Well that's what has to do with the movie "Planet of the Apes."And as we are aware when making a pact with "the devil", it must bear the consequences.This "Remake" is a bunch of bland action movie any. The dwarf "Tim Roth" is really funny to want to do too much. Moreover it should stop doing action films of science fiction (as Al Pacino). This kind of movie is not really for people of small sizes. It is like seeing actresses frail and without muscles (Jennifer Garner, Jennifer Lopez, etc.). Making action movies. We do not believe it for a second. It is true that men only look at the beauty and forget the rest most of the time.Mark Wahlberg is bad as always. Looks like a guy who is always angry and frustrated. Like his brother also. Films with special effects only always the same script.A century or ideas without a single idea: make money! A century where everything is uniform and lifeless. A century of Globalization.

Review title: A Remake That Assumes You Don't Know It's a Remake
Review_body: I'm one of the few people out there that made the mistake of seeing Tim Burton's Planet of the Apes a good while before seeing the original. What kept on making me look away from the 1968 original more or less was the fact that it's over twice as old as me, which I guess you could attribute to me as being ignorant. And after hearing so much complaining about this remake with me and my best friend not seeing why (who also had never seen the original), we decided to just rent both this and the original and see what the fuss was all about.I think after seeing the ending alone you know how I feel.If I'm not mistaken, this film was handed down to several directors before Tim Burton was finally "credited" as the main director (and towards the end of the film's production unless I've misread something). Either way this film really doesn't feel like a Burton film to me, if it did I'd be calling this film "gritty" or "dark"; at least, for a few of the scenes. But other than some great visual style and excellent make-up on the apes it's tough for me to mention Tim Burton along with this film, it just doesn't feel like something he actually directed; not the whole way at least.It's funny that this film is supposed to be a "remake" when the only things it has in-common with the original are the name and the fact that the apes are superior to the humans. This is another odd thing that another reviewer pointed out; the apes don't seem to have that much over the humans other than brute strength most of the time. Whereas in the original the apes were both tougher and far more intelligent than the humans.Outside of this the film has little to nothing in-common with the original. The plot, characters, location(s) and even the ending are all different from the original. The only similarity you might be able draw is that one of the apes (a female that sees the humans as more than the other apes give them credit for) decides to help a few of them escape the ape city and go to the lands of their origins. Beyond this, and maybe a select few throwbacks to the original (the scarecrows part was pretty clever) you might be wondering if this is really a remake or just a very different re-imagining.As I mentioned earlier, this version has some great art/visual style and excellent make-up on the apes, which are even better than those of the original (even though in this day and age it's really a given for that to be the case if enough effort is put in). Really this is the film's biggest strength because outside of all the excellence visually there isn't much of a film to be had. The performances from almost everyone is average at best. Mark Wahlberg really isn't given too much to work with and you'll get plenty of his typical "shocked" stares. Tim Roth as General Thade actually does pretty well with his character and is arguably the most effective character. Needless to say, Helena Bonham Carter was intentionally given a bit more of a human look than the other apes, possibly to reflect her character's views on the humans in the film. Michael Clarke Duncan does well with what he's given and while he likely won't stand out for many he is a very convincing character given his size and voice (hopefully that doesn't sound too odd). Everyone else just feels like they're tagging along so there really isn't much to praise in the characters or actors other than that two of the main ape characters were handled very well. Oh, and I thought the cameo with Charles Heston was neat.Aside from this, a fun battle towards the end with the rebel humans and apes and an ending that'll likely leave those that haven't seen it puzzled as to what exactly happened, there really isn't too much to the film. My biggest problem with the ending is that we likely will never get an answer or resolution to it because of how negative the reception has been towards the film. I hate it when movie studios and the crew make a movie and leave room for a sequel but they never fully take into account possibility that the film will flop or just not do well. And in this film's case we're stuck with a film that had and in a sense still does have potential but are left asking "when" and "what".This film is very, very different from the '68 classic it's based on and as a result, it assumes you haven't seen the remake; or at least hopes you didn't. Since I saw this one before the original, my views on this remake were defensive and while I think it's far from as bad as some might make it out (and even as I myself might have made it out as well), it's very tough to fully appreciate it after seeing the original. So if you haven't seen this film yet (or even the original for that matter), I would personally see this one first so you can make a verdict on the film itself, then see the original and then make up your mind. As for those that have seen the original but not this, just go into it with an open mind and don't expect the same movie. And if anyone has seen both and wants to at least try and like this movie, try and watch it without having the original in mind. Keep the original in mind, and this film stinks. See this as its own film, and you should be able to find some redeeming values.

I remember the original quite well, it having made a great impact on me as a 10 year-old boy.  I remember awaiting each sequel as it arrived in theaters in the 70s.  Tim Burton's film comes as totally different take on POTA, and this time with mind-blowing makeup and outrageous action sequences.Movie-goers who cannot appreciate the joys of "Planet of the Apes" have become too mired down in investigating plot-points and errors in logic -- all of which could be explained away by any talented sci-fi writer.  Tim Burton (surely one of today's greatest film makers) isn't concerned with exposition and plot contrivances -- only in entertaining his audience like a great showman would.  And that he does in a big way with this epic-scale adventure, which hardly resembles the original 1968 movie in character or theme, so pre-conceptions best be left at the door.Burton's "Planet of the Apes" supplies more black comedy than the first, often jumping over-the-top in its ability to constantly amaze and amuse the viewer.  The scene of a "mixed" ape dinner party has to have the most outrageous and amazing makeup effects ever created.  Tim Roth as bad-to-the-bone chimpanzee General Thade is terrifying, evil and ugly and probably gives the best performance among excellent company.  Mark Wahlberg makes for a perfect leading man, understated in manners and voice as a contrast to the bizarre and outlandish apes.  And Paul Giamatti as Limbo (a stand-in for old orange Dr Zais?) gives one of the best comic performances ever seen.This is "popcorn" style cinema, and it really bends over backwards to amaze and amuse the viewer.  Credit must be given to Burton and his art department for the campy sets, costumes and obviously the convincing makeup jobs which trumped any similar ones ever on film.  Rick Baker (the great makeup up artist) has taken his art to a higher plane in this monumental effort, and really should be acknowledged for giving audiences such thrilling creatures to view.  They're like no others ever seen on the screen, and to watch the expressive faces of these apes is a remarkable experience in viewing. The faces appear so life-like that you begin to believe you're watching actual apes.Kids should love this outing, with the violence all being decidedly PG and usually occurring off-screen.  Parents can also sit back and enjoy the trip to this wild planet since its loaded with symbolism and cultural references all cleverly packaged in Hollywood's best style.

Why desecrate the original with this trash? No, really! I don't really care if this is "closer to the book", it matters not. This movie was trash. This was below the quality of ANY of the original sequels, or even the horrid series. It was awful, tedious, ugly, and disgusting.Who ever told Mark Wahlberg that he is an actor?This is just a continuation of a Hollywood trend, and I can't wait until it's over. Create trashy versions of classic movies, then market the hell out of them so people buy. My local rental place has a whole rack full of this movie, and only two or three copies of good movies.Don't actually rent this movie, wait until it's on broadcast TV then watch it just to laugh at how bad it is.

Charleton Heston wore one, James Franciscus wore one but Mark Wahlberg opts not to don the traditional loin cloth. I hope no one casts him as Tarzan. Linda Harrison wore a bikini in the first 2 Planet movies but Estrella Warren barely shows cleavage - her hair is always in the way. Tim Burton could have sexed up this simian saga & given the adults in the audience something to look at. Even the chaste Helena Bonham Carter never gets out of her costume which looks like a large curtain. She's cute but all the the love stuff is restricted to anxious looks & a little bitty kiss at the end. As in Artificial Intelligence which discusses inter species sex between robots & humans but never delivers - Planet of the Apes hints at inter species romance between the humans & the apes but only hints. Lisa Marie is the only ape that dares to be sexy. This movie has three great actors Tim Roth, Ms. Carter & Paul Giamatti chewing up the scenery as a trio of apes & they are fun to watch. Superlative  make up (a certain Oscar) costumes, sets, music make this the hit summer movie of 2001.

Let me say first that I am a huge fan of the original Planet of the Apes. When I first heard that Tim Burton was directing the "remake", I was a little concerned. I have been waiting to see this film for quite some time. I finally saw it earlier today and I was not disappointed! 
***MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS!!!!!!!***
I really enjoyed almost everything about the film. First, the story was good including the surprise twist ending. The performances from Roth to Wahlberg to Carter to Duncan were all top notch. The special effects were about what I expected with a couple of minor flaws. The settings of the villages were realistic and convincing as well. My one complaint would be that the film was a little dark. I am not referring to the mood either, I mean the actual shots were too dark at certain times but it did not take away from the film overall. Really good movie that I would recommend to any sci-fi fan!

I had read mixed reviews on this movie and having not seen the orignal I didnt know what to expect, so I cannot compare it to the first one. I was very impressed at the makeup on the characters in this movie. The apes looked so real its obvious alot of time and money was put into the makeup alone. I liked Helena Bonham's character-she was the one friendly likeable ape that didnt hate humans like her counterparts did. Interesting contrast in the movie on how on this planet apes control the humans and on earth its vise versa. Ending was kind of cool and made you think a little. Good movie overall. 7/10.

Review title: An original plot makes all the difference
Review_body:
I was pleasantly surprised with this one.  I was expecting a re-done plot with new affects, but Tim Burton takes the extra step to make an all new movie.  I enjoyed the first Planet of the Apes and I was very happy to see this one had a completely original plot.  This gave the movie a new flavor. 
The story, for the most part, was well presented and it made sense as well. However, there were a few areas which it was a little weak and where there were errors Wahlberg's character of a military officer with a science background, would not have made.  Wahlberg was good and helped the film along.  Tim Roth was also good and gave the film a sinister side.  Michael Clarke Duncan gave an explosive performance which in my opinion gave brought a lot if character to the film really helps make the film.Overall, good and worth your while (8 out of 10).

Review title: The Problem Starts With Tim Burton
Review_body: A forest planet for apes DOES make more sense than a sandy desert world, tho this is one of the few tweaks to the original that qualifies as any sort of improvement.Putting the "origin" story in the hands of goth cartoonatic Tim Burton is almost as misplaced an idea as it was to have Rod "Twilight Zone" Serling script the original version (very few of Serling's ideas, words, and social commentary actually made it onto the screen, despite him usually being cited as "screenwriter").Perhaps this franchise should instead be restarted with a do-over, as in the second Hulk movie that attempted to cleanse the public's palate of Eric Bana(l) – how cool would it be to see Remake of the Apes by Terry Gilliam and the crew behind Hellboy and Pan's Labyrinth? Ooooh, or now that Sam Raimi is off Spidey Four.

Review title: Rather than making a bad pun, I'll just tell you it stunk.
Review_body: I hope whoever green-lighted this "Planet of the Apes" remake kept the receipt when he sold his soul to Satan.  It might be tax-deductible.  I can't possibly imagine why the heck they chose to (1) remake a film that still holds up just fine after three decades, or (2) completely remove all the likeable characters and cool plot twists from it.  The only way anyone could possibly like this movie is if they'd never seen the original.  Also, this movie had the stupidest ending I've ever seen.  But hey, at least the Apes looked better...which I believe was the entire reason they decided to remake this movie in the first place.  If you're thinking about shelling out the money to see this movie, save your money and buy the original on video.

SCI-FI reboot of the PLANET OF THE APES series with an all star cast,a space station uses monkeys to pilot pods and an anomaly causes them to lose a pod,LEO the animal trainer sees it different as he feels they lost a monkey,against his superiors wishes LEO goes after his animal and steals a pod,the same anomaly takes LEO on an uncontrollable journey until he crash lands the pod,set for survival LEO sets of to find his ship with a tracking device.a surreal situation occurs when LEO gets caught up in a chase but cant believe his eyes when he sees the pursuers,a reverse roll scenario has humans being the hunted and APES being the hunters as they capture the humans in a PRIMITIVE fashion.LEO is among the captives and he soon discovers the civilization of the APES and how they keep humans for slaves as an inferior race.coming to terms with the backwards society LEO forms an alliance with the humans and a rebellious APE and he must find his ship and get back to reality...star studded SCI-FI action with an ever improving WAHLBERG in the lead,I enjoyed looking up the actors who played these roles and there is some pleasant surprises apart from the obvious....recommended
