I had high hopes for this recent installment of what might have been Burton's genius manifesting itself again on screen.My proposed delight in seeing something harkening back to days of Sleepy Hollow and Batman, was dashed mercilessly on the rocks of apedom by this very "Mars Attacks" type movie.  The plot does not meander in the least bit for there is nowhere for it to go.  It drives on endlessly whilst my company and I waited anxiously for death or the credits, whichever came first.The acting is quite weak, the characters have no development at all and the only performance worth mention is that of Helena Bonham-Carter.  She plays the role of Ari with gusto, albeit there is no explanation of why she does anything she believes in doing.  The role of Attar had so much promise being played by Michael Clarke Duncan, but there is little to enjoy in his character's action or motives.Everyone loves the villain Tim Roth plays as Thade, but even I could not stomach the growling and snarling of a pointless villain for 2 hours.  His angst-filled dialogue and actions do nothing to advance the story or draw in the audience.There are numerous plot holes that would be passively filled in if the movie made any attempt at epicurian status, but it falls short of even the humor or action of a M.A.S.H re-run.  I would have rather watched a full day marathon of old C.H.i.P.S than see this movie again.  My limited edition lunch box and movie poster will be auctioned off to lowest common denominator to be sureI may not have said much about the movie itself, but there is little to comment apon.  Average effects, weak plot, poor writing, aimless ending. The first 45 minutes is like a walk through the life of apes, which are exactly like human in their mannerisms at the table, in company, and with the help, as we are.  Burton didn't need to bludgeon us to death with the similarity.Spoilers:Don't worry about spoilers because nothing I could say will make you enjoy the ending or plot line, with my robust affirmation or denial.  I can say there was one moment I enjoyed.  I truly enjoyed Charlton Heston's role as Thades father.  It was epic Heston.  He even got to say his most famous of lines, but in reproach of the humans he once fought for 35 years ago.

OK, so loose-canon Mark Wahlberg decides to violate regulations and orders to rescue his monkey friend who was sent into a strange nebulaic disruption (a la Star Trek: Next Generation), and winds up hurled through space and time to a "strange new world" where apes rule.And there begins my sadness.I'm sorry for seeming smarmy, but I would have expected so much better from Tim Burton.  Although direction wasn't the main problem with this film, the writing was 2-dimensional and atrocious to character development.  It relied heavily on apes screaming and tossing humans 20 feet in the air at the drop of a hat (not that I blame them; I would've done the same to Mark based on his wooden performance).  The battle scene was solved with such an element of corniness, the teeny boppers behind me with eyes glued to Mr. Wahlberg actually came to their senses and laughed.  This movie deserved better craftsmanship of plot vehicles.The only really redeeming thing about this film was a "pretty good considering" performance by Helena Bonham Carter, monkey makeup and all. She found a wry character and an interesting crush on Mark Wahlberg's character, handling everything that she came across with a fair amount of grace.All in all, the movie is worth checking out- once.  And on video.  It ranks higher than "Starship Troopers", but is certainly not the best thing that Tim Burton has laid claim to.

Firstly, I think the original Ape movies are among the finest films ever produced.  The entire series is brilliant and I frequently watch them.  I'm not a big Sci-Fi fan, but those movies are just about the best representation of a mix-and-match between social satire and pure "what if" filmmaking that makes viewers question themselves.But anyways, the new Apes movie is no different.  The only thing that I really have issues with is the fact that some of the characters didn't really serve much purpose.  I don't know if they had all their lines cut out or what, but they don't really do a whole lot for the film.  Even Mark Wahlberg doesn't have a hell of a lot of dialogue.  But the film starts off much different than the first, and continues along that idea.  Most of the same themes are revisited, but skewed a bit.  The cinematography and makeup are both amazing.  This movie lived up to my expectations.  Go see this movie and judge for yourself.  I heard people coming out of the movie and saying that it sucked.  But, they probably have no basis for comparison if they haven't seen the originals.  I would give this movie 9/10.  Nearly perfect.

Review title: What Else Left Besides Makeup and Effect?
Review_body: The biggest problem in the Planet of the Apes is that there are no deep feelings within the characters. Leo (Mark Wahlberg) does not care for any of human on the planet of the apes but himself. His goal was just get himself out of the planet as soon as possible. The director knows too well that he is not a hero, that's why he decided to add a scene of heroic rescue of a young boy in the movie. But it doesn't help to make him a better character but too obvious of an effort. Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) was a confusing idealistic character that she believes ape and human should be equally live together. But the movie fails to show her feeling when she watches human killing her own kind. Instead of an internal struggle inside her, she just blindly help human beat up her own people. And the third main character, Daena (Estella Warren) she was just a pretty figure follows Leo everywhere until the end. It's not her fault that she couldn't act, it's the movie doesn't give her any chance to act. It was a failure when Leo farewells to Ari and Daena in the end, there's nothing there to drive the audiences to any feeling. It's as if we watch some stranger say goodbyeThey could have brought up much more than this. They could use the scene when Ari heard about how human treat Apes on Earth (lock in the zoo) as an ironic moral in the movie. But they didn't go further Everyone agree that the makeup in this movie is awesome. There's no doubt about that. But beside the makeup, Tim Burton directed nothing shine in this remake of sci-fi classic.Everyone agree that the makeup in this movie is awesome, but beside the makeups, there's nothing shine in this remake of sci-fi classic.HinxLinx

Review title: Another example of why Burton and Roth are so good
Review_body: "Planet Of The Apes" clearly has the "Tim Burton" seal on it, but unfortunately shows both imaginative and argumental development voids, which I blame not to bad directing, but to an irregular script, revised and changed thousands of times, due in part to the late entrance of Mr. Burton in the project. However, here I'm going to focus on the most positive points, rather than the negative ones.The Seal I talked before is present as in any of Burton's films. I mainly refer to the conception of the eccentric, delirious, out-of-this-world characters and to the Gothic-romantic, fantastic art direction this films radiates (I don't have to mention previous examples, but Batman, Nightmare and Edward are and will remain in our minds). Danny Elfman gives again the best of himself with a dynamic, at times majestic score where percussion leads.The apes are incredible, they work, they really rock in the show. Not only for Rick Baker's make-up masterpiece (which deserves not the nomination but the Academy Award NOW!), which gives them live and expression unlike 1968's sort of dummies, but because they are credible... and light years far more credible (and even more human) than the film's humans, except for Mr. Whalberg. The script said they had to talk this time.Can anybody tell me if they liked them? If they found their importance to their dialogues? And why Stella Warren hasn't been issued with the "manikin" label, as Jake Lloyd was in "Episode 1"? The native roles show no interest and slow the rhythm of the movie.Now, returning to the apes, I have to talk about the real showman:Tim Roth as Thade. Exceptional. Histrionic. Aggressive. Cool. Evil portrayed as an ape. As the Ape General, he gets so very deep into the role that you end up thinking Roth, after all his extense and peculiar filmography, has finally turned crazy and really believes he's a monkey free in the stage. He is of the very few actors, along with Gary Oldman, Edward Norton and De Niro, which I consider as chameleons:ready to face any kind of role, however obscure, violent or psychologically strong they are.About the rest, I'm definitely getting in love with Helena Bonham Carter (another example of the ape's astonishing expressivity),and Mark Whalberg is fine as always. I liked his role, in comparison with Heston's in 1968, because he is a pure survivor who wants to go home with his friends and family (he just doesn't fit in that planet), while Charlton arrived there by accident and became a revolutionary hero. .To finish with, about the ending: perfect. I love it. And I love it because 1) It is different, it's of the few which make the viewer's imagination work, so anyone can figure out an explanation to the ending the way they want, 2) Its philosophy, the paradox it represents, which I'm not going to tell, and 3)It is extremely "Burtonesque"."Planet Of The Apes" reflects again the style of an excellent director, but shows his vulnerability in works he doesn't personally project (remember the initial idea came from James Cameron), in which a studio, and not himself, determines most of the finished work. However, an entertaining film, recommended to any sci-fi lover. And an advice: read the original book by Pierre Boulle for another view of the story... Vote --- 8/10

Tim Burton has shown many things in his life as a filmmaker: a knack for gloomy atmosphere; a real sense of empathy for the lonely and different ones; a wicked sense of humor; he's even shown that he can play by the rules of the studios, delivering not only once but twice, even making a sequel and pulling it off.Sadly, none of that shows in "Planet...". The problem does not lie in the fact that they tamper with the story from the first film. As they've made clear, the producers and director are not trying to remake a classic, but use it (and the book it originated from) as a stepping stone to build the new movie, so their deviations from the original would not be a problem... if they were good.Burton doesn't have a good starting point: the script is very, very bad, your usual Hollywood-esque pastiche of old lines with (supposedly) new parallelisms and not-very-bright pop culture references. All that would be interesting if something happened, along the story, to the characters. Sadly, it is not so: the astronaut, the good apes and the pretty girl remain the same (that is, totally uninteresting) throughout the movie. Even the bad apes are not really changed, as the ending goes. And let's not even start with the inconsistencies...This is by far Burton worse movie ever, light years away from his classics. His trademarks barely show: we don't care about what happens with the characters at all, the sets lack the grandeur that we've learn to love and expect ("Sleepy Hollow" and "Batman" come to mind) and his "wicked sense of humor" is limited to changing classic lines from being spoken by humans to simian mouths.The acting is really bland, too. Mark Wahlberg has proven that he can act. But he wanders through "Planet..." with his best "Keanu-I-don't-know-what-the-heck-is-going-on-Reeves" look on. And Stella Warren... well, she IS pretty. Helena Bonham-Carter is as boring as usual and Tim Roth has lots of fun but is well below some of his best movies.The summing up of all of this is in one word: disappointment. Not from what it is (even at this point the movie can be seen if one has enough popcorn and soda) but from what it could had been with the talent implied. And yes, the make-up is awesome and Heston's cameo is really cool, but somehow they are not sufficient to save a picture from being just another fancy way of wasting your time and your money.

Review title: So Much Promise Turned To Waste
Review_body: You know what happens: human crash lands on planet ruled by apes that can talk and think humans are beneath them, human has to fight to survive, twist ending. Blah, Blah, Blah.This new "Planet Of The Apes" is probably the most-hyped and most-anticipated summer release for 2001. You've got extremely dark and stylish director Tim Burton paired back up with scoring buddy Danny Elfman. Cool ape costumes and Marky Mark out in front. How could any of this go wrong you ask? Well, it does.Now, don't get me wrong, I did like this movie. That was until the last ten minutes of the film. The ending is so ridiculous that it cause the rest of the movie to make NO SENSE at all. The ending is terrible and I cannot express enough how much sense it does not make! I'm not going to give anything away, but you aren't missing anything life-changing. The movie was good, except for this contrived and senseless plot twist that is completely tacked-on.Besides the fact that the movie ends up not making any sense after it was on the right track, the musical score, I hear, had to be completely redone mere days before release. So, the new score has no resemblance of Danny Elfman at all. It's your generic action movie score. Thanks, studio executives! That's why you guys collect the money to back the film and you leave the movie-making to the movie makers! What an original concept.I don't need to go into the story or the plot, you know it. The only thing you don't know about is the new ending, which causes the whole movie to be worthless. Oh, and did I mention that there is no resemblance of Tim Burton's style anywhere? Then I'll say it here: nada on the Burton style.I was really, really excited about seeing this movie. I really was. But then the ending made no sense, which I cannot repeat enough, and it all went to hell.

Review title: Tim Roth as the Feral Chihuahua
Review_body: I REALLY wanted to like this movie.  I'd hoped Tim Burton would bring the same clarity of vision he brought to Sleepy Hollow, Ed Wood and even the first Batman.  Instead, he gave us the second Batman: some great visuals, a few strong archetypes and a terrible script.  Tim Roth as the feral chihuahua was ridiculously over-the-top and not in a good way.  Perhaps Rick Baker should've stopped punching Estella Warren in the mouth long enough to find her motivation.  Or at least a personality.  This was a straight-ahead, cliched escape movie, with no pause for character development.  The ending wasn't as bad as many suggest and is definitely feasible if you consider that Thade's ultimate fate is left up in the air.  It'll take some explaining but it's possible.  All in all, I'm hoping Burton will take a pass on the sequel and let someone with stronger STORYTELLING skills take over.  NOTE TO JOEL SCHUMACHER: THIS DOES NOT MEAN YOU!

Review title: Not a pure Burton movie but a really good entertainment !
Review_body: I remember having seen original 'planet of the apes' when I was young. The apes at this moment didn't impressed me at all, and now I can't even remember them. In Tim Burton's you are really looking at apes. They are, I was going to say 'human', they're true. And this is a very good point for Burton, having done an impressive movie. Burton's universe is there, but not too much, I mean it's not Sleepy Hollow! Even Danny Elfman has made an effort on not doing his kind of music :) You spend a really good time, it's funny and smart, and well, Mark Wahlberg is nice!

I went to see this film with great expectation. I loved the original series of films, and I expecting this to be just as good if not better, and it was! It's hard to say if it was better, I'd say, they are almost on different grounds, due to the Special FX we had in the 60's and the stuff we got now. So that changes a lot, but it's not just the FX, the story is great, it keeps you guessing, and near the end, you just..don't know what to expect, I didn't and I read about the ending on the net anyway. This was defiantly a "Re-Imagining" not a "Re-make" This is so different than the first. In fact, I don't even know what the heck the ending was about, was it earth, was it another planet...I swear, you think about the ending to this movie for more than 5 minutes, your head will explode. But all I can say is, this movie rocks, great acting, awesome story, sweet plot, I'm just stoked for the sequel!

Review title: What in the world? (May contain some spoilers)
Review_body: Ok, I don't get the ending AT ALL.  What does it mean and how could that happen.  I knew there was going to be a surprise ending, but that was shocking.  Is it even possible for them to have a Planet of the Apes 2? What would he have to do, go back and fix it or something!  I thought the movie was good in some parts and i enjoyed watching it.  I just thought that it was weird!  But its a great movie if you are thinking about going to see it.

Review title: If your airconditioner is broke & you need get out - maybe
Review_body: They put a lot of time and effort into getting the apes right. But they forgot to put the same effort into the story.Good:the apes Helena Bonham Carter Charlten Heston as an ape.Bad:Mark Wahlberg - why does Carter and the humans follow him? He is a jerk.Carter says this human is different - How? The eyebrows on the female chimps - I'm sorry they annoyed me. Every "surprise" I could see coming a mile away.

I approached with caution...having been a fan of the original films.  I rented the film on DVD, sat back and waiting to be disappointed.  I wasn't. Tim Burton takes the original idea and makes something new (and better?) out of it.  Fans of the original film shouldn't consider this a remake, more a homage.  Burton adds his own twists, which work well, and the ending is more than adequate (especially when you're trying to top the shock ending of the first film).  I can't believe I enjoyed it, but I did and would recommend anyone who was put off should give it a chance...

Tim Burton's remake of the 1968 film PLANET OF THE APES was OK. It wasn't anything special. The make ups were excellent and the acting was decent. But the story line was rather weak. Tim Roth steals the film as General Thade. However, the original is a lot better.

Review title: A stinker in a summer of stinkers
Review_body: This movie merely goes through the motions. The story just moves along with little emotional connection or suspense. The "climax" creates some interest but is over far too quickly.Sure the apes are impressive but much of the effect is obscured by the darkness that shrouds 80% of the movie.Oh and then there's the ending which is the biggest sham I've yet to see in movies. It leaves you feeling like you were just scammed out of your money, taking place in a marketing gimmick. I am refering to the blatant set up for a sequel.Hollywood seems content just to fill cinema's on hype without trying to give any satisfication to those foolish enough to waste there money (or think this one will be any different from the last 10)Wait for DVD.Mike

Review title: The first is really good, the last part sucks
Review_body: The first part of the movie is really good, and keeps up with the original, it even is a little better - but the last ½ hour (give or take..) really sucks. I was so disapointed at not only the ending, but also the story that leads to the ending. So if you ignore the ending, it's a 8 or 9 movie - but since the last ½ hour is there - I give i a 3...

First off, Tim Burton is one of my all time favorite directors.  Batman, Beetlejuice, Nightmare Before Christmas, all excellent movies.  All of that aside though, this is one damned good movie.  The special effects and make-up look fantastic.  Each ape actually looks different from each other one, and they all move like you would expect an ape/human hybrid to move. The acting is great, especially Tim Roth.  His character Thade is one of my favorite parts of this entire movie.  I have to say I think that the only real weak link is Mark Wahlberg.  I usually like Marky Mark too, but this time his performance seems to fall a little flat.  I know alot of people probably aren't going to like this one.  Some people will mistake certain aspects as being corny, but that can be said about just about every piece of Science Fiction in existence.  The end is good, maybe not as good as the beginning of the original, but good nonetheless.  Overall I enjoyed this film a great deal and recommend it to all.

Tim Burton, known for his visual style, delivers yet again with Planet Of The Apes (POTA), but the film is lacking in virtually every other aspect, from the thinly drawn characters, the barely-there script, to the shockingly bad/incomphensible ending. I'll start first with the character development. There is none. Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg)is so one dimensional that at no point did i care if he ever got off the planet and back to, well, whatever and whomever. His entire time is spent throwing out cliched lines instead of being awed, inspired, terrified, or confused of his surroundings. Any emotion would have worked. As for the humans who live on the planet, I'm not sure what their problem was, they werent savages, they outnumbered the apes supposedly, they could communicate at the same level as the apes (unlike the original movie), so why exactly were they living in the hills scared for their lives. Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) and General Thade (Tim Roth) are by far the most interesting, and well acted, characters.  Miss Carter brings a sensual aspect to her character that is very appealing (yes, i know shes playing a simian, but it doesnt seem to matter). While Mr Roth plays Thade deliciously evil and cunning, and his ape-like movements are a sight to see.I was especially disappointed with the relationship between Leo, Ari and Daena (played by model Estella Warren, who is way to beautiful here to pull off a role as a jungle woman). There are obvious hints of attraction between Ari and Leo, yet these scenes go absolutely nowhere in developing the awkwardness of it all. The script doesnt go beyond yearning glances, which is a shame. The last half hour of the movie was basically the standard action plot. The movie builds up to an inevitable war between the humans and the apes, with Leo devising this absurd plan to stun the first ranks (out of thousands of CGI created apes) with the remnants of his old ships ignited fuel tanks. Never mind the fact this would only eliminate maybe 5 percent of the total forces they are up against. The final conflict is never exciting, but then how could it be when we have no emotional investment in the characters.I will not discuss the "surprise" ending, except to say not only is it not surprising, it doesnt make sense, and i defy anyone to explain it.In fact, i read an interview with the higher-ups involved in this fiasco, and they revealed that the ending isnt supposed to make sense, its supposed to leave the viewer confused and guessing. Well, thats just what i want after watching this for two hours, and ending that insults the viewers intelligence by admitting "we didnt even care enough ourselves to give you a plausible ending." Thank you Hollywood. And thank you Tim Burton, for reminding us once more that classics should be left alone and time honored. If you're going to remake a movie, remake a bad movie. In fact, remake this remake.

The new installment to the "Planet of the Apes" saga is a skillfully made film.  It combines a new adaptation to the familiar story of the original. However, it is by no means a remake.  The new movie has some very striking similarities, but is a new and different film.  This "Planet of the Apes" uses enough of the now famous content, that made the original great, to sell it to the older fans, as well as a new story to win over a younger generation which would not properly understand the social gripping message of the 60's version.  This film is clearly Tim Burton's best work.  The cast does a very good job, especially considering all of the makeup.  Charlton Heston steals the show as Gen. Thade's father, proving once again that no one does a "Planet of the Apes" film like Mr. Heston. Despite the overall excellent nature of this film, it is flawed in one major aspect.  This film has no star quality.  No offense to Mark Wahlberg, but he is not capable of carrying a summer blockbuster by himself.  Mr. Wahlberg is a fine up and coming actor, but he has not yet reached the point in his career (and maybe never will) where he can open a film by himself, let alone a major film such as "Planet of the Apes".  Wahlberg tries his best to play the reluctant hero, but the key word is "tries".  He lacks the major presence that Charlton Heston provided in the original.  Wahlberg is unable to sell himself as an "action star".  His lines are not believable, and are quite commonplace.  In order for such a film to have been properly done it would have required a big time action star.  That star could only have been Arnold Schwarzenegger, whose name was mentioned for the Wahlberg role. His presence in the film would have made a big summer hit into a mega summer blockbuster.  Just imagine Arnold delievering the lines "I'll be back..you dirty apes!" If the casting directors have any sense they will make sure that Arnold is back when they make the sequel. Despite all of this it was still a very entertaining film. 3.5 out of 4 stars.

Yet another Hollywood attempt at cashing in on a proven franchise, Tim Burton's supposed "re-imagining" of the 1968 sci-fi classic Planet of the Apes is a dreadfully dull, meandering affair, which consistently fails to engage the viewer on any meaningful level. Sure, it tries to live up to the lofty social-political commentary of the original, but here there's nothing to back it up-- the plot is shallow, the dialogue lame and the characters are so underdeveloped we can hardly recall their names.
For example, near the end of the film, a human boy stands up to his ape oppressors in what I assume was meant to be a moving moment. But it has little impact because the character has never been properly introduced; the scene is the first in which he figures prominently. Similarly, two Ape generals square off at one point in what is clearly intended as a battle between two giants. But the set-up for their feud is so scant (the bland line of dialogue inserted earlier in the film) that the pay-off is virtually non-existent. They fight, one wins...whoopee.Characters like these appear throughout the film. The lead female human seems to exist solely for her cleavage; Kris Kirstofferson appears as a human male who does almost nothing and who, like his counterparts mentioned above, engages in a Big Moment that fails to have any impact. It's hard to feel bad for human slaves who are this dull. As for the apes, they're so one-dimensional they're better described as types than as actual characters. Most notably, there's the evil general (played with wonderful vitriol by Tim Roth), who seems to simply hate all humans, period. His behavior is entirely one-note: he stomps about, growls and acts viciously at every opportunity, and almost always without sufficient motivation. As a villain he's about as interesting as Skeletor was in the old He-Man cartoon. Likewise, Helena Bonham Carter's character, an ape with a soft spot for humans, is little more than a caricature of good will.Finally, the lead character, played by Mark Wahlberg, walks through the film in an apparent daze. Never does he seem amazed by this monkey planet he's landed on, nor does he appear distraught by the predicament in which he's found himself. Charlton Heston's lead character in the original POTA film may have been over-the-top in places, but he at least struck the right notes of paranoia, amazement and outrage. By comparison, Wahlberg seems drugged; and this is a problem because we're supposed to be seeing this world, at least in part, through his eyes. Recall the introductory portions of the original POTA, in which the team of wayward astronauts slowly makes their way into Ape territory. Their journey becomes stranger and stranger as they encounter human skins, a tribe of primitive humanoids, and finally the fully-clothed warrior apes. Never does this new film approach this level of horror and amazement. Instead, its protagonist runs through its world like a blip in a video game. And that's a shame.On the good side, Rick Baker's makeup is, on the whole, extraordinary; Danny Elfman's score is rich and bombastic; and the physicality of the ape characters' performances are fun in that they are much more simian in nature than those featured in the 1968 original. But even fans of Tim Burton will have a hard time finding his personal stamp on this film.
And what of the surprise ending? It's there, and it's fun. But it feels tacked on and most viewers will probably figure it out a minute or so before it actually happens.If you really want to enjoy this movie, go buy the action figures. That's the point, right?

Review title: Edward Scissorhands trip to Planet of the Apes
Review_body:
I have been so often disappointed in the past going into movies with high expectations: Indianna Jones and the Last Crusade, Phantom Menance, Batman, to name a few.  So I suppose my learned skepticism somewhat saved Planet of the Apes for me.  I had absolutely no expectations for this film, after having enjoyed the first one so much.  And of course, the new version does not live up to the original.  The original was filled with layers of political, racial, and sociological themes; and it had an incredible ending.  And who can match the tortured, almost humorous essence of Heston.  Oh, and it was fun too. 
But the greatness of the original does not make the new version a bad movie. In fact, it was in my opinion quite an enjoyable movie.  It surpasses the original in terms of its visual effects. While the theme/story is more simplistic, it is very well told; it moves very fast and fluidly, yet is not so packed with chaotic action (see Armageddon) that it does not allow for slower moments that can be saviored.  For example, there is a great scene with Heston in a cameo.  I wonder if he knew what he was saying when he said it: humans are deceptive and dangerous and are even more so because they have guns; beware of them?  Not exactly the NRA's mantra.  Anyways, he had a great cameo.  There are many other humorous moments as well.  Basically, the movie did not take itself seriously.  It tipped its hat to the original without trying to mimick its feel.  It is obvious Burton wanted to have some fun with this movie, paying tribute to the original while at the same time trying to give this movie its own unique perspective.  I believe he succeeded and I believe that that is the movie's saving grace.

Three good things about this movie: the poster, the score and Tim Roth's Thade. Everything else had me embarrassed for all involved.  My number one pet peeve in a movie is when a character does something that makes no sense, but gets the writer out of a jam.  This movie is filled with that kind of action.The mixed metaphors of animal rights and civil rights, where humans fill each role as the script demands, are full of cliches, ultimately making this B-O-R-I-N-G. And while I like much of Tim Burton's sense of humor, the over-the-top jokieness here was the saddest, right down to a female ape complaining of a 'bad hair day'--Yuk yuk yuk.Icing on the cake was the 'twist' ending, which would have been cool HAD IT HAD ANYTHING TO DO WITH THE STORY BEFORE IT. Yeesh. Bad.

Review title: What a waste of time and money. Give this one a miss.
Review_body: ***This review contains spoilers.***  You have been warned.I gave this film a 2 out of 10 which means it wasn't *entirely* bad: some of the make-up was reasonable and the music didn't make me ill.  That's it for the film's redeeming features.As for the awful bits, where do I start?  Let's see:(1) An ultra-politically correct message hangs round this film like a 52,000 ton battleship.  We're supposed to bring away the message 'Let's all live together in a nice, warm, and fuzzy multicultural society in which each individual has his own special little contribution to make, etc, etc'.  If I wanted to hear such a message, I would read the PC rubbish the UK government puts out.  If the apes and humans have to all 'sing from the same hymn sheet', who will determine what the music and words of that hymn are?  Who dictates what is in and what is out in this 'multicultural blending'? Living in so-called harmony is *NOT* some 'intuitive, natural' thing -- someone is going to lead, lots of someones are going to follow and that is just the way things are -- and any film that ignores this is just pushing another insipid 'feel-good' fairy story.(2) I object to the insults to men.  Both the woman scientist who is in charge of the genetically-modified apes on the ship and Ari (Helena Bonham Carter), the woman-ape 'human rights' activist, make comments about men either being insensitive or making women miserable.  It's a sure bet that no such comments would have been allowed if they were to have been made about women.  When is Hollywood going to give up its love affair with feminism? When is it going to see that films that contain such insulting material drive men and women -- and I am a woman -- away?(3) The plot, such as it was is a mish-mash.  This film could have gone the straight-forward science fiction route, or gone down the path of satire, but instead, it is neither one nor the other.  All that happens is that the pilot, Captain Davidson (Mark Wahlberg), goes from one pointless bit of so-called action to another.  The plot is also riddled with illogic. Certainly I don't expect films to be completely logical or even mostly so, but I do expect them to have at least a passing acquaintance with logic. How in the blue blazes did horses get on the planet?  If the apes are so non-technological, how did they get the armour they wear and how do they manage to build houses and other things?  How did the apes even manage to dominate the planet if they are terrified of water?(4) The ending is idiotic.  Yes, I know there are x number of possible explanations for Davidson going back in time to Earth to find an 'Ape' Lincoln statue and a world populated by apes, but so what?  Certainly I don't want a film to tell me everything -- I want to read between the lines -- but I want some lines, just a few, between which to read.  It is clear this 'surprise' ending was just tacked on for the shock effect.    It didn't even shock me, though, it just bored me.(5) The acting was boring, boring, boring.  Does anyone ever bother to portray a character these days, instead of a few traits labelled 'hero' and 'villain'?  The human characters, including Davidson, haven't even the depth and presence of onion skin paper.  The apes are just plain silly, and that includes General Thade (Tim Roth).  So what if the make-up makes the men look like apes of some sort?  It takes acting to make a man into an ape, and acting was clearly beyond anyone in this film.(6) The atmosphere was as bland as low-quality white bread (the type sold so that the masses can always afford something that at least looks bread-like). Part of this is down to the sets, which were surprisingly uninteresting and even minimalist for such a big budget film.  Funny thing is that in the low-budget European films of the sixties and early seventies, the sets, although clearly crude, managed to convey a wonderful sense of time and place.  It is clear that today's sets are just bad money thrown after a lack of imagination.(7) The 'action' sequences were boring.  What I wouldn't give to see a film with the flair for violence that the Spaghetti Westerns had.  If there's a fight, I want to see some blood, some guts, some death and pain.  The fight sequence at the end looked as if the humans and apes were just slugging it out in a Saturday night pub fight, and a nice, mannerly fight at that. Grown chimpanzees are said to be strong enough to rip a human's arm out of its socket.  That would have made a good scene.  And why in the world did Davidson wait until after the apes started recovering from the effects of the explosion to tell the humans to go out kill them?  The whole point of stunning your enemy is so that you can slit his throat while he is helpless. Doesn't anyone know anything about fighting dirty these days?This list isn't comprehensive: I almost certainly have left out other reprehensible bits.  I can't be bothered, however, to make a complete list. Let's face it, this film is a waste of time and money.

The story behind Planet Of The Apes is such a great one that it is almost impossible to mess it up. This new version of the film thankfully does not do that. I liked the original and I like this one as well. It adds a lot of special effects to an already great story to create something that I would want to experience again.

Worst movie I've seen in a decade... sweet jesus, how did this happen.  It says this has to be four lines long, but that's a problem cause I think saying it was a total suckfest with no redeeming qualities sums it up pretty good.  Well, look, I just got four lines.

Does this movie MOVE! Don't blink or you might miss - the plot? You didn't miss it, it really was that short.Here's a tip off for a bad script: If you see more than one name in the writing credit, WATCH OUT!There are alot of reviews of this blockbuster, so I will just ask a few questions which you could answer as you watch the film:Was Michael Clarke Duncan was the only ape that sort of looked like himself? (A nice touch that George Lucas did in the Phantom Meanace).Did you catch the meaning of CALIMA? CAution LIve ANimals, easy to miss!If the apes wanted no one to go to CALIMA, why was the it so poorly protected?If it was the center of their universe for thousands of years and so easy to reach, why were there no apes AT ALL there? Wouldn't they come to "worship" at least?How come Davidson all of a sudden cares about this kid? Just exactly what was the point of having him stay behind the ship? Who was the kid? What the heck was going on there?Did you care at all when Kris Kristofferson got killed? Nope!
Did you care a little when a couple of guys in Davidson's original band got iced? Only a little.What was the point (from the writer's point of few) of taking out the (cool) gun? He brought back later, anyway. With two guns, that might have been fun. One guy shooting up himself was just stupid, didn't you think?Just exactly where did all the aps and all the humans come from? I mean, seriously, would the humans live so close to the apes if they were rounding them up as pets and slaves? Give me a break! I'd have found a better neighborhood.  (On top of that, there's a little problem of genetic diversity here of there were no natural apes and humans on this planet in the first place. But, we'll give Tim poetic license on that).So, the GOD arrives, literally out of the sky in a space ship. NO ONE is scared of this technology AT ALL. They recognize this is a prophecy come true yet they have NO PROBLEM letting the UNCLEAN Davidson walk right up to their DEITY.  Then, they proceed to beat the daylights out of the diety nearly kill him.  (I guess that answers why no one was worshiping). Question: Is there a story here or not? No!Would a good alternate title be "Crouching Humans, Hidden Monkeys?"Who exactly would have the Lincoln-esq Thade have liberated to get the statue? I think it might have been humans, don't you? So, maybe Davidson didn't do as bad as is implied. (But, now, it looks as if he should have stuffed the girl into the capsule with him, eh?)How did this movie get made? Here's a senario:(Office of Richard Zanuck, producer)
ZANUCK: What did you think of that script I told you to read?FLUNKY: Great movie, sir.ZANUCK: Who does the make up on "Star Trek?" Do we have anyone who can do that stuff?FLUNKY: Yes, sir!ZANUCK: Don't just stand there? Where's my bagel?(Two days later, Tim Burton's office)ZANUCK: Well, Tim, what do you think of the script I sent over. My brother-in-laws newphew's Dentist calls it "The Visitor."BURTON: I wouldn't have my name associated with this recycled waste. It's a remake of Planet of the Apes!ZANUCK: I knew that.BURTON: Well, then, get lost. I don't do remakes!ZANUCK: (non plussed) We're offering 25 million.BURTON: Well, my Rolls is looking rusty. OK! I'll do it!

Review title: remake or re-creation... weak either way
Review_body: Crash landing... capture... escape... battle... the end.  Intricate plot isn't it?  Burton decides to sidestep any meaningful themes in this film, and that's a shame.  There are a dozen social issues that could have been examined in the movie, but apparently Burton was in a hurry to get to the Braveheart-style Ape vs. Human battle.  As for the acting: Wahlberg was a jerk, Roth was too dramatic, Michael Clarke Duncan was bland, and Estella Warren hardly said a word.  The only worthwhile performance was from Helena Bonham Carter.  As for the ending, it's sad that Burton felt he had to match (or top) the original by throwing in that outrageous ending.  He fell short by a longshot.  I suppose the movie was entertaining if you didn't compare it to the original... but can you really watch it without comparing?

Review title: Not as good as the first one...
Review_body: All though this was an excellent movie with awesome special effects and costume design, it still can't compete with the original Planet of the Apes. It was not at all what I expected. I expected a total remake of the movie (same exact story, same characters, etc.). However, this movie has a more easy-to-understand story.

Review title: Terrible. Special Effects don't make a good movie.
Review_body: I left the theatre wondering what sort of opinion the makers of this film must have of the audience.  Do they think we're stupid?  Do they think we will accept anything they put on the screen just because it has special effects?  What was the point of making this film?Despite being very courageous to even attempt re-making such a popular and well known movie, the perpetrators of this waste of time and effort seem to have forgotten some of the cardinal rules of movie making.  It's great to have special effects and lots of make-up artists working for you but a decent screenplay and some talented actors might have helped, too.  The actors in this debacle were one dimensional, at best, with the most believable character being that of Pericles.  There was little if any development of the characters and there was no  hint of the messages found in the original.The worst part of all of this is that the altered ending of the movie opens up the opportunity for a sequel.  If it gets made, that's one movie I won't be spending time or money seeing.In summary, this is a thoroughly forgettable movie that deserves no more than the score I gave it: 1/10

For those not familiar with that expression, it dates from a 'Punch' cartoon of 1895, where a nervous curate is breakfasting with his bishop.Bishop: I'm afraid you've got a bad egg, Mr Jones.Curate: Oh, no, my Lord, I assure you that parts of it are excellent!So, parts of Tim Burton's 'Planet of the Apes' are excellent. The lifelike and varied ape makeup, combined with the effort that has gone into making the apes... well, apes, and more individual than the oppressed humans can manage to be, makes their society utterly believable. Helena Bonham Carter delicately brings out the character of Ari, shewing us that a full face prosthesis need not handicap a great actress, and Tim Roth camps it up completely as Thade (which you may not think is a good point).On to the bad parts. Mark Wahlberg does nothing to arouse my sympathy, or indeed interest. It doesn't help that his character is halfway between James T Kirk and Dorothy from the Wizard of Oz, and does not develop at all throughout the film. The plot is stupid, ridiculous and yet utterly predictable, and forces characters to act unrealistically. The eventual resolution is contrived and unsatisfying, it gives no extra depth to anything, in fact, it seems to be the only way the writers could think of to finish off the plot. The ending is tacked-on and inconsistent.I would recommend avoiding this film unless you really have nothing better to do, and no expectations of intelligence. But stylistically it's worth something, and Helena Bonham Carter's performance is worth adding a couple of marks, so reluctantly, i give it 4 out of 10.

i've never watched the original POTA, and never read anything about this movie except the outline (man stranded on a planet inhabited by apes). so you can say i started off fresh, without any forethoughts or good/bad expectations.. and after watching it, i'm quite disappointed.
the movie was very low on character developments, i can hardly remember any names save Leo, the main hero, and some 2-3 more. one thing that bugs me a lot is the female apes. the way they're portrayed is simply.. disturbing.. i dunno maybe it's just me. and the human blonde babe! she's obviously being paid for simply walking around in that jungle outfit and looking worried (and pretty at the same time). she's hot, though. and mark wahlberg is just plain bad here. i like him in some other movies like three kings, but here he just dont have that hero feel.the script needed a lot of work, with lots of plot holes (why did/didn't he do this?/ why does this happen when that doesn't?). but while everyone bitches about the ending, i kinda like it, as it finally grabbed my attention, there, right at the end of the flick.disappointing movie, really.

Review title: Not nearly as good as the original
Review_body: This is not a bad "remake" but I still get a feeling that the original is, even though it is set back more than 20 years still highly superior in every way, only special effects are better but that can hardly be called an accomplishment considering the technical possibilities compared to the 60's. The first Apes movie spawned 4 sequels that got worse with every film, If this one is followed by one or more sequels I really hope these sequels can beat the sequels to the original ones. Go out to the video store and rent them both, you will know what I mean, the original is super(ior), the "remake" is not bad.

Review title: The reason why I don't like Tim Burton anymore
Review_body: Before seeing this film, I was a fan of Tim Burton's famous work such as Beetle juice, Batman, Edward Scissor hands, and Mars Attacks! When I learned that this move was directed by him (I didn't see the film until 3 years after it came out), I was dying to see it. I had watched the 1968 original and was familiar with the original novel. After seeing it, in all honesty it was the biggest waste of garbage I had ever seen. Oh sure the make up and special effects were good, they always are, that's why they spend so much time working on that stuff rather than writing a good plot or developing characters. The dialogue was cheap and the acting was more wood than a redwood tree! Mark Wahlburg's acting was so out of place for this film, throughout the entire film, he really shows no emotion and when he does it's only for a split second. I wasn't expecting something like that of Charleston Heston's epic role in the original (heck his role in this film was only minor yet beats the crap out of the rest of the cast), but I'd at least expect some effort to be put in it. All the characters really just filled out the stereotypical roles seen in the real world today from the war mongering general, the peaceful animal loving hippie, the rebellious doubtful sergeant, the ignorant leaders, the royal waitress, and the bumbling idiots the humans. The plot was as straight forward as a derailed train. Everything was just hoping around and far fetched even for a movie like this. It is basically this, guy lands on planet, gets caged, frees a bunch of prisoners, goes through a chase in the desert, rounds up prisoners, rebels, uses rocket buried in the sand for centuries to blast away charging army. Than monkey comes from the sky and everyone is best friends with each other. h yeah, Apes can not swim, because... well that's never explained. And the end was the worst attempt at a twist I have ever seen. And it's bad when the director in the commentary couldn't even make heads or tails out of it. I was relieved when the end credits came. That was the last Tim Burton film I have seen and since seeing this utter failure I avoid all his films, even the ones I liked before. If you don't want to take my word for it, fine, but don't blame me for wasting your time with this sad excuse for a movie.

What a crappy movie. One of the worst remakes I've ever seen. Wahlberg sucked. The ending sucked. The costumes sucked. The special effects sucked. Everything about it was half-assed. I doubt this review will be published, but it is worth writing 10 lines just to express how much I think this crappy movie sucked. IMO, Wahlberg is a crappy actor and must've slept with producers to get into the movies. I've always thought Helena Bonham Carter was somewhat overrated, but her performance in this movie verified it for me. So, all I can really say about this movie is that I would've expected more from Tim Burton judging by his past work.

I would like to respectfully disagree with jackzen from Wales. To be fair though, I will preface this by saying that I never saw the original TV shows, and if there was a book, I never read it.But, that said, I would say that this movie stands as a fine piece of work in it's own right. It was, I believe, very well acted and filmed, and I believe that the plot was basically good. I did however dislike the ending, but don't feel that it was a fault of poor plot, just personal taste.I won't say more, because I don't want to spoil this for anyone that has not seen it. I believe that it is a movie you will enjoy watching.

Tim Burton remake of Planet Of The Apes is underrated. No deep message like most of the franchise but the comic relief gives some breath. The acting, Human eyes underneath it all makes it more real for me. Ending people cry about was a nice twist.

Ok, we saw the film on opening night. It was showing on 3 screens at a multiplex and every showing was sold out. We waited to see this at the 10:20 showing-so maybe I expected too much or was tired. Having said that... The movie was so-so at best. The makeup was phenomenal as were the special effects. The apes were BRUTAL. Exceedingly so. This is one PG-13 movie that our girls will not go see for a long while. We carefully screen "older" movies and deem some appropriate-this is not one of those. The original was so fantastic-perhaps it was too good to ever improve upon. This version did stick closer to the original book story, however. Lastly, the ending was horrible. I have no interest in re-watching this movie, once was more than enough. Happy Viewing!

I have to agree that the makeup and visual effects and even the look of the movie are vintage Tim Burton. Compared to the original film the ape effects are great, and actually make you feel that you are seeing human sized apes, and not some guy in a monkey suit. A+However all looks and no plot make for a bad film. The film starts of promisingly enough, but one we get to the planet of the apes it is as if the scriptwriters figured just shooting scenes of flying apes and a ragtag group of humans trying to escape (Hmmm sounds like something from the Wizard of Oz) would be enough. F-One feels sorry for the cast for having to muddle their way through this script, but then cast is not up to the task of even handling this script. Only Tim Roth as the evil General Thade turns in a great menacing performance, and winds up out acting the rest of the cast. D (Roth A+)And let's no even talk about the ending! Anyone who has watched any sci-fi films involving wormholes, etc, must have seen where this film was going from the opening few minutes. As the final climatic scenes, yawn, made me wish I had some popcorn left over to occupy myself with something useful, no wait I could have put the bag over my head to hide me from the shame of wasting $12.50!!

Review title: It's a one star disappointment. Hopefully the sequel will be an improvement.
Review_body: I have to admit, I never read the book.  Maybe this thing was true to the letter.  If that's the case, the creators of the original movie were even smarter than I thought.  Regardless, this time around was an abysmal disaster.  I gave it a "4" because Charlton Heston was awesome in his cameo. Nothing else impressed.

Although I'm not a fan of the previous Planet of the Apes movies (I've never seen them), I was pretty excited about seeing this remake/sequel.
Unfortunately, I was very much unimpressed with what I viewed. The special effects were great, the scenery was realistic, and the cast seemed to be very talented (opinion not based on this movie). However, they were lacking in one MAJOR department: the script! As someone said before, I agree that you and a bunch of your friends could have written a better screenplay for the movie than these talented, well-paid writers did.There were many interesting directions this movie *could* have taken and didn't. I noticed that in the beginning of the movie, the woman scientist on the spaceship mentions that with chimps the female is dominant sexually. Of course, this led me to think; `What an interesting twist to the movie! The female apes could be really domineering instead of the males!' But instead the comment seemed to hold no relevancy to the rest of the film whatsoever! It turns out there were hardly any female apes at all, and those were hardly very aggressive.Maybe I shouldn't have gone to see the movie with such high hopes for a great flick, but I did. I am officially insulted at spending good money on a film that seemed to have lots of possibility but no delivery. For those of you who haven't seen the movie and plan to, my advice to you is to go into the movie with lowered expectations and maybe you'll appreciate it more than I did.5 out of 10

Review title: A good satire depicting human nature and apes that can act humanely
Review_body: I had never seen a good science fiction movie since "Star Wars: Phantom of the Menace" until I saw "Planet of the Apes". Although the two films are about future human interplanetary adventures, "Planet of the Apes" stresses more on human compassion for and understanding of other living creatures. The film is also a good satire on men's foolhardy behavior to launch nuclear wars that could annihilate everything on earth only to find that, in the end, they would be ruled by "wiser-than-human" apes. For such a good film, all the kudos go not only to Director Tim Burton but also to all the crew, particularly the makeup artists, set designers and the actors.

Review title: Great film. I have a few quibbles
Review_body: Taking this movie for its own merits instead of needless comparison to the original, I thought it was quite good. As many have said, the acting (at least of the apes) was astonishing. The villain chimp (Tim Roth) and Ari the sensitive chimp (Helena Bonham Carter) were amazing, both the acting and the technology to support the believability. Yes, the ending was strange and didn't follow logically whereas for the most part the rest of the movie was logically self-consistent. However, it was a good ending and I'm willing to reserve judgment to see how they develop it in the next film. My few quibbles with the movie were these: * I didn't see any gorillas on the space station and such large apes seem entirely inappropriate to the space mission, so where did the gorilla breeding stock come from? * I realize the apes are stronger than humans, especially the gorillas, but when they hit someone, the impact of the punch was ridiculous even considering their strength. If you could hit as hard as 5 Mike Tyson's on his best punch, you couldn't even come close to getting the target rocketing through the air like they did. And if you hit that hard, it would seem to be instant death but wasn't in the movie. I know, I know, Hollywood needs to really exaggerate. * The year was something like 2032 that it all began, right? Well, there is no way the world will even be close technologically and space achievement in 31 years. Transportation pods smaller than a compact car that can land on an earthlike planet and launch again? The apes genetically engineered to be very smart? The military has a massive space station?                This would be more believable in 2132. Enjoy, Jon

Review title: A travesty of a sham! A sham of a travesty!
Review_body: Is there anybody left that actually remembers the original 'Planet of the Apes'?  If so, do remember the point?  Man, given enough time, will destroy himself with technology.  Simple ebough.  Flash forward to the present, and the film is remade.  And what does Tim Burton do?  He gives the moral a 180 and suddenly man is the utmost being and technology is his savior.  It just goes to show how self centered and over confident we have all become.For the record, even if there was no original Planet of the Apes, this would still be a worthless movie.  It becomes more campy by the second, there are far to many innconsistancies to mention here, and the ending was quite possibly the most ridiculous thing I have ever seen.  What, did they have a whole bunch of left of monkey suits to use?  Not only am I about to give up on Tim Burton (that's two, Mr. Burton, remember Sleepy Hollow?) but I am completely fed up with the bastardization of old movies.  Has hollywood run out of new ideas?

After watching this film, you appreciate the films of the past that so many have tried to redo. There really not a lot of action in this film except for some fight scenes toward the latter half of the movie. Looking back at the original Planet of the Apes, you could see where there was a definate plot and goal. This remake doesn't have that cohesion. It does work well with the relationship between Whalberg and Carter. But the relationship between Warren and Whalberg develops too quick after the demise of Kristofferson. In that type of primitive society, Kristofferson could be father or husband but we don't know because Warren just says "my family". It's too obvious that the writers used her as competition for Carter. In fact you really see no reason for Kristofferson to even be in the movie. Whalberg's involvement with the primitive humans comes too quickly also. It's like they cut out a part where Whalberg should find out what this planet is for the sake of the length of the movie. The fight scenes seem inconsistant. One minute an ape kills a human with one blow but our hero (Whalberg) takes several blows and falls. But somehow,again, Whalberg maintains the common sense he has in many of his movies. Somehow through all his movies, writers give him lines that make him act (or react) realisticly. While the others have lines and actions that don't seem be what it would be if it was real, Whalberg comes in and acts like the only one sensible or realisitic being. (as though he walked from the seats into the film) So much so that when we see him in the end....an ending that makes absolutely no sense or connection with what we just saw in the rest of the movie, the look on his face is as though he thinking, "what kind of stupid ending is this to a movie" right on the screen.*see more in goofs for inconsistant content

Maybe it is because I grew up with the old Planet of The Apes, but this movie just didn't do it for me. The acting was poor and the story line was poor.  You can't make a great movie with an kick butt set, killer make-up and cool costumes alone. Was I the only one (on this planet) that noticed that the only living things on this planet were humans, apes and horses?  Hello!  Where did the horses come from?  Why no fish in the swamp where the shuttle crashed?  Why no bugs?  Why no birds?  Did I miss something?  Do I need to see this movie again?  I have also always wondered what would happen if you set an ape on fire and blasted him a hundred feet in the air.  Now I know that "nothing" happens. ------------ W H A T E V E R!  I think this movie must have had a different ending that was never put on film, because the script did not add up.  What was good about this movie again?

Awful, just awful! Bad casting, bad acting and not a patch on the original. It could have been so much better. I know the idea is somewhat far fetched about apes ruling the earth, but the original film was entertaining and thought provoking. This version is just downright silly. Sorry, but it stinks!

Review title: This movie with great potential was ruined by the ending and lack of development of characters...
Review_body:
First of all, this movie is not as bad as a lot of the reviews make it out to be.  Second, it didn't bore me and I was actually pretty content with the film until the last 10 min.SPOILER**** When the chimp landed on the planet during the "big final battle"  I just knew that this film was spiraling down, and in my opinion it did.Mostly everyone knows the story of this movie regardless if they've seen it or not.  It's about a human pilot Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) who crash lands on a planet ruled by apes a few thousand years in the future and tries to escape because the living conditions of humans there are very poor due to the tyranny of the apes.  This simple plot I think would have made for a good movie.  Also, I'd like to mention that I haven't seen the original Planet of the Apes so I'm making no comparison.  However, what ruined this movie was the fact that there were too many plot holes.  A big part about enjoying a movie is to understand the story and when a movie is presented with a plot-holed story-line, you'll be spending a lot of time wondering instead of letting yourself enjoy the film.Anyway, the plot summary seems very simple, yet the movie is cluttered with so many different things going on.  This proves to be a big obstacle for portraying the development of the characters.  This was unfortunate because I believed that the characters were worth relating to, especially Daena (Estella Warren).  Actually, now that I think of it, she had about 5 lines in the film, other than that all she had to do was pose, and by the time of her last scene, I still didn't know her name.Another thing that bothered me about the film was the somewhat love-triangle between Leo, Ari, and Daena.  Throughout the movie, it was so obvious that a romance between Leo and Daena would've worked well, but they didn't even have a conversation together.  As for putting Ari in this equation it was just a bad idea because why would Leo even give Ari a second thought as a love interest when he has the HUMAN Daena right in front of him.  It was clear from the beginning that Daena was smitten with Leo, yet he doesn't even notice because he's too busy with trying to get off the planet which is understandable, but I think it would have been good for the film if Leo and Daena had connected emotionally.  First of all, Estella Warren who I think has enormous potential would have had a better role.  She could have been sort of the woman behind the great man, helping him believe in himself and just being there for him.  They really wasted the character of Daena in my opinion.  It's also unfair for others to criticize Estella Warren's acting, I mean how much better could she have been with the script she was given?Thade, annoyed me after a while because he sneered and growled too much. However, overall I didn't think Tim Roth did such a bad job.
I've mentioned how Daena's character was wasted, well actually all the human characters weren't much for the plot.  Karubi, Daena's father had absolutely no relevence to the film.  Birn (Luke Eberl the boy) was a waste of screen space, and then they try to make him important during the end of the film, but that falls through because his character didn't develop just like everyone else.SPOILER*** Attar's (Michael Clarke Duncan) conversion at the end of the film was also unbelievable.  It's also hard to believe that when Thade gets stuck in the ship and starts shooting off his gun, that he didn't get hit at all even though there were like 7 bullets ricocheing off the tiny room at the same time.Finally, the ending.  A movie's ending can make it or break it.  This movie's ending broke it.  It left far too many questions unanswered, but not only that, it didn't make any sense AT ALL!  I have a feeling that the movie makers only put this ending in so that people will hear through word of mouth about this twist ending and make them want to see it.  It's nothing but a money making sham which unfortunately is working.  It leaves room for so many different types of sequels, what bothers me is that it doesn't seem to leave room for most of the characters to return for the sequel (eg. Daena, Ari...).Well, this movie was a feast for the eyes, it's visually a masterpiece, but unfortunately visuals aren't enough to make a great movie, a story and characters one can relate to are still the key and unfortunately this movie lacked this.  It's definitely a movie worth a look at, just not at the price of today's cinema admission.

Review title: Nothing Special......1968 Apes were better period.
Review_body: Honestly, my expectations for this movie diminished right after I watched 2001 version of the "Apes." I thought that Tim Burton would bring something fantastic but it was a total failure.....Not as much passion inputed as an old "Planet of the apes." I wasn't fully disappointed with the special effects but I was well disappointed with the story lines and the visual content of the film. Apes didn't look as real as the 1968 Ape.I would just like to say that this movie is for an entertainment, not for an enlightenment of the hidden meanings and themes behind the film. If you just want to relax and watch the film off the curiosity then this film is a perfect feature. However, if you are a person who wants to be in awe of unexpected glimpse and extraordinary story lines, then either read the novel or watch the 1968 version of "The planet of the Apes." I personally didn't enjoy 2001 version of "The planet of the Apes." 6.3/10 I would give.

I loved the original.  It had a lot more to it than a simple sci-fi flick. Everyone agrees with that.  Did I expect this remake to be up to the same level?  No.  I went in with a fresh perspective, letting the movie stand on its own.  What a mistake that was.One plot' point that bothered me was all the people wanting to see the man who defies the apes, since they defy the apes every day by congregating in roving bands of scavengers evading capture.  Also, there is a difference between giving the ending a hanging twist, the sort that requires you to think, and incomprehensible one.  Oh, and the two swiped lines from the original ("Get your stinking hands off me..." and "Damn them...") had the feeling of being forced into the script.  They just did not flow.Warren is a horrible actress.  Wahlberg was fairly stiff.  Bonham-Carter was a caricature.  Roth was the stereotypical mister-mean-man.  The script was just plain weak and the craft of storytelling was nonexistent.So, I thought I would read the book.  Let's see, the beginning was nothing like the book, the ending had little in common with the book, the middle wasn't really that much like the book.  However, there were talking apes... So, yeah, it was similar in that respect.I am glad I only rented this.  Well, not really.

Review title: What were they thinking? Hollywood bunk once again.
Review_body: The original Planet of the Apes was awesome for its time. The number of follow up films produced prove it. I admit with each new sequel the quality of the story went down, but one tends to be forgiving because they were made so closely together and had some cohesion.  This new film doesn't have that luxury. They took a chance and changed the story and failed miserably.  The original had implications of mankind's destructive nature which caused this twisted society to be born. In the new version the ape society was born from an astronaut not following orders. How Trite! I'll say that the make-up was impressive, but so what. I'll take a story with some depth and meaning any day.

Review title: Great Movie, LAME Ending !!MAJOR SPOILER AHEAD!!
Review_body:
well i have to say overall this was better than the original. I mean, first the makeup was amazing it makes you think its actual monkeys acting! Second the story about how the apes came to be was better than the original story in th '68 version. I mean the space station with apes crashes on the empty planet and the apes become superior than humans. Mark Wahlberg lost in a phenomenon in space and crashes a thousand years after the station after only minutes since he left. The culture of the apes is more defined. The ending if directed by me would either have him leave and go to HIS time period or stay on the planet. BBUUUUTTTT .......... how on earth did that happen??? weren't the apes ruling on another planet???? that ending was lame.......will stay this way until a sequel explains what happened!!!!!! overall it's worth your $$.
7/10 stars!!

Review title: Great Movie, LAME Ending ! SPOILERS AHEAD!!
Review_body: well first of this was a really good movie. The ape makeup blew me away, i nearly thought it was real monkeys acting!SPOILER AHEAD Second the story behind how the apes got to ruling over humans on the unnamed planet was actually better than the original apocalyptic earth thing in the Charleston Heston epic. The whole about time warp and the station with the apes crashing and Mark Wahlberg crashing a thousand years later was cool. Everything was going so amazingly well......when it came to the end. SPOILER AHEAD!!The movie should have ended with him staying on the planet...but he takes off.....and crash lands on earth in the past(1990's)and its ruled by apes....how did that happen????? i mean earth was far from everything......well i hope a sequel will explain everything.....7.5/10

The original Planet of the Apes has been around for over 30 years so It's not that big of a suprise that the fans of it didn't like this version. They left their comic book stores and went to the theater expecting a shot by shot remake of the original. Well -- suprise! -- This wasn't a remake. Tim Burton's Apes was a different story all together with a similar --more sensible-- plot.   This one, in my opinion, was better. It contained connections to not only the first few movies in the series but to the novel as well [examples being with the GREAT suprise ending or the 'fun for the whole family' monkey named Pericles - who sadly died in the book]. Also, The Special Make Up Effects to this 2001 version --when analyzed-- blew the original out of the water. Rick Baker's work to this is his best since 'an American Werewolf in London'. When you combine all of that with Danny Elfman's pounding score and Tim Burton's smooth direction you get something that hasn't been conceived since Warner Brothers' BATMAN was released.   Oh, and In regards to a few news group critics' spiteful reviews, Tim Burton's visual style is very much evident in this million dollar 'Blockbuster' movie. If you'll think back to the cold white/black contrasting space station segments or the jungle / desert shot lay-ups then you'll realize that a sort of Hitchcock reminiscent style of frame composition is present. That's pure Tim Burton. The colors and set designs are prime examples.   In my opinion, Don't you compare this one to the original, it's a great movie on it's own. It explains more than the original did --or the book-- and makes more sense, like how the apes speak English. Tim Burton hasn't done something of this calibre since his 1989 comic book film renderings. So in summation, for all of you whiny little 1960's Apes Fanatics, just think about the references this one made to the original, Think about how much better the old one could have been and think mostly about why the movie made so much money - if it was so bad? Tim Burton's a genius artist and this film was his pallet.

One of the best films ive seen.  Not just the plot but the beauty of the scenery.  Once again he created a beautiful spectacle like in Sleepy Hollow and Edward Scissorhands.  The apes looked so real, and they moved so perfectly.  An amazing film.  7-1/2 out of 10!

Outstanding makeup and possibly the most evil screen villain since Darth Maul won't save this movie from being placed on many peoples' worst lists of 2001. Insipid dialogue, rote acting (by humans, mostly) and action sequences that almost never gain momentum are but a few of the indignations marring what could have been a triumphant revisitation to the Ape planet. After seeing this, after seeing another down in the up-and-down career of Tim Burton, I almost wish this HAD been made by originally planned director Oliver Stone with Arnold Schwarzenegger starring. That version may at least have enjoyed some campy fun.

Only a couple of good things to say here. The makeup is, of course, amazing. Rick Baker deserves awards galore for his work on this film. General Thade is probably the best villain I've seen on screen since Darth Maul, but being probably the worst movie of the year, likely no credit will be given. The dialog is insipid, the acting is grade school and the action never gains momentum. What a waste of a premise. No scathing social commentary, no clever nods to the original (only a few stolen lines), no real development of any kind. Save your time and see something else.

Review title: A terrible film that totally sells out.
Review_body: I was anxious to see this film, thinking that it might pay tribute to the greatness of the original. What I found was that the film was poorly written, and it lost all of the flavor of the original. All of the social commentary is gone, as well as all of the mystery. The plot has been replaced by some substitute filler, and the entire thing wreaked of recycled plastic. Although I did find some scenes laughable (most notably the ones that required acting) I would see it once just to know what I am talking about. If you are looking for some of Tim Burton's better work, look elsewhere.

Review title: I hope it doesn't turn into a Star Trek
Review_body: I saw this film the day it came out with high hopes.  My friends told me how great the original was and i could only think of how awesome a writer must be to create such an original story.  Oh, i was a fool.Burton has had a successful streak, hasn't he?  Batman, Batman Returns, Sleepy Hollow, and the cult favorite Nightmare Before Christmas.  Yes it is an awesome life.  But every career has a hitch.  This is his.  Mark Wahlberg's career has also been rising.  From the innovative Boogy Nights, to the highly rated Three Kings and The Perfect Storm with another blockbuster (Rock Star) on the way.  Maybe this can be an oversight.No matter the director or the stars, our hero, Leo Davidson cannot see that his ape costars are real actors.  Whenever speaking to them, he inserts a short pause, as if trying to prove to himself that these are real people. His eyes are blank and emotionless.  He plays a hero just as well as Steven Seagal, take that as you will.The apes are frighteningly lifelike, but you can't base a movie on its makeup.  The film is dark, very dark (visually) for the first 3/4.  As if these future apes couldn't figure out lightbulbs, or even gas lights.  The film also uses the rope and pulley system made popular by the Matrix.  While it looked new and exciting in Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, and even Romeo Must Die, seeing apes jumping vertically eight feet (from a sit down) is just silly.None of the "human" characters, beside Leo, play an important role.  It makes you wonder why he's trying to save them.  Apes have evolved into intelligent, thought processing individuals over thousands of years... but what happened to the humans?  Did we just stop at a certain point in time, and someone said, "This is enough for you"?  The ending is so confusing it's physically impossible.  Burton rearranges time so much i think HE get's lost.  Overall, it's a 4/10- saved by the makeup and the ape's acting.

Review title: A fun movie, though not burtons best
Review_body: Ok let me say this outright.  The people who were expecting the original planet of the apes are idiots.  The original, though it had its strong points dragged on to long.  The extended walking in the desert scenes were just silly.  And for all these people are hanging onto, it is still just a B-movie. Tim Burtons version, which is exactly that, is tim burtons version.  It is pretty silly to compare it because the whole entire movie was reworked. But people forget the whole entire original book was reworked to have some commentary on racism and nuclear war in the original movie.  But back to the point.  I went in this movie expecting burton to deviate, even hoping. That is exactly what happened, burton reworked everything.  Thank GOD.  (no offense, but the original is a pretensious, seriously flawed, sixties, B Sci Fi movie, that has alot of inconsistancies to it, but it is probably the funniest movies I know of, because of all those reasons) Let me put it this way, this is a film that burton did for fincial reasons, mainly to fund his pet projects(Ed Wood the most notable). I was not expecting greatness, i was not expecting this to be sleepy hollow or ed wood.  I was expecting this to be a b-movie.  The acting was bad, but who cares, all acting in action movies is bad, the exception being batman, where jack nickolson brought it to a whole new level.  That and i did not think burton wanted good acting, or he would have cast his regulars.  Tim burton saw this movie as an opportunity to indulge in the b-movie genre, and make a bundle(which he will).  It was not supposed to be high art, just a fun sci-fi movie, and it would be foolish to expect anything else.Visually the movie is not so trademarky burton, but his touch is there. Yeah some of the battle scenes are silly, and in fact there are alot of inconsistancies.  But who cares.  The movie moved along very well, though a bit to fast at times.  The movie alone is worth seeing for the charlton heston apperance, which is possibly, and probably intentionally on burtons part, the funniest scene in the movie.   So go see it, but do not expect a masterpiece, or a loyal remake of the original(which never was a masterpiece).

Review title: Rather entertaining, rather memorable, rather good
Review_body:
I think Burton did well in creating Planet of the Apes for a generation that did not know it, and as well, keeping the ones who did satisfied. The acting by the human-played apes was marvelous, mannerisms such as hoots and grunts in amusement, anger, or excitement were quite well done.
