Burton was also able to create a scientifically logical theory behind the concept, engineering the thought that the primates were tampered with in the human image, and taught English when they were genetically engineered, which all of course was fantastical but eerily plausible.  The ape culture was intriguing as well.There was moments where I was saying, "Wow, that was a really great idea".  However, there was also times when I found myself saying, "Jesus Burton, not that!", although the latter was less common.
All throughout his career, Tim Burton was trying as hard as he could to balance entertainment with his cinematic vision, and this time he struck gold.
All in all, Planet of the Apes is not the kind of remake that people who loathe action films would enjoy, nor people who despise art films, but if you have no preference (Or you can at least stand both), the new Planet of the Apes is truly great science fiction! My only complaints were the blonde supermodel (Paper thin character), and some really lame dialogue(More character developement would have been nice too).  Both a B movie and a cinematic marvel (If it's possible).Ah, and on a final note, Helena Bonham Carter (the period-piece-princess) made a rather attractive chimpanzee!

This is a good movie.  I love Tim Burton's style.  The character's were good, the scenery(as always in a Burton movie, especially Batman).  It was very cool.  Everything was all good until...the ending. That came outta left- field.  I won't tell you guys the ending but, let me till you that it had me and other people little confused on how it happened.  The score is GREAT. Danny Elfman rules. The score is a little like Batman.  Also, the opening Credits are EXACTLY like Batman, which is great. 8/10- Go check it out.

Review title: Get me the spaceman! CONTAINS SPOILERS
Review_body: *Spoilers* Unlike, seemingly all of the people who went to see this movie, I have read the novel on which the POTA series was based. The twist at the end being that by the time the main character had returned to earth the apes had taken over society. This is what would appear to have happened at the end of this version of the story, not some of the bizarre interpretations other people have posted. The main problem people seem to have with this film is that it has a sense of humour about itself. at a time when so many films are ruined by taking themselves to seriously, this film probably should have taken itself  seriously but a sense of smirking fun prevails throughout. Burton's unique visual style is perhaps not as dominant as in some of his films but it's still clearly there. The film is riddled with plot holes and nonsense which are clearly going to drive the petty logic obsessed viewing public crazy, in short if something about this film annoyed you, (most of these complaints are just to stupid to list) chances are you missed the point. Oh, and the film is not set up for a sequel (not to say that there won't be one) but think about it for god's sake (the ending was a parody of the book, a joke no one understood), how would that work exactly?

Review title: mark wahlberg is a heck of an actor.
Review_body: At first i thought this movie sucked, but the longer it went to the more i realized how well it was written.  I am 18 yrs old i watched this film with 5 other peers.  i am the only one who liked this movie.  i think this film is great.  it had some low points but overall it was worth the 7 dollars i paid to see it.  if i had to pay to watch it again i would.  this isn't like the original planet of the apes, this is not a sequel and the ending is what makes me like this film more and more.  i think that anyone who is openminded and likes sci-fi movies will love this film.  overall i thought this was a good movie.

I went into this movie not expecting very much, and came out with the same attitude. This movie was predictable and boring. Three major flaws stood out for me. #1. How did horses, exactly the same kind as we have here on Earth, evolve on this planet, when no other animals seemed to? What did the horses eat, is their food from the jungle or the desert? #2. How did Leo grow no facial hair in this entire movie, which I am assuming spanned a larger amount of time then a day. #3. Was it just me, or did nobody else miss the character development of Estella's character? At the end of the movie, when she kissed Leo, I realized I had yet to learn what her name was. My rating: 2 stars

Review title: It's not Scottish so it must be....Crrrrrraaap!
Review_body: This was so inane and awful I actually for fun starting picturing Jean-Claude Van Damme in it for laughs. I think what's so flabbergasting about it's awfulness is it's the same director who brought us Edward Scissor Hands and Sleepy Hollow. How did such cheesy dialog and typical action movie twists and turns get by him. Maybe they should never give large action movies to more artistic smaller budget directors. They get so swallowed up the studio machine protecting it's investment in a franchise and happy meal tie-ins kinda way. I bet someone like John McTiernan might have actually been a better choice. We'll have to see what he does for Rollerball. This movie makes Mighty Joe Young look like a Dickens classic.

Review title: SPOILER ALERT - interpretation of the ending
Review_body: ************SPOILER ALERT******************This is my interpretation of some of the events about the movie that people have argued about here.Go to the next review if you don't want to know what happens in the movie!First off, I don't believe that Leo (Wahlberg) ever goes to the future. Sure you see the year in the ship fly up, but I still don't believe he went into the future.  I believe he actually goes into the distant past, on Earth.  Why else would there be humans (and monkeys, as noted in one conversation) on that planet?  All the humans on the ship were killed by Zemos.  It's too hokey to think there are humans on another planet.  By the time Marky Mark gets there, the humans will have learned the English language that the apes had been speaking all this time, thanks to the brain enhancements the ship scientists had been making to the apes.At the end, Leo goes back to the present-time of the movie (2100something, I don't remember) and lands on Earth, as the monitor on his ship stated.  He never notices he landed on Earth the first time, because he was going after Alpha Pod, and was busy trying to land safely, etc.  And in one scene in the beginning, the people in the Obeuron start getting the signals on their monitors that are showing all the events of Earth's past - hence, giving Thade and his future generations, the idea to construct things like the Lincoln Memorial and cop cars, etc (ok, it's strectching a bit, but it still works).So basically, if Leo didn't chase after the chimp, thus having the crew chase after him and crash land on ancient Earth, and if humans weren't trying to manipulate the Apes' brains chemically, the Apes would not have evolved, and in the end they would not have taken over the Earth.The movie, especially the ending, which I thought was a little silly, but still satisfied me, makes a lot of sense when you think that he actually never did go into the future in the first place, but the past instead.Which brings this movie to the same lesson that the original one did: Humans are always F-ing themselves over....Oh yeah, I gave it a 9 out of 10.

Review title: Tim Burton, Please Help Me, I'm Freaking Out Over Here!
Review_body: Well, I'm not going to lie to you but, YES, I did enjoy this movie. The special affects were decent to good, the makeup was excellent, and the scenery had some room for improvement. Characters such as Thade(Roth), Attar(Duncan), and Ari(Carter) were mostly flawless, With my hat going off to Mr. Roth for his more than excellent portrayal of the "Ape General". Leo(Wahlberg) was well... about what I expected from Wahlberg (He was a better Dirk Diggler then Leo Davison), and Daena(Warren) was either to attractive for her part, or should have had more lines, (i may have enjoyed this movie more if her and her family were developed a little more) but whose to complain. This movie also laid good homage to the original '68 version, especially With Heston's small part as Thades father. No matter what others may say, Yes I liked the original just as much, however, i think the whole way the plot unfolded was definitely more complex then its predecessor. This version doesn't only question race(which it may or may not supposed to do), however it definitely questions religion and evolution more. SPOILERS AHEAD I'm not going to bore everyone reading this huge comment on plot summary, because you'll be able to read it in 99% of the other reviews on this movie. SPOILER ALERT On the other hand getting to the ending. Someone please tell me what Burton was thinking. Not that it was bad, but what does he want people to think happened. Some people say it was obvious that it was Earth all along, but could you be sure of it, I distinctly remember seeing two moons ( I even went to see the movie twice just to prove to myself that they were there) It couldn't be earth with 2 moons could it?? So maybe its not earth that they're on the whole time but, first of all where do they get horses, was that the only animal originally there? And how the hell did Thade get to earth and lead a revolution. Does he brake out or is he lead out, and by himself find a way to do space travel to earth, somehow to lead a revolution of apes on earth?Who knows maybe When Leo passed through the electrical storm he passed between parallel universes, or dimensions. Does he even land back on earth? Maybe he lands back on the same planet in the future and they have similar statues to earth??? Am I just looking in to it to far. I wish Tim Burton would just give us a straight answer, Please oh Please, don't ruin it with sequels. Tim if your out there just tell me what you wanted everyone to think, because personally my mind is going in circles trying to pinpoint what the explanation, Hey maybe its just to be left open with the intention to drive us to think about it this much.If any of you see this and have a definite ending reasoning please email it to me.8.5/10 (It had some room for improvement, but it makes you think(For me way to much).)

Review title: Tim Burton, Please Help Me, I'm Freaking Out Over Here!
Review_body:
***SLIGHT SPOILERS*** Well, I'm not going to lie to you but, YES, I did enjoy this movie. The special affects were decent to good, the makeup was excellent, and the scenery had some room for improvement. Characters such as Thade(Roth), Attar(Duncan), and Ari(Carter) were mostly flawless, With my hat going off to Mr. Roth for his more than excellent portrayal of the "Ape General". Leo(Wahlberg) was well... about what I expected from Wahlberg (He was a better Dirk Diggler then Leo Davison), and Daena(Warren) was either to attractive for her part, or should have had more lines, (i may have enjoyed this movie more if her and her family were developed a little more) but whose to complain. This movie also laid good homage to the original '68 version, especially With Heston's small part as Thades father. No matter what others may say, Yes I liked the original just as much, however, i think the whole way the plot unfolded was definitely more complex then its predecessor. This version doesn't only question race(which it may or may not supposed to do), however it definitely questions religion and evolution more.
I'm not going to bore everyone reading this huge comment on plot summary, because you'll be able to read in in 99% of the other reviews on this movie.
On the other hand getting to the ending. Someone please tell me what Burton was thinking. Not that it was bad, but what does he want people to think happened. Some people say it was obvious that it was Earth all along, but could you be sure of it, I distinctly remember seeing two moons ( I even went to see the movie twice just to prove to myself that they were there) It couldn't be earth with 2 moons could it?? So maybe its not earth that they're on the whole time but, first of all where do they get horses, was that the only animal oiginally there? And how did Thade get to earth and lead a revolution? Does he brake out or is he lead out, and by himself find a way to do space travel to earth, somehow to lead a revolution of apes on earth?Who knows maybe When Leo passed through the electrical storm he passed between parallel universes, or dimensions. Does he even land back on earth? Maybe he lands back on the same planet in the future and they have similar statues to earth??? Am I just looking in to it to far. I wish Tim Burton would just give us a straight answer, Please oh Please, don't ruin it with sequels. Tim if your out there just tell me what you wanted everyone to think, because personally my mind is going in circles trying to pinpoint what the explanation, Hey maybe its just to be left open with the intention to drive us to think about it this much.8.5/10 (It had some room for improvement, but it makes you think(For me way to much).)

Review title: All Window Dressing, No Substance Here!
Review_body: So sad! As a fan of the original, and Tim Burton as well, I had high hopes for this movie.  Well, dispense of any ideas of suspense or sci-fi drama! This movie is totally predictable, but COMPLETELY, TOTALLY, nonsense.  It has become a complete fantasy, with no tie in to reality or logic that made the original so compelling.OK, the filming and mood is nice, but the story is so stupid you will cry.Save your money.  Rent it later if you have to.  But take my word...one of the biggest disappointments awaits you here.Soon to be covered by MST3K!!

Wow, what a bummer! As I am a fan of the original, 1968, movie, I was excited when I heard they were doing a re-telling. I thought that with today's effects technology, and a story idea as compelling as Planet of the Apes, I thought there was no way this could fail. But boy was I wrong. There is utterly no character development aside from pointing out to us who are the villains and who are the heroes. There was no motivation for General Thade's (Tim Roth) hatred or Ari's (Helena Bonham Carter) great compassion. To call the plot shallow would be to imply that there was any substance at all. And all the inside jokes concerning the original series got old, too. However, nice touch having Charlton Heston appear in a cameo as General Thade's dying father. Mark Wahlberg, who has consistently turned in very good performances in films like "The Perfect Storm" and "Fear," falls flat with a one-note character stolen from the pages of a comic book.Sure, the effects were great and the costumes were superb, but no matter how much make-up they pancaked onto my grandfather at his funeral, he was still lifeless, as was this film. All in all, a disappointment; no drama, no suspense, no depth of plot. Just another forgettable action film. My rating: D.

Review title: Well made movie even though it was full of holes.
Review_body: This movie was extremely entertaining to watch.  Mostly, it was quality filmmaking.  The story is definitely lacking in several places and you really have to forgive certain things that don't make sense but it makes a great summer blockbuster.  It is absolutely worth seeing.

In short, Great acting, great effects, great make up, great sets, great idea but it just didn't seem right. I'm not a great advocate of remakes anyway, sometimes they work, sometimes they don't, in this case the latter applies. Near perfection should be left alone.

The previews of this movie were very promising: directed by Tim Burton, with such stars as Helena Carter and Tim Roth, and a huge budget for special effects, it had the potential to be one of the year's hits.  However, a smarter move on the part of the directors would have been to scrap the film, and screen the preview in theaters.  This film in the region of the worst film I have ever seen.  Mark Wahlberg, as usual, adds nothing to the film with his despicable acting and moronic facial expressions, except the impression that he is severely constipated; Tim Roth (who has contributed to such great films as Reservoir Dogs and Little Odessa) was physically painful to watch; and I still don't understand why they bothered to include Helena Carter in the cast at all.  It takes a flight of the imagination to imagine Tim Burton saying "cut!" on the set, and being pleased with what he had created.  Bottom line: DO NOT SPEND ANY MONEY ON THIS FILM.  The actors are pathetic, the new ending is as pointless as it is absurd, and Tim Burton should beat himself in the face with a frying pan for this one.

I've read some of the comments and I won't add another one that trashes the movie; we get the point! This is a typical reaction of moviegoers who are kinda uptight about certain films, mainly those who deal with humanistic philosophy of good and evil, like Lords of the ring, Star Wars or the Star Trek series. Probably Dungeon and dragon players too. Kinda nerd? I thought the movie was okay, not great but Burton did a good job considering he was touching sacred material (a cult film, woooow!). And I especially like the ending which was like a finger (guess which one!) pointed at those freaks who like to have an ending that answers all questions for them and let them think they are intelligent. It reminded me of the ending of Hitchcock's the Birds which still drive people mad because it doesn't explain why the Birds decided to attack. Who cares: it's a movie!!!

Myself and my girlfriend left the cinema bewildered and disappointed by this terrible film.  We are both Tim Burton fans and were willing to overlook the mixed advance press.Suffice it to say that this film is a mess, doesn't make any sense, and has severe acting problems.  The male lead is a man who used to advertise underpants and is a complete emotional blank.  Even worse, his love interest is that curse of Hollywood films, a model woman who has no acting ability whatsoever.  Just think: they spent tens of millions of pounds on this, could have had anyone in the world write a script and work on it and this is what was produced.

This movie(if you want to call it that) was a complete debacle!!! I really wish that people would leave the classics alone and come up with new ideas. It is impossible to try to capture the feel of the original movie, even with modern CG effects. Then to add insult to injury the producer even went as far as to re-write the movie to their liking! The only place this should have been seen was on the cutting room floor, and that is even being nice! To the Producer... please... if you want to remake a movie... please choose something that you have a chance at making better instead of ruining classics that will be around longer than you will! What a legacy for you to leave... I destroyed a classic!

Review title: These were always bad movies, the good kind of bad.
Review_body: I remember renting and re-watching all of the VHS movies before I even went near the theater to see this one. Yes people the movie is bad and cheesy and whatever else you'll make of it, but many seem to forget that is exactly what we have always loved about these films. This addition does not ruin the series at all it just adds on a slightly prettier addition to the wonderfully awful movies we have always enjoyed. The acting is decent and the action is fun so take a moment and remember that these movies were never as splendid as they are in our hearts. Just try to enjoy the movie and stop fighting it because of its style.
I thought this was a good remake a much more in depth tone for the series as well as amazing special and practical effects

Review title: Disappointing effort to relaunch good series
Review_body: Tim Burton has made quite a lot of good movies, but none of them would ever give you the idea he would be the director best suited to direct a "Planet of the Apes"-remake. His style of filmmaking pretty much couldn't be further from what was needed here.The film abandons just about every detail from Pierre Boulle's original book. At the start of the movie, Wahlberg's character, Davidson, is working on a space station, and he is involved with experiments with primates. While the back-story behind this seems interesting, you don't get to know much about it because not long into the movie, one of the chimpanzee's from the station disappears with his spacecraft, Davidson follows and ends up on the eponymous planet. Unlike in the original movie, here all humans have the ability to speak and are completely civilized. Since the apes are in that sense not dominant over the humans, that removes a lot of the suspense present in the original movie. The humans still are slaves though, but Davidson escapes with a female slave and convinces a female ape to sort of join their cause. Two apes, military commanders, start chasing after them and we get to see some uninteresting chase scenes. The Ape City also looks badly compared to the one from the original. Later, scenes take place at Davidson's old space station, which crash landed at the planet hundreds of years before he did. The apes apparently created some kind of temple there. Eventually, there is a battle between the humans and the hostile apes.Now, I've heard people say they were interested in seeing this movie because of a cameo by Charlton Heston, but his appearance is so short and since he is unrecognizable I would hardly say it would be worth sitting through this movie just for that.This movie is also infamous for the horrible ending, which deserves a special mention of its own. They must have worked really hard to make the last scene especially as bad as possible, in the vain hope they would get to make a sequel to tie up the infinite number of loose ends they created in this.Fortunately, the series got a proper reboot with "Rise of the Planet of the Apes" in 2011. Do yourself a favor and watch that one instead of this.

Review title: should be called Planet of the Pants
Review_body: A horrid, hateful, hash of a movie. A totally needless exercise. What is the point of remaking a perfectly good film made less than 30 odd years ago? Put simply, it's because Hollywood has run out of ideas. Why waste effort trying to create something new when it can simply rehash superb older movies and create garbage.For all you people out there who've never seen the original I urge you to. It's a wonderful and powerful film with a truly exciting and surprising ending, which if you don't know will come as a startling shock.I saw this 2001 abomination when it first opened I was hoping that perhaps Burton might be able to do something with it - sadly, Burton did. He took a fantastic film and turned it into a turkey, filling it with tedium, nonsense, overblown effects and Walhberg. It's so obviously a film made by committee - 'we can't have the humans silent! We need a sexy, strong female freedom fighter, we need massive war! We need sexy female apes! And we need to out-shock the original film's ending with an ending so shocking, the audience will leave their seats shocked by the shocking revelation of it all!' Boy, was I shocked.There's so much wrong with this film I'm not going to even try.Don't waste your time with this, don't waste your money.It was shown on TV recently and I thought I'd give it another go and work out when it goes off the rails. Actually it's not difficult to spot. It's happens just after the main credits have finished rolling.I'm surprised the entire film isn't just listed in the goof list.Goof - the entire film.Avoid and save a precious couple of hours of your life. Because when you're lying on your death bed wishing you had a few more hours of life left, you're gonna wish you hadn't wasted them with this trash. I know I am.
This movie was a great remake with a different twist......Tim Burton did a great job.....much better that the newer ones with all the unnecessary prequel back story....less is more in my opinion!

Review title: The worst movie since Waterworld, and the worst remake ever!
Review_body: This movie is so bad that the only thing that could adequately describe it would be a particularly-foul-smelling, one-hundred-minute fart. The producer, director, and screen-writer should all win 'Chumpies' (or should that be 'Chimpies'?) at the Anti-Oscar Awards.The acting is so bad that, no doubt, Kris Kristofferson pleaded to be killed early in order to escape the locale. Most of the other actors were mainly trained to say, "Grrr!" and leap about like demented chimps.The attempts at humor are pathetic, being mostly banal take-offs on modern stand-up one-liners. The hero is a blockhead space pilot who can't fly as well as a trained chimp, and whose face is far less expressive.If you're going to rent this movie, be sure to rustle up a biiig bag of popcorn, 'cuz you're going to want something to put over your head to escape the worst remake, ever!

I'm ambivalent about which of the two is more significant: It's a beautiful movie, but the story has more holes than swiss cheese.I was impressed by the production values: the makeup, sets, editing, and such. I'm less sure about the costumes. (Most outfits appear to look like they're made primarily from vinyl.) In many ways, it's visually stunning. A lot of the things they did with ape culture, modes of expression, even movement were very creative. Though some turned out silly, like the "running".The acting was, on balance, pretty good. Some of the characters were preposterous (even ignoring the ape makeup), but in particular Tim Roth and (in stark contrast) Paul Giamatti were amazing in their roles. In some sense, just the variety of personalities shown in the apes was impressive.But the story had holes in it bigger than the ones the spaceships flew through. While I understand that it's a fantasy, rather than SF, given the "auteur", the inconsistencies in the plot, if you will, were too much for me. I can suspend disbelief for the big things, but the details are too much to handle. (Some of these questions may be spoilers.) How did the apes become masters of vinyl-making, when they can't produce a decent knife? Where did the horses come from? And for that matter, where were the gorillas from? Their "escape route" from the city was laughable. The climactic battle was *terrible*! And the "twist" at the ending evoked more stupefied laughter than awed thrill.Maybe upon repeated viewing, I can gloss over these flaws, but I don't think so.

First of all: I'm a HUGE fan of the original 1968 POTA. And this is not a remake of that movie. It's simply a reinvention of the same story, filtered through the eyes of one of the most creative Hollywood directors. Everything in this show work in a perfect way: the screenplay is inventive and brilliant. All the performers gave their best, in particularly Tim Roth portraing the main villain, General Thade, and Helena Bonham Carter under the make-up of the kind chimp Ari. Costumes, art direction, special effects are amazing! Great part of the success of this film is due to the wonderful make-up effects by the genial wizardy of Rick Baker and the complex score composed by the talent of the sublime Maestro Danny Elfman. Main titles (music and images together) are simply astonishing! Absolutely a must see by all the fans of fantastic cinema. Rating: 9/10.

Review title: Tim How Did it All go Wrong - Stick to Gothic 'Horror'
Review_body: Oh dear, I had such high hopes for this film.At first I was worried when I heard that 'Planet of the Apes' was to be re-made. It all seemed like a rather cheap (well not if the budget is $100m) attempt at a 'sure-fire' summer blockbuster - but on hearing that Tim Burton was to directed I began to look forward to seeing the finished product. After all wasn't this the man who had brought us Edward Scissorhands, Sleep Hollow and BeetleJuice.But after seeing the film all I can say is stick to gothic horror Tim. It doesn't engage at any a level, its not exciting, not at all interesting, predictable and worst of all the shock ending makes no real sense. It does look 'authentic' and the make-up was first class with Tim Roth and Helen Bonham Carter doing their best to kick some life in a hack script. But with little success - a dead dog (or ape in this case) is still a dead dog. One of the worst of the Summer 2001 blockbusters.

Review title: I cannot believe how bad this movie was
Review_body: Let me just start of by saying that this movie was a total waste of time, money, effort and was possibly the biggest dissapoinment I have ever seen.With all the hype behind the movie I expected a lot, and I mean a whole lot more out of this.  The acting was second rate at best, characters were so predictable, and the plot so thin that I was about ready to get up and leave 1/2 way through the movie.  How many of you out there actaully managed to predict the movies ending at about the half way point???  And the Ka Li Ma thing?  Makes you think they ripped that off from Star Trek when the spacecraft came looking for "v y ger".Absolutley no premise was given to the scientific background that would make such a series of events possible.  Not just the time shift but the whole evolution of monkeys into something more.  If in the thousadn years or so that the monkeys had become dominate then why had the humans not also changed?  Wouldnt the humans be a lot smaller and dumber?  And all the perfect teath in the movie?If you have to see it wait for the video to go into the $.99 special of the week section.

Planet of the Apes is missing the comedy and the edge of Tim Burton's other films.  Though stranded on a strange world, Leo Davidson lacks the outsider quality of other Burton heroes like Edward Scissorhands, Ed Wood, or Lydia Deitz (Beetlejuice).  Similarly the comedy seems wedged in, rather than forming an integral part of the story, as it does in the likes of Mars Attacks or Ed Wood.It is really only the performance of Tim Roth that redeems this picture. He has never really had a reputation for being a physical actor but here he shows himself to be up with the Oldmans and the Nicholsons.  It would have been good to see someone more animated than Mark Wahlberg in the Davidson role.

Expecting an enjoyable evening of cinema-going, i went to see Planet of the Apes. Last week I saw Sleepy Hollow for the 5th time, so I hoped (and expected) for some more Burton-magic. When I left for home I had seen almost none of that.First the story. The script had to many flaws. During the whole movie the story stays mainly too shallow, for instance the character of Leo is always two-dimensional. I also missed some big-scenes. Their were just a few moments in the movie that 'resparked'the movie. Also Burton could have done better, for instance the big fight-scene could have been a lot better. Also disappointing was the scenery, it looked like a set all the way. The acting was mainly poor, Wahlberg en Bonham-Carter can be good actors, but this time he couldn't convince me. Warren was a big laugh. The exception was of course Tim Roth. Maybe sometimes over the top, but in general great.
In general: 4,5/10

This movie sucks.  The plot is W-E-A-K and rife with holes.  The acting was on par, but the script was horrible.  With so many writers, how could it be so bad?  One can only guess that so much attention was paid to the makeup (fantastic) that a good script was overlooked.Tim Burton has officially sold out and Mark Wahlberg is capable of so much more when he has a good script to work with and a director more concerned with storytelling than points on the back end.If you just HAVE to see "Planet" on the big screen, save some money and go see a matinee.  Or better still, just wait until "Chimp Week" on Animal Planet.

Tim Burton's new remake of Planet of the Apes is pretty disappointing... visually interesting but shallow.  It really doesn't explore the issues of the day as did the original.  In fact, it's best moments were based on contrived references to the original with familiar dialogue. Interestingly, the only people in the theatre laughing when those references were made were my friends and I (proving my contention that we were among the oldest attendees).  Sadly though, most of these high school students will never see the original and won't know what they're missing.  This film is predictable at just about every turn...  lacking any of the punch that allowed the original to hit audiences with its stunning visual revelation at the end. This movie should have been be more than an opportunity for the makeup artists to remind us that it's 2001 and not 1968.  Shame on Tim Burton for not engaging the challenge!

Review title: Did Tim Burton sleep through this?
Review_body: I've got a theory, and it's the only only way i can fathom how this great tragedy of a movie came to be the way it is... Tim Burton slept through every single take, just to wake in time to shout "Cut!" and then nod through the next scene. Honestly, every single element of this movie was without vision, without style, without anything.There is honestly no one to pick on, cause everyone and everything was equally bad. Even Tim Roth irritated me as the over the top Thade. Where did that stupid kid suddenly come from just before the final battle? The so-called twist at the end seem to have been forced in there just to give this film some credibility when compared to the first film. Ironically, it just highlights the incredible shortcomings of it.There are honestly SO MANY BAD THINGS to pick on, but i'm sure the guys here at IMDB have some sort of limit on the length of comments. So, in conclusion: The entire cast & crew of this flick must have been on an overdose of sleeping tablets, god help them.Burton, you better do something next that's up to your previous standards, otherwise i'm coming for your soul...

Review title: Another attempt at a remake of a great film that ultimately fails
Review_body: Usually they blame the director when a film goes awry...but I'm afraid that this time the blame must be put on the moviegoing audience. I actually can't believe the overwhelmingly positive response by fans and critics alike to this movie!Okay...it looks great...but there are several major flaws...first, did anyone else notice how a few of the apes (Paul Giamatti's "Limbo" in particular) too closely resembled The Grinch?...second, notwithstanding the great acting by Tim Roth, everyone else seemed stiff as a board...third, and most importantly, and without revealing the ending, did anyone else notice how preposterous it was for that ending to be possible? There is NO possible way that the events at the end of the film could have followed anything that came before it. Instead of a twist ending that meant something, we are left with a sense of confusion that seems to have been tagged on to make jaws drop...until common sense prevails and you realize that they couldn't figure out how to end it in a realistic manner.I guess that the average moviegoer will walk away semisatisfied at what amounts to little more than style prevailing over substance...something we have too long settled for...but as always, most people will forget about it as soon as the next overblown hyped summer blockbuster comes along!

It's not often that I find a movie that I literally wanted to walk out of during the film.  This movie just happens to be one of those movies.  Mark Walhberg was not the cause of this movie to stink, nor was it the acting in general.  I liked the acting and the special effects.  However, the story and script should never had made it past the producers.  In fact, I am surprised the ink in the pen wanted to write it out.  This whole story does nothing but tarnish the original movies good name.  I literally, as soon as I left the cinema went and rented the original Planet of the Apes to wash the bad taste this one left in my mouth.Let's compare the new movie to the old;Actors: Charlton Heston & Mark WalhbergWhile Hestons brand of acting may not appeal to all, it IS brilliant acting. Mark Walhberg is an up and coming star, this is true, but for him to rise to the level that Heston sits upon, Mark is going to have to start looking for some seriously good scripts and take some more acting lessons, maybe even from Heston himself.  ADVANTAGE: OriginalSupporting Ape Cast Old & Supporting Ape Cast NewApes are Apes but there are aspects from both the new and old films that I liked.  The Original movie had Dr.Zira and Dr.Cornelius and who could forget Dr.Zaius, who were all pretty great characters which added a lot of character interaction and development for Hestons character(Taylor). While the new movie has Ari? An Ape with a serious case of the hots for Walhbergs character(Leo).  ADVANTAGE: OriginalSupporting Human Cast Old & Supporting Human Cast NewBased on the fact that the original only had Linda Harrison as Nova, I have to give the advantage for this class to the new movie.  ADVANTAGE: New MovieSpecial Effects:While the old has some fantastic sites where they shot the film, we do have to give the new movie the advantage in the special effects department. The only thing I really did not like where the Gorillas that were leaping distances of 30 or so feet.  Advantage: New MovieStory:Well this is the big kahuna.  The old movie had an amazing script.  The new movie was geared too much towards quick action where the old movie was a lot of character development with enough action to keep it interesting.  After watching the new movie there were definite aspects that I really would have liked to see in the old movie.  Such as the fact that the Apes were using primitive weaponry.  Makes sense.  Also they lived in the trees, again.. makes sense.   I was very dissappointed when the humans in the new movie opened their mouths and could speak perfect english.  WOW, it's actually very  difficult to see, at least in my point of view, how the apes could regard humans, that can speak just as eloquent english as they.. AS SAVAGES. Or question whether or not they have souls??  Hello?!?!  I thought the whole reason they were "savages" was because they could not be taught, were stupid and were almost neanderthalic in behavior.  What I saw in the new movie was an excuse to have at least a few more characters for Walhberg to talk to since they did not have the character interacton with the Apes. I liked the idea or Thade.. but he was just a tad bit too insane for my liking, then again, maybe there just wasn't enough character developement for me to like him.  Overall.. ADVANTAGE: Original
In short, this movie is a waste of time, don't see it, don't rent it, don't buy it.  I give it 4 thumbs down

I knew this was going to be a bad movie. I loved the original so any attempt to top it was, in my perspective, bound to fail. And surely, it did.
This is one misconceived film, and has nothing in the form of pace, believability or lovable characters. The ending (here we go again) is glued on for no apparent reason, other than trying to be true to the novel on which the film is based. The plot is more or less non-existent. And why is it that these "wild" humans, are running around with nicely combed and washed hair, and look like a million? A film such as this, has got to be more dirty. We're talking about a planet ruled by monkeys damn it! And when humans can talk and communicate with the apes the analogy to our own world is lost, along with any reason as to why Mark Wahlberg would make a difference.Speaking of; one of the main reason for the failure is Mark Wahlberg. I havent seen an actor do such a bad job in....well, ever actually. He has got the face of a robot, and less talent than one. And why does he make such a big difference in this world? He has got no charisma, he displays no leadership, he has trouble raising his voice, he delivers all of his lines with the same tone of voice and is generally as inspiring as a taxaccountant. Why are we led to believe that he could lead a rebellion against monkey-tyrrany?Without a doubt Tim Burtons worst film. Avoid!4/10 for good makeup and nice FX's.

Review title: Mark Wahlberg a bit wooden - watch the original first
Review_body: In this version the ending is not the same as the original.  However I would strongly recommend watching the original first as it develops the idea of the human/animal relationship being turned upside down.  The original has same corny lines but that was 1968, filmakers nowadays should have no excuse.

Review title: PoTA - Never send a monkey to do a man's job
Review_body: I wanted PoTA to be my favourite film of the year, which on reflection it probably ended up being. Lacking the originals social comment, and released at a time when the World's social ills and insurgency are less than in Charlton's '68 original, the film nevertheless provided good action sci-fi and a clever (if not a bit confusing) ending.HBC gave a good performance, and Roth probably outshone Wahlberg as the mean and devious Thade. A great looking film, well delivered by Tim Burton, who was the ideal director to carry the primate adventures into 2000.Burton brought subtle humour to the film (which I had anticipated being a lot darker than it turned out). The orang-utan love pastiche, the little girl as a pet, and the two card playing apes - one calling the other a "Cheater" (Cheetah).A lot of acknowledgements were given to it's father film. Several quotes and a cameo Heston. I preferred the fact that the apes on Burton's planet were unarmed, other than with clubs, the original (especially the TV series had them kitted out with all sorts of weaponry). It was a shame one of the original underlying mantra of "ape shall never kill ape" was dropped, but by and large it stayed relatively true to it's original.Overall: A good re-working. 8/10

Lots of action, a great sound track , special effects and make up, made this film an enjoyable two hours on a hot July evening. Helena Bonham Carter as Ape Avi is wonderful...so were the apes of Tim Roth and Michael  Clark Duncan. Very menacing for sure. Tim Burton has done a fine job putting this remake together.I rated an 8 out of 10. Visually, it won't disappoint anyone. If you like action and fighting, it is here also.

Review title: Unlike the original which is good.... but...
Review_body: but it's a very weak story with unremarkable special effects and full of gaping holes.  Which is bad.  Very very bad.I went in expecting a good movie that would live up to the name of the franchise, despite the presence of Burton in the director's chair.I cannot believe a story resembling an early draft and not much more than a comedy sketch in someone else's production would have received final approval and the go-ahead by an entire studio.When it's available on video (DVD), watch this along with the original 1968 Apes.  If you care for nothing more than MTV special effects, maybe you'll come away with a distaste for the original.  But if you value any type of consistency and plausible story, in an implausible world, then the newest Apes movie will leave you wanting a lot more.  Not even Helena Bonham Carter nor Tim Roth, both whom put forth excellent performances, could save this picture.  Paul Giamatti was brilliant - his performance might have been a little too comedic over-all, but again, that was a problem with the writing. His performance was stellar.  Mark Wahlberg has chosen far better roles in the past.Ah, Burton signs his name on another ruined production.  He certainly has earned his over-rated respect directing this type of swiss-cheesed fluff. The picture does nothing to advance the state of cinematography or story telling.  It adds an easily forgettable movie to the Apes line-up.  If nothing else, at least a sequel, with someone else handling direction, doesn't stand much chance of being any worse.POTA-2001 earns a solid (1) rating.  Wahlberg offers a one liner which would sum this picture.  I'm only paraphrasing... "you shouldn't send apes to do a man's job" - and that there points to one of the biggest holes in the entire story.  No spoilers though.  Watch it for your own opinion, but do yourselves the favor of going in expecting very little.

Review title: Visual achievement make up for plot deficiencies
Review_body: I must say, after seeing the PotA edition of Exposure I took their advice and went into the movie without considering that this was the second adaptation of a French novel from the sixties--trying to watch it as if it were an original script.  That gave me no expectations and disappointment that things were so different.The surprises (including Charlton Heston's cameo) just kept me glued to the screen.  I even enjoyed the ironic twist at the end even if it made very, very little practical sense.  Paul Giamatti deserves extra credit for an outstanding comedic performance.  Tim Roth has never been sexier.My only disappointment was the serious lack of explanation, mainly toward the end.  I think they allowed way too much freedom for our imagination and we deserve to know just how (...)Rich Baker can look forward to his Seventh Oscar for Best Makeup at next year's Acadamy Awards.

Review title: Great movie with a rotten ending
Review_body: Let me start of by saying that I loved everything about this movie except for the ending.  The ending made me think of a line from a Bette Midler concert film that goes "What the f---."  The problem is that their is not any logical explanation to this films ending (to say more would mean giving a major spoiler to the film).  It seems that Tim Burton and company felt they had to have a stunning ending like in the original "Planet of the Apes" but it doesn't work (unlike like in the original where the surprise was quite logically explained to the audience).With that said please check out this remake because besides for the ending it truly is a great movie.P.S.  Mark Wahlberg once again proves to movie audiences as to how great an actor he truly is.P.P.S.  Mr. Burton when the film is released on DVD would you please record a commentary track in which you explain the ending to this movie.

Having just returned home from viewing this film, I remain stunned.  I expected much better from such a fine director and cast, complete with what seems to have been an unlimited budget.Main beef - where's the plot?  This movie was so predictable and lifeless, I don't know where to begin.  The so-called "plot", was rife with absolutely fantastic leaps of logic (ie. an accidental one-button location of a space/time warp - puhleeeeze!).  Such a pity.The film offered no surprises, other than the guffaws of disbelief from many in the crowded theater.  I'm still trying to understand why somebody felt the original movie, deserving of much praise, had to be remade.The primate characters looked like actors wearing rubber masks.  Nearly every set looked like... well, a set.  Several characters (ie. young warboy), invisible during the development of the story, somehow become important near the end of the film.  But without character background, I felt nothing for them.  The requisite buxom blonde was easy to look at, but left me wondering why she was even there.  Any romance angle between man/blonde or man/girl-illa was undeveloped and anemic, and shouldn't have even been attempted.This was one lame waste of a Friday night, and my hard-earned money.

Review title: A set-up for many sequels to come
Review_body: After seeing this Planet of the Apes, I wonder if they will make 4 sequels to this too. Unlike the original movie, this one leaves you with a lot more questions. At the end of the original, we realized that he was on earth after all. Simple as that. But this movie leaves me with so many questions that I am counting down the days till the next one is released. I compare the ending of this movie to that of the original Star Wars.....abrupt. But I did indeed enjoy the movie, for several reasons. One was the great special effects and terrific Make-up and Costume usage. (Give em the Oscars now). I had to keep reminding myself there were humans under all that make-up. I didnt care too much for the beginning, it just seemed a little far-fetched, like this might have been the best idea out of a bunch of bad ideas on how to begin the film. Man risks life for monkey? As it went on, we saw the viciousness of General Thade and wondered "Whats up his butt"? Although thoroughly p***ed off the entire movie, Thade does display a side of him that is very human. His scene with Heston as his father bleeds with politics, because the one possesion he has of the humans is a gun, and considering its Heston, Pres of the NRA, I couldnt concentrate on what they said to each other, because I was chuckling at the Irony of this scene. Heston saying humans are dangerous for creating this kind of technology? Did I hear that right? Wow...... We have all heard of movies that are too slow. This one went too fast. I wanted more explanations, and more about the apes...the general daily life of these apes is hardly delved into, and we go into the sequels knowing very little about them, except they dont like humans and they screech a lot. The ending did leave a lot of doors open for sequels, but will this movie go down as being better than the original? Probably not. Will this movie be remembered for its stunning visual images? Yes. And thats why you should see it. Dont get too entangled in the plot...because you will be tangled for a while. Enjoy the movie, and wait for the sequels to explain what we dont know.

You wanna see a bunch of guys in ape suits?  Okay, this is your film.  You wanna see good acting?  Go far far away, as far as you can from this movie. The only one worth his weight in bananas is Tim Roth, but don't go expecting to see his Four Rooms/Resevoir Dogs personality because you'll never recognize him.  Kudos to Roth for actually ACTING.  Everybody else, well, I stick out my tongue and beat my chest at you.  And who would have thought that all of Charleton Heston's classic lines would be hijacked by the apes themselves?  And this "incredible new twist-ending"?  They could have brainstormed a thousand years and never come up with anything sillier.

Review title: Pale imitation pulverizes where original mesmerized
Review_body: A pale imitation of the 60's classic, obviously made only with the intention of raking in big bucks at the box office.  It has no resonance, no spark, no soul.  No reason for being.  I was suckered into seeing it by the promise of Tim Burton's visionary direction; but the end result could have been filmed by anyone (just a few more explosions and it could have been Michael Bay). While sitting through it, I indulged in a fond reverie of watching the original in a theater, way back in the day, mesmerized.  Monkeying around with this classic only left this audience member pulverized.

Review title: Tim Burton needs Batman and Batman needs Tim Burton
Review_body: Tim Burton's new vision for the "Planet of the Apes" is completely dumbed down for the increasingly tolerant American movie audience.  Why can't the studios just bring out the original films, instead of remaking them? I will admit that I went to see this film with as much trepidation as going to see Gus Van Sant's misguided redo of Hitchcock's "Psycho" a few years back. This isn't as bad as that, but it's very close. Franklin Shaffner's original 1968 film is a classic (yes, classic!).  It holds up very well today and should be seen by anyone who hasn't. The new version has none of the political and social satire that makes the original so fun to watch.  I knew that Mr. Burton wouldn't even attempt a political film, so we are left with a fairly mundane film in which our new time traveler encounters a planet ruled by apes, and then immediatly wants to get the hell out of there.  The problem is there is absolutely no danger.  Mark Wahlberg doesn't face immasculation or lobotomy like Charlton Heston faced in the original. He is only faced with a villain that hates humans, but we never find out why.  Tim Roth is quite good in the role, but we need a backstory. The film does brighten up for a few minutes at the midway point, with a brief cameo.  Let's just say it's the best acting in the film. If we are going to have to sit through remake after remake, please let's try to make a film that is inspired.  Tim Burton is a very original filmmaker, who this time out is hampered by a very poor script. If William Broyles cannot come up with anything more witty than an ape saying "Get your stinking paws off me, you damn dirty human!" then perhaps he should start working on that script for "Apollo 13 Part 2" What the audience should be saying is "Keep your stinking paws off of classic movies, you damn stupid producers." In conclusion, I hope that Tim Burton can find some way to get the "Batman" franchise back from Joel Schumacher before he causes any more damage, save Michael Keaton from doing "Jack Frost 2" and stop screwing around with classic films from the past. As for Producer Richard Zanuck: PLEASE DON'T REMAKE 'JAWS'or 'THE STING' Leave those films alone for the love of God. COMING SOON: 'PAPILLON' STARRING LEONARDO DECAPRIO AND JASON BIGGS!!!

Review title: Typically Burton - huge on style, light on substance
Review_body: First up, I'd like to say that I liked POTA.  It is absolutely gorgeous to look at.  The make-up, effects, cinematography, costumes and sets are all pretty hard to fault.  On the acting front, Tim Roth is utterly fantastic as General Thade and he just about makes up for the price of admission on his own.So what's the problem?  Well as much as I want Mark Wahlberg star to continue to rise, I just don't think he has the charisma to carry Charlton Heston's role.  Not that he was bad or anything, his acting is fine and he is certainly a lot better looking than Chuck ever was.  But is he really the brave and indignant leader of the human race who defies the apes and their dirty paws?  Maybe he would have been better as the plucky young male that defiantly chases after the hero (read George Clooney) after being told to stay behind with the others?But in Mark's defence, I don't think replacing him would have necessarily made the film any more satisfying.  This was a difficult film (conceptually) to make when you consider how highly the original is regarded.  Do you just remake it with the same emphasis of script and story, or if you are going to do something different, what do you change?So Burton does what he does best and creates a film that emphasises style over story, and action over acting (or actors).  It worked for Batman and I think it does for POTA.  Time will tell after the franchise has come and gone whether people criticise "POTA Forever" as not holding a candle to Burton's original!Enjoyable: 7/10

I've seen a lot of bad movies lately and I refuse to pay full price anymore because the quality is crap!  But this one is truly a stinker for the ages. I am continually amazed that people shell out their hard earned money for a story with so little forethought.There were so few entertaining scenes that I found myself yawning through most of it and just as we seem to reach a (aww) happy ending that explains everything.  Marky Mark flies through the universe in about three minutes, lands on earth, and sets the scene for probably one of the worst sequels that will ever be made (Next to Jurassic Park II of course).Exactly how stew-pod (book reference) do movie makers think we are?  How much crap will we actually put up with before we refuse to go to movies anymore?  Oh yeah, never mind, JP 3 made 80 million last week,  guess that our stupidity has no limits.Save your money, read and book and leave something to the imagination.2 out of 10

Review title: What's all the fuss about? - it's fine!
Review_body: I spent a long time reading review's of new new Planet Of The Apes here at IMDB. I got the general impression that this movie was a waste of time. Yes, Estella Warren spent the entire movie uselessly pouting with those inappropriately glossed lips.  Yes, Mark Wahlberg was not nearly as dynamic and emotional as would be expected for someone crash landing on to a strange planet to find himself suddenly faced with ape-rule.However, I still enjoyed the movie very much.  Tim Roth as Thade was a powerhouse, Bonham Carter was good and Michael Clarke Duncan as General Attar was perfectly cast.  He actually made a very funny quote which I read about in a newspaper.  He said "when my agent called me about a part in this movie, I knew I wasn't gonna be no human!"Anyway back to my comment... this is an entertaining movie, yes it is. Purists, please stop this quest for perfection, it doesn't exist, not anymore anyway.  Entertainment is what matters.  Planet of the Apes with Charlton Heston is brilliant, and emotionally stirring, but it is history. Appreciate it, but move on.  Please.

I whole heartedly concur with the user comments dated August 12, 2001 which were printed by Just_Voards.  If you HAVE seen the movie, read their comments as they are spot on and filled with lots of POTA trivia.  If you HAVE NOT seen the movie, see the movie and THEN read Just_Voards comments. Would someone give this writer a newspaper column!?  Well done!!!!

Review title: Only an adequate outing by Burton...
Review_body:
I found this particular effort by Burton to be not quite up to par with Batman, etc.  But, hey, Burton is allowed to falter somewhat occasionally. These comments, however, are not directed at the movie, but at the posters who complain about illogical and inconsistent events in the movie.  Some of these are valid such as the engine of the USAF ship being operational years after it crashed. Sure nuclear powered engines can last for hundreds of thousands of years, however, everything else around it would have decayed (circuitry, wires, etc).  It's a minor problem, however.  The other "problems" can be explained I believe though. SPOILERS AKERT(1) I'll begin with the "origin of the apes" point first.  Clearly, the apes (chimps, orangs, gibbons, gorillas) on the planet Leo crashed landed on were not descended from Leo's chimp.  They were descended from the apes which were on the USAF ship.  After the crash of the USAF ship, the apes (being genetically engineered to be smarter than normal) ran amok and took over. 
(2) The second point is about the time gap between the sending of the mayday message by Leo in the future and its reception in the past by his crew.  Now for those of you who were not paying attention, there is a point in the movie where the USAF ship receives a message emanating from the time warp. It was sent by the captain of the ship, only he appears much, much older. Clearly, it was sent from the future.  It's a time warp folks!!!!(3) The third and final point has to do with the conclusion.  I have to admit, it was a bit contrived, but like the previous 2 points, I think I can come up with an explanation. The only one I can come up with is that Thade somehow regained control on the ape planet and used perhaps Leo's crashed pod or salvaged pods from the USAF ship, went through the time warp back into Earth's past and conquered the Earthlings.  Yeah, I know -- it's a stretch.  I can't wait for its elucidation in the sequel, and you know that was a classic sequel setup.

Review title: A Chance to Go Ape Ruined by Tedious Audience Junkfood
Review_body:
Contains SpoilersNo one can expect a remake to equal up to the legendary sci-fi classic even with all the special effects and ape costumes in the world. Well considering that Mark Wahlberg doesn't show a single expression beyond stupefied' doesn't help either. It's also his character, Leo Davidson, who gets transported to the future after he dives into a nebula of testosterone.If you need me to explain the plot, go out and rent the 1968 version. But Burton and friends took liberty with adding typical action flick characters and scenes that'd not find home in the 1968 classic. Like General Thade (Tim Roth), who sets himself apart from all other Apes by talking in a series of near incomprehensible grunts. Or Karubi (Kris Kristofferson), who not surprisingly sacrifices himself to save everyone else because he's old (originality?). The movie, like the entire franchise, is hauled into a dark alley and beaten to death, kicking and screaming the entire way.
One thing that I loved so much about the original was it's unique score, primarily composed of drums and horns. The opening of the remake has exactly that, even better. I loved the opening score, yet that's the problem; it was only used during the opening. I faintly remember hearing it in the background for about twenty seconds later in the film. But Burton and Elfman decided to follow traditional boring action movie music, the kind that makes you want to attack the screen in a flurry of shotgun blasts.
I sat bored through most of the movie. It's really really boring; half the scenes are dominated by General Thade bouncing off the walls and howling `Get the humans!' Or Mark Wahlberg (who can't be surprised by anything, even landing on a planet rules by tyrannical apes) heroically taking the lead with lines such as `Uhhwe've gotta escape' Scenes invite groans, such as Wahlberg's insta-army. Once the escaped humans, and their ape companions have made if far enough away from the ape city, an army of humans come to join them. What's so terrible about this scene is that the army comes in from all directions simultaneously. In the next five minutes an army of humans are ready to go. Also, the ape city was walled off, with no room for expansion, what are they trying to wall out? Or in?You may remember Charlton Heston's kiss to Dr. Zira (Kim Hunter) in the original. Considering that Helena Bonham Carter's character Ari is nearly a spitting image of Dr. Zira (the reason why I liked her the most in the film) it isn't surprising that she gets a little smooch from Mark Wahlberg. This is the big disappointment in Burton's `Apes'. Here is a chance to go over the top and really screw with the audience. Why didn't spaceman Leo Davidson sleep with Ari? Instead of kicking the audience in the ass, he's just invited snickers from the audience moms. If you're making a movie about a planet that's ruled by tyrannical monkey-men, how can you not go over the deep end? The 1968 version was a great movie with mixed satire, the remake fails.From the way I sound, you must think I hate this movie. The remake had some redeeming features I loved. I loved the ape costumes and how director Burton used the apes in a more primordial fashion. In the original the apes stood up and ran straight. In the remake Burton lets them run hunched over and perform bouncing leaps. The greatest thing about the remake? The ending of course, I won't spoil it, but it's genius. It doesn't make sense, it doesn't have to (just look at the title to the movie).The remake should've been titled 'Mark Wahlberg vs. the Planet of the Apes' because that's what it is. Instead of producing a social satire that explores dual bestiality and the inner workings of a nations ruled by apes (which would've been great). Burton throws a summer action movie at us with little redeeming features and wooden characters (except Ari, of course).

I could have never imagined that something more idiotic from "mummie 2" would come to me this year,but it happened...The remake of the famous and outstandingly good "Planet of the apes" from 1968,I think...I went to the cinema anxious,I came out p***ed of.What the hell was that?The incredible "flight to neverland",the characteristics of the apes,idiotic plot and outline,and MOST OF ALL,the image of the true,brave,intelligent,handsome all-American heroe.I wanted to vomit on the carpet and leave the cinema.Like all American air-pilots,this one has a knowledge of pursuading people(apes),making weapons,riding,fighting simultaniosly with 300kg gorillas,natural lidership...Go home Rambo.Make place for one and only captain Leo Davidson!Incredible.And the pure,pure acting of an "Victorias Secret" model goes well with the movie(we all know who that is).The director is a genious of its own kind.Tim Burton.Yeah.I think everyone will notice the unforgettable clishe-scene of the "american airborn" hero on the horse and the sunrise(or sunset,whatever)behind the mountains waiting for the final countdown.Truly original.The only think missing is the pack of Marlboro (welcome to...) and Morricones score from "The good,the bad and the ugly"...

I expected the new 2001 Planet Of The Apes movie to be a high-tech blast of chills, thrills, and spills.  It had none of that, I was not chilled or spilled.  But I was thrilled at the end! That was pretty cool.  But I won't tell ya anything about the ending so don't worry.  Of course, the ending was nothing compared to the original- (and if you haven't seen the original I won't give that ending away, either.) Some scenes were quite ridiculous, though.  And the storyline was not as good as the original.  Although at least Tim Burton had his own special storyline instead of copying the original's. Overall, it wasn't a bad movie.  If you like movies without blood and a lot of swearing, and you are not totally opposed to science fiction, I think you won't be disappointed, but won't be exactly thrilled either.Not Too Shabby!-madmax-1

The film was decent for a summer movie, but this is not vintage Tim Burton. Too commercial like Mars Attacks.  What is true Tim Burton?  Edward Scissorhands, Batman and Sleepy Hollow.  When I heard that 20th Cent. Fox rushed this movie for a summer release I started to get worried.  Out of all the summer movies this year (which has been a horrible year for movies) this ranks up there with The Score.  THe make-up is some of the best you will ever see and the one of the fun things to do is to guess who is playing the ape.  I would recommend it, but remember it is a true summer movie (bad script, good special effects and some bad acting).

i went into this movie thinking it would be a good, fun movie, i was way off.  the story was bad, the humor was stupid and it was very predictable. it also had barely any action and way to many apes screaming and howling. i really reccomend not bothering seeing this, especially with the line you have to wait in to just get in.  you may think differently and very much enjoy this movie, but you're probably wrong.

Well, I won't pretend to be a professional critic... just a guy who saw a terrible movie. I'd been hot to see 'Apes' since it was first announced so I went to see it on opening night. When the lights came back up I sat still, stunned at the atrocity I had just witnessed.Let me see if I have everything right... the days on this planet are what... 100 hours long and the planet itself is sometimes huge, other times somewhat larger than a football field, but not by much. The continuity problems were a constant, and I do mean CONSTANT distraction. The story line was insulting to even the most forgiving sci-fi fan and the acting, well... for the humans it was tepid at best.Now... the apes themselves. Hands down, the technical Oscars will be gobbled up by this movie and deservedly so. Despite all of the flaws, the work put in by Mr. Baker and the actors themselves <Tim Roth was, as always, fantastic>  to give a complete and realistic image of a talking monkey made 'Apes' worth the trip. Just don't go in there expecting anything more than a technical spectacle and you should be fine. Me? I expected so much more.... and I wish the kid had been left to the apes. Who the heck was he anyway? I didn't even know his name yet I am expected to care? Sigh... go.. see the movie... but check your brain at the door.

Review title: It took Tim Burton a long time to make up for this one.
Review_body: I've been a Tim Burton fan since day one. I actually own "Frankenweenie", and I've watched it about ten times. Pee-Wee's Big Adventure. Edward Scissorhands. The Nightmare Before Christmas. I could go on and on. I love the guy. Then he made "Batman" and "Batman Returns". I winced, but I managed to get over it enough to enjoy "Ed Wood", "Mars Attacks", and "Sleepy Hollow". I had almost forgotten the pain I felt at realizing I paid good money to see Danny Devito drool for two hours.Then Tim Burton went and did it again. He turned out a ghastly piece of garbage, and gave it a sacred name--"Planet of the Apes".Where do I start? Timmy boy screwed everything up right from the start. The plot is too convoluted. The makeup is impressive, but it can't make up for bad writing. Then there's the plot holes. The apes have mastered the art of warfare but can't figure out how to get across a pond. The humans run around in what look like costumes from "Caveman", yet they speak modern American English. Mark Walhberg looks like he's trying to escape from the movie, not the planet. And the ending--WHAT THE &*$%# IS GOING ON??? Rod Serling is rolling over in his grave.Oh well. Maybe if I watch "Big Fish" a few dozens times I'll forget.

Review title: Makes me want to stare at the sun so I don't have to watch movies like this ever again
Review_body: Remake of Planet of the Apes....worse than battlefield earth, worse than Howard the Duck and much much worse than Congo.  This movie sets the bar for awful not only in film but in metaphors for life.  Tell your friends only to see this if they want motivation for killing themselves.

Review title: Do not give out the name
Review_body: Well, this movie is good for eating popcorn however, the original one was sooo much better than this one. The plot itself is not original however it has some changes which I won't spoil for you. The acting was average. The make-up was  really good, the special effects were cool as well. Directing has the typical Burton style.The movie is very entertaining however, if it wasn't because it has that name it wouldn't be so good. I am not disappointed but I'm not amazed because it is an average movie.

An enjoyable one, none-the-less.  As I was watching it, I thought to myself, "You know, I'd really like to see this with my 9 year old brother".  It's a slightly original action movie that supplies enough twists from the usual good guy v. bad guy flick to make it interesting.The movie makes some ham-fisted attempts at social commentary.  At one point in the movie an ape played by Paul Giamatti even exclaims "Can we all get along?" That line has been parodied so many times, it's almost painful.  In fact, as memory recalls Tim Burton had Jack Nicholson say the exact same line (to a much greater comic effect in "Mars Attacks!"  The racism allegories seem so forced, it's distracting.  You almost expect Helena Bonham Carter's ape character to organize a big human-ape chain and start singing "I'd like to teach the world to sing"But aside from the failed commentary, the movie succeeds.  All of the performances were above par. Tim Roth treaded the line of overacting, but never crosses it and makes a great, and perpetually angry, Thade.  Micheal Clark Duncan surprises as a loyal, and religious gorilla general.  Mark Walhburg makes a convincing action hero, although the tough guy role doesn't allow his trademark less-than-brilliant charm to come through as well.  And Estella Warren, well, she stands there with a look of constant surprise on her face. But, hey, she looks great doing it.The only thing I thought was missing was more of Tim Burton's trademark quirkiness.  If you had shown me this movie, and told me to guess the director, I would have had no clue.  Burton's eye for the odd is what excels good movies to great ones.  But, all in all, a fun couple hours. I'll give it:7.5/10 bananas

Review title: Think of it as a Twilight Zone episode...
Review_body: No points for originality or creativity, +2 points for visuals, +2 points for make-up, +1 point for Helena B's excellent work, and +2 more for the director being Tim Burton (his stories are always fun.) I liked the movie for the most part, a good 70% of the movie. There are some really bad scenes, but they're mostly countered by the wonderful Helena Bonham Carter role as Ari. I dunno, but she's the sexiest Chimpanzee I've ever seen. Almost to the point of contemplating beastiality. But does Ari count? Thank god it was a movie. The best way to enjoy the film is to think of it as a Twilight Zone episode. i think it pays a great homage to Rod Serling (co-writer of the 1968 original) and his strange, almost predictable, but twisted endings. Go see it if you're a Burton fan, and/or if you liked Sleepy Hollow.  7 points.

This was a very disappointing film. It was far too childish for my liking. The bad ape, was ridiculously "bad". He was putting faces and making sounds with the apparent intention of being scary. Clearly intended for the younger audience. There was even a "smart ass"-"joking" character, as in the typical Walt Disney films.

Review title: I'm not sure what to think.
Review_body: I haven't seen any of the original Planet of the Apes films so I can not compare the remake to any of them.  However, I do know how the original Planet of the Apes film ends and I would say that it seems a much easier ending to understand.  Don't worry, I won't give any spoilers for either film.The acting was very good, especially Tim Roth as Thade and Bonham Carter as Ari.  I don't understand why others have complained about the poor acting. The special effects are also unbelievably brilliant in every department and a lot of effort was put into the little things like the behaviour and mannerisms of the apes.However, there are plotholes and the ending is very confusing.  This doesn't mean it doesn't make sense as so many people have claimed.  No offence to anyone but you should really make sure you understand the ending and it's relationship to the rest of the film before you judge it.  I myself don't understand the ending 100% and am therefore making an effort to find out what it means.Some of the plotholes pointed out by others are minor and don't really make the film any less enjoyable.  Then again, I don't fully understand what happens in the film so maybe the plotholes are significant.  Anyone who claims to understand the end can feel free to explain it to me.Possibly the poorest area of the film was the action scenes.  They just weren't exciting enough.All in all, although I didn't fully understand the ending, the film is entertaining and definitely worth seeing.  I might change my mind if I ever see the film on video, seeing how the special effects and sound effects were breath taking, but I'm sure I won't ever consider this to be a dismal pointless movie.  There's just too many clever ideas for that too happen and I can't stop thinking about the film now.My provisional rating: 7.5/10.

This movie is a very big disappointment, it looks like it was made by some rookie trying to copy Tim Burton style. Neither the scenarios and make-up are outstanding like it was said. And the holes in the story? -Were did the horses came from? They were riding horses in the ship? I don't think so. -Why there were so many species of apes, chimps, gorillas, etc, etc; when in the ship there were only chimps? -Where was Cornelius? One of the most important characters in the book was left off? This is to say that this movie should be avoided by Tim Burton fans... or not...

I went into this movie with no expectations.  I loved the original, but understood that this was a re-imagining rather than a remake, so the movie was bound to be at least a bit different.  Burton does an excellent job of visualizing what a city built by primates might look like, vaguely jungle-like, but with buildings.  The plot is at least as good as the first one-I found that whole humans are mute angle just a bit much in the original.  This deals with rights of a stronger group over a weaker, touches on the dangers of allowing military leaders to make political decisions, and in general creates a believable world, especially when it becomes clear just how the apes got there in the first place.  (Just a note of science here-genetically altered chimps can only mean mixing DNA with a compatible species and we share 99% of the same DNA as chimps)  Carter and Roth are outstanding, details such as the gait of the apes are considered and the special effects are kept to a minimum.  I admit I am still undecided about whether or not I like the ending, but let's be honest here-Burton would be less than human if he wasn't planning on a possible sequel.  So why the uproar?  It's not every day you get to see an interspecies love story either.  There are some minor complaints I had, such as why Wahlberg was hell-bent on trying to get all the way back to Earth in what was obviously nothing more than a landing craft, but that hardly detracts from what was an enjoyable and entertaining movie. I recommend it.

Review title: A planet where screenplays are written by apes?!
Review_body: Tim Burton is not a director. He is one of Hollywood's top production designers, but he is not a director. His direction is all style, and no substance."Planet of the Apes" is too self-consciously jokey, and has a mean-spirited quality that is becoming too common in Burton's films. He seems to resent his own audience.The film is worth seeing because of the ape makeup, and the performance of Helena Bonham Carter, but it is, overall, one of the biggest disappointments of a weak summer.

All the advances in makeup, computer graphics, and whatever other expensive high tech stuff went into this film could not overcome a plodding and ultimately boring script and pedestrian acting. Where are Charlton Heston and Roddy McDowell when you need them? I never thought I would say that.

Went to see this last week, and decided before going not to compare it to the old classic. I have to say the make-up effects were pretty good.-Except Helena who really does look like Michael Jackson. I have to say the feeling of physically powerful apes came over very well. Acting was so-so. But I really missed a good battle scene. I thought the included scene was pretty short and pathetic. And then, like a lot before me have said...The ending....What ??? How ??? Huh ????

I really looked forward to see Planet of the Apes, but it was a huge dissapointment.The settings and masks are great, but that is the only good aspect of the film. All other things are really annoying. Mark Wahlberg is not acting, he is just in the movie, looking stupid. The other actors are also not very good.But the worst point of all, is the story. It is absolutely ridiculous! For example: the apes are lying unconsiousness on the ground, but the humans don`t attack them, no, they wait until they are up again! This is just one example for the stupid story, but it would take too long to tell them all.

I've just bought it on DVD and yeah, it is REALLY good and the apes look very real! It's about an ape being sent into some big magnetic storm in outer space. It's being sent to see what that storm is, but it doesn't come back so our hero takes a little spacecraft and heads in the same direction as the ape. When he hits the storm, his spacecraft goes nuts/out of control and suddenly a planet appears. Too late, he regains control, just to crash down into a lake in a rainforest. After he has rescued himself out of the craft, the movie first really begins! He has crashlanded into a world where apes are like humans and humans are like apes, locked up in cages.
