He get caught, but after a short time, he finds out that there is this one ape that's not like the other apes...I've heard people asking me if this really just ain't either a follow-up or a remaking of the original planet of the apes - the answer is definately no! It's a whole other story. I gave it 7*

I liked it , but saddened by what could've been syndrome , the anticipation was more exiting than the finished product , the story originally was a covert Military space station , tuck away behind Jupiter , doing " Genetic " experiments with apes , hence the apes become super intelligent or close to it . (very similar to another fox franchise, the "Alien"series,) ,by human meddling , but the topic genetic interference not has frightening as the previous film / films.with the prospect of WW3 As a plot thread who can forget the scene with ,what is left ,of the Satue Of Liberty..The updated film the hero is transported a short time into the future ,to find a thriving ape society , they that way via genetic manipulation . at the I read this ,in one of the trades , But it ended up in the Rise:Of The Planet Of The Apes . Please someone out there , would have read the same information as well please let others know . 34 years it took to get a new Planet Of The apes film of the ground and a lot of pitches . I personally liked the film , faults and all , I do believe it is Tim Burton deserves , any criticism , The is Twentieth Century Fox , The Dark Force of Hollywood ...

Tim Roth and Michael Clarke Duncan are fantastic in their roles and they truly convince as evolved apes.  Mark Whalberg and Estella Warren, on the other hand are more wooden than a log cabin convention.  The make-up is impressive, but from such a visionary director as Tim Burton, you'd have expected far more.  It seems that the executives were convinced that as many references to the original 'Apes' film will be funny, but instead they only emphasise how much worse this 'reimagination is'.The apes are great, it's the humans that don't convince.

Review title: The most visually stunning god awful piece of tripe you will ever encounter
Review_body: Directed by Tim Burton, this has all the things that you would normally associate with him - fabulous costumes, gothic scenery etc etc. These are visually stunning and serve as an excellent background to the movie. What's missing is a good storyline, good dialogue or (apart from a few notable exceptions which I will come to later) decent actors. It takes the plot of the original film and "updates" it (although why it needed updating, I don't know).Why do I think it is so awful - let's start with the dialogue. From the moment Mark Wahlberg utters the line "I'm going to get my monkey" the script is laughable.Now on to the storyline - well as I said, did it need updating? Take the original, add in some human talking (although it was mostly Wahlberg) and a truly cringe making ending and you have the disaster that was this movie.The acting - I've watched a couple of Wahlberg movies now and I really don't rate him. He seems to think a perma frown relays a pensive side and that if he stomps, he will appear powerful. As a main player, he doesn't convince. Tim Roth - love him but overdone. Helena - don't get me started - ape sensitivity, I don't think so! Michael Clarke Duncan - hang your head in shame. And Estella Warren - god love her, she didn't have a chance. She gets so few lines and is blatantly there as eye candy alone.The human characters who deliver the lines don't even have the decency to look embarrassed. The one exception is Kris Kristofferson who I can pass off without comment, mainly because he wisely keeps his mouth shut for most of the time. The ape actors are well hidden and we won't know if they were embarrassed or not - and they should be. I really respect Tim Roth as an actor but this was ape ham that I was watching - overdone evil, a flat performance. The only decent ape performances that I saw were by Paul Giamatti as the slave trader and the brilliant minute or so that Charlton Heston was on the screen.If you choose to watch this movie, remember you will never get the time it took to watch it back.

Tim Burton re-imagines Planet of the Apes. To put it simply, I enjoyed watching it. The original Apes films are masterpieces of cinema to be sure. So Burton decided that instead of merely retelling the original story, he would put his own spin to the tale. As such, it should be appreciated as a film in its own right and not a mere rehash. The cast, namely Mark Wahlberg, Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan, etc., gave pretty impressive performances. One of my favorite bits has to be Charlton Heston's cameo. In ape makeup, no less. I will not spoil the ending here. it has to be seen to be believed, but I can assure you, you won't forget it. Highly recommended.

***CONTAINS SPOILERS***This was a strange, great movie. As you're watching it, it all seems to tie in with the original. The planet does not seem to be earth. The special FX and sound are wonderful. The acting is average and the movie almost seemed a little boring at times. But what I really hated was the quotes from the original (one made by the man that originally said "Damn them all to Hell!!" as he lay in his death bed. The ending of the movie makes absolutely no sense whatsoever and this totally ruined the it. He clearly lands back on earth and clearly shown to be going back in time. Now if it's all about inter-dimensional travel, it still makes no sense as the present cannot be altered by an action in the future. But images of General Thade were on display everywhere indicating he was a hero in the past. It just cannot be put together to make sense and that's why I hated it so much.

Let me first start of by saying Tim Burton is a visionaire, he has proved that over and over with films like Beetlejuice and Edward scissorhands, etc... but as far as telling this classic tale he kind of got lost along the way in expressing his vision on this tale. Resulting in the end in having more and more beautiful pics and awesome action cut scenes but the story stays behind, and even though the actors do put on a great show, as we can see that Tim Roth is on a roll while portraying a vicious Ape General, even a bit over the sadistic side. But nevertheless it is an OK flick, just that when u expecting the great story told in the novel u would come out deceived.But for pure entertainment reasons I would go for it

Whenever I hear the name of "Tim Burton", I always cringe. Severely! I knew this movie was doomed from the word go. I could have made a better Planet of the Apes movie myself, blindfolded, with both hands tied behind my ankles. After having seen this movie I am truly convinced that for Tim Burton, Edward Scissorhands is about as good as it gets. I don't understand how the industry continues to applaud and lavish this director with accolades. He just simply isn't all that good of a director. And he proves it time and time again. I remember when this movie came out in theaters. I knew better than to waste my time or money to go see it or to even rent it on DVD later on. I just got done watching it on TV a few moments ago. It's about adequate for TV, but only just barely. However, I've seen TV shows better than this movie. So that should say something. I won't waste anymore time critiquing this movie other than just to say this: don't bother with this re-make, do yourself a big fat favor, go and rent the 1968 original instead, or better still, buy it. You'll be glad you did!

I'm going to be one of the few to say that this movie is not as bad as everyone makes out. I often feel that people just jump on the bandwagon when they slate it, especially the hardcore Burton fans. It's certainly not a great movie, nor is it a bad one.Visually it's amazing, as with any Burton film. The sets are spectacular, the CGI is convincing and not burdensome and the ape make-up/costumes look truly realistic and in some cases, menacing, particularly the character of Thade. Danny Elfman's musical score is suitably brooding and savage and I think the slew of weird percussion sounds is inspired. The acting is good, with stand-out performances from Tim Roth, who is the perfectly grotesque Burton villain, and Paul Giamatti, providing light relief.The story and script seem to be the main culprits for all the controversy. I actually like the fact that there is little dialogue. Sometimes movies suffer when there is too much dialogue, as it just becomes convoluted. Although Planet of the Apes is nowhere near as profound as Kubrick's 2001, this is the perfect example of 'pure cinema'. There is not one word of dialogue until 40 minutes into the film. Not everything needs to be explained with dialogue, a picture paints a thousand words, as the saying goes. As for the ending, it's more true to the novel. I will say that the Ape Lincoln memorial makes a mockery of the film, which is a fabrication and NOT in the novel. Although there is humour throughout the film, the ending loses its impact as a result of Burton's outlandish joke.

Review title: Don't watch this underrated movie as a remake, watch it as a different movie
Review_body: I watched this movie first before the original. I have watched both films many times. In my viewing experience, this movie was definitely better than the original, but that may be because I watched this first. This film did lack something extra, but there were many interesting parts. The quality was definitely better than the original. The apes were more ape like. They used their ape strengths instead of being more like humans with a mask on. A must watch if you did not watch the original.

Review title: The Remake utterly failed to set the tone of the Original Cinematic Masterpiece
Review_body:
How to describe what's so disappointing in this movie? Others have described many of those points so ill not go into them here, but for me, what ruined the remake was the crash landing.In the remake, the main character, astronaut Leo Davidson (Wahlberg) crash lands on an unknown planet into a jungle!
Compare this to the original where astronaut Taylor (Charlton Heston) and his crew crash land into a bleak desert, its awe and desolation so well portrayed that it firmly set the tone for the movie going forward, add to that the brilliant sound effects during the various desert scenes, and the tone stayed with you until the very last scene of this cinematic masterpiece!In the remake, the jungle landing instantly deflated expectations, and drowned the tone in the swampy shallow waters of the cramped confines of the dense jungle foliage. While the tone was artfully and carefully developed in the original, where the astronauts spent some days traversing this vast eerie desert, cleverly building up expectation and and a certain level of suspense, the remake assumed the audience has no attention span, and immediately sends astronaut Leo to the ape city just a short walk away from his crash site.From there, one scene runs to another, as the plot and setting is further dumbed down.
One final note: The Forbidden zone in the remake is hiding what is more or less a single object, but in the original, the Forbidden Zone conceals an entire ancient civilization. The original far outdoes the remake in scope, vision and refinement. The remake, while it made good effort in ape makeup, cannot hold a candle to the original motion picture, which far excels the remake in practically every category.

Review title: Could have made it better (Contain Spoilers)
Review_body: I haven't seen the original version of the film so I can't compare the two versions.  I just saw this film and I must admit, they could have done a better job.  The special effects were good and there were some funny moments but the plot had a lot of holes in it.  Capt. Leo Davidson was captured, sold as a slave and escaped on the same day!  How realistic is that?  There were too many unexplained scenes.  Why did the Army Commander kill those two apes that told him about the crash?  How did they know this particular human was from space?  Why did the General switch sides?  It may be a fiction but even a fiction can be made more believable.  It was a good film but it could've been much better.

Review title: When is the Sequel coming and whats with that long stupid trailer????
Review_body: Man I went into this movie really thinking it was going to be a dog because of the poor trailers for this movie. I mean does every movie have to show the dumb trailers that either show you every laughable line or worse yet, show you a synopsis of the whole movie??? I think a simple teaser would suffice for any and all movies before they are released. Unless we are all turning into little children as adults and need the whole movie pratically explained to us before going to go see it.Anyway, this was a very good version of POTA. I was very pleased and a little surprised at the outcome of the movies ending. They practically gave it away, probably for the slower people who like long trailers.This is very much worth seeing and I hope they get the sequel done by next year. They better not leave this one hanging too long. They never made people wait too long in the past series.Thanks, Gary

Review title: no comparison, well maybe 2 or 3 (possible minor spoilers)
Review_body: Everything you see, except the ending, is explained more or less as you view the movie. You will notice if you have seen the originals that several lines of monologue were reproduced for an insider's bit of hilarity. It's a bit flipflopped from the point of view in the first Planet Of The Apes but is memorable in that people having seen the first one recognize these quotes immediately. The first and last quotes by the human astronaut(after capture and escape) in the first film are reproduced from an ape's perspective in this latest one. For example, "get your paws off me you damn dirty ape" has been reinvented as "get your hands off me you damn dirty human". Also, the famous "damn them, damn them all" was used by the same actor but in an ape role. All Hail, Charles Heston.K1

Review title: Predicable movie from start to finish
Review_body: ******************************************************** ****** SPOILER ALERT *********************************** ****** I will talk about the ending ******************** ********************************************************I saw this movie the first weekend it was out and thought the movie was entirely predictable but I can enjoy movies where you already know the plot line and the ending. There were no surprises I knew what was going to happen next.  Like James Bond movies you know Bond is going to get the girl and save the day. I liked this picture better than the original not because of the story line but because of the sets, acting, and costumes.  The characters behaved in a more realistic manner other than the first one which just humans dressing up in ape suits.The ending was a disappointment to me.  When I first heard they were going to do the Planet of the Apes again, I thought to myself "here we go again the movie will end with human hero of the picture in front of a monument with Earth being conjured by the Apes".  This is what I expected from the beginning, when I walked in the movie theatre, all the way through the picture, and at the end when the space craft landed.  I heard that the movie wasn't going to be a remake, the picture took place on another planet and the ending was going to be shocking.  I was personally waiting, hoping and praying for a different ending to the picture that would be surprising and shocking.  So much for that idea. Hollywood came through again with the same old same old.  I guess there was no other way that Hollywood could end the picture, but it was incredibly predictable. What a disappointment but I enjoyed the movie up until the ending.

Terrific "retelling" of a classic sci-fi pop culture icon. But this ending will leave a lot of folks scratching their heads like monkeys. You should really rent and watch the original film first, which I think was still better than this new one but just as enjoyable. While the original 1968 film was more a statement against nuclear war, Tim Burton's 2001 version focuses more on racism and religion. Still, it's the best popcorn movie of this summer.

Review title: Think back to when you first heard the news...
Review_body: When I first heard they were going to "re-imagine" the original Planet of the Apes I just about freaked out. It is impossible. The original has such an intense impact. It works because the viewers are expected to suspend disbelief at least a little bit in order to really feel the power of the movie. The original runs more like a parable or an urban legend than it does a believable action movie. This was also in a time where almost all movies and TV shows were done in the same vain- look at Alfred Hitchcock films, The Twilight Zone, and even Welcome Back Kotter - the list goes on and on. In this day and age people want to criticize the reality of everything and the filmmakers(and TV producers) see that as a challenge. This fact makes Planet of the Apes(2001) fail. I admit that after finding out Tim Burton and Danny Elfman (both of whom I am a gigantic fan) were on board I got very excited. I believed it might be done properly. I knew it couldn't be done but still got suckered in. After seeing it I realised that what I knew all along really was true. The costumes and makeup were perfect and so were the sets but there is no denying that this movie falls flat where the other made it's mark - the ending. They did pretty good with the story by putting a whole new twist on the origin of the Planet of the Apes, but in the end it all turned sour. When I first watched the original I thought of how they were going to end it and there was a certain ending that I (and many others) thought of that would make the movie stupid and very cliche. Thank god they didn't do it and instead made history. Unfortunately the new version of this movie has the EXACT twist ending we were afraid of seeing in the original. Very stupid, very easy and worst of all VERY unimaginative. I was actually cringing in my seat hoping they wouldn't end it the way they did. All I can say is "Bummer".

Review title: *sigh* I think I want to cry
Review_body:
This was a BIG disappointment.  I want to cry because I am a huge Tim Burton fan and I have never been disappointed until now.  As everyone will agree, the visual effects and the makeup are amazing.  Rick Baker and crew deserve yet another Oscar.  However, this is where the compliments end.  Let's go down the list of things that I have a problem with:(1) The first 10-15 minutes on the space station looked too much like Buck Rogers for my taste.  Everything was too sanitized and too white. The acting made matters worse especially when it comes accompanied by lines like "Never send a monkey to do a man's job."(2) There was a long period after this where I was happy.  Once he landed on the planet things got better until they reached Calima and it turned for the worse.  Does anyone actually buy the idea that a 3,000 year old piece of equipment that crashed from space would work?  Oh yeah, that's right!  It's NUCLEAR powered.  I guess that the equipment itself would never corrode or rust.(3) Okay... the rest of the humans show up because they heard about the amazing human that will save them.  Uh?  Did I miss something?  Did he do something amazing that I'm not aware of?  At least in the original, Charlton Heston was the only human that could speak.  This ability made him stand out from the rest.  In this version, all humans could speak.  What's so great about Marky Mark?  That's right, he "came from the stars" to save them all.(4) Does anyone else find it extremely cheesy that a chimpanzee lands in a spaceship and saves the day?  Ridiculous.(5) The ending reminded me too much of "Conquest of..." and "Battle for.."
I hope there is no sequel, but I'm sure there will be.  I just pray that Tim Burton does not shame himself again by directing the follow-up.

Review title: Formulaic movies are popular these days...
Review_body: Anyone care to tell me where they got the horses from?  Were there horses on the ship when it crashed?  Were there gorillas?  Hmm, I don't seem to remember them being there...  Not that gorillas could leap 30 feet into the air anyway.  And someone find me that computer - it can tell what the year is even through a time-warp!So we go through this horrid excuse for a movie not really ever knowing the names of more than maybe 3 characters - I managed to pick up 2.  And to boot, Estella Warren has like 10 lines in the movie - she's basically Darth Maul all over again, but with a supermodel body instead of a lightsaber. Character development, which is crucial to any good story, is completely lacking - some characters sort of get a real cheesy and formulaic revelation near the end, but the hero and antagonist stay the exact same throughout the whole movie.Sure, everyone's saying "well, they were up against a lot when they decided to re-make an old classic," which is true, but they didn't make a good movie - they just took the standard sci-fi / horror / action movie plotline and put apes in the place of villans.  It's a formula and it's really really sad, and regardless of what movie they're trying to remake, going with the standard formula will satisfy the masses, but it won't ever be a "good" movie.

Review title: Great tribute to a classic film
Review_body: This movie is a stunning tribute to the original films.  Tim Burton took elements of the original story and created something surprisingly new. Tim Burton, as always, demonstrates incredible cinematography; the ape makeup is near perfect; and the acting is fine (Tim Roth as Thade is particularly good). People complain about it's "plot holes" and "confusing ending".  The movie doesn't conflict with itself, does it?  Since when are movie makers required to spell out every detail of the story they are telling? It's not as good as the original, but it's got a lot going for it. Don't let the whiners who are afraid to think about a movie after it's over convince you not to check it out..

Standard Hollywood action fare which we have numerous times seen before. The film is completely flat and predictable with zero originality. Canned food, as opposed to a delicious meal that one might expect.

Review title: A horrible re-make of a classic
Review_body: This movie has fails to create any sense of empathy towards its human characters.  There is absolutely no reason to care for the humans aside from the fact that they look like us.  Very poor script. I have no idea why Tim Burton let this script, with its crappy dialogue (I'm going to get my chimp!) be realized into a film that will waste millions of people's lives as they sit in darken theaters for no reason.

I had extremely high expectations when i entered the theatre, for the first 3 quarters of the film, my expectations were being fulfilled, however.... with the last quarter i became a tad bit disappointed. Aside from the ending, i would say that it was a pretty good movie.

I was pretty satisfied after walking out of Planet of the Apes, and I couldn't see how many could outright complain about the movie. Then I heard it...for the first of many times..."It's not like the original". How many people walked into this movie expecting to see the original? These people should have saved some time and effort and rented the original. For those of us wanting a fresh look at the story, we couldn't be disappointed. You have Mark Wahlberg and Tim Roth doing outstanding jobs...especially Tim Roth. You have fantastic make up work by Rick Baker. You have Charlton Heston making one of the most ironic statements in history about guns. What more could you ask for? Possibily a little more of Tim Burton's touch, but that isn't a huge complaint...it is still a fantastic movie, even without some of Tim's signature looks. If you aren't expecting to see this movie and watch the original all over again, then this movie is for you. If you want the original, just redone with Mark Wahlberg, rent the original and use your imagination. To make up for the lack of Tim Burton's touch in this movie, I would suggest following this up with Sleepy Hollow.

I remember that the original Planet of the Apes frightened me badly the first time I saw it- the first image of gorillas on horseback bearing firearms was an effective attention-getter.  If nothing else, Tim Burton's new APES carries the torch in this respect- even though I knew what was coming, the gorillas, orangutans and assorted other talking simians repeatedly raised the hair on my own neck, especially Tim Roth's incredibly athletic and menacing Thade.  On top of that, Burton manages to throw in quite a bit of humor, including some goofball nods to the original APES. The sets of course are magnificent, and so are the makeup and effects.  The SciFi sensibility of this version, however, is lacking (especially compared to how far ahead of its time the original was).  The beginning of the film has a rushed feel to it, and there are some plot holes regarding space travel and basic physics that will turn off many hardline SciFi fans.  All in all, though, summer audiences don't ask too much of their summer blockbusters, and this one delivers on that count.  Never a dull moment, lots to look at, and the simians in this version are a LOT more ape-like. The acting achievements of Roth and Bonham-Carter are amazing, and steal a lot of thunder from the human co-stars, including Wahlberg (who unfortunately for his female audience never appears bare-chested... sorry girls).  7 out of 10.

I really enjoyed this movie. This is an entertaining film.Mark Wahlberg played superb. Of course the original is better, but it is definitely worth watching.The costumes are very well made and the surroundings look also very real. I give this movie a 9 out of 10

"Why can't we all get along?" the Rodney King ape asks. Maybe it's because Hollywood insists on doing awful re-makes of classic movies! There is NOTHING worth seeing in this film (except, maybe, Charlton Heston's cameo). The remake is cliché-ridden, wholly predictable, and the ending makes no sense whatsoever . Why would anyone even THINK of tampering with a work of art like the original version of the Planet of the Apes? Avoid this travesty of a movie and rent the video of the 1968 classic.

Review title: Uneven, but by no means horrible
Review_body:
I have never seen the original Planet of the Apes nor its numerous sequels. So, I wasn't going into this movie expecting to not have any "cult-classic" expectations dashed upon the rocks.  I was hoping that 1) This film earned its "Directed by Tim Burton" tag, 2) I wanted a half-way intelligent story, and 3) I wanted to marvel at the monkey (excuse, me, *ape*) makeup.Let me take those points in reverse.  You've probably heard that the makeup is incredible.  Well, it is.  Different species of simians are represented, from baboon to monkey to chimpanzee, and the "evolved" forms represented in the movie are pulled off well.  But it would be for naught if the actors themselves couldn't "get into character."  Let me tell you, the ape cast did superb jobs.  Mr. Roth, playing the villain general Thade, should get an award; his imitations of simian mannerisms (pawing of his comrades, wild vine-climbing screeching fits of anger) were spot-on.  Helena Botham-Carter kept up with her costar in her role of human beneficiary; she would toggle back and forth between heated intelligent arguments on the worth of humans and "ooh ooh ooh ah! ah! aaahh!"-ing when she'd panic.  Ok, that's exaggerating, but you get the idea.Story-wise?  Ehh... I think I would have liked it better if we were focused on the monkeys rather than the "spaceman".  Mark Wahlberg (sp?) was decent, but he was a bit rough in some parts, and when the movie trailed behind him and his rag-tag bunch as they fled the city, it dragged.  When the focus switched back to the apes (especially Thade), you had interesting dialog exchanges, wonderful acting, and a generally more interesting movie.
Are you going to this movie to see a Tim Burton movie?  ... Well, you *may* be disappointed somewhat.  I didn't get the Tim Burton feel like I did watching "Sleepy Hollow".  But if you go in simply expecting to see a well-directed movie, you'll probably like it better.  Burton fans need to draw their own conclusions, but it felt like the movie was being directed by someone else, though someone equal to the task.Bottom line: It's not the best film.  But it's a good film.  I didn't feel like I wasted $7.00 seeing it in the theater.  I hope you don't, either.
Rating: 7/10

i was hoping for so much more than this from a director as good as tim burton, but i left the cinema extremely disappointed. visually this film is impressive, you can see nearly all the budget being shown on the screen, the apes themselves are very convincing. the main problems lie firstly in the acting (the apparent love between Estella Warren and Mark Wahlberg is laughably unconvincing).... only Tim Roth and Helena Bonham Carter show any form of skill... the second problem is the terrible script which doesn't waste it's time in resorting to cliche and annoying post-modern referential dialog.... and the ENDING(!) is the biggest load of rubbish I've ever had the misfortune to witness this film pales in comparison to the originals

Review title: I Never Imagined It Could Be So Bad
Review_body: Planet of the Americans - This is what happens when you take a film with substance and put it through the hollywood machine.   Buy the best special effects - the respected director - the British Act-ToRRs - the composers - the make-up and the most hyped STAR.This film was agonising to watch.  It was as though someone had fed the plot summary into an American English word processor and pressed the button "Generate Script".Classic lines such as "I'm having a bad hair day" , "C'mon Guys! Let's Go, I have an idea, We've only got one shot!" and "OK kiddies who wants some asprin"This film was Dumbed Down for its (12) rating which must surely be referring to the IQ of the writer.  So entirely predictable were the plot twists that I almost fell asleep.I give this movie Zero.

There's only one thing worse than paying $8.50 for a movie that has an axe to grind:  a movie with APES doing the axe-grinding.It's hard enough to suspend one's disbelief and get into this whole farce based, essentially, on Darwinistic evolution (which in itself is nothing more than ideological dogma, rather than anything truly scientific).  But to believe, in a "relativistic universe," where we all supposedly evolved by pure chance without intelligent design nor moral purpose, a BEAST like an ape is going to develop a moral sense and espouse a knowledge of "right and wrong" (where this came from is never stated) is just laughable.  And this is almost how the movie comes off.I would have been more able to suspend my disbelief had the apes--ALL the apes, been truly beasts.  It would have been horrific and been, FINALLY, this remake's only shot at equalling (let alone improving over) its 1968 original by creating a more potent nightmare.  Instead, it tries to re-create the original's formula--as if any of us would still be "oh'd" by the notion that this "actually could happen."Been there, done that.So, instead of exploiting the truly hellish potential of this concept, we are constantly reminded that this is a remake.  No risks are taken.  No opportunity missed to "sensitize our political ignorance" (thanks, Ms. Ape). For lessons on creating a masterful (read 'believable') science-fiction world, the makers should have studied Ridley Scott's ALIEN and BLADE RUNNER, or Cameron's TERMINATOR series.

Well, this film is Planet of the Apes in name alone.  Well, and the fact that it's about a Planet.  With Apes on it.  For anyone who has read the book, the original book, you'll know what I mean.  It bares no relation whatsoever to the original premise.  The humans talk (wtf?) and the apes appear to have evolved from genetically modified chimps in a few thousand years (yes, all of them.  Including the Orangs and Gorillas.  There are two types of chimp too).  The defined political structure has also been chucked out the window.  And the ending?  What the hell is that meant to be?Anyway, if you haven't seen the originals (been on Soror for 100 years or something) and haven't read the book, then you might as well see this.  The acting is good, and it's semi decent if you don't care about the original stuff.  There are some good moments and nice SFX.  But, it's tripe.  Next thing you know there will be a Star Wars film set in 1960's Chicago...

This movie was a real letdown.  I was expecting so much more from Tim Burton.  All this movie did for me was help me to appreciate the original that much more.  Whatever it was that made the original movie work is absent in this remake.  Burton's 'Planet of the Apes' is a rental at best.

As a fairly big fan of both the original Apes movies and Tim Burton, not to mention the novel, Tim Roth, Helena Bonham-Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan, etc, I had high hopes going into this movie. I don't think I could have been more let down.I, unlike many others, will back up my feelings. What is the sense of setting up the big battle between Apes and Humans if it's not going to happen? It's a complete waste of screen time.As for the ending, I suppose that Burton and/or the studio wanted to have something of the shock value that the Statue of Liberty had in the original and set themselves up for a franchise of sequels, but this one ruins all logical sense of the movie. If Leo traveled back in time instead of forward (That's what I took the ending to mean, anyways...) how did human civilization exist BEFORE the Apes'? How were there guns before guns were invented? And how do apes believe in Hell before Dante wrote the Inferno? As in "Damn them to Hell."

The original Planet of the Apes was a brilliant satire of human nature that touched upon such themes as how man treats animals, how science being led by religion leads to nothing, and of course mankind's ability to destroy themselves. Every moment in the film was earned through a slow and effective pacing, good dialogue, and a horrific visual ending that put a chilling exclamation mark on everything the movie had been saying throughout.Tim Burton's new Planet of the Apes valiantly tries to make some of these same points again but never lets it sink effectively in our minds due to choppy dialogue, non-existent characterization, and a tacked on ending that will again cause a lot of discussion. But not in the way the filmmakers intended.The good parts of this film are how it plays with your expectations of the original. Hearing some of the classic Apes lines said in a new way gives the audience some laughs. Charleton Heston plays with his own role by being an ape in this film, and getting to talk about some of the film's best themes of humanity's power of invention and destruction. (I'm sure Heston never imagined being in another Apes movie, especially after convincing the producers of the original series to let him blow up the planet...) The apes themselves are reimagined in a spectacular way. The different species are more noticable and the primal way they move and interact with one another is better in the original making them seem more animal like. Some of the plot is revealed in effective and believable, at least as much as can be for a film of this type, ways. The setup of the film is compelling and effective enough. Which unfortunately makes the payoff more dissapointing.The bad parts of the film start to show up as more and more characters begin interacting. Characters are introduced in as simple of terms as possible. Their is no shading of these characters. Characters also seem to come to grips with difficult choices, change their views of the world, or suddenly change character with no effort at all. All this seems to stem from what seems to me to be someone wanting to show us 'cool moments' and then not knowing what to do with the characters after. SPOILERS: Examples being when an ape gets a human girl as a pet. Our heroes rescue the girl and then LEAVE THEM WITH THE APES! If you don't want your daughter around apes, don't leave them with them. Characters dies with no effect on anyone. Apes scar one another with no explanation really given other then to create a 'cool visual moment' later in the film. Suddenly a character becomes rebellious and almost ruins our heroes chances. Since this wasn't effectively established into a character I liked, or let alone noticed. I didn't care and really hoped the apes would get him. An ape's entire religion changes in a split second and it doesn't seem to effect him. The secret of the planet can work, but is highly, highly unlikely given the information shown to us onscreen. And where do the horses come from? The only explanation for them at all is that they were in the original so they should be in this remake. But having horses in the original makes sense. The climax feels very by the numbers with a huge fight scene that plays too messily. And we have our hero kiss both women, way to make a choice screenwriters. And the ending is the worst of these 'cool moments' of all. A shock ending was written just to have a shock ending. I know the ending is true to the original novel but the original novel didn't really earn that ending anyways. This film earns it even less. The original film's ending was truly an extension of everything proceeding it. This ending will cause a lot of division among filmgoers.In the end Planet of the Apes has some great makeup, great physical acting with the way everyone moves, and honestly some cool little moments. But it's script is a great example of bad big budget filmmaking. Huge plot holes that are created through the need for 'cool moments'. With the original film being such a great insight into human nature bringing to the big screen the idea that we are able to destroy ourselves the only thing this film shows us is that Hollywood also has the ability to destroy themselves.

My father bought it on DVD and I watched it with him. The movie was quite good right up to the ENDING!!! The ending basically ruined the movie. If they ended it totally differently, It would have been an awesome ending. The Ending came out of nowhere when all they had to do was end it with Mark Whalberg crashing into his mother ship to make the cycle complete!

Review title: The little movie that could... but didn't.
Review_body:
Planet of the Apes has many things going for it.  The first three are the creative minds of Tim Burton (director), Rick Baker (Make-up), and Danny Elfman (Music).  The sets and locations work well with the costuming and make-up to give this an original look and an authentic feel even though it is a remake.  The cinematography and music work well together because neither one overshadows the other making the combination very powerful.
The acting was good and I must take my hat off to Helena Bonham Carter and to Tim Roth who did exceptional in their portrayals.  The supporting cast didn't stand out like Carter or Roth, but they did a good job of holding their own ground.  Mark Wahlberg's character, Leo Davidson, is the classic military hero who never shows too much emotion because he is trying to stay in control of the situation.  It almost seems that if Wahlberg weren't an actor, he would have actually been this guy.  Estella Warren's character could have easily weighed down the movie by being the typical sexy woman, but thankfully Burton never really draws attention to her in that way: we know she's beautiful, but we don't need to waste 20 minutes of the movie proving it.  She doesn't have any dense lines bent at attracting Wahlberg or any slow motion shots of her character taking a hot bath.  Instead Estella Warren does a good job of playing a character simply caught in the story and reacting in a realistic way.  A personal favorite part of mine was the cameo appearance of Charlton Heston, who almost has the same classic line that he had in the original.The story, though shaky at the beginning, quickly regains its composure and holds the audience's attention.  Once upon the actual planet, there are many satirical references to the way our society has treated animals, the environment, and each other (in cases of slavery).  It is this ability of holding a mirror to society that has made Burton a genius in his craft. Even though the storyline is a tad simple and any audience member can guess or just about guess how the whole story transpired, it doesn't matter because we are trapped in this world and we become interested in the characters interaction with each other.The ending is what could have wrapped up the entire experience into a good movie but didn't.  The last ten minutes of the movie was a horrible attempt at a twist ending.  If you watch closely you can see the movie end, but for some reason, another whole ending is added.  The problem with the second twist ending is that there is no bridge that connects this ending with the rest of the movie, so instead of discovering an ending you didn't even know you were looking for, you leave the theater thinking `Ummm ok, that doesn't make very much sense.'  The storyline should take you from point A to point B, but the ending tells you that you are actually at point C and doesn't attempt in any way, shape, or form to explain how you got there.I gave this movie a 5 because it has the attempt, it just doesn't have the follow through.

Review title: Don´t forget it is a FANTASY movie
Review_body: WARNING! Don´t read if you didn´t see the movie yet!At first I have to say that I didn´t see the original movie yet (shame on me!) but I don´t consider this to be important for this review. As I´m a Tim Burton-Fan, I had to watch the new "Planet of the Apes" - and I liked it.It is a great movie, full of fantastic pictures - the great comic-style, which I love Tim Burton for. The soundtrack is perfect, the special effects are great and , what is the most important: the story is very entertaining and full of suspense.Of course, as many of you did, you could ask many logical questions as: - Why are there horses on the planet? - Why are there different races? - How is it possible for a few humans and two apes to ride through a complete camp of aggressive apes? - Why does the chimp land exactly at the moment when Leo is about to lose his fight? - How is it possible for a small spaceship, to fly from the planet of the apes back to the earth? And why does it only take three minutes? - Why does Estella Warren wear lipstick? - Why is the earth full of apes at the end?I read many questions like this, and of course there are many more you could ask! But please don´t forget, it is a fantasy movie! A fantasy movie doesn´t need to be realistic, and it also doesn´t want to be!Nobody asks why it is possible to hear noises, when space ships in Star Wars shoot at something - although it is impossible to hear noises in space! A fantasy movie lives of exaggerations! Why do you always bother about realism in fantasy films? If you want to watch a realistic movie, then you should watch a drama or something, but no fantasy or science-fiction movie! - Or at least, don´t wonder about exaggerations!Of course it was not a perfect movie. Mark Whalberg really didn´t act very well, and I often asked myself why Estella Warren is in this movie. She is always in the middle of the plot, looking beautiful but speaking only five sentences over the whole movie.But altogether it was a very nice movie. I will have to buy the DVD as soon as it is available!Therefore 8 out of 10.Well, I think I will watch the original movie soon, but I´m not looking forward to compare the movies!

OK, so they can build houses, but cannot build boats or bridges? I'll take that. Space ships power still there? Alright, and all the little fun holes I won't even bother on. The ending? Yuck. A movie where the time travel is worse than what Bill and Ted's excellent adventure, and an ending which tries but fails to get close to the original. Wooo another monument used, how impressive. (snore)

Review title: Summer movie filler...could've been better with more thought and time...
Review_body: A summer movie, popcorn, bad script and cool FX...The Make-up creations by Rick Baker kicked butt!!! But I cannot recommend the 'new' version of 'Planet of the Apes' even for that point. Tim Burton has helmed a film that has the 'taint' of 'HOLLYWOOD' all over it...I was expecting a PIZZA HUT box to show up on the obvious sets...Everyone involved has simply hacked it out...besides the rightious make-up, the only other noteworthy aspect of the film is the decent acting by the actors playing APES...(Especially Tim Roth as the main villian...he was very menacing...) those without make-up had little or nothing to do. Sitting down and thinking it over, I realized that I hated seeing this film, and hope that Tim Burton and all involved will have better luck on their next projects...I'd rather watch 'Dude where's my car?' that sit through this big budget hooey again...4 out of 10

Review title: Had a lot going for it... but ultimately failed
Review_body: I just saw this film (takes a while to come out in Ireland).. and while the special effects were generally excellent, the film was extremely unconvincing.possible SPOILERS to follow:From a technical viewpoint there were many weaknesses, the number of apes in the army? In the initial marching scene there were tens of thousands, which then became about 50 in the all-out melee in front of calima. The fuel cell is another contentious point (one was full and it only managed a light fricassee of the apes... how did the ship move with only 3 of them?). I can forgive a few inconsistencies, but eventually they add up, and I'm left with the feeling that the makers just didn't care. I did feel that the movement of the apes was done very well, the slightly sideways walk, and the many gestures, sniffs and twitches were excellent.In the acting front, Tim Roth was excellently psycopathic... but ALL the time. There was no break even when talking to his father which gave the character a very 2-Dimensional, overly aggressive feeling. The romantic feelings of Helena Bonham-Carter towards our dashing hero was puzzling... surely monkeys find us as sexually attractive as we find them?Estella Warrens part was almost painful, her short dress and revealing top, coupled with very few lines made her simply a female to ogle. The film then attempts to strap on a romantic involvement with Mark Wahlberg at the end? Is there something we've missed? or is he simply regretting not having sex with her.The end, without saying what it was, was overly depressing, and pretty much expected.. what did he think? That going back into a highly unstable random time-jumping storm would bring him home? Oh well...I had high hopes for planet of the apes before I saw the ads (Tim Burton has produced many excellent films).. but I was disappointed with some glaring goofs, some fairly weak plot elements and some confusing characters.

It seems the actors in this movie were so busy portraying apes that they forgot how to deliver a line. Tim Roth over-acted completely, start to finish, and Michael Clarke Duncan under-acted. The ending is also completely out in left field; come on, would the apes really have evolved EXACTLY like we did? I don't think so. Okay, I've just listed all of the flaws with this movie that I can think of. Otherwise, it was well choreographed and had a decent plot. Even Mark Wahlberg did a good job.  I think, given the ending, a sequel will be ridiculous, but there's not much that can be done there. Go see the movie, though. 7 out of 10 stars.

Well, not really... but it was a lot of fun.  For all those who didn't like it, I'm curious what you were expecting.  Did you really expect a movie about angry talking monkeys to be a masterpiece?  Yes, it has it's flaws, but for the most part was well executed.  Tom Rothwas pure evil, some have said that he was "too evil", but isn't that the point of a super-villain?  His character was over the top, and I loved it.  The only real flaw for me was that Mark Whalberg kept slipping into Dirk Diggler, but I was able to ignore him for most of the film.  As for the ending, it was great.  I don't think that it was supposed to be logical, so stop whining!  It was a great over the top way to end an over the top film/concept.  So...go see it, expect to be entertained, not educated and you will love it!

That was a complete waste of time. The script was so jagged, simple and ridiculous that it was almost painful to follow. The visuals like most of Hollywood these days were good, but forced to compensate for the badly written script. May be it was written for an audience of monkeys.

Planet of the Apes was done extremely well for a remake. I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. It was not far-fetched and silly like other recent movies. There was no jumping through glass, and not getting a scratch type movie. And I was not over overwhelmed by so much action and special effects. The special effects were outstanding, and you could sometimes make out the faces of the actors. I give it *** 1/2 stars out of 4.

Review title: Another great film done by Tim Burton
Review_body: I must say I too thought it wasn't going to be all that great a few months ago but when I saw more previews of it and tv spots I began to think it might be good after all. So I finally see it and when I came out of the theater I was very surprised about the ending it made me wonder like most people, but I won't say any more don't want to spoil it. Tim burton has done again just like with all of his other movies he has made in the past this one i think tops them all in my opinion his movies are in a eyecandy way oh and don't let me forget about the great Danny Elfman his music it so great I bought the soundtrack the next day, but I must say it's better then the original I mean Rick Baker did such a fantastic job on the make-up you would sometimes forget that those are actors up their with all this make-up on. I know that some people wouldn't agree but i hope that there is another Planet of The Apes so to speak sequel I would only see it only if Tim Burton direct's it. Well I must give this movie a 10/10 it's by far the best movie I've seen all summer long.

I saw Planet of the Apes last Friday and I got a say that although it's not a bad film, it could have been much better. The film s biggest flaw is that some characters are just plain useless. Especially the boy who always wants to help Leo and Leo's love interest ( he talks to her like 3 times in the whole movie!).On the plus side the acting is pretty good, the special effects are A+ and the ending, while it doesn t have the same impact the original had, wont disappoint you. Tim Burton is known for his great visual style(Sleepy Hollow, Batman) and he does a great job here too.7/10

Being a fan of Tim Burton's, I was highly anticipating the release of this movie. After seeing it, I was definitely not disappointed. Burton's version of "Planet of the Apes" is just as good, if not better than the original idea. He adds just the right mix of action, adventure, and comedy in the movie, making it a thoroughly enjoyable experience throughout. As for Charlton Heston's cameo...that almost made the whole movie for me...absolutely classic. Tim Roth does a fantastic job as Thade, the evil leader of the Ape Army, and the costumes and effects are simply amazing. The ending was an interesting piece...leaving some I know confused. I just smell a possible sequel if things go well for this movie, which it should.

Review title: not Burton´s best, but not bad
Review_body: I must say that I was very dissapointed when I saw this film. The "re-imagine" concept just does not work in the movies (just ask Gus Van Sant). But I thought Burton might make it work. Well, I was wrong. I adore Burtons work and in my personal opinion he is Hollywood´s greatest director, but that does not mean that I love every piece of celluloid that he comes in contact with. POTA has some potentials but somehow they just fizz out. You can never stop asking yourself "Why?" Why make a remake of a near perfect film? If POTA 2001 would have been the first ape film, this might have been hailed as a great film. The fact simply is that we have seen this before. And what what is Burton doing with a comic relief?! Limbo is doing the same for this movie as Jar Jar did for Episode one! He is to much, to "haha funny" and should have been killed when the humans escaped. But no, we have to endure him throughout the whole film! The movie does have some good points though. First of all it has Tim Roth. He is without a doubt the best actor in this film and his ape impression is at times very frightening. The sets, costumes and everything in that department was impeccable, in a Burtonian way. There have been some who say that the make up in this film is no better than in the original. That is pure nonsense. I am inclined to think that these people are only blinded by some hate of Burton and his POTA and for fouling the memory of the original that they can´t give credit where credit is due! The makeup in this movie is sheer brilliance. The movement of the actors lips are now visible and so are other discreet features. This is better make up and saying otherwise just underlines that some people can´t judge films without letting feelings cloud there judgement. Last words. See the film at least two times. The initial shock wears off an you like it better the next time.

This is the only movie I ever walked out of angry.  Tim Burton took the idea of the original (which was great) and turned it into one of the most expensive crap piles ever assembled.  I hated this movie!!!!!!!!!!! And the ending?  Don't get me started, don't even get me started!

Review title: Hollywood has a hopeless predilection for ripping itself off during the 21st century
Review_body: The original PotA movies will eternally be ground-braking, epic and timeless. Once you've reached the top of your game there's nowhere else to go but downhill. It's a fool's errand attempting to improve upon perfection. Stop with these unnecessary unwarranted jackass remakes marketed solely to millennials including their hokey cartoonish CGI embellishments.

I really liked this version of 'Planet of the Apes'. The costumes were excellent and the acting was very well done but I was really p***ed off with the ending. I feel the lead up to the ending needed to be explained more. Over all it was a good movie.

I have no idea how people could bash a movie like this. Movies like these (ESPECIALLY Sci-Fi movies) are very rare, and i must admit, when I was walking into the theatre, I thought this was going to be an awful movie ripping off the previous "Planet of the Apes". I was so wrong.The movie starts off with Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) in a USAF Starbase that experiences a strange nebula. The captain sends out one of Leo's monkeys to explore the nebula, but they lose contact with the monkey. Leo jumps in another spaceship and goes looking for the monkey (Which was very strange in the beginning, but they had to get him on the planet somehow, I guess). When he gets trapped in the nebula, he goes forward in time and lands on an alien planet (Unlike the previous movie, where Leo lands on a futuristic earth). He encounters a group of humans who are running from the apes. Leo is very confused, which becomes a major point for the beginning of the movie.The film is a direct remake from the original, but is much darker, thanks to the wonderful directing of Tim Burton. He captured the atmosphere from the previous film perfectly, but he also added a bit of an extra touch by making the apes seem much more menacing. The performances aren't Oscar-worthy, but they aren't bad (Including Mark Wahlberg, who I think was always a good actor since his starring role in the movie "Boogie Nights), and the make-up by Rick Baker is sure to get him an Academy Award. The music by Danny Elfman is amazing (Including the opening theme, which in my opinion is probably one of my top 5 themes) and it perfectly captures the atmosphere in the movie. But probably the most controversial point in the movie is the ending. It was either you understood it, or you didn't. Luckily, I was one of the people that understood it, and it almost made the movie for me. But without spoiling any of the ending, let me just say this: It's very sequel-friendly (Which in my case is a good thing)Review: ****1/2 / *****

I have to admit that this "re-imagining" of the original 1968 film was a huge disappointment. Specially when taken into consideration that this is a Tim Burton film. He is defenetly one of the most original and, might I say, cool directors Hollywood has produced.I am personally a great fan of his work, but something obviously went wrong with his latest flick, The Planet of the Apes. I really enjoyed the original film. When it first came out people expected just another cheezie 70's science fiction film, but a very surprise anding totally proved that theory wrong. It had indeed a clear cut message. An obvious anti-war message. Fear of the cold war, where it was taking the world and fear of the use of nuclear weapons played a big role in the mind of the film-makers. Those reasons made the film rise above all expectations and it became a instant classic. Although, the new film, the "re-making" or whatever, leaves us with nothing. No message, no ideals behind it. It is just another money-minded summer blockbuster.Visually Tim Burton does not let you down. The dark and creepy settings were excellent and of course the make up was terrific.Obviously that is not enough to keep people intrested in a film. There has to be an exciting plot or storyline. In this movie the plot is highly uninteresting and it is extremely badly thought out. The script is very lame and it is full of gaps. It looks like this film had been written in a big hurry. The explanation for why the apes where there, and why the ruled the planet was indeed very stupid and proved the script-writers ignorance.It raised a lot of questions, which had no reasonable answers to.For example; Why did the apes speak English?, why were there other ape-species than chimps on the planet (given that there were only chimps in the space ship that crash-landed on the planet) Where the hell did all of those humans come from? How were a few chimps able to evolve into a huge raise of all kinds of monkeys in only a few thousands years. (I mean it took a few million years for us to evolve from monkey to man!)And finally, the bad surprise ending was just plane dumb. It was probably just thrown in because the original film had such an  end, then they felt that the audience were expecting the same kind of ending. The ending also raises a lot of questions, which I KNOW, don´t have intelligent answears. Did Theid learn to work the space ship?, which was power-less, and learnt to fly back in time and take over the earth single hand?, and, what did he do, breed with all the women? And lets say that that would happen, I higly doubt that history would stay the same, like Washington would be built exactly like it is today! (I mean wouln't there be a huge banana instead of the memorial?)Well, just to say something posative about  the film. Some of the cast was great. Helen Bonham Carter's character was interesting and well-acted, as for Tim Roth as Theid. He was very good, a little exaturated at some points of the film. Michael Clark Duncan  was also fine. I was not happy with Marc Whalberg. He is not much of an actor, and plays here a very macho colour-less character. Very unbielevable and is nothing compared to Hestons character in the original. And the main female character had no reason or place in the film. She was just casted for the looks. Hardly said a word throughout the entire film.Well, I think that in the future when people think about the Planet of the apes, they will think about the original one. The latest will soon be forgotten.

"Planet of the apes" was good film, it was not a great film like the 1968 classic and in fact it was horbble remake. Most of you  have probbly seen the original "Planet of the Apes" so i wont bother explaining the plot. But while I was watching this remake I was wandering, why did Tim Burton direct this? As I said this was a good film but, Tim Burton has directed some great films like "Edward Scissor Hands" and "Sleepy Hollow" It should have been directed by somebody else since this was a remake the whole movie was laid out, so Tim Burtons brains were wasted. But still it is a good popcorn movie witch can be viewed by the entire family.

Review title: The only thing I didn't like about this movie was what the adolescent character was asked to do.
Review_body: I recently saw this movie and was surprised to find a line.  This was the first time I had ever waited in a line to see a movie.  It was especially noteworthy because I live in a moderate size town. The stuntmen in this movie seem to be trying out for "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon".  At the same time they made it look very simian.  I thought this movie was well done.  It is a little too dark most of the time but I'm pretty sure this is on purpose.  There is one problem with this movie that I noticed.  Actually I've been noticing it for years.  That problem is the adolescent actor (in this case Luke Eberle).  For the past years both televison and Hollywood have written two main types of characters for adolescent actors.  In the first type the adolescent character is told to: go in the house, go over there, etc.  Why is it that the "adult" actors are afraid for the adolescent characters to be an integral part of the defense of the home or whatever the movie entails.  The second type is where the adolescent character either is allowed to help or just does.  However, the "adult" character either has to fix what the adolescent character did or save the adolescent character from death etc.  This movie is no different.  In it the Luke Eberle character is basically told to go hide by Mark Wahlberg.   The Luke character then refuses and decides to try and help.  Then in typical fashion the Mark Wahlberg character has to save the Luke character from certain death.  When is the establishment and the "adult" actors going to realize that adolescent characters actually can  help in defense situations and many other situations as well?  I realize that many of these adolescent actors have not "paid their dues" yet but to me that is a terrible reason to perpetuate a stereotype.  For that is indeed what it is.  So even though this movie perpetuates both of these stereotypes I think it is still a rather good movie.  However, it could have been better had the writers filled the stereotype spot with something important.

Review title: Started off strong, then got really bad really fast
Review_body: This movie, especially the ending, was very poor.  It started out very promising, and I certainly enjoyed the crew seeing it's own future transmission.  After that part, though, the movie went completely downhill. Estella Warren, as far as I can tell, was in the movie solely to get young teenage boys to come out to the movie for the eye candy.  The ending was especially bad.  How does Thade exist in 2329 AND 2029.  It just doesn't make any sense, any way you slice it.  I'm also wondering if Tim Burton joined PETA just before the making of this movie, because the ethical treatment of animals message was really, really heavy-handed.

I found nothing noteworthy in this movie. The story line was ok. The acting was competent. The effects were good, but not outstanding given today's technology.This movie managed to get campy at times without having any redeeming qualities to compensate for it. It struck me as very politically correct and thus didn't really have anything to say.It is a simple action flick, and an average one at that.It is immediately forgettable, except perhaps for the ending which breaks any chance of the movie being self consistent.

I was fired up to see this movie.  I went right away so no one could spoil the surprise ending.  I was extremely disappointed in the film and urge you to save your 9 bucks.  For the record, I think the original was excellent. Here are the main reasons why this movie falls short. (No spoilers) - Many plot holes - Cheesy humorous references to the first movie...why is this necessary? Apparently, they rightly felt that this movie couldn't stand on it's own. - Stereotypical bad guy (ape) - Stereotypical good guy( female ape , made up to look like Janet Jackson) - Drags at times. - Gratuitous "surprise" ending...not well thought out and inserted merely for the sake of having a surprise ending like the good, first movie.Rent it when it comes out and you'll see what I mean...or better yet, go rent the original.

after i got out of the movie with my friends, we all were trying to figure out what the end was , it was very confusing and made me dislike the movie, but now  that i have been home for like an hour the ending makes more sense and i know understand what happend and now im thinking how great this movie is, if you go see it watch out, its a thinker. but an 8/10

Let me start by saying that I am a huge Tim Burton fan. I consider his visions on film absolutely fantastic! I see Tim's hand in about  the first 2/3rds of this film.The last  1/3rd seems like the work of "suits" rather than "artists. While the film has a certain awesome visual style-give Rick Baker the Academy Award for Makeup right now-we are constantly challenged to suspend disbelief for shallow plot points and trite dialog. Forget character development. Forget logic and check your brain with your ticket stub. The ending (which I will not reveal here so as not to spoil for those who have not seen yet) is a nightmare. I understand that there were possibly 5-7 different endings- maybe a DVD Special Edition or definitive director's cut could make more sense than this "barrel of  monkeys." Hollywood get original. Less effects more story. No  more sequels - I'm feeling sick.

***SPOILERS AHEAD****Ok, I read a little bit about this movie before i saw it and went in not looking for the original. I liked the original, the best part being the ending which tied everything together - just like a movie should be done.
Now i go into this one knowing that is will be different, and was enjoying it for the most part. One thing i cant figure is how a monkey can make a perfect landing on one try and the Air Force pilot crashes twice? Aside from that i enjoyed the movie very much. I am not one to blast acting so other reviews i have read talking about the acting does not bother me as long as it is not terrible and this was not. The costumes were very good, action good all in i would have given the movie about an 8 or better.............until the end. Someone has to explain this to me. I am totally lost. This ending put a rotten cherry atop a very good sundae. The story till the last 5 minutes was great things made sense everyone was able to follow along till that ending.The only thing i can think of is DVD sales. You throw in deleted scenes and alternate endings and sell a ton of DVDs.

Review title: Boooo, Mr. Burton, Boooo indeed. SPOILERS
Review_body: I have been a big Planet of the Apes fan since I was very little. It is the first "grown-up movie" that I can remember watching. So you can imagine my excitement when this remake was announced.You can imagine that my excitement was doubled when I learned that Tim Burton would direct! And  can you believe it they even hired one of my favorite actors of all time Tim Roth to play a starring role.Now Imagine if you will that it "stinked"!!!!!They spent millions on elaborate sets and costumes and years in production, just to miss the whole point of the original movie: The "Planet" of the Apes was EARTH! You know the whole reverse evolution thingy ... What was Burton thinking!?! I'll admit that if this was an original movie I would have liked it, but it's not! There are certain elements of any classic that just shouldn't be messed with.Maybe if they would have changed the name a little, say "Ape Planet" or "Marky Mark goes Ape" or "Clash of the Vertebrates"Boooo, Mr. Burton, Boooo indeed.WAIT FOR THE VIDEO!

This is the movie I have been waiting for 30 years to see, ever since I peeked over the back seat of the station wagon at the drive in theater waiting for Doctor Dolittle (http://us.imdb.com/Title?0061584) to start.  I was five years old, and this was before the days of real ratings.  Besides, the original Apes movie was rated an amazing 'G' as was that other talking animal film we went to see.That said, I was terribly disappointed in the 2001 re-visioning of the 'Planet of the Apes'.  Tim Burton is one of my favorite cutting-edge directors, and Danny Elfman a top composed.  The cast looks excellent - on paper, but in reality the characters are mainly one dimensional and shallow. The possible exception is Helena Bonham Carter as Ari, who at least seemed to have fun playing a rather muppet-like Chimp/Human rights activist. Burton didn't dare go anywhere but the obvious places, and even with the attempt at a surprise twist ending (which left me slack jawed at the sheer disconnectedness of it).  There were so many opportunities to build these characters in an otherwise visually stunning universe.  Would it be bestiality for two sapient members of different species to actually explore their apparent sexual tension that Burton was trying to portray?  Could it have been possible for Daena (Estella Warren) to do anything other than pine and heave her fur-bikinied breasts about?  There was a real opportunity to explore something here that Burton ignored.  And Burton usually hits these on the head.The first ape line of the film made me dread what was an otherwise decent start to the movie.  I won't reveal what it is, but it was too obvious an attempt to try to a) make you laugh, b) set the tone of the film, and c) nod to the original film.Overall, I give this film a 3 out of 10 for an overall impression.  I give Rick Baker a 10 out of 10 for an AMAZING bunch of creatures.  I give Mark Wahlberg (Capt. Leo Davidson) a -2 out of 10 for mailing in his performance and avoiding any sort of commitment to his role.  Helena Bohnam Carter (Ari) gets a 7 out of 10 for her role, and Tim Roth (General Thade) gets 8 out of 10 for being a peeved chimpanzee and a vicious character, and making me truly dislike him.  Or was it the complete shallowness of his character that I hated?  Wait, I give Tim Roth an 8, and I subtract two points from Tim Burton for not allowing such a fine villain to have any depth for a total Tim Burton score of 3 out of 10.  Visually, the film gets 8 out of 10 from me.Nutshell summary:  A mediocre attempt worth seeing for the makeup and soundtrack, and for the uncomfortable laugh at the end when you realize how much Hollywood is spending to produce crap these days.  This film is definitely worth a rental, but save yourself the $8.50 to see it in the theater.

Review title: Remake of "Fistful of dollars" using Klingons?
Review_body: Tim Roth's "original" villian seems to stem from the touchy-feely evil Ramon/Indio villain in "Fistful of dollars/Few dollars more" spaghetti westerns (titles which sum up what this remake is all about). The bonanza of great effects make for great entertainment but the lack of a visionary story make this a one-dimensional kid's movie which won't stick in the brain for adults. There is no "discussion" on the moral/philosphical place of man in the universe: in the original book/movie, our hero is clearly divided since he neither fits in with the future's primitive humans nor the apes. This version is just another uncompelling "Us vs. Them," and the war-like gorillas sound and look like Klingons in "Star Trek." Speaking of gorillas, whom did they evolve from since there were originally only chimps? Where do they live, since there are too many for that hilltown? Where did the modern-speaking humans come from if the caucasian astronauts all died? Why does the blonde babe keep ducking out of scenes - does she have a bladder like a thimble? And are we on earth in the far future or far past? Or another dimension? This last plot problem ruins the great visual ending (try as it might to be like the book's end). The soundtrack also doesn't credit it's inspiration to the better original. For those who absurdly claim we need remakes because kids won't watch the originals, it was we kids who loved the original enough to generate 4 sequels, a live-action and animated TV series, lunch boxes, etc. and inspire Tim Burton.

The movie was decent, not great but good enough to be a good remake. I'm a Tim Burton fan, and while I think that this is not his best film, it's still worthy enough to be a part of his work. The make up is great, and Tim Roth probably gave the best performance of a villain I have seen in quite some time.It's good but it needed a better Story.

Review title: Whoever wrote this needs to be shot.
Review_body: The movie looks amazing.  The story is one of the lamest I've seen in a while.  There little or no character involvement and the little that they did, was super weak.  The script was crap and I'm really suprized that Tim Burton would have let it slide.  I'm really suprised at how disappointed I was with this film.  Really suprised!

I have NEVER ever been do disgusted/disappointed with a movie. (Well, there was that Artificial Intelligence movie that made me laugh SO hard @ the end I had to plug my nose from laughing so hard so the REST of the people in the audience wouldn't hate me, since most of them were INTO it.!!)Please don't see this movie. It's stupid. There's nothing good about it except the makeup/costume bit. The ending was ridiculous. The acting made me vomit. There was *no* character development, and the character you DID get developed to was that stupid Chimp, who by the time made his second appearance, you wanted to leave.Come on. Really? I want my money back.

The story is not quite as good as the first film, but is definitely alot of fun to watch. The one downfall of the film is the overall substance of the human beings and their relationship with one another.  It was pretty cold in that area.  I would have given the lead to a different actor other than Mark Wahlberg. His character needed to be as big as the apes in the film.  And the apes in this film were just as good as the characters in the first movie.  Super makeup by Rick Baker and the sets looked fantastic.  One final note...I wish the battle scene at the end had more substance and a little more thought put into it.  This would have given the film its climax that it badly needed.

Review title: Good, but did anyone understand the ending?
Review_body: To sum it all up the movie was alright, I wasn't expecting to be as good as the originals, but I just wanted to go see a film to see some good action...and excellent makeup.  I gave it a 6/10, it would've been rated possibly a 7 or a 8, but the ending was confusing...and I still don't get it....

Tim Burton... Planet of the Apes... what could be a better combination? Well, pretty much anything. I was very disappointed by this movie. First the good - it is visually stunning, as you would expect from a Burton movie; there are a couple of good performances, particularly Helena Bonham Carter who is outstanding. Sadly that's it.Now let's get to the bad and the ugly. The story is so full of plot holes that you'll weep with anger. Didn't anyone bother to read the script? Its nonsense. Characters do things that are obviously absurd and have no internal logic. An example (warning: very minor spoiler), when they get to a river crossing guarded by part of the Ape army, Leo tells us that they can't go around because they don't have time - they have to ride through. But then they wait hours until the dead of night before doing that. The only reason they wait is to make the visuals of the "ride through the camp" scene more dramatic. This makes no sense. It is literally nonsense. And don't even get me started on the ending... its meaningless.Its not just one scene, almost every point in the movie is gibberish if you think about it for more than 2 seconds.Beyond that the characterizations are non-existent. Apart from Leo and a couple of the apes, no one has a character. Who on earth are the humans? What motivates them? Would we care about them if they all got thrown into a giant meat grinder? No we would not.What is most annoying is that this could have been a great movie. The visual execution is stunning. The apes look real and move as you would expect an evolved ape to. They must have spent so many hours and so much money on that aspect of the film. Why did they only spend 26 minutes and $2.80 on the script?Finally, however much of a cliche it has become and however cheesy the costumes where, the 1968 film at least tried to be about something and its famous ending was genuinely related to the point of the film and was truly shocking. The new Planet of the Apes has no point; its ending is a crass setup for a sequel. What a waste of a great potential.

Review title: Could someone please turn on a light?
Review_body: Ugh!!!  Aside from some inventive costumes and makeup, this movie blows. That is, when you can actually see what is going on.  Predictably, the sets were dark in an attempt to make it appear foreboding.  But, my God, the writing was atrocious -- and that blonde with the bee-stung lips......! I did enjoy Helena Bonham Carter, but she was one of just a few bright spots in the film.  Marky Mark was so-so, but Tim Roth was WAY over the top.  It was cartoonish.  The first 15 minutes of this film was so badly written and acted, I nearly walked out of the theater.

I can't understand why so famous and really talented director as Tim Burton can take so obviously poor screenplay and made this rubbish!Hey! It's not much better then BATTLEFIELD EARTH! Sometimes I thought it was directed by Ed Wood, but with mega-budget.Great make-up, and really evil Tim Roth can't save movie where we have no Tim Burton's style, indifferent Mark Whalberg in title role, terrible plot holes and, at last, silly finale.I was very, very disappointed! Rating 3/10.

I still cannot believe that the users of the IMDB have given this crap a rating of 6.4.  I will say this: the performances were good, there was nothing especially WRONG with the directing, and the effects and makeup were everything that you would expect, but in many respects, this drivel reminds me of another ill-conceived sci-fi project.  You could probably guess what that is by the title of my comment.Battlefield Earth has been panned non-stop by critics all over the world, but is this really much better?  Come on...This film's ending is the most incoherent copout I've seen in years.  The script is completely unoriginal, the action sequences are muddled and unexciting, and the attempts at comedy are cringe-worthy.  Both are big budget mistakes.  The only difference is that this one was successful (and ok...maybe not quite so laughable).
