The fact that this film has at this point grossed around $US350 million internationally is a huge indictment on the intelligence of your average human being.  If you haven't seen it yet, don't.  If you want some decent sci-fi entertainment, see Jurassic Park 3.  It may not be the epitome of originality, but at least it delivers what it says it will.Tim Burton was, until this film, a symbol of originality, style, and great black humour, but this could just as easily have been directed by Michael Bay (except he'd probably find some way to sneak in a dogfight between the apes and humans in F-15s so there'd be more explosions).To Mark Wahlberg, pick better projects.To John Travolta, you're finally almost off the hook.

Review title: Apart from Helen Bonham Carter, there is nothing worthy about this movie.
Review_body: Apart from Helen Bonham Carter, there is nothing worthy about this movie....And the surprise ending?! The thought of a sequel is even more annoying. Save your money, wait for the video and ignore that too.

The trailers were good, and I'd heard that it was supposed to be a good movie. Unfortunately, I left the cinema quite disappointed.The costumes and make-up was magnificent! The special effects were very good (though we're all becoming used to computer generated special effects these days, aren't we??)But the story was pathetic and poorly acted. Disappointing, even.

When I heard all the critics bitching about how terrible the new Planet of the Apes movie was, I was unfazed. I knew that there would at least be the signature Burton touches I love so much to get me through a poor script. Imagine my distress when I found none. The movie had great potential; I don't know what went wrong! Mark Whalberg, Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth are all spectacular actors, but here they were either cardboard cutouts, or merely annoying. Sleepy Hollow, for example, was not a great movie by any means, but at least it had Burton's flair and imagination. I'm sorry to see that one of my favourite directors of all time has now jumped on the Gus Van Sant bandwagon (I'm referring, of course, to that normally amazing director's stinker of a Psycho remake). If there was anything good to be said about this movie, I would tell you.

Dont waste your time with this film, its crap and a waste of money, the effects are the only thing to its credit. its filled with long boring scenes, which all result in a boring film and the ending is the worst ive seen 2 date, COME UP WITH SOMETHING ORIGIONAL GODDAMN IT!If ya wanna see a good version of this watch the old one, its better directed, better acted, and a better story by far!#

Review title: Nothing compared to original but worth seeing. Kept me entertained.
Review_body: The film was nothing compared to the original BUT you have to understand that going in.  Otherwise, it kept me interested and entertained even though it left alot to be desired.  I rated it a solid 6 - its worth seeing.

It's not good as the original but still a fun ride! I read a lot of bad comments of this movie. A lot of people was expecting the plot like the original. What do you expect, it's a Tim Burton film! It has action, dark humor, some romance, drama, and so on. If you are going to see this film, don't expect it to be like the original. Expect it to be another great Tim Burton film. I had so much fun watching this film but it has some flaws. See it, but do not expect it to be just like the 1968 version. It would be better if there was a sequel. The ending was not as good as I thought it would be. If Tim made a sequel, then the ending would be explained better because it was confusing. So go ahead! See it!

CAUTION SPOILERS WITHINHaving just viewed this film last night, it is fresh in my mind and I wanted to make a few observations. Not a review per se, just some thoughts.Although flawed, it does have a few good things going for it. Rick Baker's work is truly amazing. The flexibility of the masks/make up used allows the actors to produce varied, expressive and very believable expressions. Nicely done.Most of the art direction and costume design is creative and well implemented. The ape army is cleverly and boldly realized.The acting, overall, is good, and especially in the case of Tim Roth, David Warner, Michael Duncan, & Helena Bonham Carter. They help create believable, if somewhat two dimensional characters. The lovely Estella Warren does fine in an underwritten role.Danny Elfman's creative score, effectively covers a wide variety of moods ranging through suspense, comedy and militaristic combat themes quite well.And then there's the other side of the coin, an at times interesting, but largely wooden formula driven plot, with dialog suffering from a bad case of pun infestation.A few things that don't work:At no time did I get the feeling that Captain Leo Davidson (Wahlberg) was all that surprised or impressed that he had discovered a culture where apes could talk, and ran the planet. It was sort of like `hmmm, that's odd, talking apes in charge of the world, hey look over there, we don't have oak trees like that on earth, this is INSANE!'And then the escape from the ape city, whose route cleverly goes right through the center of about a half dozen ape houses, `we'll keep running through these houses until we find the forest, its got to be around here somewhere. Once we've checked all the houses we'll start searching for the forest outside.'What's up with people (and apes) flying twenty feet or more through the air when they are struck by any ape (not just the gorillas), not occasionally, but everytime?  The great strength of apes? It would happen on earth. Lower gravity? Then apes would fly when humans struck them. Lots of stuntmen with springboards? Maybe.And then there's that one scene that just defies any logic, and I'm not talking about the `surprise ending'. Its when Captain Leo, wins the battle, brings a new understanding and compassion between apes and humanity, finds himself as the leader of a new world order, and then immediately hops in the space pod to return to earth. WHAT??? I mean, what's the hurry? He knows his crew have been dead for thousands of years, he's just won this planet's version of the Superbowl, the Nobel prize, and been elected President, clearly Estella Warren wants to jump his bones, and even Helena Bonham Carter's Ari is obviously intent on more advanced and exotic interspecies research. Even if he chooses not to lead this world through a new political, cultural & scientific revolution, how about taking some time to smell the roses, you know, a few weeks to gather scientific samples to bring back, to help advance anthropology by studying cross cultural (and species) mating rituals, to work at turning his space pod into a two seater, or to even bring extra food and water for what is likely to be a long and possibly fatal journey? I just don't get it.Worth seeing and entertaining, even for its flaws.Six out of ten stars.

I was looking forward to seeing this movie.  After finally watching it I felt disappointed and confused.  Too many questions left unanswered.  Very poor job of making it seem realistic.  The special effects are mildly entertaining but don't make up for the poor story.  This was the most over-hyped movie of the past 5 years.  I wouldn't see it again for free.

Review title: Candidate for the Golden Turkey Award
Review_body: Sorry Tim, I've enjoyed most of your other films, but this was disappointing. I just couldn't work out if this was supposed to be a parody of the original version or to be taken serious adventure/drama. I loved the old Charlton Heston movie, but this was not anywhere near those standards.So what was wrong with it? The make up and special effects weren't what you expect to see in 2002. Perhaps better than the original, but not that much better.There were so many logical lapses that I just kept shaking my head at it. Yes I know that it is a sci-fi movie, but there has to be some realism in it anyway.The acting was on many parts poor. Mark Wahlberg as Leo could have been replaced by a log. What Estella Warren was doing there except running around looking confused and pretty I just don't know. Certainly not acting. Helena Bonham Carter as the ape Ari was Ok, but no more. The same goes for Tim Roth as Thade.The ending just seemed to be glued on. Left-overs from the cutting room perhaps? It didn't add to the story, but just left you confused. Worst of all it was a clear opener for a sequel. Shudder.

i went to the film expecting to come out with a massive grin on my face, but came out rather disgruntled. although the film is perfectly adequate, it is nothing compared to the original, and the ending, as everyone knows, makes no sense whatsoever. my other major problem  was the colour. a tim burton film in yellow? everyone knows that tim burton films are supposed to be blue and black.

When I heard that Tim Burton was making a new version of the sci-fi legend Planet of the apes,I was really excited.I'm a huge Tim Burton fan, and the combination seemed too good to be true.Unfortunately,the movie was one of the biggest disappointments of the year and Burton's worst movie since Mars Attacks! Don't get me wrong!The new version of Planet of the Apes is not a bad movie and in it's own genre actually quite satisfying.The ape-masks are great(even though they make almost impossible to tell which actor is which) and the sets are pretty impressive.The biggest problem with the movie is that it doesn't have the unique visual look and oddness of Tim Burton.The second problem is Mark Wahlberg.He has the same one impression on his face throughout the movie and is one of the most unintresting hero of all times. All in all,not a bad film,but when compared to massive hype,a huge disappointment

2 hours of mark mark huffing and puffing. Are you kidding? Mark Mark spends the whole movie looking like a little girl. It's like every time he talks, he is exhausted. In shape my ass. The only plus side is the great strides in human/monkey relations. OH, and how does one fuel cell only give them one blast when his stupid, ugly mini space ship at the end could travel through time with no room for a fuel cell at all. And the ending makes no bracken sense. Monkeys on motorcycles...only at a circus...stupid. Is there any explanation as to the ending of the movie. I'm pretty sure movies can't make complex machines like engines and factories to make cars. WTF. Oh yea, and why does shifty eyes try to sell crack to the kids at the end of the movie. Matter of fact, I need to start taking some crack after seeing the crap.DON'T WATCH THIS monkey malarkey

Review title: I've seen David Lynch movies that made more sense than this
Review_body: Absolutely horrible.  God only knows what Burton was thinking with this. This movie lacked the intelligence to make it a "make you think" film and the action to make it an action film.  It falls somewhere in between.  The ending tried to be as clever and shocking as the original, but was simply idiotic.  Avoid this movie.  If you want to see a movie with a great surprise ending, watch Memento.

Review title: Great movie, but green ape sidekick ruins highscore.
Review_body:
I watched the 1968 Planet of the Apes and afterwards I was amazed how well I liked it. It was sent on TV and I thought like " I am going to die along with the movie runtime " but it was really good. So therefore I thought that Planet of the Apes Redux, or whatever one calls it, would be fun to see. And when I read Tim Burton had directed the whole thing I was even more excited. Edward Scissorhands- director doing a redux of one of the true movie classics, is that great or not.So I saw the movie and I was delighted to see how the masks had got even more realistic. And we also had Mark Wahlberg performing quite good, but alas he did not prove to be better than old Heston of the original. Helena Bonham Carter as sweet ape Ari was perfect for the role but this human-beings-seller in green? A typical sidekick, and I have never liked sidekicks. He has these spot-on comments to the movie's happenings but this true " evil ape empire "-feeling at once gets toned down by this fellow.
Tim Roth plays evil ape general Thade, the ultimate bad guy, breathing a little bit like Darth Vader in Star Wars. Michael Clarke Duncan have been showing off for the Apes- posters, so naturally he plays a great role as armyleader Attar. I have now seen the movie three times, one time on cinema, two times on VHS and I can't still figure out how the ending was like.

Review title: WOW! I hated this piece of garbage more than Pearl Harbor.
Review_body: I was vomiting for a week after seeing this "movie".  I love the original Planet Of The Apes.  But Jesus H. Christ why would you ruin a classic with this? Mark "Marky Mark" Wahlberg reprises his role once again as doing something he sucks at but getting a lot of money for it.Tim Burton, tisk freakin tisk, someone should be homeless for what they did to a classic.  Maybe we should let doctor Zaius kick your ass, and I would help.Well, altogether it was a waste of time 1/10

Review title: Why are sequels rarely as good as the original?
Review_body: I was contemplating that question after watching remakes of The Time Machine and Planet of the Apes.  The answer of course is that people always do remakes of good movies. They really should be doing remakes of bad movies, they are ones that need it.And there is no better example of the above then The Planet of the Apes, a movie that is such a pale imitation of the original that I was angry at myself for paying $4 to see it.Tim Burton is a very good director, I'm usually a fan of his work.  But, with this movie he seems to have gotten so caught up with turning actors into monkeys that he lost sight everything else.  The movie has great makeup, but no soul.  It just reeks of being a directors vanity project. This movie far surpasses the original in it presentation of the monkey planet, i.e. make-up, effects, acting, yet is less believeable.Burton also seems to have been so consumed with his monkey cast, he forgot his humans.  It can not go unmentioned how insipid Mark Wahlberg is movie. A potted plant would have held my attention as much as he did.And finally, nothing illustrates the futility of trying to remake this movie then the "surprise ending".  Obviously, he couldn't do the same ending as the original, it wouldn't be a surprise.  So it became necessary to come up with something totally different, but would still have the power and impact of the original.  Well, I guess they couldn't think anything so they decided to go with nonsensical instead.  Yes folks, the big surprise is that the movie's ending MAKE NO SENSE!!! None, zero, zippo.

A real turkey and I want my two hours back.This is not a worthy remake of the Chuck Heston original.  The plot tries to have twists, but they are more like contortions.  The acting is terrible and the costumes are pretty bad for the most part.If you want Planet of the Apes, watch the old one.

A question to the author or the director: Why is the movie ending with the apes again being dominant? After the captain has showed humans and apes to live together, how can apes win again? Either apes and human cross breed and apes genes were dominant or the author or the director might have answer.. Your answer will be greatly appreciated. The movie is overall good for a fiction but I think can be made with a fantastic story in sequels. I do not think this is a remake of the 69 movie. Even the director himself might have tried to make this a remake. I see no possibility of this one matching anything with the first movie.Thanking you.BGhimire- A Physics and Philosophy student

Not having seen the original, I was forced to judge this movie on its basic credibility alone.  I get the feeling that being attached to the star of its namesake is why it saw theatrical release at all.  This thing was mind-numbing.  The characters made no sense, the plot was inane, and the science was terrible.  You can only watch so many scenes of monkeys jumping on each other and pounding.  That's basically the whole film, briefly interrupted by scenes of Mark Wahlberg trying to look heroic.  The special effects are pretty good, but that's like wrapping up feces in a pretty gift box.  What happened to you, Tim Burton?

Review title: Mediocre film, but succeeds in doing what it was made to.
Review_body: I say.  This movie, while poorly written, acted, and for the most part, executed, was entertaining and though provoking.Many of the reviewers don't realize that the movie is NOT a remake by any means, and obviously doesnt pretend to be judging by the fact that the plot is almost entirely different, and any messege the film tries to get across to the viewer is also quite different.The purpose of the film is to confuse and disorient the viewer and make them sit through the credits with a perplexed look on his or her face.  The ending is much too bizzare to make any conceivable sense, and not even the director could clearly explain it.Though it falls short when it comes to the script and acting, the pace of the film is sporadic, and its clear that Tim Burton didnt give it his all, this is not a bad movie.  Its an entertaining film that succeeds in doing what it was meant to.  I give it a 7 out of 10.

Review title: Please don't waste your time with this movie
Review_body: After suffering through the abysmal plot development, I then had to suffer through the even worse execution of the plot! It would have been nice if the actors, who have potential, would've had a script to work with...But unfortunately, that was not the case, there was poor dialogue and the screenplay was even poorer. I was especially disappointed in the lack of any type of sequence among the events that took place. Not to mention, I'm not too thrilled with monkey romances. It was a very hairy experience, no more monkey business for me or Soe. Democracy to Burma.

Having never seen the original, I watched this movie many years later and the plot on its own is very entertaining.The story flows well, and everything seems to make sense as the story keeps on going. I'm not good at judging effects, but I found everything quite believable. On top of it, I loved the atmospheres created (mostly because it is a Tim Burton movie but with less of his usual style).The actors were incredible and sincerely, it was an awesome movie. I liked the plot, the actors, the directing and I think this movie is way underrated since it's being compared to the original which I heard is not even close to this plot. All in all, definitely worth watching!

I will give this movie some credit; it's not just a remake, which is probably the best thing it has going for it While the make-up is great, the film ends up being too serious to be campy, too silly to be taken seriously, and there are more loose ends than an unraveled sweater. (Which are sure to be tied up by the obviously sequel that the end sets up) Mark Walberg's tries to find his monkey and lands on a planet where Monkeys are superior and humans are the lesser primate. The make-up is astounding, and Mark proves to be a pretty good no-brain action star. Tim Roths is a pretty good monkey-gone-bad, but as I said before, this movies too silly to be taken seriously and his intense performance is kind of lost.After it's revealed how the monkeys got the way they were, (and why their English was so good) the plot just get's silly and builds up too a fairly laughable ending. The blond girl, Estelle, isn't bad as far as models-turned-actresses go, but her character serves no purpose other than to give 14 year old boys something to look at. Plus, even with more makeup than the cast of Cats used for 20 years, the best apes-actor is still the real thing, Mark's chimp Pericles, who gives a better performance than half his human-cousins.It's not a bad movie, it's a style-over-substance movie, but then again, so's most everything else that's at the theater. But underneath the latex it's just a campy monkey movie destined for cult stardom.

Review title: Tim Burton is In Sever Need of a Life...
Review_body: Oh My......Let me start out this review with one word.....Run. Run as fast as you can. Save yourself. Stay away from this move....Now, moving on....Horrible, revolting, bad, unwatchable, Plain out Bad. There are a million other words I could use to describe this film. First, let me start of by saying, Mr. Burton, get a life. You need it. I have yet to see a movie from you that is actually GOOD. You have ruind this Great Franchise! I fear what Charile and the Chocolate Factory Will be like.....*cowers at the thought of another HORRIBLE Tim Burton Film*For the movie itself.....like i said earlier, run. Bad Acting. Bad Plot, Bad Everything.

Review title: A strange and Wonderful Love Letter to Insane Sci-Fi
Review_body: Sci Fi- It's often scolded by most in this world, and sadly now such Sci-Fi films are most viciously attacked by their own fans! The fact it that this is a flawed movie, saved by Tim Burton's fantastic Visual Style and Danny Elfmans terrific score. The Cultural references are terrific: but once they are scrutinized further- sure it's unlikely that Apes would develop beautiful armour reminiscent of Ancient Armour worn by Turkish Knight in their religious wars, but man they look terrific and fill this strange world with a rich history and culture! While most merely see "REMAKE" up in lights and scoff at Hollywood- the film is more of a tribute to The concept of what Planet of the Apes has become, evolved with the help of fans through a horde of crappy sequels and weak spin off television series to the point where Pierre Boulle and what we know as Planet of the Apes are actually worlds apart. Bravely however, the films controversial finale is not to be taken seriously in any way! The ending which I will not give away, is an homage to many things.It's a tribute to Insane Sci- Fi, The deliberately profound endings to both the original film and Boulle's novel, and having a bit of a chuckle.It's like the Twilight Zone without taking itself seriously in any way.

I like the concept behind the Planet of the Apes franchise, and I like all of the people involved in this project.Beyond patronage and past accolades, there is simply no hiding from the fact that this is a bad movie -- poorly written, poorly directed, and poorly filmed.It stands as a kind of parody of the original films, combined with only the sort of slow boiling inner turmoil that Tim Burton seems to understand.Instead of being indifferent to this film's existence, I wish I could watch this film more than once a year like any of the "real" Planet of the Apes films.Herein lies the beauty of cinema... one can dream.

Hardly can hold a torch to the socialpolitical themes that the 1968 original tackled.  Obviously, special effects are well beyond what could be done then.  The action holds your interest, but the story is lacking.  If this is a "re-imagining", the Mr Burton would have done well to stick with what the original did so well.  Then, we might have a movie well worth watching.

Review title: Some great performances squares out the unnecessary use of violence.
Review_body: Inevitably you must compare the 1968 original with the 2001 reimagining. What I missed the most was the scientific approach that the original had. Showing why the apes' beliefs were covered in lies and why humans actually were intelligent.In this Tim Burton movie it seems he has to add the violence and fighting needed to get the big movie producing budget from 20th Century Fox.In one sequence Leo (played by Mark Wahlberg) points a gun at an ape, but is told to not sink to his level (the ape was a trader-in-humans) by Ari (magnificently played by Helena Bonham-Carter). Yet in the end there is no problem to fight the Ape army in Braveheart-style.The whole magic usually included in Tim Burton movies is never there, and somehow he falls for the blockbuster-syndrome: a cool action-hero and a lot of incredible stunts.And the ending, without spoiling anything, must be the worst ever displayed on the screens.However, the costumes and make-ups are incredible, but they are in line with modern movie-technology. They could give one or two Academy Awards next year. But I don't understand why apes covered in body-hair/fur would want to wear clothing or uniforms. Overall, the great performances by Helena Bonham-Carter as a Senators daughter and revolting youth preaching humanism and equality and Tim Roth as the dangerous and evil general Thade makes this movie a pretty good entertainment and raising the Rating to 5/10.

I went to see a preview of Planet of the Apes with some reservations. After all, I grew up with the original movies, and didn't think Tim Burton was the one who should "revisit" the franchise.  But the special makeup was incredible, and the mannerisms by the actors seemed so realistic that it blew me away.  Tim Roth is amazing - truly menacing, and wonderfully intense.  And the explanation of how the planet's inhabitants came to be was one of those last-minute "Oh - NOW I see it coming!" moments, where it wasn't obvious from the get-go.  All in all, I'd highly recommend seeing it!

Review title: This movie was pure drivel, absolute crap. Rent South Park instead.
Review_body: This movie was pure drivel, absolute crap. Rent South Park instead.  I'm not sure what was more painful, the $5 matinee ticket price or the fact that as I sat through it I was trying to figure out what I was going to do for the rest of the weekend.  Plot was predictable and there were not surprises. Not even the "surprise" ending.

Okay, sure, it's very (very) cheesy here and there. I laughed where I'm sure you're not supposed to laugh (although most people did). But if you can get past the cheese, and just kick back and let your imagination flow for a while, this is a really good movie. The monkeys.. sorry apes, are not just ordinary humans that look like apes, they have their own culture and ways. There's alot of aggression and sexual tension between them, and things boil down to who's the strongest. I liked all the twists, the last one being a predictable one, but it can still tickle your imagination, if you let it. So, I say open your eyes and ears and go see it. There are not a whole lot of movie out there that works from beginning til end, if you compare them and their plots to real life. "Planet..." never tried that, it's all about a  really cool experience, and Tim Burton is a master of making that happen. 8/10

This was one of THE WORST movies I have ever seen in my entire life (and I've seen Sugar and Spice, Jane Doe and Smokey and the Bandit III). The only part worth seeing was Chartlon Heston's cameo. If you MUST see this movie, walk out after that part, go into another theater and watch another movie, any movie will do (and I do mean ANY). I wish I'd brought a book.

Review title: An excellent movie...right up until the last ten minutes.
Review_body: The special effects and the makeup in this movie is the stuff of legend. The script is tight and moves at a respectable pace.  The acting is above par given the accomplished supporting cast.  Now the downside...Mark Wahlberg isn't a strong enough actor in his own right to carry this film. His character doesn't grow at all from the start to the end.  And speaking of the end; I'm not going to give it away but it made no logical sense in the context of the story that we had been watching for the previous two hours.  I was completely hooked into the movie until this ending that seemed as if it was filmed later and tacked on.  If they had left off the last ten minutes of the film I would have given this movie an 8.  But the crapola ending brought the whole picture down to a paltry 5.

This could have been a great movie, but they dug themselves into a hole and then couldn't figure out how to get out.  I enjoyed the up until the "battle" scene.  Then things stopped making sense.  Leo's big plan turned out to be a dud.  The humans should have been wiped out.  Then, even though the highly trained human pilot crashes not once, but twice, we are expected that the chimp pilot experiences none of the same problems and can land his pod without difficulty.  Why does a cute chimp landing in a space craft make the apes suddenly believe that the humans aren't so bad after all?Then there's the stupid "suprise" ending.  The whole movie is based on the premise that the smart apes evolved from genetic engineered apes that crash landed on the planet with the humans.  So why are we supposed to suddenly believe that Leo would crash land in a second parallel world where Washington D.C. looks just like ours, but everybody is an ape instead of a human?  This ending had nothing to do with the rest of the movie.It had potential, but it bombed instead.

This movie must be a practical joke. It was predictable, silly, and stupid. The make-up for the gorillas was great, but most of chimpanzees looked like pigmen. I hope they don't plan on making any more of these but I'm sure they will. The "big surprise" at the end was obvious once Mark Walberg got in his ship. The only thing this had in common with Pierre Boulle's book was talking apes, and the only thing it had in common with the original film was talking apes. Other than that, everything that makes the book and the original film great (even though they are also very different from each other) is gone. This movie should come with an apology at the end.

Review title: Definitely one of the worst films of this millenium
Review_body: Don't believe the hype. This is definitely the worst film I have seen in a long, long time. Only the second film ever where I fell asleep in. But there is a worthwhile scene at the end when apes fall from the sky, "frog-like". Otherwise, forget this very quickly.

I read the novel in jr high and thoroughly loved the ending.  Now that Tim Burton's film is out I can enjoy the ironic ending Boulle had visualized (only set in DC rather than Paris).  This is a much better film than the original.  Thank you Tim!

My expectations prior to this film were high. Being a big fan of the original film I hoped that this new version would come some way near its excellence. In my opinion it came nowhere near. Many key elements of the original were changed, but why? To cater for today's audiences? So as not to be accused of copying the original? If Tim Burton or anyone else could make a decent copy of the original that would be great. Why were all the humans able to speak? The actors who played humans didn't even have anything decent to say so it would have been preferable to have had them mute. Yeah the script was that bad and surely the muteness was an integral part of the original. The film had some 'to be expected' special effects but no substance while the original had very little in the way of special effects and so much more substance. It seems that Tim Burton used the cover of special effects (like so many other film directors these days) to hide a poor script. There are many other aspects of the film which I could comment on but I don't want to give any of the plot away so I'll refrain. I suppose you must expect a remake to be of inferior quality, you only need to look at the vast majority of remakes to know this. This film, unlike its predecessor, will not stand the test of time. Hire out the original and enjoy.

Review title: Oh, so THAT'S the surprise ending
Review_body: Surprisingly contrived maybe, or surprisingly pointless.  The original had a memorable twist at the end, so I suppose they felt they needed one too. I'm torn between whether the idea behind it was bad or just poorly executed. Either way, I can see why they didn't want it to leak out. It wasn't a horrible movie.  The effects were decent and the make-up was outstanding, but I just couldn't help thinking all the way through that I should have been enjoying it more.  I tried, but it just wasn't happening. None of the people I saw it with really felt satisfied at the end.  And the Goofs page for this film should be pretty interesting once people get going. Maybe my expectations were a little too high, but I was glad I saw it at Matinee prices.

Review title: People, this is a BAD movie...
Review_body: ...it's not as terrible as "Sleepy Hollow", but it's pretty darn bad. The only "saving" grace is pretty design and excellent ape make-up. But there is nothing else - not a damn thing else - to applaud about it. I like action and sci-fi movies as much as anyone - and I don't expect them to be "Citizen Kane." I do expect to care a *little* bit about the characters - this is really just the minimum for buying into a film's world. Unfortunately, this movie only has one performance that even qualifies (Helena, naturally) - and it can't make up for a blank "hero" and a toilet-paper-ready "script." The "surprise ending shocker" is stupid because there is no explanation for it at all to be found anywhere on this planet or another. Twists are great, but they should at least appeal to logic a little bit - and not be just completely inexplicable. If you think this movie is a ten, really, you should see more movies.

Review title: As good as one would expect
Review_body: Initial while watching the movie I liked it, however the more I think back on it the more I think it was only average.    It was however a very well done remake.   Very tough to improve on the classic Planet of the Apes movie.

Luckily for everyone Planet of the Apes didn't follow Tomb Raider and the many other summer movies into the major disappointment catagory.  Simply put, the latest from Tim Burton is exciting, perfectly paced, and a hoot! Rick Baker's makeup is the most convincing makeup work ever to grace the screen.  The performances by those wearing it is phenomenal.  Tim Roth may be one of the most engaging FX aided villains ever as General Thade.  The story isn't too complicated, nor is it nonexistant as we have come to expect from this summer's crop.  It lacks the predictability that makes so many FX laden movies fall on their face.  This is a movie that will be mixed with critics, mixed with fans of the original (this strays a lot from the classic's elements), extremely popular with young audiences, and worth everyone's dollar at the box office.  Only gripe is the casting of Mark Wahlberg.  He can usually turn in an engaging performance, but he's no Charlton Heston.  The ending is a mind blower, but teeters on a little too confusing.  Yet, you will leave the theater wishing the sequel came out tomorrow!

**SPOILERS**I'll start off by syaing that I'm not much for remakes.  I roll my eyes whenever I see a preview for a remake of a classic (i.e. The Time Machine this Christmas).  Nevertheless, I'm in line opening day.  Ever since Elementary School when my Dad made me watch the original Planet of the Apes I've been enchanted by it.  A school friend Robbie told me the ending before I saw it; yet it still captivated me.  The dialogue was a little weak in the original, and the special effects and makeup are a joke now; but they were pearls in the late 60s.  The ending was a mystical cliffhanger that made you want the world to freeze and allow you to just ponder life and our society for a moment.  I commend those actors, they did great back then, but it's just not a movie for the 2000 years and on.  This brings me to the remake. Not many people know, in fact, that both films were remakes of the original French novel by Pierre Boulle.  It upsets me when people call the new one a "remake" of the old one.  It's not...It's a new idea on an old book.  I commend Tim Burton.  He did a great job with the futuristic feel of this movie.  Most movies these days do a HORRIBLE job conveying the future. It's better to watch 2001: A Space Odyssey because the effects look reasonable. Take "The Sixth Day" for instance.  That movie was nothing but an excuse for Arnold lines and special effects.  They overused the effects, in my opinion, which created an overly-exotic, extremeley wild picture that I couldn't keep controlled.  Our current technology needs to be limited in the display of our future; a fine line George Lucas walked with Episode One.  However, I think Tim Burton did pretty good with not overly-special-effecting this film.  The opening scenes in our not-too-distant future seemed reasonable and not too stretched and wild.  I also really enjoyed the scenes on the space station, in which Tim paralleled our relation to apes with the apes relation to us.  They didn't do this in the original film.  It allowed younger viewerd to more basically understand the parallel between the two relationships.  The one thing I didn't like in the film was the humans. They didn't seem evolutionary-backtracked at all.  They seemed like normal humans who had just been scavenging around for 3,000 years while the monkeys evolved tremendously into an entirely new identity.  The "Nova" character, Daena I think, was interesting.  Obviously placed as a sex object, she didn't quite pull off enough of a attraction with Davidson (The "Taylor" of the film).  Oh ya, one more thing I didn't like.  The ending, after the struggle with the apes is over, I thought was too rushed.  THey should have slowed it down and taken it a bit steadier.  Otherwise, I loved this movie. The two parallels to the original film were great, and I felt out of place as being one of the only people in the theatre who was laughing at the line "Get Your Stinking Hands Off Me You Damn Dirty Human."  Ya so it was corny, it was great.  The Charlton Heston cameo was an awesome tribut to a great American symbol.  It was awesome, and his last words "Damn them all to hell..." made me laugh really hard.  It was a great tribute and I applaud the writers for it.  General Thade I thought was great, he did a good job acting.  It was much different than the book's/original movie's Dr Zaius, but he still had the same premise.  All the ape characters were outstanding, especially the two Generals and the comic relief slave trader.  The premise was quite different AND IF YOU DONT WANT TO KNOW THE ENDING ***STOP READING NOW*** and I liked it but I didn't.  The idea of the space station going back in time and the monkeys taking over and evolving was interesting.  As said above, I thought it strange that the apes would advance so much and the humans not, but still.  I liked that idea; it was an interesting new idea. But it still lacked all the glamour the original ending got.  It didn't make me think and it didn't really spark an interest in me to question existence. It was good, but not POTA worthy.  The ending was, however.  I thought that all the cliffhangers were over with.  After Thade was locked up I think it was rushed way too much.  It all kinda wrapped up and took off too quick. When Davidson crashed on Earth I knew something fishy was up.  And when I noticed the Lincoln Memorial I knew what I was about to see.  What I didn't know, however, was that the modern-day Earth would end up completely controlled by apes.  This was a great cliffhanger ending and it made me puzzled at first.  However when you think about it, it leaves little to the imagination.  Obviously, somewhere in Planet of the Apes re-imagining sequels 2-5 Thade will go back in time and alter past.  When this will happen, how it will occur, how well it will be pulled off, who will be the characters, and exactly how many boring sequels we will have to sit through are all questions that lay heavily on the shoulders of director Tim Burton...good luck...   8.5/10

Being quite a fan of Tim Burton's work (especially the Batman movies), I was utterly disappointed with this one. I haven't read the book and I can't remember properly how the original film was, and so I expected the film to be funny, ironic, visually challenging, etc.: So it was a very bad surprise when I found out that the film was really dull, seemingly going nowhere, being illogic and all (Why do the female apes not look at all like apes while the male ones do?). And the ending was the worst, as I considered many possible solutions, but they all seem so non-sensical that it made me really angry. And Mark doesn't even take his clothes off!

Review title: The worst movie I saw this summer
Review_body: This movie is a joke!  One of the worst movies I have ever seen!  The only thing that kept me from walking out of this nightmare was Estella Warren. Not only do I think Tim Burton has completely lost his originality and independent risk taking but Mark Walburg???  This guy is the most over rated actor to date.  Are you kidding me, all he does is breath heavy and talk breathy in every movie he's ever in.  My rating for this flick would be GARBAGE if there was one.

Review title: What a silly movie - see it if you must.
Review_body: The best parts of this movie were Tim Roth's deliciously evil general and Danny Elfman's music.  I had a great time with my friend making fun of the movie as we watched it - flying monkey theme song from "Wizard of Oz" and the "Star Trek" series action music.  At one point we made a reference to the Monty Python "dead parrot sketch" - when the first wave of ape soldiers got hit with the afterburner and were lying in the sand - "they're not dead, just stunned." What a silly movie - see it if you must.

Review title: Planet of the Apes makes my brain bleed.
Review_body: What do you get if you take a lousy screenplay, add some miscast actors, and top it off with state of the art special effects? Easy: a bad movie that makes millions of dollars. This movie was awful, no two ways about it. I have the utmost respect for Tim Burton, but that doesn't mean he's incapable of making an absolute garbage film, which is what he did here. The screenplay had all the depth of a fourth grader's story contest submission, stooping so far as to have a character say (and I'm not making this up) "Can't we all just get along?" I swear, Paul Giamatti's bad comic relief character was pulled from a thrown-out Disney script. This movie was cliched at its best, at its worst it was painfully stupid. I can't say more without spoiling the ending, but know this: When you're sitting in the theater thinking "Oh sweet jesus don't let that be the way they're gonna end it," stand up and leave, because the ending you dread is the one you get. As long as movies like this keep making money, they'll keep making movies like this, and that's a damned shame.

i was expecting a great movie since i'm a enjoy tim burton's movies. I was amazed with sleepy hollow and was looking forward to this movie. but what i saw was a piece of crap!! the story made final fantasy's look incredible, the acting was pathetic (except for the apes), the ending was horrible. and what's with charlton heston's speech? how can it be so full of clichés; i really hope someone gets fired for that one. so, kudos to tim roth, micheal clark duncan but the rest of the movie is awful. please don't make a sequel!!!

Review title: Id' rather spend my time sleeping!
Review_body: I'm as disapointed as can be!The worst thing about it (I have to get this out of my system!) was the awefull predictablility! I had expected at least some sort of surprise during the movie. But NO!!!Not that I wanted anything like the original, nor "The Usual Supects" or "From Dusk Till Dawn". But atleast a little surprise!Ok, I have to say the apes are excelet (though I didn't really like Thade as much as the general IMDB users)If you havent seen it, DONT go to the movies RENT IT!!! (it's not woth a trip to the cinema, but in your own couch it might be ok!)One last thing...Trailers are meant to be informative and tempting NOT revealing!!!P.S. don't mind my bad spelling, I went out and got locked after this disapointment!

I went on the movie, Planets of the apes, with "semi" expectations. For some reason I didn´t expect much from talking monkeys. In some way I was surprised with how fantastic the make up was in the movie and how well the monkey, sorry, "ape" caracters were well performed. The physical expression off them was believable and worked quite well but thats about it. I hoped that the movie would get better in the second "half" but on the contrary it got twice as bad.I heard that Tim Burton had made 5 endings to the movie and this one was chosen rather than the others. Anyone who has seen the movie must be thinking, how bad could the other four endings be so that this one was chosen. The ending is so bad that it effects the whole plot of the movie and made me give this movie 4/10.If the ending would have been different, would have made a little bit of sense, then it would possibly get a higher score.Please write me if you think this writing is out of the blue, or even smack down in the middle of the blueÁgúst Kr, IcelandP.S. pardon my spelling

Thanks for selling out Mr. Burton... for caving-in and creating another high action piece of garbage that Hollywood thinks makes a good movie. Sure, visually, this movie is plenty slick and the make-up and costumes are artistry. Too bad that's simply not enough to hold the interest of most ten year olds, let alone adults. The lack of plot and character development really shocked me for a Burton film. I'm left to again wonder if Hollywood really thinks we are all that stupid? From the completely impossible story line and ridiculous scenes, to the humans glossy lips in the desert, I felt like a victim of a very bad joke. Even my eight year old began asking "how much longer is this movie?" a short 30 minutes into it. Save your money and rent the classic - for all of it's weaknesses, it at least has characters that you come to care something about.

There is only one thing to say about this movie. Uuuugggghhhhhhh!!! No plot, bad acting and an ending that confused everyone in the theater killed this movie. There are some movies that are classics without a remake. Tim Burton, shame on you.

I thought the movie was all right, up until the end.  I can't agree with the first person's comments - that ending would not satisfy me even if I were to see this movie multiple times.  It had the feel of a run of the mill Sliders episode.  Of course, Hollywood's almost always got to set things up for possible sequels.  Though they could have come up with something a lot more plausible.

I'm glad the local store rents DVD's for $1.49 a night, otherwise I never would have gotten to see this.  What gets me is all these "industry" types, who know the film is a total disgrace, but since they really don't give a whit about anything in life but padding the bottom line, are like- "who cares if the acting is miserable and there's no depth to the story, no complexity, no nothing - I thought it was pretty entertaining,  and the costumes and special effects were great!"  Or "we'll recap on the foreign market and dvd special features"  Gag.These people are ruining the medium of film.You put so much money and time and effort into a work like this, but you completely ignore the few things that could turn it from TV-quality crap (with GREAT SPECIAL EFFECTS!!!!) into a real, honest to god movie.  To bad they could collectively care less.  They're not movie-makers, they're just businessmen.Well, I'm glad to say you got all of about 5 cents from my viewing...cheers.

This movie is by far the movie of the summer.  I didn't like the original but I loved this!  Tim Roth plays one of the best villans that I've ever seen.  This movie keeps you thinking and leaves you thinking even more after the credits. ****10 out of 10!******

Review title: Great...but I should have left before the last minute of the movie!!
Review_body: I was impressed by the majority of the movie.  I especially like Thades' (Tim Roth) walking motion as i have been imitating it all day.  Apart from some of the cliche comic relief remarks (you know what i mean), and the very end (last minute or so), i thought the movie was GREAT!!  But that ending .. .

this is a great film. the original was also great. but you cannot compare the two. as tim burton said, this is not a remake. it is a re-thinking of the original story. so, after taking that into account, this new apes movie is a great, great film (i'm biased though, i think tim burton is one of the most creative directors ever).

Review title: For once a summer movie that thinks its audience is SMART!
Review_body: To sum up the monumental movie Planet Of The Apes in one word would be a discredit to Tim Burton and his wonderful remake of the groundbreaking movie.  A deep movie that managed to keep my attention for about 2 hours, spark questions and for once, NOT EXPLAIN EVERY LITTLE ACTION THE CHARACTERS TAKE.  My pet peeve today is that movies have to take so much time in explaining every tiny detail about the plot.  In essence they are preaching to the lowest common denominator. In a movie that contains so many sub-plots, Tim Burton does a great job of presenting the foundation though dialogue, and then the rest of the plot though visual aids.  If you want to understand the movie you have to look for the details and then come to your own conclusions, which isn't that hard if you were actually watching the movie, and have some reasonable level of intelligence (which of course is rare into days movie viewing demo graph, and no I'm not an old cranky manI'm only 16).  If your tired of the same mush that infests out cinema today and want to see a movie that is smart, funny, and makes you think see this movie.  If you don't you can always go for the special effects, make-up (Wonderful job), and of course Supermodel Estella Warren! ;-)10/10!!!

WARNING: THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS (though hopefully you'll read them and then not decide to see the movie and thus save yourself seven hard earned bucks...)This movie was garbage in practically every regard. The dialouge was terrible, the plot didn't make sense, the acting was mediocre at best, the action scenes were lame, the hyped "social messages" were blunt and shallow, and the big surprise ending was astonishingly dumb and impossible. Given how many screenplays Hollywood must get, its pretty incredible that they made this one into a summer blockbuster. There are a couple bright spots in this movie: Many of the ape actors do fine jobs, especially Helena Bonham Carter who turns in by far the film's best performance, and Estella Warren looks absolutely gorgeous wandering around in her skimpy outfits. Beyond that, the movie is worthless in every way. First of all, the plot makes no sense at all. A couple examples: 1. The name of the ape's secret city is Calia, which we learn comes from a sign reading "Caution Live Animals" which is covered by dust except for the first couple letters of each word, except that presumably the city was named thousands of years ago when the apes left it BEFORE any of the dust accumulated. 2. When the humans are about to be totally overrun by the ape army, Mark Wahlberg comes up with the idea of using the still intact fuel in his spaceship that crashed thousands of years ago (huh?) to blow up the apes. "Cool" we think, except that all it seems to do is knock over about 40 apes out of the few thousand in the army, and they just get back up again. So then the humans attack and the battle seems to be pretty fair. Huh? If they could put up a fight in the first place, why were they coming up with this dumb scheme that didn't even do anything? 3. Okay, I know Estella Warren is gorgeous, but seriously, neither her character nor any other human character in the movie except Mark Wahlberg had any significance to the plot. I think she had literally about 5 lines and was ignored throughout most of the film. Her father's only purpose was getting killed by a big ape early on, after he said somewhere around 2 lines, and that little kid (her brother?) was also completely insignificant except towards the end when he somehow tips over his horse, except that didn't really matter at all to the plot either. 4. The ending (BIG SPOILER AHEAD) was just dumb. Dumb dumb dumb. Okay, so here he is in PRESENT DAY earth except it's all apes again. First of all, this is predictable, but it still doesn't make sense. We're supposed to believe (I think) that Thade somehow managed to go back in time to earth and change the course of history, but somehow it turned out exactly the same way, down to the archetecture of the Washington monument, as it was when humans were the dominant species. What? what??? Whatever, it's dumb as wood anyway. Also, the rest of the movie was just lame. For one thing, the big hyped action scenes were ridiculously lame. Basically, a human would punch an ape, who'd turn around and punch the human and send him sailing about 25 feet into the air at which point he'd die, unless he happened to be named Mark Wahlberg, in which case he'd be perfectly fine. huh? Also, we were set up for this big climatic fight between the two ape generals, which predictably happned, but it was remarkably tame too. They pretty much just jumped at each other and beat each others chests for around 15 seconds before one the them died. Also, the whole social message thing had been done much better before and seemed unconvincing when done here. You get the impression that the actors in ape makeup are having trouble keeping a straight face while delivering these overly deep and significant but at the same time really really dumb lines... 1/10

WARNING: MY COMMENTS MAY HAVE SPOILERS IF YOU HAVE NOT SEEN THE MOVIE. READ AT YOUR OWN RISK.I couldn't enjoy Planet of the Apes because of the gaps of logic taking place.In the original, Heston (Col. Taylor) landed on a planet with air, with apes ruling over humans, and they could speak English!--all these strange things were explained with the ending--Heston had returned to the Earth of the future.In the remake, I was thrown off from the beginning.Why are we using apes in space exploration? This would have made more sense in 1968 original, with Russian cosmonauts and apes being sent into space.But right now we use robot probes to explore Mars. Wouldn't that technology be all the more advanced and probable than using simians in the future?This planet is not Earth. It's convenient that Leo landed here and that there is oxygen to breathe. But in addition to that minor point, this planet was populated with ape and human survivors that crash landed on a ship. This begs the question--WHERE DID THE HORSE COME FROM?Again, it made sense in the original--they were on Earth from the beginning. But here, on another planet, it doesn't make any sense.Where did Ape Charlton Heston (Thade's dad) get the gun?Again, everything on this planet started from what survived the crash of the ship on the planet. Leo uses a modern laser-like weapon. Where did Ape Charlton Heston get an old gun even by our current standards, to present to his son, Gen Thade?How can the apes evolve so quickly, and yet the surviving humans are in the caveman stage of things?Apes can speak, ride the "native" horses of the planet, have a whole society and hierarchy, yet man, with all his technological know-how is now running around in loin cloths. Righttt.I knew this movie wouldn't be perfect, but even the couple of beers I downed before the movie could get me over that idiotic ending.Okay, Gen Thade somehow got smart enough to get back to Earth before Leo, and change history. But it isn't a new ape-history, it's a parallel Earth history where identical versions of things exist--The Lincoln Memorial with an Ape head, Cop cars with Gorilla cops, society in duplicate form to ours, the only thing changed is apes instead of humans.I give up, maybe it'll be explained in the sequel--but I ain't going to cough up 8 bucks to find out why.

Keep this filthy stinking movie away from me you damn dirty humans.Hands up who cringed at the awful reworking of the classic 'filthy paws' and 'damn them all' lines from the original film?Save for the insight into the origins of the 'planet of the apes' and the adherence to the original novels ending, I was more than let down by this production. And as much as I would love to give Rick Baker and his team praise for the make up, what were they thinking of when designing the female chimpanzees???Sorry Tim, but you ain't no organ grinder!

Review title: Better storyline than original, but could have been even better...
Review_body: I usually prefer originals to the remakes, however this one is an exception. I was trully surprised by Burton's handling of this story with a respect for the original in intent. The cameo appearances and treasured lines we all look to hear were brought back and with a twist in context. When reviewing the deleted material on the DVD, I was puzzled why two very detailed scenes were redone which tied up a couple of loose ends the finished story failed to answer. The time differences were not great, so I am not sure why they were removed. With the exception of the choice of Mark Wahlberg (who I still feel cannot act his way out of a paper sack) Tim Burton did a superb job. This one is worth the purchase if you have a great home theatre system.

Review title: Great new visionary Planet of the Apes
Review_body: Tim Burton has once again created a visually stunning and a "new" Planet of the Apes. It is NOT a remake; and never tried to be but another "tale" on the same concept as the old movies. The old ones were great as well - masterpieces in itself. But this DOES NOT reduce the great work that Tim Burton has done in creating this movie. A great movie and well worth watching in it's own rights. If you want the "old ones" - watch the old ones; if you want to watch a great new movie - watch this one. And WHY not watch both the OLD and the NEW ones.Happy viewing!

Review title: Bad Remake, Zero continuity, Serling turning in his grave
Review_body: This is a horrible remake/ new version of this classic movie. There is no continuity. Characters appear and disappear for no apparent reason. A troupe of Mark Walhberg and other humans and Apes trek across the Forbidden Zone - I thought I was watching the Wizard of OZ. The movie is packed with through away 'one-liners' making it more like an action comedy instead of science fiction.

This would have been a much better film if Tim Burton had not sought out to "reimagine" the original story.  Granted, the makeup and special effects do surpass the original, but that is where the superlatives stop. The story in the current version just does not work.  It does not adequately explain how the apes came to be where they are.  The ending does not have a fraction of the impact of the ending of the original film.  It is ridiculous and illogical.  This is one movie you can wait for the video on..and only if someone else pays for the video and invites you over.

This film is quite horrible... I can't believe they've made so much hype about that! The plot follows no logic. It seems that the writer stopped the film at that point so he'll have two more years or so to make the story sounds logical. The end is so pathetical that looks like a comedy and not a sci-fi adventure. It's bad directed, things are just thrown away and the scenes have no elaboration. The camera work is nothing but elementary, and, also, the make-up of the female monkeys looks fake and unreal. A real class on how to NOT make a film. 2/10.

Despite all the bad reviews "Planet of the Apes" is a thoroughly enjoyable film.  Perhaps Wahlberg, while clearly trying to avoid the over the top melodrama of Heston's character, could have been a little more passionate at times, but the apes, especially Thade and Ari are wonderfully portrayed with a rich dimension helped along by Rick Baker's fabulous makeup effects.You must bear in mind that this is 21st century post-cold war America and this is a Tim Burton film.  There is no substantial socio-political commentary here, although there are plenty of gentle nods to racism, classism, sexism, religion, and the rest---along with several well placed winks at the original production [including a splendid cameo by Heston]. This is much more of a "fish out of water" and "search for belonging" movie that is Burton's specialty.

The ending just made me want to barf.  It was so tacked-on and disconnected that I just couldn't take it... it was worse than the end of the remake of "Mighty Joe Young"... I wonder if the DVD version will have the option to roll credits 3 minutes earlier.On another note, I think it's amazingly hilarious the way some have misinterpreted Charlton Heston's "support" for gun control.  Let's see, he's an old-guard member of a genocidal regime that wants to eliminate humans or at best enslave them, and warns his son to beware of the human power of invention, symbolized by firearms.  DUH!  Of course tyrants want gun control -- it keeps them safe from their victims!  Charlton Heston made EXACTLY the point about guns that he wanted to make, some people apparently just missed it!On the whole, the movie isn't as bad as some have made it out to be, nor is it as good as others have said.  It was a good action movie, but not much else.  I give it a 6.

Forget all of the critics. This is not supposed to be a physiological thriller. This a great movie. Visually spectacular.This movie delivers excitement and lots of action. I cannot wait to see the sequel. This (so far) is the best of the summer of 2001.

I had high expectations from Tim Burton's new film, hoping his unique genius would improve upon the dated preachiness of the 1968 original, but, alas, I was greatly disappointed. Of course, this is a high-class action movie and the apes' looks and movement are quite stunning, but the plot is so corny and juvenile. As for the ending, I don't see any difficulty in understanding it (although I'm not going to spoil it to anyone), it is just a pointless twist on the 1968 ending. And Back to the Future I-II handled time-traveling paradoxes so much better. Acting is quite horrible, with Helena Bonham-Carter as her usual pathetic self, underneath all the make up. 6/10.

Good actors, great director, great story and brilliant plot twist. I dont know why you hate this movie so much and I can't see any reasons. Its good remake and it isn't bad just because original was better.

I'm gutted, one of my all time favourite movies Planet of the Apes' is to be remade by one of my favourite directors Tim Burton' at last a film to really look forward to. Oh dear! What's with these filmmakers, why do they seem to pay no attention to the story and script? Planet of the Apes (2001) is a stunning piece of film work with great make-up, effects (a few actors aside) an excellent cast.The first half of the movie is entertaining and builds well though it doesn't take a genius to work out where the story going. The second half comes across as though they ran out of time and were not sure which way to take the movie. Because this it becomes farcical! It looks like they panicked, the problem is the original movie is a classic and easily stands the test of time, the end, still a very powerful image. They concentrate of trying to replicate (in a different way) this but it's desperate. If you're going to see this film try to forget about the original and just enjoy it as a different film. This is difficult because they insist on repeating the classic lines from the first movie. I suppose they were trying to be funny, it was funny but for the wrong reasons. Planet of the Apes is an entertaining movie that does not carry much impact Michael Clark Duncan is big, Mark Wahlberg is good, and Tim Roth is great, though given the costume, setting and make-up not a difficult task! People will not be watching this film in thirty years. Yet another disappointment.

Review title: Can you be entertained watching a terrible movie?
Review_body: I am not quite sure how, but watching the worst movie of the summer was not a complete waste of time.  It has been a while since I saw a movie where the audience actually groaned and mocked the movie while it was playing.  The movie is so poorly written that it should have insulted each one of us watching but the Tim Burton visuals do help pass the time quickly.  We were stuck there so we made do, don't waste your money and you will be ahead of the game.

Review title: A horrible, cliched, schmaltzy waste of money.
Review_body: As a huge Tim Burton fan, I anticipated greatness and creativity. Imagine my dismay as I sat through a big-budget Hollywood crapfest with the worst dialogue (so laughably bad!). The special effects were cool, but there was nothing remotely Tim Burton-ish about this movie- this is exactly what you'd expect from some hatchet artist like Michael Bay, not from the usually delightful Tim Burton. I am thoroughly disgusted by this- he has clearly fallen for the Hollywood method of fearlessly distributing crap, so long as he makes a buck (or a million). DON'T see this trashy, stupid, waste-of-time movie. Mark Wahlberg's acting is totally sub-par and boring. The rest of the characters are background filler and serve no purpose. Tim Burton is capable of so much more. Let's hope he chooses something more substantial with original dialogue next time.

I see that a good film of Tim Burton (Sleepy Hollow) is very excellent his work with his beautiful equips!!! I find that the film in 1967 to 1973 is much difference with today. I want to tell you my comments of culture, costume and decoration and actor and actress.
For costumes and decoration, I find it's very beautiful decorations that he are like a real future if possible. They are very odd culture of the monkeys. They are good a color!!! I see the costumes are beautiful too!!! It's gone in film! For the actors and the actresses, Mark is cool. to play the perfect role of Leo. He is a good actor. For Tim Roth, it is played a good role of malicious!!! It's excel!!! For Helena, it is actress a little as in the film Club Fight. For Michael Clarke Duncan, it is the role of large gorilla!! It gives me fear. The others of the monkeys are differences the characters in the village. They are special culture.
I believe that Burton is a good spirit! Congratulated!!!Finally, I'm talking about my comments of costumes and decoration and actors and actresses. I hope which the film is still a sequel film of planet of the apes in Washington D.C. with the director Tim Burton and the actor Mark.

Sorry everyone, this reinvention of the 1968 classic just isn't up to par. Mark Walhberg as the astronaut is awful. His acting ruined what might have been a strong male lead. He is not believable in his role. The ape make up is Oscar worthy, though at most times it distracts from the already weak plot and make most dialogue incomprehensible. This film parodies the previous "Ape" film with several one-liners. This is not supposed to be a comedy or satire, it is a "message" movie on how we treat and behave towards other beings. At least that was what the novel and 1968 version was about. I think another problem was that the director did not know whether to have the apes behave like apes or humans. Dd they evolve and become human like or retain there ape behavious and just learn to speak? So many questions? Goofs? Disjointed plotlines and other errors that cannot be detailed without giving away the plot. Enjoy the make up and effects but that's it!!!!!

Forget 'Pearl Harbor,' the biggest movie of the year is here!!This is a credit to the fun of film-making.  Burton keeps the viewer nailed down and anxious to see what lies ahead.Tim Roth could very well be in award-contention for his no-holds-barred representation of a human-hater.  His speech, walk, even his eye movements completely transform him into a vicious ape.  Hats off to an actor of his caliber.  Wahlberg is good, as well.  He is the typical 'boy-next door' American whom is smart enough to not ask questions while he secretly plans his escape.  Kristofferson's cameo is nearly non-existant, however. Development of the human tribes and their ways of life would be interesing to learn of, but action wins over plot thickness.  Estella Warren is simply eye-candy, while Bonham Carter is the lead female with a brain to match.The film is fast paced, and at a few moments seemed to be out of control. Not Burton's best work personally, but working with an ensemble of terrific makeup artists, photograhphers, and Elfman (with a terrific score), it is tied together nicely.

I was so excited for this movie, and man, what a let down.  Granted, casting, make-up, costuming, and sound were wonderful, but that's about it. The script was poor, and actually made the audience laugh at parts that weren't supposed to be funny.  Everyone coming out of the theatre gave the movie two thumbs down! The ending could've been better written by a 5 year old!  Don't waste your money on this one!

Review title: A great re-interpretation and under-rated film ruined by nostalgics
Review_body: I for one love this modernised view of Planet of the Apes. Coming from a younger generation of Film viewers, watching movies with 30 year old plots and FX isn't as captivating as newer renditions with updated technology and plots. The Hatred towards humans feels more genuine especially from Thade as well as the fear shown when the apes realize the power marky has. Obviously the makeup and effects are a lot more advanced which helps remove some of the silliness of the notion of a planet ruled by apes. I enjoyed the ending, it makes you think and left me wanting to see more, perhaps the ending meant nothing whatever the case it left people thinking and debating. I would love to see a sequel to this version if it were possible.

Review title: I fell asleep... effects without a movie!
Review_body: while watching this piece of crap! The Day after, I saw a 1min Trailer - that one minute included all, ALL what was at least not boring to watch...so don't waste money or time on this one, get the original, it's much better though the effects might not be up to date...

This movie was terrible.  I went into it with high expectations, only to get a sneaking suspicion that something had gone terribly awry after the opening credits.  These are some of the elements which made viewing this excruciating:1) The set: it looked like a cross between the Wizard of Oz's flying monkeys, the Ewok Adventure and Willow.  I know we're dealing with Tim Burton here, but I just couldn't take it seriously.  And, it always looked like a SET.2)  The cast:  Mark Wahlberg, whom I normally like, just seemed too flat and not commanding enough of a character to lead any insurrection.  Estella Warren, who plays the 2001 equivalent to the original film's Nova, is so bad it's comic.  Check out the first scene in which she's introduced side by side with the Kris Kristofferson character.  The look on her face is so vacuous, you wonder how she's supposedly survived this long on the run. And speaking of Kris Kristofferson: why is he in this movie at all?  His character is completely wasted.3) Danny Elfman's swollen, distracting score:  I felt like I was watching Batman all over again.4) The character development:  The human characters are not developed at all.  We're supposed to buy that there's chemistry between the Mark Wahlberg character and Daena (Estella)?  One doesn't even really know the human characters' names by the end of the film.  I had to look them up on IMDB. I didn't care about any of the characters, and hoped they were all killed by the time the movie ended.5) The tacked-on, twist ending:  Send this ending back for a rewrite! Let's make some sense here, people.In addition to the points listed above, the dialogue was corny.  There were also numerous plots holes and distractions.  One of the distractions was how Daena got lip gloss and managed to shave her armpits while living such a primitive lifestyle.  It's also a wonder that the enslaved and nomadic humans spoke English so well.Helena Bonham-Carter does what she can with the terrible script.  The make-up effects were mixed.  The look of the female primates was not to be believed.  I assume this was done for Burton's lame satiric elements in the film.  The make-up effect on Tim Roth's Thade was more believable.  Tim Roth's scenes fare better than others, although he goes way over the top at points.Don't waste your time with this movie.  Do yourself a favor and rent the original 1968 classic instead.

Review title: Good but had the potential for excellent
Review_body: Really enjoyable, good remake, the attention to detail is very impressive however the character development could have been stronger.Good piece of escapism, nice to see a half decent sci-fi film again, however the potential was there for a more complicated storyline.The film also was crying out to be more violent and even a little gory, but has obviously been sanitised to give it a 12 certificate(uk) to cash in on a younger market, shamefollow up films a certainty

Review title: Guess Tim did what he could...
Review_body: As a HUGE Tim Burton fan, I must say I was disappointed. Problem is I think Burton did what he could with a script that probably could fit on infants fingernail. At most, three lines are exchanged between the actors which leads to an almost non-existent dialogue. Some scenes sparkled with magic, but sometimes it felt like the scenes were pasted from Xena, Warrior Princess.This of course, made it difficult for Mark and the rest of the actors to create personalities which actually were interesting. I was however impressed by Tim Roth and the other monke..I mean apes.Time-travel.Always trouble.In this case,big trouble.MAJOR trouble.I didn't understand a thing.At least the ending opened for a sequel and hopefully a better one. (And why on earth did the little chimps have to play basketball??)

If you want to see another example of Hollywood dumbing down cinema, then please watch this film.The film completely misses all of the story that made the original compelling. What happened to the compelling points of the original, such as:Relegion vs Science ?Evolution ?Animal Cruelty ?Ethics of Zoo's ?Animal Experiments ?Racism?All of these wonderful points (and more) of the original are left out of the movie, to make way for an awful script, predictable chase and fight sequences, and one awful ending.SPOILER!!!!!!!!!!!Explain to me this, we leap forward in time, to where General Thade etc are, and then, at the end of the movie, leap back again.Yet, at the whitehouse, there is a General Thade statue, and the earth is ruled by apes , and yet, at that point in time, General Thade had not even existed!Whether you take it that the Ape planet was earth or not, the time sequencing of events is a paradox, and completely naff.I loved the first movie, and was hoping that this new version would bring in new arguments (such as genetics and DNA, discussed by another posting here), and yet all we get is another dumbed down picture.Hollywood is showing a contempt for its history, and for the viewing public.A big, big shame.

I just wonder how is it possible to dispense so many money to make such a pour film. Except the apes everything has no interest in this movie and we can't say that it is better than the first version of 1968. Just one thing : if you want to laugh just go and see the five last minutes (I don't want to say anything more).

-- A little bit of spoilers --Well i can tell you that I have not seen the Original movie, so I cannot compare like most people I hear are doing! Let me just say this, if you have seen the first one and now are seeing this one.. Sure... you might not enjoy it as much because:(1) You know they are on Earth (2) You know what the Story is about anyway.. So no thinking is involved, No thinking no Fun :)For me it was all new so it was very nice Story! I Recommend this movie to anyone who has not seen the Original. And for all you folks that have seen the Original.. Ease up a bit.. It is only meant to be a fun Entertaining movie based on a "novel" NOT THE ORIGINAL MOVIE for a new Generation to Enjoy!I give this movie 9/10! Later!

First I'd like to say that I really enjoyed this movie and Mark Wahlberg's performance in particular.Many people have wondered if there will be a sequel, well I did a google search and found this article entitled "No Apes sequel, says Burton": http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1496974.stm If this article is true, then someone other than Tim Burton would be directing it. Here we are 5 years later and still no sequel. It's unfortunate, because amidst all of the speculation about the meaning of the ending - it certainly screams SEQUEL! Another observation - a lot of people seem to think the ape planet that Leo crashes on (in beginning of the movie) is Earth. But Tim Burton's ape planet has two moons - it can't be Earth. However, the planet he crashes on in the end of the movie is Earth - it has one moon and the correct continents.

With it's excellent effects and direction this film was always going to be a big summer hit and unfortunately that has given them the excuse the forget about the plot. The film starts well enough dropping clues and introducing the main human. It flows along nicely with alot of references to the original film ('Take your hands off me you damned dirty human'). There is a humour and darkness to the film that can only be provided by Tim Burton as well as his trade mark scarecrows. But as with all good things, what was right about this film came to a crashing end and that comes at the end. The initial plot resolution seemed to be an afterthought and then the 'shock' ending was illogical and did not seem to tie in with events in the rest of the film. If anybody has any theories as to how the ending is possible please let me know as we haven't been able to work it out.So for effort, cast (especially Estella Warren), direction and initial plot I give this film 6 out of 10. But it would have been higher had the ending been better.

Went to the sneak preview on South Beach tonight (Thursday 07/26/01).  Do NOT listen to anyone reviewing this movie that tries to tell you the ending. This version remembers its earlier incarnations so the mythology continues. The special effects and music are excellent.  The story is new with plenty of original twists that make this an exciting movie to the very end.  "The Planet of the Apes" should make the dinosaurs of Jurassic Park extinct once more.  RULE THE PLANET.

What a waste. The original idea was so interesting but got spoiled by this terrible re-make. It takes more than an heroic USAF officer to save the audience from boredom. I was expecting much more besides the special effects. A stunning end for instance?... please, someone explain the last scene! A personal note to Mark Wahlberg. Here is a tip for your new movie: take a breath and stop panting for two hours even when there is nothing exciting on sight!

Review title: Mark Wahlberg is Brilliant in Planet of the Apes!!
Review_body: Mark Wahlberg was absolutley brilliant. He couldn't get any better. He was perfect for the part of Captain Leo Davidson. But if I could change anything about this movie, it wouldn't be so straight forward. Everything was explained for us. I mean there were a few little twists especially at the end, but I would have made it a lot more deeper. All and all it was a great movie and I would definitley go see it again.

Review title: The best movie of the summer is finally here!!!
Review_body: A lot of folks have expessed their disappointment in the final twist of the movie, but let me just say Tim Burton is one funny guy.
