The end was a great twist and lent a smile to my face.  You people that hate the end, too bad. There's nothing you can do to change it, so live with it and take it for what it is, Tim Burton's sense of humor shining through. The screen play by William J. Broyles and others was fabulous, and who can say more than "The Oscar goes too...Rick Baker for Planet Of The Apes"?  Burton delivers his usual chuzpah in his own dark and twisted way, and his long time friend, Danny Elfman delivers one of his best scores ever.  If you are looking for true summer escapist fun, Planet of the Apes rules.  So, grab some popcorn and a banana and be prepared to have fun.

Tim Burton does a spectacular job of re-imagining and re-telling planet of the Apes. In watching Tim Burton's Planet of the Apes you can see the simularity's to the original film, but Burton also manage's to tie in his usuall twists and turns that make him such an amazing and one of a kind Director. When watching this film you tend to forget that there are only people under all that fur and makeup and not real Apes,thanks to Rick Baker.As if all that is not enough the casting for this film couldn't have been much better. Tim Roth Plays Thade the General of the Apes that despieses the humans.Tim Roth Delivers an unbelievably frightning performance that he should be recognized for. Helen Bonham Carter gives an absolutely steller performance as Ari. Ari is an ape that has pity for the humans because she see's how poorly they are treated by the Apes, after she meets Leo Davidson (Mark Whalberg)  she starts to realize that Leo is different from the other humans and she starts to believe in the humans more and more. Mark Whalberg Delivers a good performance but nothing that he will be remembered for. And last but not least Danny Elfman, Elfman composed perfect music for this film which I guess was not that big of a surprise because he always gives a 110 percent. Great music, great acting, Burton+Elfman= Great Movie!!!

Review title: did everyone see the same movie?
Review_body: slow, predictable, and lacking any real magic at all.  I didn't care if all the apes died or the humans were wiped out.  The big battle at the end was about as "epic" as the jim carrey fight scene in Dumb and Dumber.  Cheese ball ape-human love scene with some out-right horrible add-ons, like having the young boy ride out to help and oops, don't you know it, his horse falls. I guess since humans are animals and don't have horses readily available we shouldn't expect them to be doing and jousting are dressage.  Predictable ending that lacked the jaw dropping effect of the original.  Terrible cameo with Heston, ain't it funny the president of the NRA is now dressing up in ape make-up and preaching the evils of technology and guns.  The make-up was beautiful and some performances were actually good, but the real problem is, if you're going to use the same name as the original, it better be as good as the original.  I expected better.  Sleepy Hollow, Beetlejuice, Edward scissor hands..... Tim Burton was not up to par with planet of the apes.

A terribly horrid film.  Predictable, with a poor script, and worse dialogue.  Sadly, the ending was, as expected, just horrible.  It's a shame because the original film is just excellent, and I don't understand how Tim Burton got involved with this.

I just previewed this movie at the theater that I work as a projectionist for last night. I especially enjoyed the great audio in the movie. Halfway through the movie and especially in the battle scene I was right on the edge of my seat. Very very good movie, well worth seeing.

Review title: A movie which I didnt expect much from and enjoyed.
Review_body: Well, I have never seen any of the original Planet of the Apes movies so therefore I cannot compare between them. But after seeing this movie I might just go out and rent them. The costumes and sfx in this movie are pretty amazing, and it has a good cast. And overall its a movie I enjoyed, I give it a 8/10.

the movie simply was not good. Tim Burton had good IDEAS, but never executed them well. the movie was so god awful predictable. there were NO surprise story twists(EXCEPT the ending which was AWESOME), and no reason to care for any of the characters(well, i cared about the lil' chimp in the spaceship). Tim Burton DID develop the ape social structure very well, but it took HALF the movie to do so. the whole humans versus apes battle was not exciting at all. The action just wasnt good.the big PLUS of the movie though were the Apes. The makeup and set design were awesome, and the actors LOOKED like apes! so, kudos to Rick(or rich?) Baker for the makeup, but that wasnt enough to save this movie.it is worth going to see once.

Well,I had been waiting for the last few years (after hearing of a new Planet of the Apes being in the works)for this film to become a reality.After many script changes (not to mention stars & directors) was it worth the wait?YYYYYYEEEEEEEEESSSSS!!This version ROCKS! Now, I am almost 40 years old and grew up with the original films,TV series & cartoon.I was an apeaholic back in the day!I had everything from the Mego figures to the Don Post masks. I had realized early on,that this was NOT a remake but a "re-imagined" Planet of the Apes by Tim Burton.I am not a huge Tim Burton fan,though there are a couple of his films I enjoy.After seeing his version of POTA last night,I have to say that I am very impressed!Great story,great acting and fantastic make-up! Though the story and the names have changed,Burton's film is exciting to the core.I will not give much away as the movie has yet to be released on Friday,but I will say that there are more than a couple of original POTA quotes thrown in and the ending is a nice twist (as it was in the original). Don't be too hard on this version,even though it is not the APJAC vision,it stands on it's own!APEAPHILES ENJOY!! 9 out of 10.

Review title: A warped plot line wrapped in incredible acting and makeup.
Review_body:
The film overall was only mediocre but some performances and all the make up jobs were done so well you might think they were apes.The star of the film in my opinion is Tim Roth. He acts the psychopathic homicidal ape perfectly. Even the walk he seems to have perfected. No wonder Quentin Tarantino hires him so much; he works well with twisted characters and plotlines. (Watch Reservoir Dogs if you don't believe me... Mr. Orange)The love triangle of Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg), Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) and the blond chick with a big chest [i think she was called Deana] (Estelle Warren), is hilarious. Some critics have said that they wished that Davidson and Ari had more of a relationship instead of the blond chick with a big chest and Davidson. This is totally crazy! Have they SEEN THE MOVIE??? The only thing that blond chick with big chest did was kiss Davidson once and look exactly like a blond chick with big chest. She is a token piece in this movie.... The relationship with Ari and Davidson not only involves a kiss but he saves her life more than once, and they even TALK! I think that some critics need to cut back on their drinking!Speaking of blond chick/big chest being the token piece, she is only in the movie because people expect her. They screwed up the ending, so why keep her? But yet again the adolescent male attitudes that every guy keeps hidden SOMEWHERE rear their ugly heads. Look at most of the movies these days, find one that doesn't have a token chick with a big chest? It doesn't seem well. Natural.Well then, the makeup jobs. INSANE! Each of the prosthetics that the actors wore was individual created. Unlike the original movie, every ape has a different face, which is highly expressive and flexible, Kudos to the makeup crew:Rick Baker,   Brigitte Bugayong,  Gabriel De Cunto, Toni G, Teressa Hill, Jamie Kelman,  Patricia Miller (II),  Denise Paulson, Alex Proctor, Robin SlaterI was highly impressed.The directing was impressive as well, timing the movements and brining a vision to life was left up to Tim Burton and yet again he brings the screen to life. Every scene in the film was well thought out and well held together, this was an impressive feat for a remake.Forgive me but the ending of this movie sucked. I wont say more but it did....
Adios

I thought that this movie was going to be great. Save your money. Besides the makeup and costumes, there's not much substance here. If Tim Roth and Heston hadn't shown up, the party would have been unbearable. The story is weak, the characters are undeveloped and the situations are premature the majority of the time. I couldn't believe how bad this movie was (I'm rambling, I know, but I am really disenchanted). In my opinion, it seemed as though Burton had a vision that did not pan out. I'm not sure if it was money or creative pressure, but the outcome was one that would have been better off if it never happened.

Thought there would be more to it. The end was dumb, movies are better when they are sumed up, not just left to wonder. If there was more stuff explained in it, you kind of had to piece stuff togethre, also he should not have kissed the monkey.

I am a huge fan of the original series, maybe that's what ruined the new one for me. I was looking forward to an all new installment and what we got was a boring plot-less mess that decides to use movie lines from the original as jokes. The Makeup and sets are great but who cares? This movie is lifeless and dull for the first hour as apes sit around discussing human rights.The New Planet of the Apes lacks the mystery and intrigue and character the first movie had and only decided to capitalize on the fact that Apes can talk. The ending is a ridiculous mess too that only sets up a sequel possibility. This movie is garbage and you should spend your time watching the original instead. I came as close to crying when I walked out of the theater as I ever had in my life.

This is without a doubt, Tim Burton's worst film to date. I've read other reviews of the film and agree with the general consensus that the score (Elfman) and the makeup/special effects (Baker, etc.) were spectacular. Of course they were! Why shouldn't they be? With the current level of sophistication we enjoy in special effects and advanced makeup/prosthetic applications there is no excuse whatsoever for shabby makeup and crappy effects. What are we left with after the glitz? Stuntmen jumping 20, 30 and 50 feet into the air again and again and again. That particular effect was so overdone throughout the film as to render it completely flaccid by the end of this piece of garbage. Plot? There was none, really. This was purely an action film with a "screenplay" that was written by and for idiots.

Review title: Roger Ebert missed the main point
Review_body: In case you missed Roger Ebert's review, he didn't like Mark Wahlberg's role as a hero, or his lack of heroism in the movie.  He must have been asleep during the part where his character points out to Carter's female ape character, that "...we are not alike, you care about everybody else but yourself."  For me, this whole statement defines the movie. He only wants to go home.  He only cares about himself.  And all without the arrogant 'attitude' we're used to seeing in movies.  It's either Look at me I'm cool, or Look at me I'm a hero, Wahlberg's character and final decision in the movie pave the way for turning upside down everything you ever thought you knew about what's really going on.  A perfect sci-fi where the seemingly explainable goes unexplained.The plausibility of the opening year at 2029?  A stretch...only if you believe we're in the same reality, which you will find out becomes one for the X-files.   The original 1968 movie left you with a shock, so you could figure out the timeline and the ape evolution.  This movie doesn't try to shock, as many are thinking it's supposed to.  It's actually supposed to make you THINK who came first, human or ape?  You will realize that you would have never reached this point if Wahlberg walked the path of the true hero.

Review title: Damn You 20th Century Fox! Damn you all to hell! (Mild spoiler alert!)
Review_body: Remember the 1968 original Planet of the Apes?  Now imagine an updated version of that same movie without the creativity, witty social commentary, and entertainment value and that's what you get out of Apes circa 2001. This year has proven to be a wasteland of one bad movie after another, and Apes 2001 will most likely be looked at as a contributor to this wasteland, at least by me.The original and subsequent versions had social commentary that mirrored the current events of those times, such as the Watts riots and the Vietnam War. Apes 2001 was just a lame attempt to make a blockbuster movie by trying to capture lightning in a bottle a second time with name recognition, cliches, and special effects.  I started looking at my watch well before the halfway mark of the movie.The movie insults the intelligence of the moviegoer by having the apes give that annoying, piercing, headache-inducing shriek everytime they get excited, mad, happy, etc.  I suppose that director Tim Burton wanted to drive the point home that they are in fact apes in case we couldn't figure that out from the title of the movie and that they call themselves "apes" a lot.  It felt more like being at a zoo than a movie theater.Let's not forget the touch of absurdity too.  Apes teases a love triangle between Capt. Davidson (Mark Wahlberg), a native human woman, and Ari the bleeding heart ape.  Yes, you read it correctly.  Thank goodness it was only a PG-13 movie.Nothing noteworthy about the acting.  Wahlberg struts around as the hero, which is par for the course.  Tim Roth as Gen. Thade came across as more of an annoyance than as ruthless.  Kris Kristofferson contributes little, other than to continue his own streak of being offed in a movie before it's over. Of all the actors here, I felt bad for Michael Clarke Duncan.  After his breakthrough performance in The Green Mile, he was typecasted as a dimwitted giant ape in most other later movies.  I never expected for him to be literally typecasted as that to boot, but Apes 2001 does just that by feeding him the limited role as the stooge/friend of Gen. Thade.The ending - which by the way many will see coming a mile away - leaves the door open for a sequel, and if Apes 2001's undeserving blockbuster numbers hold up, sadly that's what we will get.Stay far, far away from this movie, even if you're a diehard fan of all the original Apes movies, have all the episodes of the TV series and cartoon on tape, have back hair, and crave bananas constantly.  Rent the original and just leave it at that. (1/10)

Review title: Excellent, Without doubt better than the original
Review_body: You have to go and see it! Tim Burton has out-done himself again! His Idea of what the ape world should look like is completely different, and better than the original, without doubt this movie is worth going too see. I don't really want to spoil things, just go and see the movie!

Why would you remake a classic? Why would you spend 100 million to make such a bad movie? And for that 100 million could they not have come up with a better script?This movie is horrible, save your money and catch the original some weekend at 2am... And if you really want to see what this remake is like, then catch one of the sequels to the original planet of the apes. Those are just as painful..

The worst movie I have seen in a long time.  The ending made no sense in any possible permutation of events.  There were so many holes in the movie I could use it as a strainer.I am very upset because I was hoping to like this movie.  Instead, a wasted money.  I have never openly discouraged anyone from seeing a movie before but... Don't go and see this movie! Please, for the love of god! Stay away!

Review title: A real disappointment and conclusion begging for a sequel.
Review_body: ***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS*** I was about 12 when the first movie came out. I have seen it about 10 times since.Not since "Back to the Future" was an ending more ripe for a sequel.The story-line was definitely different.The major differences between versions were: 1. Humans could speak. 2. Apes had no technology. 3. Planet was not earth. 4. Overall acting was inferior. 5. Special effects however were OK. 6. Apes were more ape-like in attitute and mannerisms.It was obvious from the start that the world was not earth. Yet the conclusion of the movie ended on earth.  This was very confusing to me.

Review title: An exercise in what not to do.
Review_body: In brief, this is a tragic example of a movie that should not have been made. I am not saying that the original was so amazing that it is blasphemous to re-do it, far from it. What I am saying is that this movie is so lacking in a compelling story that the truly amazing Ape effects and acting are utterly wasted. The human actors are uniformly wooden and seemingly unaffected by thousands of years of oppression, not to mention that lipstick and hairspray seem to have been developed in the jungle somehow.If you can overlook the glaring plot holes, and somehow completely ignore the, lets face it, ridiculous ending, then you stand a chance of appreciating the truly fantastic apes. If this movie could have been made without the human element, it would be an excellent portrayal in itself, as it is, this film never rises above mildly entertaining. If you are old enough to have seen the original in it's time, you will probably loathe this disaster.

Review title: Seeing it for the first time
Review_body: Unlike most people, I did not see the original Planet of the Apes before I went to this movie.  So, I did not get a lot of the jokes that pertained to the previous movie(s).  Based on that, I have to say that this movie is not as good as I thought it would be.  The action is great, and the costumes phenomenal (Rick Baker is awesome).  But the dialogue lacked depth.  Go see the movie for the action and laughs, but don't go if you don't like cheesy lines delivered badly.

Dark, even for Burton. None of the social commentary & bite of the original. He missed the point.None of the dark humor of the original. No in-depth look into the ape society. Simpleton plot.Really stretched to provide a twist in the end which had none of the shock value of the original. End made no sense whatever!

Terrible movie, plain and simple!No character development (save for Ari) and even the main character Leo had nothing of interest to say. (Roth is fine as Thade but all he does is sniff and snarl)Sure, the make-up is amazing but it's the 21st century for heavens sake, of course the make-up should be amazing.Unfortunately the art of storytelling hasn't done too well in this new century.The "CA-LI-MA" trick was a bad rif-off from "Star Trek: TMP" where they used V'ger!And by the way, if, on this new planet, humans out-number the apes 4-1, why would this be a planet of the "Apes"?
** SPOILERS **The basic premise of the movie that the space station crash lands thus giving rise to the planet of the "Apes" is ok but not exactly mind-blowing.The D.C. ending is just stupid. It feels so "tacked on". And what a stroke of luck he managed to crash land right there too, we might have had to sit through another 20 mins of this rubbish if he didn't.

Review title: Smooth plot, Impressive apes, and Great overall aura
Review_body:
The look and feel of this film is great!  It's a different, yet consistent aura, which makes the film very interesting and feasible.  Danny Elfman's score fits in seamlessly with the film, and the casting is very good.
The plot is very smooth and the film carries along well, which is to be somewhat expected, as it's a re-make, but that shouldn't be taken for granted, because even with little changes, re-makes can be screwed up.The actors and makeup artists did an amazing job creating believable apes. The movements of the actors are astounding - the walking especially.  The makeup is incredible - becoming more rare as cinema progresses because directors and producers want to do things computer generated, because it's quicker and easier, even though makeup is more realistic.  Tim Burton's decision to go with makeup was very shrewd.Planet of The Apes is a fascinating film and provokes much thought, if you are open to it.  I liked it very much.

Review title: Great movie, but doesnt stay true to the originial
Review_body: I remember watching the original, with good ole NRA leader, Charleton Heston.  I remember it being meaningful, instead of this new-age "save the little people" approach that try to teach us animal rights and how humans are cruel and unpredictable.Let me just get this out in the open, the ending sucked.  Sure it was a surprise, but it made no sense and it forces a sequel to explain it.  I would've enjoyed it better if it was more like the original (and not the book).If you've seen the original, it's nothing like this version.  He lands by himself and is quickly thrown into the conflict.  A minor change (that I wasnt expecting, actually) was that he could talk as soon as he landed, where in the original it took Heston a while to talk.  Dr. Zaius is back, thrown in a comedic role thus losing the serious role he had back in the original.  Again, it's just a matter of taste.  If you want a reved up, updated classic...this is the movie for you.Something has always bothered me.  It was in the original and in this one as well (I dont know if it's the same in the book as well), but why doesnt the main character get that HOT human chick?  He seems more interested in that female monkey!  Sheesh, Estella Warren is very VERY hot, and she's a Canadian as well! ;)  That chick from the original was hot too, but she's like 4 000 years old now... :(The effects were there, the musical score was there...the plot and development of characters was not.  We get a sense of the theme, but neither the main character or his human friends are developed in any way.Overall, it's a very enjoyable movie, however they took a lot from the original that hard-core fans such as myself dont like.

Review title: There should be a prequel, not a sequel
Review_body: "Planet" was, until the last 5 minutes of it, a great movie. The apes look very realistic thanks to Rick Baker's make-up design, which definitely is Oscar worthy.  The actors playing the apes were superb, I almost forgot that there were humans under all that make-up, while the human actors almost took away from the movie.  *SPOILER* The time travel story line is what really hooked me onto this movie.  The twist of Leo being indirectly responsible for the apes creation and domination over humans yet also being directly responsible for getting apes and humans to live in peace is genius.  I'm very curious as to how exactly the apes got smarter and stronger.  Instead of a sequel from the absolutely awful ending, I think there should instead be a prequel, something like "Before the Planet of the Apes".  I heard the rumor that 5 endings were shot for this film but both why Tim Burton chose this ending makes no sense.

Review title: No Story, very bad ending, just a hide and seek movie, very bad
Review_body: This movie as no real story. An ending that is totally out of context and not in the line of the movie, it is only good to make a sequel. It is just a hide and seek movie (get in and get out like a bad alien movie) Only the mask are a little better that the one in the original.

I've just come from the cinema after watching Planets of the apes, and i can only say that it was one of the best i have seen for years...I've always enjoyed watching movies made by Tim Burton and this one was no exception!

Some fans of the original will complain that it's so different, but in this case that's a strength.  Planet of the Apes was always one of my favorite movies and this one is even better.  It has a deeper story line and when you leave the theater, you're still trying to figure out the end.  I went with 3 other people and we all had different interpretations.  It was exciting, intelligent, emotional and the make-up was outstanding.  The soundtrack was fantastic too.  Very Tim Burton.

Review title: Worth seeing, but not an all-time fave.
Review_body: I sat through the movie and thought it was awesome. Later: I have a real problem with the storyline. There was not hardly any character interaction.  The "love" between Wahlberg and the two girls was never even examined.  There were looks, but absolutely nothing to believe that he cared even a little about them.  It was a little mind boggling with the crazy ending.  After I left the theatre everything got to me, and I decided I was trying to hard to interpret it. Now: I can only say it is worth seeing and try not to be too critical.

ENDING ALERT!!! DON'T READ THIS IF YOU DON'T WANT TO KNOW!!! What the hell was with that ending? Even if apes took control I don't think they would develop Ford Taurus police cars or white ambulances or even red fire trucks. Or the Washington monument or any of the rest of Washington D.C. Somebody please explain that one to me!

Well, a typical burton movie some would say. I agree to a certain extent. Burton means a good looking movie with a pretty bad script, but he most often get away with it. Sleepy Hollows is excellent for example.This movie however, has a really really bad script. There are plotholes all over and the ending is terrible. One would think that since he based it on a idea very well covered before that the script would be easy to make into something marvelous. But instead it was predictable and full of plotholes. I will not mention them here since a few of you might not have seen to movie, but trust me on this one.The actors taking the shapes of apes are excellent, and they do a good enough job. Mark Wahlberg is stiff and doesn't really feel like he is in a perilous situation, but that is mostly because of his lack of lines, he says very little, asks almost nothing it doesn't really fit in what a person would do in his situation. You don't really get to know any of the characters.So, pretty good effects, lousy script, a typical burton movie, but in this case, the script is so bad and the effects not good enough to make watching it worthwhile.

***SPOILERS***    ***SPOILERS*** The "suprise" ending that the trailer harks about was not really such a suprise. I saw it coming but it still makes no sense at all.If he travels back to his own time and lands back on earth how did what he did in the future effect the present? How is it that there is an Abraham Lincoln ape at the Linclon memorial. Flawed cop out ending

Review title: The biggest diappointment of the millenium.
Review_body: It all sounded so good, a "reimagining" of Planet of the Apes. Richard Zanuck returned to helm production and Tim Burton was brought on board to direct. We were so optimistic. The original was a landmark film, could they do it justice? The sequels were so juvenile and simplistic surely they had learned, alas it was not to be. This movie is a train wreck. Poorly concieved, poorly written, poorly acted, preposterous in logic and impossible to follow it defies our hopes and dreams. Even without comparison to the original it fails miserably. But we can't view it without remembering. The fundamental mistake I think is that this is more than just a story about Apes. Its about one mans odyssey, his journey through time and space searching for .... well shall we say the perfect world, only to arrive in a nightmare. The remake conveys none of that. Its a chase movie aimed at the 12 to 18 yearolds who dominate the market. All the critics gush about the wonderfull makeup and effects, really? They are all in denial. They assume that because of the technical advances in the last 30 years it must be better. Well its not. The gorillas are pretty good, but we are forced to watch closeups of Helen Bonham Carter who looks ... well looks like she has a mask on. The sets look like ...sets and the Ape village in the original is 10 times more realistic than the graphic in this version. The ending? it defies any and all explanations. I remember after watching the 68 version staggering out of the dark theater with the rest of my stunned human companions, well I staggered out of the theatre again......in disbelief.

This was truly a great movie, I loved it! The ending though was really strange! So I really hope for a follow up!But I recommend it! Tim Roth plays the role of general Thade great! I´ll just say one thing to you: SEE IT!!!!

This film has taken a bit of a bagging and I did not know what to expect. POtA is a great "retelling" of the orginal. The story is simple and well rounded with only some minor faults. The major fault is how do the humans find out and track down the hero so quickly.The best part of the movie are the characters especially the apes, all played very well especially Tim Roth.The twist at the end is not to bad and does leave you thinking.

Overall I would rate the movie as poor.  The last 20 minutes especially were so so predictable.I am also find Tim Burton's dark, gothic style sets and use of lighting is starting to get boring.  He has used the same style in Edward Scissorhands, Batman and Sleepy Hollow.It would be good if Mark Wahlberg displayed more than one set of facial expressions during the movie as well.Don't waste your money.

Okay, I generally like the first version of a film and tend to skip the sequels, remakes, and anything else designed to remind me of the first film. Being a child of the 80s, I recognize that some sequels are inherently superior to others (i.e. Star Wars films, Indiana Jones, but not _Temple of Doom_, and others), so I tend to be suckered into repeats.So I purchased my $5 IMAX ticket (thank you, Canada) and was eager to see the newest addition to the _Apes_ saga.  From the first scene the sound and special effects are great.  You get wrapped into this film quickly and intensely.  You are, in fact, held throughout the entire film.Burton, as usual, has created a very, very dark film that seems to offer no hope for salvation.  Characters become aware of their "sins" and misconceptions of reality.  The battle seen of ape vs. man shows the reduction of man to his survivalist instinct, and a hope, albeit distant, for reconciliation.Most films would have stopped there.  Kudos to Burton for going further, but where did he think he was going to take us?  A great film was RUINED by the ending.  Too predicable, too "I need an ending, let's go with this one." You lost me, sir.  As we left the theater, my friends and I all echoed the same disappointment.  Tsk-tsk for going the easy way out.

I found the movie Planet of The Apes very interesting. Although I admit that I never saw the original series, I found this movie very entertaining. I also found that it was very refreshing, I needed to see a good movie this summer. I'm not interested in the mindless comedy of American Pie 2, or even The Princess Diaries. Even though I walked into the theatre slightly sceptical of "talking apes", I walked out completely satisfied. Definately a movie that will leave you thinking even long after it's over. If your sick of all the teeny bopper movies, and ready to see an unforgetable tale of human kind being turned upside down, I recommend this movie to you!

It's easy to feel sorry for the actors in this weak update to the Sci-Fi classic.  These are cartoon characters with about as much depth as a rain puddle.  The script they're forced to use is chockablock with utterances such as "I'm sick of this human" which kicks off the key battle scene. And, simply "Gotta go," as Leo (Mark Whalberg) bids adieu to his gorgeous model Daena (Estella Warren).  Maybe the only reason to see it is to try to puzzle through the twisty ending.  Better yet, have someone tell you what happens and save the money.

I liked this movie much better than the original.  The story was good, and I love the look of everything. The sets and the character make-up were wonderful.  Thade was an excellent character, as was Ari.  I'm interested in buying this one when it comes out on DVD.

Review title: Visually brilliant, scriptally good but not great
Review_body: The apes look good and are menacing in Darth Vader manner.  The characters ape or human never really get time or the opportunity to grow.  The script does just enough to try and explain the main characters actions but a lot more time should have been spent on building relationships between the characters.  The pace of the film is good but the most disappointing part of the film is the ending just before the ending.My advice is to sit back and enjoy the film because it looks great and for the most part is engaging and interesting.

Review title: One of the Worst Movies ever
Review_body: I was a fan of the original Planet of the Apes and all of its sequels, which told a fairly convincing story.  This new version blows all of my expectations away.  It was one of the worst movies I've ever seen.  The acting was terrible and if we ignore the little facts (like how easily Ari let herself be lead by humans or how Daena has lipstick and a boobjob on this planet), the overall plot made no sense.  This movie was made to have a sequel, because there was no explanation of why earth was exactly as it is now, just with apes.  All in all, DON'T SEE THIS MOVIE!!!

Review title: Intriguing and strange with a twist at the end.
Review_body: I found the movie to be quite exciting and strange.  I had to give great credit to the make-up artists for the movie.  The make-up was so terrifyingly real.  I was kind of lost at the end, but that was just because I had seen the original and was expecting something different.  But it was all in all a wonderful film.

I've never seen the original Planet of the Apes, so I went into this movie cold.  I had no expectations other than what I've seen on the previews, and Tim Burton's reputation.  The only thing I really liked about this film was the make-up effects (except for Helena Bonham Carter's make-up.  She looked more like Michael Jackson than a "lower" primate).   ... And, I would have changed the ending.  I hate it when movies go for the obvious sequel ending.

Review title: It took three writers to finish this?
Review_body:
This movie was a rank defiling of the memories I have from childhood of the Planet of the Apes movies and TV shows.  I don't know if I was more disturbed by the fact that the acting was bad, the makeup occasionally laughably bad, or the nagging feeling that the end was rushed and limited because they were running out of money... hard to tell.  But I have decided the majority of the blame should sit on the shoulders of the writers, who obviously just punched the clock and saved their best stuff for something else.  It is impossible to build a good movie without a good script.
I'm sick of seeing movies like this one, that cash in on a big opening weekend before word of mouth can get out that it stinks.  I'm  also sick of seeing movies where it is obvious that the writers ran out of steam and rather than take time to make a good product, just churn out another piece of mediocre crap.  Everything doesn't need to be high art, but decent entertainment is a good aspiration.

I have watched every Burton's film but this seems to be a job which was taken by accident. The movie is average and there's little of 'the Burton' influence. I hope the next project will be more independent. Danny Elfman's music has a bit change of style. But it remains mysterious and attractive.

Awesome costumes but an absolute CRAP movie...they should have kept closer to the original story-line and avoided the love triangle confusion.  It was embarrassing to watch the two women vying for the attentions of Mark Wahlberg.

Review title: good to look at, script not so great, some spoilers
Review_body: Planet of the Apes was not a brilliant movie, and nowhere near as good as the original.  Tim Roth completely over-did the whole husky-voiced bad guy thing, Helena Bonham-Carter was no more than annoying, and Estella Warren couldn't act to save her life.  However, Mark Wahlberg gave a good, solid & good-looking performance and he makes it rate 10/10.

This film isn't nearly as bad as lots of people are making it out to be, there are weak areas and it isn't perfect but most people just got over-hyped and expected a perfect film. There's some good characterisation for Ari and Thade and the plot wasn't all that bad and leaves plenty of room for a sequel. Some people thought it was boring but they are just petty minded simpletons who went to see a horror/action film which is more like the originals and don't understand anything outside that. Don't go expecting more of the originals, like Burton said, it's not a remake, more of a rehash.

Review title: Awful remake of great sci-fi classic
Review_body: I've just seen the movie, and man did I sit through one of the most tasteless, tacky, non-inspired remake of one of the great sci-fi classics there is out there...I know it's tough to make a good remake of an older film, with regards to the conflict between fans of the original film and the fans of modern-day action, blockbuster movies, but - come on! A total rip-off of the original plot, except for the classic ending which had to be different since the ending was so surprising and by now well-known in the original, an un-inspired casting (lets face it; Mark Wahlberg will not be remembered for his great acting skills) and an over-all feeling of "Oh, I know what's going to happen next" throughout the movie. I felt totally cheated and exploited after coming out of the theatre!My five cents worth to you: Save your money, it's not worth it!

Review title: Not as good as it could have been, or should have been.
Review_body: While this movie did have a couple of upsides to it, like Tim Roth's excellent performance, the make-up, and the gun thing with Heston; I still feel like I should have just mailed the theater $5.50.It was way to over the top and exceeded the limits normally given to action-adventure films.  I know that the concept of the movie is over-the-top in and of itself, but c'mon.  Heston's last line as he dies was murder.  I think Burton went a little to hollywood.

Review title: Just the name and lots of money
Review_body: How dare they? I was hoping to see something new, modern and interesting. What I did see, was Marky -I look so good-, a bit blabla and a very expansive looking decoration and mask. Nothing more. I had some hopes, that the Three angle story, the hero, the ape and the girl will get more weight at the end. The character girl was so ironic and the ape the one to fall in love with. No, nobody must have had the ambition to use the tones of money something like this cost, to create an interesting story. The voting in imdb.com is 6.1. What is up with you? Don´t you know, how a good film looks like? Sad, but true, let´s hope, they don´t sequel this one,tooRichard

What a disappointment, especially in light of the budget provided, the technical resources available, and the talent assembled.  Isn't the fundamental rule for science fiction/drama to create in the audience the willing suspension of disbelief.  POA 2001 creates a plausible beginning, suckering us in, but thereinafter Mr. Burton forgets that his moviegoers have working brains.  The over the top libertarian of Helena Bonham Carter's chimp, the worthlessness of the humans' lockup, the ease of their escape, their extraordinary skills of horsemanship (this is an astronaut and a group of human primitives suddenly riding full tilt), the massive and immediate human rebellion all are too unbelievable.  Mark Wahlberg never once projects any sense of real fear, danger or comeuppance in this world turned upside down.  Compare to the original, in which Chuck Heston's nakedness metaphorically captured his utter helplessness and astonishment at his turn of events.  The uniformed Wahlberg preserves his modesty, but also his apparent sense of management and control in an inherently wacky situation, and we never really wonder about his well being.  Unlike Heston, he seems never to be in real jeopardy.  Tim Burton should have used some of the f/x budget for some competent screenwriting.  In fact, after this inferior fiasco, I wonder why Hollywood's producers ever bothered to settle the screenwriters and directors strike threats. Let them walk.  Trained monkeys could have done as well as they did in Planet of the Apes 2001.  I'll bet the repeat viewings of this effort will be nonexistent.  It could have been a new franchise, and a wonderful new step for imagination.  Another opportunity lost.

Review title: Possibly the worst dreck I have seen this year
Review_body: I debated through the whole movie, "should I leave this mind numbing experience, or might I miss something original and entertaining appear?" Alas, the answer was... I should have left.Mark Walhberg again shows he can't act his way out of a .... paper bag? When he is attempting to show pain, his pathetic grimace looks like an act. When he attempts to lead the humans in the final confrontation, you can see what's going through his head: Hmmm, I can't act, let alone lead this rag tag bunch of humans. I HAVE NO COURISMA.Then there are the technical issues regarding the pod, able to fly about like a space ship in and out of the atmosphere? At least Charlton Heston had a real ship to crash into the earth with. And then there are the  plot holes and contrivances I could drive a Mack truck through. Arggg, enough.Sorry for any errors, omissions, or spelling mistakes.

Tim Burton is one of the most original and appealing directors of all cinema history, but this time, he seems not to be believing in what he is doing. What is more, you can easily realize, that this is not an own fiction. It is perfectly truth that make-up, special effects, costumes design, mourning atmosphere and its production design are brilliant, but the screenplay as well as the some of the performances are uneven. The movie easily bleeds because of its narrative weakness and its forced final twist. It has also a great rhythm and spectacular action moments, by far the best, however it sinks rapidly not only because the relations between characters are a kind of childish, but also because of its sense of humor. In spite of that, it is a decent and interesting motion picture.

Review title: Great New Visualisation of the "Planet of the Apes" Idea
Review_body: As a fan of the original Planet of the Apes movies, I really enjoyed this new motion picture.Normally, remakes suffer from the fact that they are just copies of the original movie, mostly without the excitement or fun of it.Planet of the Apes is a new attempt to use the idea behind Planet of the Apes. Thus, it is worth to be seen even by die-hard fans of the original movies.Mark Wahlberg can never match the quality of Charlton Heston, and was probably not a good choice, but the Apes are even more realistic and differentiated than in the old movies, as far as their characters are concerned. The girl which was Nova in the 1968 movie is also much more intelligent and has more to offer than just to look good.All the cruelty of manhood is being shown to as like in a fable on the example of the monkeys - sorry, apes! This content alone makes it really hard to create a bad movie upon it.Planet of the Apes (2001) is really worth the money, it has impressive shots to offer, a smooth storyline, interesting characters and an idea which should make us think about ourselves and our history.Only the end is really poor and doesn't fit the rest of the movie. It looks as if this was only added to ensure future sequels. It is very primitive and doesn't match the quality of the actual movie.

Good movie, actors, and plot...what more would you need? Nothing in this movie is lacking definition or explanation....it's all right there! The only part that needs description is the ending, but it's just a great leading into the sequel, which obviously there will be. I don't think anyone should criticize this movie unless this is the kind of movie they like. Also, all you old POTA fans, you can't compare this one to the original. The only thing in common is the basic plot....it's not the same movie!!! So I think anyone who likes this type of genre of movies really will like this movie, but only see it if it interests you, not because you like the old POTA because it's just not the same.

I think bas rutten summed it up pretty well. I got the DVD of the Planet remake for free from the video store, and I still got ripped off! 2 hours of my life that I'll never get back! Yep, cool CG, adequate make-up (I'm not as impressed with the make-up as are others) and an uncredited cameo that made me smile when I realized who it was under the make-up. Aside from that, I can't think of anything else that's noteworthy about this movie.As I watched the remake of Planet, my mind began to wander.... I lost interest in the movie and was preoccupied with making a mental list of crappy movies that must've "looked good on paper." That is, instead of screwing up classics like Planet, go back and remake old movies that had potential, but didn't come through for whatever reason (direction, editing, cinematography, screen adaptation, etc.).

Review title: Burton adds his original vision to Planet of the Apes
Review_body: I was blown away with how well Burton adapted this movie. I guess adapted isn't even the right word. He basically re-worked the whole thing. The main ideas and some of the most important visuals are there, but the story is quite different. Planet of the Apes has gone from a hokey cult movie to an amazing science fiction vision of the future. But it's not only the effects and costuming that are much better. Burton has created a chilling yet realistic version of what apes might evolve to. The way they move, their facial expressions, the behavior. Everything is really well thought out. I don't know what others were expecting, but I though this movie really delivered great acting, great effects, and a nice story adaptation.

Eek! When I imagined someone may judge all SF by this movie, I thought about burning my SF collection. The scenario was written without giving much consideration to probability or common sense, not to mention complete disregard of most basic rules of science. OK then, it's action movie dressed in space suit. But action movie needs to make sense too! This one doesn't. I can't believe such steaming pile of bullpoo comes from director of Edward Scissorhands, Mars Attacks! and Batman(s).

Review title: Burton and the Apes--the commentary and documentaries were excellent!
Review_body: I just love movies that have director commentaries and this one certainly didn't disappoint. Apparently, Burton decided to do this commentary at the very last minute, and, have no doubt, the spontaneous accounts from the fevered mind of Tim Burton are something to behold. It truly gives you an idea of the intricacies that went into crafting each scene of this visual feast.Some highlights from the commentary include Burton talking about what it was like to work with real apes. He said, 'you get this weird vibe from having a relationship with apes. There's a definite connection between humans and apes but its weird, so primal, and so shocking.' Burton's comments reminded me of what Michael Aped, director of Gorilla's in the Mist, had said about working with apes. He said there were many times when he thought there was a real person staring at him and when he turned to see who it was, it had been an ape. He said the experience was eerie, yet fascinating.Burton also talked a lot about this idea of his version of Planet of the Apes being a circular thing. About everything coming back to the beginning or the middle or something. I couldn't quite understand fully what he was talking about, however, it reminded me of Joni Mitchell's Circle of Life song. Oh well,...a creative mind like Tim Burtons is not to be completely understood, only enjoyed.Anyway, the movie is great and Tim Burton's commentary makes the DVD spectacular.

i would just like to say that planet of the apes was a really good movie. the only thing that i did not like about it was the ending but i think that they are thinking of making another one and thats how they decided to end it. oh ya and Mark Wahlberg is really hot!!!!!!!!

Review title: Waste of Four dollars and Eleven Cents!
Review_body: I was unfortunate enough to pick this movie up today at the local video store after seeing a slightly above average rating on this site.  Sadly, this is the first time the ratings have been, in my opinion, totally inaccurate.  From the savages to the apes, I can't help but laugh at the pathetic dialogue, poor, uhm, acting?, and the, well, general atrocity of the overall movie.  The blond savage was the highlight of this movie with her sequined(I didn't actually notice the sequins, but it was commented by the rest of the excited crowd gagging on the movie), tight-fitting, low-cut cave woman swimsuit, and I can't forget to mention the sexy red lipstick she manages to keep smudge-free throughout the movie. *note:  i just heard "what a crap movie!" as i'm typing this review.  For some odd reason, the rest of them are still watching the blockbuster.Don't waste your time!!!

It is by blindly choosing the unknown that everything in the world gets thrown upside down. He enters a time warp, finds that he has traveled in time (forwards, backwards -- who knows?) Ends up on a planet dominated by apes that his ship previously planted there -- irresponsible time travel with powerful results over the course of time.Then there is a whole lot of action, climaxing to the insight of the hero. One man has the insight into these phenomenon... and what does he do? when he gets the chance he jumps right back into a time warp and sees the results of his actions as they have spiraled out over time.. He left a peaceful situation on the ape planet only to find that had he stayed, the course of history could have been drastically different. Thought provoking movie wrapped up in a modern day action flick.

This is possibly the worst movie remake ever.  Tim Burton should be ashamed that he made this garbage.  Planet of the apes without any of the original characters makes this a complete waste of time, and diminishes the original. The only thing that could have made this movie better is if Marky Mark was not the lead.

Review title: This movie was clearly a 6 till the last 10 minutes which, made it a 1.
Review_body: This movie was clearly a 6 till the last 10 minutes which, made it a 1. This movie falls under the category of phantacrap.  The end of the movie must have been conceived while under the influence of some amazingly boring drugs.  This work is staple 70's crap that has been digitally remastered to spread poor film viewing to the new generation.

Review title: In all Honesty, this is extensively more of a movie than the original. No offense Heston!!!
Review_body: In all honesty, I can say that Tim Burtons version of this film made the original in all honesty look like (as that saying goes) look like ape sh**! But that is just my opinion. The graphics, the story, the whole thing seemed to grab more of my attention than the others did... Now there is no doubt that Charleton Heston did an extrodanary job acting in the others, but Mar Wahlberg isn't bad at all in this one! Mark Wahlberg is honestly a good actor, and just because he is not viewed in the same way that Heston is, doesn't mean that he can't give a good performance! Anyways, the whole film was extrodanary in the aspect of anyone who enjoys good plots and imaginative views! PS, I loved the intro for some reason... So Tim Burton, keep up the good work!

I have seen and liked the original film, and expected more from a remake than this.GOOD: Effects and makeup are good.  No complaints about the score and visuals, they are adequate, and the performances were okay (Tim Roth was excellent, the other principals were fine, and a handful of the "supporting supporting actors" did very well with extremely limited roles).  The action scenes were exciting and fun.BAD: The escape from the ape city was terrible.  The characters are going in circles, then suddenly someplace in the middle of town there are tunnels to escape.  Plus, what escape route leads through everybody's bedroom?The story was pared down to include as much action as possible.  I like action scenes but the original film had more meat to it and deserved more respect.Finally, the ending was completely nonsensical as presented.  Without seeing the inevitable sequel, there is no justification for it.

The revision "Planet of the Apes" pretty much lived up to my expectations as a not-too-good nice try. By itself it makes a reasonable action sci-fi but falls far short from the great originals. Although it does try to make a statement of some kind, it is far too obviously and shallowly done. The characters were also a let down, being quite one dimensional.That said, however, should the movie be judged by it's own merits, and not seen in the shadow of the original Planet of the Ape movies, it does deserve some credit as far as entertainment is concerned. It follows a good, exciting and 'non-stagnating' plot, and the viewer remains interested throughout.Overall; a nice try but should not have tried to follow in the foot-steps of the originals.

Review title: Lesser drama, a load of action.
Review_body: To put this film directly into perspective, I watched the original version of Planet of the Apes (1968). Although I enjoyed the newer version, there are some small disappointments to mention: Minor changes to plot seem to make this movie less mysterious and dramatic.The main character, again an astronaut, doesn't come out of deep hibernation this time. Heroic enough, in an attempt to rescue a monkey during an experiment, he himself loses contact with the space station too.When he - the astronaut named Leo Davidson - is stranded alone on a planet the dialog shifts to the inhabitants. It's a pity he is able to communicate with both apes and humans. In the older version the humans talked apey.Nonetheless, the art direction of this movie is very impressive. The costumes look superb. I question however why there are various ape species chosen. It takes away some of the realism, although it is supposed to be fiction from the start.Due to the dark sounds used, this movie is still somewhat of a thrill. There may be lesser drama, but it contains a load of beautifully captured action. Tim Burton, the director, did a good job, as well as the art direction.

Review title: Although good, could have been much better
Review_body: Planet of the Apes while good, could have been much better. The actors, I feel gave great performances and were very convincing as apes, however, the story line was poorly developed. In the original POTA films, there were hundreds of apes that looked exactly alike, so although you knew their names it was hard to distinguish each ape. In 2001 POTA, Rick Baker did a wonderful job of creating a wide variety of apes with very different physical features, however, most were never called by their names. Even the human's name were not mentioned so although you could tell them apart, who were they? I feel that this film is worthy of a sequel, if for no other reason than the performance of Tim Roth as General Thade who needed a female in the worst way. I believe that if a sequel is made, Tim Burton will redeem himself or at least I hope so.

The 1968 version was truly a sci-fi masterpiece. The remake however, was not. The fact that the humans were not mute was completely un-disturbing, and meant that some terrible dialogue was included. As humans go, the acting was woeful, especially Estella Warren's performance. On the positive side, the special effects were impressive, the soundtrack was flawless and the ending was a welcomed shock, however this less than makes up for the rest of the movie. A huge disappointment for fans of the original movie series.

I would have given this movie a 8 / 10 rating had it not been for the ending.  I don't want to spoil anything for those that haven't seen the movie and want to, but the ending blew me out of the water.  I bought the movie at Sam's Club after they lowered the price $10.  I'm glad I waited. Rent it, it's really good except for the ending.

Review title: Judge It For What It Is
Review_body: The trouble with many films is that when they have been remade from an original title is that people expect it to live up to the previous film and also to be based on the original. This is not the case with this film on any of the above points. Tim Burton did an excellent job creating a unique film which is not like the predecessor and also to make use of the acting talents among the cast.The main star of the show of course is Mark Wahlberg takes on the role of Captain Leo Davidson and portrays the role excellently. His interaction with the apes and humans takes on interesting twists as the story progresses but he gives a solid performance and his unusual but interesting relationship with Ari who is played by the very talented Helena Bonham Carter who always gives a very credible performance is very intriguing. Ari who is of a important family ( the daughter of a senator ) is what can be described as an idealist which is a minority within the Ape culture within the film. She reaches out to the humans and in peticular Wahlberg as he is dragged into this conflict which he does not really want to be a part of.The supporting cast within the film are excellent and Tim Roth who plays General Thade does what can only be described as an excellent and versatile performance. Displaying constant anger towards humanity only to be further angered with the predicament of his father. A lot was weighed on Thade within the film due to his family being ancestors of the first ape on the planet ( Seamus ). His trusty friend and deputy Michael Clarke Duncan is very well known for the role he played in the Green Mile showed just how good of an actor he is in this film due to the fact that he had to portray a range of emotions while obviously being made up into an ape costume which would of taken a substantial amount of time. He is his trusted friend but being a devout follower of the faith within the Ape community which in the end gives him a massive decision to make. Estella Warren who plays Daena who is a human 'rebel' in the film has a major part to play in the film and appeals to Wahlbergs human side constantly while obviously having confused feelings for him.Throughout the film apes are closely linked to ourselves and on several occasions their are very clever pieces of writing to alert us to the common links between ourselves and apes. Also I believe the film is used to have a sharp dig at some of the aspects of our society. Also with unique ' Ape' humour and their take on human traditions and games is excellent to see what an ape society could be like if Apes ever evolved.In all this film is not like the original and viewers should not compare it to it. This film in its own right is a solid watchable film which has a bit of everything an all round fan of films would like. Drama, suspense, action, slight romance, comedy and above all putting the thought into our heads of ' What would it really be like if Apes had a society or planet.' Well I asked myself that and it scared the hell out of me.

I liked it right up until the ending, which made no sense to me.  I do understand that the director (Tim Burton) had to keep the options open for a sequel, but whoever does that sequel (if they do it) will have a difficult time basing it on what I saw!  Good Luck!

Review title: Okay, but no replacement for the original.
Review_body: I saw this movie when it was first out, five years ago. I am often skeptical about remakes. This one was Okay, and worth seeing. But since that time, I have several times noted that "Planet of the Apes" was playing on one of the cable/satellite channels, and then been disappointed to find that it is the remake rather than the original. I might have watched it if it were the original. I have not yet felt inclined to re-watch the remake.Sometimes a remake is better than the original. I have never seen the original "Maltese Falcon" with Ricardo Cortez, but the remake with Humphrey Bogart is probably better. Everybody remembers the remake, many not even aware that it is a remake. I hope that, when we remember "Planet of the Apes," we will remember the original and not this lesser remake.

This film is Tim Burtons remake of Schaffner's "Planet of the Apes" from 1968. Mark Wahlberg surely was not the best choice for the protagonist. Take a look at old Heston in 1968, he did a great job. He's a leader, a strong man with authority. Mark Wahlberg lacks those charisma. Compared to Heston he looks really poor - a half-grown boy trying to command. The rest of the film looks like a more or less solid film. But Tim Burton likes to show some weird things in his films, but this time it made a medium film worse. I am talking about the unrealistic end of the film (!!!). In my eyes it was not logic and useless.

Apeing the classics.Even the few special effects and the tolerable makeup (unless you're wearing it) aren't up to snuff. The acting is barely sufficient to carry the undemanding plot: all that was required was to update the 1968 original with the current state of the art: and I mean ART. The only good idea in the film is the casting of Charlton Heston, who starred in the original.The remake's finale is worrisome with its latent opening for a sequel: let's hope it never does come about -- but as the saying goes, monkey see, monkey do.If someone from the film industry actually reads these comments, I would love to hear an explanation of how a scene with four-handed apes outrunning four-hoofed horses makes it through the final editing. Maybe this will become clearer in "Planet of the Horses," where the noble steeds take over the world mounted on very fast apes that run on all fours. Director Tim Burton demonstrated his genius with "Big Fish": one movie per species should suffice.

Review title: Apes that rules a planet, has to be Tim Burton
Review_body: When i heard that they were going to make a new version of the old planet of the apes movie, featuring a bunch of apes that rule an entire planet, I just knew that Tim Burton somehow was involved, the only thing logical about the whole thing is that he's behind it. they movie it self was not what i hoped it would be. one of the big things this movie lacks is that it cant really follow the footsteps of the original movie, if the original was none existent then this movie would probably have rose a bit in my book.But after all its a Tim Burton Movie and its at least worth to rent

Review title: Start a new part when 2001 part is end new and modern monkey world
Review_body: Hi i am Salman From Pakistan. i want to tell you i watched Planet of the apes of 2001 . please make a new part of 2001 movie and make part... new part where 2001 is end i mean there he drop again in Modern monkey world. sorry for my bad English. if anyone understand me then ask them again for movie .
Mark Walberg should only do comedies. He has one facial expression: extremely confused.

Review title: Of you love makeup in movies watch this movie
Review_body: t is the year 2029: Astronaut Leo Davidson boards a pod cruiser on a Space Station for a "routine" reconnaissance mission. But an abrupt detour through a space time wormhole lands him on a strange planet where talking apes rule over the human race. With the help of a sympathetic chimpanzee activist named Ari and a small band of human rebels, Leo leads the effort to evade the advancing Gorilla Army led by General Thade and his most trusted warrior Attar. Now the race is on to reach a sacred temple within the planet's Forbidden Zone to discover the shocking secrets of mankind's past - and the key to its futureDear all, Forget all non nonsense about the ratings and bad reviews if you are a true Hollywood remake lover and wanted to see best makeup of the year and of its era just rent this DVD or buy it, if you can

This movie has had a lot of bad reviews through time. Well, people complain that this isn't a good replacment to the original planet of the apes. This is not the case, for this is a prequel of the movie escape from the planet of the apes. The movie was to imply that the apes came from human activity, and the ending was a possibility for a new movie. The sequence of the movies are, planet of the apes (2001), escape from the planet of the apes, conquest of the planet of the apes, battle for the planet of the apes, planet of the apes (1968), and beneath the planet of the apes. The new movie rise of the planet of the apes is just a new way of showing how the world resulted to the scene of the planet of the apes (1968). So, don't bag on it, for it is good for what it is.

Tim Burton's rendition of planet of the apes is just an interesting interpretation, not a remake. overall i thought it was well done. i do enjoy the originals quite a bit. after watching almost every original form of POTA, watching the Tim Burton version was fun, but just as long as you see it as his interpretation. the first time i saw the movie, i thought the ending was messed up, but after i saw it again years later, and understanding the time line of events i figured it out. many people have different opinions on what it means, but no one is close. the whole time Leo is on another planet. we know this from the 2 moons. then at the end he jumps into the alpha pod and heads for the electrical storm again, in hopes of going home. after Pericles arrives and just before Leo leaves the apes and humans have a respect for each other and now live in harmony, good job. then he leaves. however, general thade is still left there and being the ape-supremacist he is, is surely nothing less than disgusted. now, in an effort for revenge or even to alter his present, Thade becomes preoccupied with the delta pod. he is still one of a select group that knows about it. he somehow manages to resurrect it and get it to work. more than likely it still has power because A) its run with nuclear energy that "lasts forever" or B) just because Leo didn't use that much to get to the ape planet to begin with. Thade then takes off in the delta pod (possibly with another ape but i'm not sure, it is unlikely though) and manges to get into the electrical storm and make his way to earth. and because of the electrical storm he arrives long before Leo does. i think it may even be in the early 1900's. while he is there he, no doubt, wreaks havoc among the humans and through a series of unknown events, procreates and eventually overtakes the human race. and mysteriously history stays basically the same (except of course for the appearance of thade). thus when Leo gets to earth around the same time he left apes have long since ruled earth. we know its thade because if you look at the inscription on the back of the Lincoln memorial its says that it was built "in memory of general thade" (and it looks just like him). also, given that we now are back in time to the first present, Leo more than likely will not be able to go into space and have the beginning of the movie happen again and the first ape planet stays uninhabited.

Review title: stunning makeup 'makes up' for weakness elsewhere
Review_body: i gave this a high rating partially as a razzberry to the higher marks the current cgi films are getting, but mainly because a great deal of what i loved about the 70's movies was the makeup. it made even the last films of that series watchable (and paul williams as an orangutan!). so, in spite of a typical Hollywood snoozefest type plot/script and, worse yet, miscasting mark wahlberg in the lead (more digression, his human 'love interest' should have taken a page from the original and kept her mouth shut) , the wonderful makeup is just so fun to watch! i can't describe my disappointment at knowing we'll never see this again. i cannot abide the cgi cartoonish current apes versions with, if it were possible, even worse plots/scripts...in fact i'm on my way over to them to give them '1's right now, ciao!

Review title: Good-good movie showing reality in strange ways
Review_body: The movie grasped me from the beginning. Everything I saw on screen took my interesting point of views to the limit. The time-limiting exposed from the start faded into a more complicated, abstract way of cinema. The monkeys were exciting but didn't show reality, unfortunately. I could see a good movie from the start, but then interest started to fade. My reality checking didn't match up to that of the movie. I could see further ways that it could have ended but never understood why they didn't involve the guys in the beginning. You know those guys with the shirts? Why didn't the director make us follow those guys instead of the monkeys? I can't understand the way the formated the movie to make us disoriented from reality-view, really annoying. The way I see it, people has made good movies, and THIS was not one of them mates.
This best movie I watched in my life.This best movie I watched in my life.This best movie I watched in my life.

First of all, one of the central plot elements of the original was that the humans couldn't speak. The second I realized that element of the plot had been changed, I knew it was going to be a pretty rough ride. The capper comes when Marky Mark climbs into a space vehicle which has apparently been sitting out in the desert for hundreds or thousands of years. He tears a six inch layer of dust and crud from the front of a computer console, which, miraculously, still works perfectly. Puh-leeze. The ending was senseless and idiotic, it quite frankly insulted my intelligence, as did the entire film, for that matter. I absolutely hated this movie, I had high expectations going in and felt ripped off after sitting through this weak effort.

this movie was awful. i have not seen trash this bad since my last family reunion. it insults the classic original. it was over acted, the story was weak. it played off as some stupid political statement. no thanks! i get enough of that on CNN. Tim Roth wasted his talent on this one. he is much better than this movie. Mark Whalberg needs to go back to either singing or playing a pretend porn star. the humor was bad. the slave trader with a heart of gold? the blonde chick. nobody that oppressed is gonna look that good. and to end this off, Helen Bonham carter, she is better looking as an ape than in real life. the make-up improved her looks, too bad it did not help her acting.

I loved this film, and think that all the bad comments it has received are undeserved. Although I haven't seen the original, this film looks wonderful and dark, and this is surely thanks to Burton's skill as a director. It manages to make the slightly detached characters really work well together, and the acting was great throughout. Very interesting race/ animal rights issues are raised by this film and, although I'm guessing that the original also raised these issues, I suspect it provoked much thought with teenagers who wouldn't dream of watching the original. Of course, you've got to compare it with Burtons other films, and, as far as spooky, Gothic atmospheres go, this doesn't really live up to them. But as an action film it surpasses so many. My favourite character was the Tim Roth evil general. He is the kind of bad guy whose evil has been set so deep within himself that he can no longer control it, and when he kills those gorilla-type creatures it's absolutely amazing. He also emanates pure evil through his wonderfully made facial features. The ending is an issue that raises much debate, but I loved it, the master plan, killing one wave of the enemy with an explosion, was beautifully futile, and the coincidental monkey landing was pleasantly ridiculous. And his return to earth was just really cool. All in all, a great film, watch it. By the way, did anyone else find themselves fancying Helena Bonham Carter in this film. Although, because of the amount of hair and her weird posture, it sounds quite wrong to think that, it just feels so right!

This movie is FANTASTIC. Everyone complaining that the movie is 'outdated' 'corny' etc.. are actually dumb. The movie is directed by TIM BURTON were you expecting 'The Expendables' with apes? This film is very reminiscent of other cult classic like 'The Dark Crystal' 'Labyrinth' etc. This movie is a wonderful exciting adventure that felt very nostalgic which is OBVIOUSLY what Burton set out to do.
Old heads will tell you this is a terrible remake, stoners will tell you that this is a fine piece of art.
8/10
